00:00:12.188 --> 00:00:13.517
I can't help but this wish:

00:00:13.541 --> 00:00:17.974
to think about when you're a little kid,
and all your friends ask you,

00:00:17.998 --> 00:00:20.586
"If a genie could give you
one wish in the world,

00:00:20.610 --> 00:00:21.764
what would it be?"

00:00:22.141 --> 00:00:23.530
And I always answered,

00:00:23.554 --> 00:00:24.864
"Well, I'd want the wish

00:00:24.888 --> 00:00:28.376
to have the wisdom to know
exactly what to wish for."

00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:30.081
Well, then you'd be screwed,

00:00:30.105 --> 00:00:33.120
because you'd know what to wish for,
and you'd use up your wish,

00:00:33.144 --> 00:00:36.967
and now, since we only have one wish --
unlike last year they had three wishes --

00:00:36.991 --> 00:00:38.477
I'm not going to wish for that.

00:00:38.501 --> 00:00:43.504
So let's get to what I would like,
which is world peace.

00:00:43.528 --> 00:00:45.560
And I know what you're thinking:

00:00:45.584 --> 00:00:47.548
You're thinking, "The poor girl up there,

00:00:47.572 --> 00:00:49.349
she thinks she's at a beauty pageant.

00:00:49.373 --> 00:00:51.624
She's not. She's at the TED Prize."

00:00:51.648 --> 00:00:54.234
(Laughter)

00:00:54.782 --> 00:00:56.821
But I really do think it makes sense.

00:00:57.202 --> 00:00:59.797
And I think that
the first step to world peace

00:00:59.821 --> 00:01:01.641
is for people to meet each other.

00:01:01.665 --> 00:01:04.153
I've met a lot of different
people over the years,

00:01:04.177 --> 00:01:05.579
and I've filmed some of them,

00:01:05.603 --> 00:01:10.499
from a dotcom executive in New York
who wanted to take over the world,

00:01:10.523 --> 00:01:12.934
to a military press officer in Qatar,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.463
who would rather not take over the world.

00:01:15.487 --> 00:01:18.172
If you've seen the film
"Control Room" that was sent out,

00:01:18.196 --> 00:01:19.821
you'd understand a little bit why.

00:01:19.845 --> 00:01:20.996
(Applause)

00:01:21.020 --> 00:01:22.178
Thank you.

00:01:22.202 --> 00:01:25.474
Wow! Some of you watched it.
That's great. That's great.

00:01:25.498 --> 00:01:30.068
So basically what I'd like
to talk about today

00:01:30.092 --> 00:01:32.934
is a way for people to travel,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:36.934
to meet people in a different way than --

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.934
because you can't travel
all over the world at the same time.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:45.194
And a long time ago --
well, about 40 years ago --

00:01:45.218 --> 00:01:47.744
my mom had an exchange student.

00:01:48.855 --> 00:01:51.673
And I'm going to show you
slides of the exchange student.

00:01:51.697 --> 00:01:52.848
This is Donna.

00:01:52.872 --> 00:01:54.903
This is Donna at the Statue of Liberty.

00:01:56.404 --> 00:01:59.424
This is my mother and aunt
teaching Donna how to ride a bike.

00:02:00.496 --> 00:02:02.409
This is Donna eating ice cream.

00:02:03.242 --> 00:02:07.555
And this is Donna teaching my aunt
how to do a Filipino dance.

00:02:09.840 --> 00:02:12.057
I really think as the world
is getting smaller,

00:02:12.081 --> 00:02:13.724
it becomes more and more important

00:02:13.748 --> 00:02:15.610
that we learn each other's dance moves,

00:02:15.634 --> 00:02:18.040
that we meet each other,
we get to know each other,

00:02:18.064 --> 00:02:21.703
we are able to figure out
a way to cross borders,

00:02:21.727 --> 00:02:24.851
to understand each other, to understand
people's hopes and dreams,

00:02:24.875 --> 00:02:26.331
what makes them laugh and cry.

00:02:26.355 --> 00:02:29.376
And I know that we can't
all do exchange programs,

00:02:29.400 --> 00:02:31.225
and I can't force everybody to travel;

00:02:31.249 --> 00:02:33.568
I've already talked about that
to Chris and Amy,

00:02:33.592 --> 00:02:35.794
and they said that
there's a problem with this:

00:02:35.818 --> 00:02:37.553
You can't force people, free will.

00:02:37.577 --> 00:02:40.684
And I totally support that,
so we're not forcing people to travel.

00:02:40.708 --> 00:02:42.962
But I'd like to talk
about another way to travel

00:02:42.986 --> 00:02:45.934
that doesn't require
a ship or an airplane,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:50.934
and just requires a movie camera,
a projector and a screen.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:55.791
And that's what I'm going
to talk to you about today.

00:02:55.815 --> 00:03:00.546
I was asked that I speak a little bit
about where I personally come from,

00:03:00.570 --> 00:03:03.673
and Cameron, I don't know how
you managed to get out of that one,

00:03:03.697 --> 00:03:07.934
but I think that building bridges
is important to me

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.105
because of where I come from.

00:03:10.129 --> 00:03:13.508
I'm the daughter of an American mother

00:03:13.532 --> 00:03:16.643
and an Egyptian-Lebanese-Syrian father.

00:03:16.667 --> 00:03:20.739
So I'm the living product
of two cultures coming together.

00:03:20.763 --> 00:03:21.915
No pun intended.

00:03:21.939 --> 00:03:22.946
(Laughter)

00:03:22.970 --> 00:03:24.227
And I've also been called,

00:03:24.251 --> 00:03:27.100
as an Egyptian-Lebanese-Syrian American
with a Persian name,

00:03:27.124 --> 00:03:29.014
the "Middle East Peace Crisis."

00:03:29.038 --> 00:03:33.514
So maybe me starting to take
pictures was some kind of way

00:03:33.538 --> 00:03:36.990
to bring both sides
of my family together --

00:03:37.014 --> 00:03:41.839
a way to take the worlds with me,
a way to tell stories visually.

00:03:42.411 --> 00:03:44.007
It all kind of started that way,

00:03:44.031 --> 00:03:47.627
but I think that I really realized
the power of the image

00:03:47.651 --> 00:03:50.863
when I first went
to the garbage-collecting village

00:03:50.887 --> 00:03:52.887
in Egypt, when I was about 16.

00:03:53.284 --> 00:03:55.458
My mother took me there.

00:03:55.863 --> 00:03:58.622
She's somebody who believes strongly
in community service,

00:03:58.646 --> 00:04:01.289
and decided that this was something
that I needed to do.

00:04:01.313 --> 00:04:04.934
And so I went there and I met
some amazing women there.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.888
There was a center there,

00:04:07.912 --> 00:04:10.950
where they were teaching
people how to read and write,

00:04:10.974 --> 00:04:13.188
and get vaccinations
against the many diseases

00:04:13.212 --> 00:04:15.307
you can get from sorting through garbage.

00:04:15.331 --> 00:04:16.896
And I began teaching there.

00:04:16.920 --> 00:04:19.934
I taught English, and I met
some incredible women there.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:24.746
I met people that live
seven people to a room,

00:04:24.770 --> 00:04:27.102
barely can afford their evening meal,

00:04:27.126 --> 00:04:30.649
yet lived with this strength
of spirit and sense of humor

00:04:30.673 --> 00:04:33.355
and just incredible qualities.

00:04:33.379 --> 00:04:37.133
I got drawn into this community
and I began to take pictures there.

00:04:37.157 --> 00:04:43.934
I took pictures of weddings
and older family members --

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.067
things that they wanted memories of.

00:04:47.099 --> 00:04:50.504
About two years after I started
taking these pictures,

00:04:50.528 --> 00:04:54.934
the UN Conference
on Population and Development

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.854
asked me to show them at the conference.

00:04:57.878 --> 00:05:00.826
So I was 18; I was very excited.

00:05:00.850 --> 00:05:06.207
It was my first exhibit of photographs
and they were all put up there,

00:05:06.231 --> 00:05:12.196
and after about two days,
they all came down except for three.

00:05:12.747 --> 00:05:14.597
People were very upset,

00:05:14.621 --> 00:05:18.231
very angry that I was showing
these dirty sides of Cairo,

00:05:18.255 --> 00:05:21.712
and why didn't I cut
the dead donkey out of the frame?

00:05:21.736 --> 00:05:23.973
And as I sat there, I got very depressed.

00:05:23.997 --> 00:05:29.595
I looked at this big empty wall
with three lonely photographs

00:05:29.619 --> 00:05:33.873
that were, you know,
very pretty photographs

00:05:33.897 --> 00:05:36.788
and I was like, "I failed at this."

00:05:36.812 --> 00:05:41.935
But I was looking at this intense
emotion and intense feeling

00:05:41.959 --> 00:05:45.412
that had come out of people
just seeing these photographs.

00:05:45.436 --> 00:05:48.417
Here I was, this 18-year-old pipsqueak
that nobody listened to,

00:05:48.441 --> 00:05:51.219
and all of a sudden,
I put these photographs on the wall,

00:05:51.243 --> 00:05:53.875
and there were arguments,
and they had to be taken down.

00:05:53.899 --> 00:05:57.247
And I saw the power of the image,
and it was incredible.

00:05:57.271 --> 00:06:01.105
And I think the most important reaction
that I saw there was actually from people

00:06:01.129 --> 00:06:04.004
that would never have gone
to the garbage village themselves,

00:06:04.028 --> 00:06:06.893
that would never have seen
that the human spirit could thrive

00:06:06.917 --> 00:06:09.001
in such difficult circumstances.

00:06:09.025 --> 00:06:10.557
And I think it was at that point

00:06:10.581 --> 00:06:14.843
that I decided I wanted to use
photography and film

00:06:14.867 --> 00:06:17.309
to somehow bridge gaps,
to bridge cultures,

00:06:17.333 --> 00:06:20.272
bring people together, cross borders.

00:06:22.671 --> 00:06:26.307
And so that's what really
kind of started me off.

00:06:26.331 --> 00:06:29.636
Did a stint at MTV, made a film
called "Startup.com,"

00:06:29.660 --> 00:06:33.934
and I've done a couple of music films.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.934
But in 2003, when the war
in Iraq was about to start,

00:06:41.423 --> 00:06:43.635
it was a very surreal feeling for me,

00:06:43.659 --> 00:06:45.535
because before the war started,

00:06:45.559 --> 00:06:47.971
there was kind of this media war
that was going on.

00:06:47.995 --> 00:06:50.011
And I was watching television in New York,

00:06:50.035 --> 00:06:53.672
and there seemed to be just one
point of view that was coming across,

00:06:53.696 --> 00:06:58.523
and the coverage went
from the US State Department

00:06:58.547 --> 00:07:00.584
to embedded troops.

00:07:01.045 --> 00:07:03.665
And what was coming across on the news

00:07:03.689 --> 00:07:07.934
was that there was going to be this
clean war and precision bombings,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.732
and the Iraqis would be greeting
the Americans as liberators,

00:07:11.756 --> 00:07:15.032
and throwing flowers at their feet
in the streets of Baghdad.

00:07:15.056 --> 00:07:17.929
And I knew that there
was a completely other story

00:07:17.953 --> 00:07:20.971
that was taking place in the Middle East,
where my parents were.

00:07:20.995 --> 00:07:24.060
I knew that there was
a completely other story being told,

00:07:24.084 --> 00:07:27.616
and I was thinking, "How are people
supposed to communicate with each other

00:07:27.640 --> 00:07:30.033
when they're getting completely
different messages,

00:07:30.057 --> 00:07:32.164
and nobody knows
what the other's being told?

00:07:32.188 --> 00:07:35.205
How are people supposed to have
any kind of common understanding

00:07:35.229 --> 00:07:37.864
or know how to move together
into the future?

00:07:37.888 --> 00:07:40.136
So I knew that I had to go there.

00:07:40.160 --> 00:07:42.200
I just wanted to be in the center.

00:07:42.224 --> 00:07:44.725
I had no plan. I had no funding.

00:07:44.749 --> 00:07:48.934
I didn't even have a camera at the time --
I had somebody bring it there,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.934
because I wanted
to get access to Al Jazeera,

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.934
George Bush's favorite channel,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:59.199
and a place which I was very curious
about because it's disliked

00:07:59.223 --> 00:08:01.714
by many governments across the Arab world,

00:08:01.738 --> 00:08:05.340
and also called the mouthpiece
of Osama Bin Laden

00:08:05.364 --> 00:08:07.545
by some people in the US government.

00:08:07.569 --> 00:08:11.843
So I was thinking, this station
that's hated by so many people

00:08:11.867 --> 00:08:13.400
has to be doing something right.

00:08:13.424 --> 00:08:16.933
I've got to go see what this is all about.

00:08:16.957 --> 00:08:19.054
And I also wanted to go see
Central Command,

00:08:19.078 --> 00:08:20.622
which was 10 minutes away.

00:08:20.646 --> 00:08:25.934
And that way, I could get access
to how this news was being created --

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.166
on the Arab side, reaching the Arab world,

00:08:28.190 --> 00:08:30.949
and on the US and Western side,
reaching the US.

00:08:30.973 --> 00:08:32.714
And when I went there and sat there,

00:08:32.738 --> 00:08:35.795
and met these people
that were in the center of it,

00:08:35.819 --> 00:08:39.425
and sat with these characters,

00:08:39.449 --> 00:08:43.726
I met some surprising,
very complex people.

00:08:43.750 --> 00:08:47.934
And I'd like to share with you
a little bit of that experience

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.432
of when you sit with somebody

00:08:49.456 --> 00:08:51.480
and you film them, and you listen to them,

00:08:51.504 --> 00:08:54.474
and you allow them more
than a five-second sound bite.

00:08:55.272 --> 00:08:59.958
The amazing complexity of people emerges.

00:09:03.659 --> 00:09:05.934
Samir Khader: Business as usual.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:10.308
Iraq, and then Iraq, and then Iraq.

00:09:12.855 --> 00:09:17.632
But between us, if I'm offered
a job with Fox, I'll take it.

00:09:22.935 --> 00:09:27.228
To change the Arab nightmare
into the American dream.

00:09:32.937 --> 00:09:35.163
I still have that dream.

00:09:35.187 --> 00:09:37.934
Maybe I will never be able to do it,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:41.678
but I have plans for my children.

00:09:42.482 --> 00:09:43.872
When they finish high school,

00:09:43.896 --> 00:09:45.912
I will send them to America
to study there.

00:09:45.936 --> 00:09:47.681
I will pay for their study.

00:09:48.599 --> 00:09:50.548
And they will stay there.

00:09:57.133 --> 00:10:00.986
Josh Rushing: The night they showed
the POWs and the dead soldiers --

00:10:01.010 --> 00:10:02.226
Al Jazeera showed them --

00:10:02.250 --> 00:10:05.454
it was powerful, because America
doesn't show those kinds of images.

00:10:05.478 --> 00:10:08.163
Most of the news in America
won't show really gory images

00:10:08.187 --> 00:10:11.362
and this showed American soldiers
in uniform, strewn about a floor,

00:10:11.386 --> 00:10:12.561
a cold tile floor.

00:10:12.585 --> 00:10:15.321
And it was revolting.

00:10:15.345 --> 00:10:16.831
It was absolutely revolting.

00:10:16.855 --> 00:10:18.307
It made me sick at my stomach.

00:10:18.331 --> 00:10:21.657
And then what hit me was,
the night before,

00:10:21.681 --> 00:10:25.276
there had been some kind
of bombing in Basra,

00:10:25.300 --> 00:10:30.116
and Al Jazeera had shown
images of the people.

00:10:30.140 --> 00:10:34.334
And they were equally, if not more,
horrifying -- the images were.

00:10:34.358 --> 00:10:36.973
And I remember having seen it
in the Al Jazeera office,

00:10:36.997 --> 00:10:40.186
and thought to myself, "Wow, that's gross.

00:10:40.210 --> 00:10:42.001
That's bad."

00:10:42.025 --> 00:10:44.935
And then going away, and probably
eating dinner or something.

00:10:44.959 --> 00:10:46.562
And it didn't affect me as much.

00:10:46.586 --> 00:10:49.409
So, the impact that had on me --

00:10:49.433 --> 00:10:53.091
me realizing that I just saw
people on the other side,

00:10:53.115 --> 00:10:55.927
and those people in the Al Jazeera office

00:10:55.951 --> 00:10:58.238
must have felt the way
I was feeling that night,

00:10:58.262 --> 00:11:01.381
and it upset me on a profound level

00:11:01.405 --> 00:11:04.989
that I wasn't as bothered
as much the night before.

00:11:05.608 --> 00:11:07.180
It makes me hate war.

00:11:07.608 --> 00:11:10.186
But it doesn't make me believe
that we're in a world

00:11:10.210 --> 00:11:11.721
that can live without war yet.

00:11:11.745 --> 00:11:14.838
Jehane Noujaim: I was overwhelmed
by the response of the film.

00:11:14.862 --> 00:11:17.545
We didn't know whether
it would be able to get out there.

00:11:17.569 --> 00:11:18.785
We had no funding for it.

00:11:18.809 --> 00:11:22.099
We were incredibly lucky
that it got picked up.

00:11:23.011 --> 00:11:25.492
And when we showed the film

00:11:25.516 --> 00:11:28.192
in both the United States
and the Arab world,

00:11:28.216 --> 00:11:30.333
we had such incredible reactions.

00:11:30.357 --> 00:11:33.365
It was amazing to see how people
were moved by this film.

00:11:33.389 --> 00:11:35.552
In the Arab world --

00:11:35.576 --> 00:11:38.413
and it's not really by the film,
it's by the characters --

00:11:38.437 --> 00:11:42.468
I mean, Josh Rushing was
this incredibly complex person

00:11:42.492 --> 00:11:44.019
who was thinking about things.

00:11:44.043 --> 00:11:46.312
And when I showed the film
in the Middle East,

00:11:46.336 --> 00:11:48.934
people wanted to meet Josh.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.934
He kind of redefined us
as an American population.

00:11:52.852 --> 00:11:56.934
People started to ask me,
"Where is this guy now?"

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.957
Al Jazeera offered him a job.

00:11:58.981 --> 00:12:00.934
(Laughter)

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.208
And Samir, on the other hand,

00:12:03.232 --> 00:12:06.566
was also quite an interesting character
for the Arab world to see,

00:12:06.590 --> 00:12:10.247
because it brought out the complexities
of this love-hate relationship

00:12:10.271 --> 00:12:12.389
that the Arab world has with the West.

00:12:13.215 --> 00:12:18.406
In the United States, I was blown away
by the motivations,

00:12:18.430 --> 00:12:21.254
the positive motivations
of the American people

00:12:21.278 --> 00:12:23.348
when they'd see this film.

00:12:23.372 --> 00:12:24.967
You know, we're criticized abroad

00:12:24.991 --> 00:12:28.482
for believing we're the saviors
of the world in some way,

00:12:28.506 --> 00:12:31.825
but the flip side of it is that, actually,

00:12:31.849 --> 00:12:34.183
when people do see
what is happening abroad

00:12:34.207 --> 00:12:36.934
and people's reactions
to some of our policy abroad,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.228
we feel this power, that we need to --

00:12:39.252 --> 00:12:41.847
we feel like we have to get
the power to change things.

00:12:41.871 --> 00:12:43.426
And I saw this with audiences.

00:12:43.450 --> 00:12:47.206
This woman came up to me
after the screening and said,

00:12:47.230 --> 00:12:48.823
"You know, I know this is crazy.

00:12:48.847 --> 00:12:50.870
I saw the bombs being loaded
on the planes,

00:12:50.894 --> 00:12:52.633
I saw the military going out to war,

00:12:52.657 --> 00:12:55.019
but you don't understand
people's anger towards us

00:12:55.043 --> 00:12:59.206
until you see the people in the hospitals
and the victims of the war,

00:12:59.230 --> 00:13:01.175
and how do we get out of this bubble?

00:13:01.199 --> 00:13:05.130
How do we understand what
the other person is thinking?"

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:10.029
Now, I don't know whether
a film can change the world.

00:13:10.053 --> 00:13:12.530
But I know the power of it,

00:13:12.554 --> 00:13:15.934
I know that it starts people thinking
about how to change the world.

00:13:16.571 --> 00:13:18.261
Now, I'm not a philosopher,

00:13:18.285 --> 00:13:21.143
so I feel like I shouldn't
go into great depth on this,

00:13:21.167 --> 00:13:24.934
but let film speak for itself
and take you to this other world.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:29.058
Because I believe that film has
the ability to take you across borders,

00:13:29.082 --> 00:13:33.100
I'd like you to just sit back
and experience for a couple of minutes

00:13:33.124 --> 00:13:34.934
being taken into another world.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:40.665
And these couple clips take you inside
of two of the most difficult conflicts

00:13:40.689 --> 00:13:42.364
that we're faced with today.

00:13:43.536 --> 00:13:46.520
[The last 48 hours of two
Palestinian suicide bombers.]

00:13:48.478 --> 00:13:50.438
[Paradise Now]

00:13:51.885 --> 00:13:55.084
[Man: As long as there is injustice,
someone must make a sacrifice!]

00:13:55.108 --> 00:13:57.433
[Woman: That's no
sacrifice, that's revenge!]

00:13:58.615 --> 00:14:03.697
[If you kill, there's no difference
between victim and occupier.]

00:14:03.721 --> 00:14:09.488
[Man: If we had airplanes, we wouldn't
need martyrs, that's the difference.]

00:14:09.512 --> 00:14:14.722
[Woman: The difference is that the Israeli
military is still stronger.]

00:14:14.746 --> 00:14:16.934
[Man: Then let us be equal in death.]

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.039
[We still have Paradise.]

00:14:19.063 --> 00:14:21.985
[Woman: There is no Paradise!
It only exists in your head!]

00:14:22.009 --> 00:14:24.233
[Man: God forbid!]

00:14:24.756 --> 00:14:26.934
[May God forgive you.]

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
[If you were not Abu Azzam's daughter ...]

00:14:31.890 --> 00:14:35.149
[Anyway, I'd rather have Paradise
in my head than live in this hell!]

00:14:35.173 --> 00:14:36.870
[In this life, we're dead anyway.]

00:14:38.608 --> 00:14:44.016
[One only chooses bitterness
when the alternative is even bitterer.]

00:14:44.957 --> 00:14:47.452
[Woman: And what about us?
The ones who remain?]

00:14:47.476 --> 00:14:50.612
[Will we win that way?]

00:14:51.238 --> 00:14:55.723
[Don't you see what you're
doing is destroying us?]

00:14:55.747 --> 00:14:59.880
[And that you give Israel
an alibi to carry on?]

00:14:59.904 --> 00:15:02.295
[Man: So with no alibi, Israel will stop?]

00:15:02.319 --> 00:15:06.527
[Woman: Perhaps. We have
to turn it into a moral war.]

00:15:06.551 --> 00:15:09.824
[Man: How, if Israel has no morals?]

00:15:09.848 --> 00:15:11.958
[Woman: Be careful!]

00:15:13.398 --> 00:15:18.888
[And the real people building
peace through non-violence]

00:15:19.983 --> 00:15:23.067
[Encounter Point]

00:15:23.814 --> 00:15:27.933
Video: (Ambulance siren)
[Tel Aviv, Israel 1996]

00:15:28.972 --> 00:15:31.421
[Tzvika: My wife Ayelet
called me and said, ]

00:15:31.445 --> 00:15:34.238
["There was a suicide
bombing in Tel Aviv."]

00:15:34.873 --> 00:15:37.385
[Ayelet: What do you know
about the casualties?]

00:15:37.409 --> 00:15:40.229
[Tzvika off-screen:
We're looking for three girls.]

00:15:40.253 --> 00:15:41.529
[We have no information.]

00:15:41.553 --> 00:15:45.934
[Ayelet: One is wounded here, but we
haven't heard from the other three.]

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.883
[Tzvika: I said, "OK,
that's Bat-Chen, that's my daughter.]

00:15:49.907 --> 00:15:52.091
[Are you sure she is dead?"]

00:15:52.115 --> 00:15:53.269
[They said yes.]

00:15:53.293 --> 00:15:55.595
Video: (Police siren
and shouting over megaphone)

00:15:55.619 --> 00:15:59.905
[Bethlehem, Occupied
Palestinian Territories, 2003]

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.934
[George: On that day, at around 6:30]

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:11.875
[I was driving with my wife
and daughters to the supermarket.]

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.982
[When we got to here ...]

00:16:17.006 --> 00:16:21.941
[we saw three Israeli military jeeps
parked on the side of the road.]

00:16:23.258 --> 00:16:25.554
[When we passed by the first jeep ...]

00:16:25.578 --> 00:16:28.520
[they opened fire on us.]

00:16:28.854 --> 00:16:31.697
[And my 12-year-old daughter Christine]

00:16:31.721 --> 00:16:34.386
[was killed in the shooting.]

00:16:34.751 --> 00:16:39.092
[Bereaved Families Forum, Jerusalem]

00:16:45.732 --> 00:16:48.800
[Tzvika: I'm the headmaster
for all parts.]

00:16:48.824 --> 00:16:51.222
[George: But there is a teacher
that is in charge?]

00:16:51.246 --> 00:16:53.162
[Tzvika: Yes, I have assistants.]

00:16:53.186 --> 00:16:56.211
[I deal with children all the time.]

00:16:56.235 --> 00:17:01.223
[One year after their daughters' deaths
both Tzvika and George join the forum]

00:17:02.921 --> 00:17:08.180
[George: At first, I thought
it was a strange idea.]

00:17:08.204 --> 00:17:10.622
[But after thinking logically about it, ]

00:17:10.646 --> 00:17:16.254
[I didn't find any reason
why not to meet them]

00:17:16.278 --> 00:17:21.215
[and let them know of our suffering.]

00:17:21.732 --> 00:17:25.176
[Tzvika: There were
many things that touched me.]

00:17:25.200 --> 00:17:30.315
[We see that there are Palestinians
who suffered a lot, who lost children,]

00:17:30.339 --> 00:17:33.934
[and still believe in the peace
process and in reconciliation.]

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:37.583
[If we who lost what is most precious
can talk to each other,]

00:17:37.607 --> 00:17:40.734
[and look forward to a better future,]

00:17:40.758 --> 00:17:46.136
[then everyone else must do so, too.]

00:17:47.707 --> 00:17:51.549
[From South Africa:
A Revolution Through Music]

00:17:52.278 --> 00:17:54.514
[Amandla]

00:17:54.895 --> 00:17:55.934
(Music)

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:59.426
(Video) Man: Song is something
that we communicated with people

00:17:59.450 --> 00:18:04.005
who otherwise would not have
understood where we're coming from.

00:18:04.029 --> 00:18:06.672
You could give them
a long political speech,

00:18:06.696 --> 00:18:08.575
they would still not understand.

00:18:08.996 --> 00:18:11.695
But I tell you, when you finish that song,

00:18:11.719 --> 00:18:15.263
people will be like, "Damn, I know
where you niggas are coming from.

00:18:15.724 --> 00:18:17.771
I know where you guys are coming from.

00:18:17.795 --> 00:18:19.215
Death unto apartheid!"

00:18:19.947 --> 00:18:22.256
Narrator: It's about
the liberation struggle.

00:18:23.320 --> 00:18:26.767
It's about those children
who took to the streets --

00:18:26.791 --> 00:18:30.483
fighting, screaming,
"Free Nelson Mandela!"

00:18:31.435 --> 00:18:36.310
It's about those unions
who put down their tools

00:18:36.334 --> 00:18:38.313
and demanded freedom.

00:18:38.980 --> 00:18:41.615
Yes. Yes!

00:18:41.639 --> 00:18:46.481
(Music and singing)

00:18:46.505 --> 00:18:48.505
(Singing) Freedom!

00:18:49.547 --> 00:18:53.306
(Applause)

00:18:53.330 --> 00:18:56.972
Jehane Noujaim: I think everybody's
had that feeling of sitting in a theater,

00:18:56.996 --> 00:19:01.242
in a dark room, with other strangers,
watching a very powerful film,

00:19:01.266 --> 00:19:03.981
and they felt that feeling
of transformation.

00:19:04.298 --> 00:19:07.250
And what I'd like to talk about is

00:19:07.274 --> 00:19:09.934
how can we use that feeling

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:13.316
to actually create
a movement through film?

00:19:14.795 --> 00:19:19.316
I've been listening to the talks
in the conference,

00:19:19.340 --> 00:19:21.395
and Robert Wright said yesterday

00:19:21.419 --> 00:19:24.987
that if we have an appreciation
for another person's humanity,

00:19:25.011 --> 00:19:27.543
then they will have
an appreciation for ours.

00:19:27.567 --> 00:19:29.365
And that's what this is about.

00:19:29.389 --> 00:19:31.934
It's about connecting people through film,

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:34.699
getting these independent
voices out there.

00:19:35.358 --> 00:19:40.142
Now, Josh Rushing actually
ended up leaving the military

00:19:40.166 --> 00:19:42.213
and taking a job with Al Jazeera.

00:19:42.237 --> 00:19:43.530
(Laughter)

00:19:43.554 --> 00:19:47.141
So his feeling is that
he's at Al Jazeera International

00:19:47.165 --> 00:19:49.934
because he feels like
he can actually use media

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:52.365
to bridge the gap between East and West.

00:19:53.373 --> 00:19:55.342
And that's an amazing thing.

00:19:55.366 --> 00:19:58.198
But I've been trying to think about ways

00:19:58.222 --> 00:20:00.882
to give power to these independent voices,

00:20:00.906 --> 00:20:02.499
to give power to the filmmakers,

00:20:02.523 --> 00:20:06.934
to give power to people who are trying
to use film for change.

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:08.807
And there are incredible organizations

00:20:08.831 --> 00:20:10.934
that are out there doing this already.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.934
There's Witness,
that you heard from earlier.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:17.528
There's Just Vision, that are working
with Palestinians and Israelis

00:20:17.552 --> 00:20:20.884
who are working together for peace,
and documenting that process

00:20:20.908 --> 00:20:23.684
and getting interviews
out there and using this film

00:20:23.708 --> 00:20:26.656
to take to Congress to show
that it's a powerful tool,

00:20:26.680 --> 00:20:31.219
to show that this is a woman who's had
her daughter killed in an attack,

00:20:31.243 --> 00:20:34.369
and she believes that there
are peaceful ways to solve this.

00:20:34.393 --> 00:20:38.203
There's Working Films
and there's Current TV,

00:20:38.227 --> 00:20:41.534
which is an incredible platform
for people around the world

00:20:41.558 --> 00:20:42.806
to be able to put their --

00:20:42.830 --> 00:20:43.834
(Applause)

00:20:43.858 --> 00:20:45.009
Yeah, it's amazing.

00:20:45.033 --> 00:20:48.460
I've watched it and I'm blown away by it

00:20:48.484 --> 00:20:51.768
and its potential to bring voices
from around the world --

00:20:51.792 --> 00:20:53.800
independent voices
from around the world --

00:20:53.824 --> 00:20:57.260
and create a truly democratic,
global television.

00:20:57.284 --> 00:21:01.035
So what can we do to create
a platform for these organizations,

00:21:01.059 --> 00:21:02.934
to create some momentum,

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:06.349
to get everybody in the world
involved in this movement?

00:21:08.452 --> 00:21:11.467
I'd like for us to imagine for a second.

00:21:13.156 --> 00:21:19.987
Imagine a day when you have everyone
coming together from around the world.

00:21:20.758 --> 00:21:27.666
You have towns and villages
and theaters --

00:21:27.690 --> 00:21:30.244
all from around the world,

00:21:30.268 --> 00:21:33.007
getting together, and sitting in the dark,

00:21:33.031 --> 00:21:37.531
and sharing a communal
experience of watching a film,

00:21:37.555 --> 00:21:39.678
or a couple of films, together.

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:46.440
Watching a film which maybe highlights
a character that is fighting to live,

00:21:46.464 --> 00:21:49.638
or just a character
that defies stereotypes,

00:21:49.662 --> 00:21:51.731
makes a joke, sings a song.

00:21:51.755 --> 00:21:54.034
Comedies, documentaries, shorts.

00:21:54.058 --> 00:21:56.737
This amazing power
can be used to change people

00:21:56.761 --> 00:21:59.585
and to bond people together;
to cross borders,

00:21:59.609 --> 00:22:03.124
and have people feel like
they're having a communal experience.

00:22:03.148 --> 00:22:06.094
So if you imagine this day
when all around the world,

00:22:06.118 --> 00:22:11.637
you have theaters and places
where we project films.

00:22:11.661 --> 00:22:15.256
If you imagine projecting
from Times Square

00:22:15.280 --> 00:22:18.058
to Tahrir Square in Cairo,

00:22:18.082 --> 00:22:21.758
the same film in Ramallah,
the same film in Jerusalem.

00:22:21.782 --> 00:22:25.082
You know, we've been talking
to a friend of mine

00:22:25.106 --> 00:22:27.780
about using the side of the Great Pyramid

00:22:27.804 --> 00:22:29.463
and the Great Wall of China.

00:22:32.133 --> 00:22:34.934
It's endless what you can imagine,

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:37.070
in terms of where you can project films

00:22:37.094 --> 00:22:39.818
and where you can have
this communal experience.

00:22:39.842 --> 00:22:42.934
And I believe that this one day,
if we can create it,

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:47.309
this one day can create momentum
for all of these independent voices.

00:22:47.333 --> 00:22:52.362
There isn't an organization
which is connecting the independent voices

00:22:52.386 --> 00:22:53.934
of the world to get out there,

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:56.138
and yet I'm hearing
throughout this conference

00:22:56.162 --> 00:22:58.192
that the biggest challenge in our future

00:22:58.216 --> 00:22:59.828
is understanding the other,

00:22:59.852 --> 00:23:03.785
and having mutual respect
for the other and crossing borders.

00:23:03.809 --> 00:23:05.682
And if film can do that,

00:23:05.706 --> 00:23:08.884
and if we can get all of these
different locations in the world

00:23:08.908 --> 00:23:11.512
to watch these films together --

00:23:11.536 --> 00:23:13.693
this could be an incredible day.

00:23:14.184 --> 00:23:17.498
So we've already made a partnership,

00:23:17.522 --> 00:23:21.411
set up through somebody
from the TED community,

00:23:21.435 --> 00:23:24.305
John Camen, who introduced me
to Steven Apkon,

00:23:24.329 --> 00:23:26.934
from the Jacob Burns Film Center.

00:23:26.958 --> 00:23:28.848
And we started calling up everybody.

00:23:28.872 --> 00:23:30.231
And in the last week,

00:23:30.255 --> 00:23:33.934
there have been so many people
that have responded to us,

00:23:33.958 --> 00:23:38.934
from as close as Palo Alto,
to Mongolia and to India.

00:23:38.958 --> 00:23:43.514
There are people that want to be
a part of this global day of film;

00:23:43.538 --> 00:23:46.934
to be able to provide a platform
for independent voices

00:23:46.958 --> 00:23:49.522
and independent films to get out there.

00:23:51.141 --> 00:23:54.804
Now, we've thought
about a name for this day,

00:23:54.828 --> 00:23:57.287
and I'd like to share this with you.

00:23:57.311 --> 00:23:59.572
Now, the most amazing part
of this whole process

00:23:59.596 --> 00:24:02.924
has been sharing ideas and wishes,

00:24:02.948 --> 00:24:05.934
and so I invite you
to give brainstorms onto

00:24:05.958 --> 00:24:09.479
how does this day echo into the future?

00:24:09.503 --> 00:24:14.234
How do we use technology to make
this day echo into the future,

00:24:14.258 --> 00:24:15.934
so that we can build community

00:24:15.958 --> 00:24:19.958
and have these communities working
together, through the Internet?

00:24:21.109 --> 00:24:23.648
There was a time, many, many years ago,

00:24:23.672 --> 00:24:25.958
when all of the continents
were stuck together.

00:24:26.883 --> 00:24:29.828
And we call that landmass Pangea.

00:24:29.852 --> 00:24:34.445
So what we'd like to call this day of film
is Pangea Cinema Day.

00:24:35.572 --> 00:24:37.071
And if you just imagine

00:24:37.095 --> 00:24:40.578
that all of these people
in these towns would be watching,

00:24:40.602 --> 00:24:44.591
then I think that we can
actually really make a movement

00:24:44.615 --> 00:24:46.934
towards people understanding
each other better.

00:24:46.958 --> 00:24:50.777
I know that it's very intangible,
touching people's hearts and souls,

00:24:50.801 --> 00:24:52.834
but the only way that I know how to do it,

00:24:52.858 --> 00:24:57.443
the only way that I know how to reach out
to somebody's heart and soul

00:24:57.467 --> 00:24:59.974
all across the world,
is by showing them a film.

00:24:59.998 --> 00:25:03.359
And I know that there are independent
filmmakers and films out there

00:25:03.383 --> 00:25:05.447
that can really make this happen.

00:25:06.030 --> 00:25:07.573
And that's my wish.

00:25:08.112 --> 00:25:12.559
I guess I'm supposed to give you
my one-sentence wish,

00:25:12.583 --> 00:25:14.361
but we're way out of time.

00:25:14.958 --> 00:25:17.278
Chris Anderson:
That is an incredible wish.

00:25:17.302 --> 00:25:19.934
Pangea Cinema: The day
the world comes together.

00:25:19.958 --> 00:25:23.676
JN: It's more tangible than world peace,
and it's certainly more immediate.

00:25:23.700 --> 00:25:29.418
But it would be the day that the world
comes together through film,

00:25:29.442 --> 00:25:30.593
the power of film.

00:25:30.617 --> 00:25:32.958
CA: Ladies and gentlemen, Jehane Noujaim.

title: My wish: Help me stop pandemics
transcript: I'm the luckiest guy in the world. I got to see the last case of killer smallpox in the world. I was in India this past year, and I may have seen the last cases of polio in the world. There's nothing that makes you feel more — the blessing and the honor of working in a program like that — than to know that something that horrible no longer exists. So I'm going to tell you — (Applause) so I'm going to show you some dirty pictures. They are difficult to watch, but you should look at them with optimism, because the horror of these pictures will be matched by the uplifting quality of knowing that they no longer exist.But first, I'm going to tell you a little bit about my own journey. My background is not exactly the conventional medical education that you might expect. When I was an intern in San Francisco, I heard about a group of Native Americans who had taken over Alcatraz Island, and a Native American who wanted to give birth on that island, and no other doctor wanted to go and help her give birth. I went out to Alcatraz, and I lived on the island for several weeks. She gave birth; I caught the baby; I got off the island; I landed in San Francisco; and all the press wanted to talk to me, because my three weeks on the island made me an expert in Indian affairs. (Laughter)I wound up on every television show. Someone saw me on television; they called me up; and they asked me if I'd like to be in a movie and to play a young doctor for a bunch of rock and roll stars who were traveling in a bus ride from San Francisco to England. And I said, yes, I would do that, so I became the doctor in an absolutely awful movie called "Medicine Ball Caravan." (Laughter) Now, you know from the '60s, you're either on the bus or you're off the bus; I was on the bus. My wife of 37 years and I joined the bus. Our bus ride took us from San Francisco to London, then we switched buses at the big pond. We then got on two more buses and we drove through Turkey and Iran, Afghanistan, over the Khyber Pass into Pakistan, like every other young doctor. This is us at the Khyber Pass, and that's our bus. We had some difficulty getting over the Khyber Pass. But we wound up in India. And then, like everyone else in our generation, we went to live in a Himalayan monastery.(Laughter)This is just like a residency program, for those of you that are in medical school. (Laughter) And we studied with a wise man, a guru named Karoli Baba, who then told me to get rid of the dress, put on a three-piece suit, go join the United Nations as a diplomat and work for the World Health Organization. And he made an outrageous prediction that smallpox would be eradicated, and that this was God's gift to humanity, because of the hard work of dedicated scientists. And that prediction came true. This little girl is Rahima Banu, and she was the last case of killer smallpox in the world. And this document is the certificate that the global commission signed, certifying the world to have eradicated the first disease in history.The key to eradicating smallpox was early detection, early response. I'm going to ask you to repeat that: early detection, early response. Can you say that?Audience: Early detection, early response.Larry Brilliant: Smallpox was the worst disease in history. It killed more people than all the wars in history. In the last century, it killed 500 million people. You're reading about Larry Page already. Somebody reads very fast. (Laughter) In the year that Larry Page and Sergey Brin — with whom I have a certain affection and a new affiliation — in the year in which they were born, two million people died of smallpox. We declared smallpox eradicated in 1980. This is the most important slide that I've ever seen in public health, [Sovereigns killed by smallpox] because it shows you to be the richest and the strongest, and to be kings and queens of the world, did not protect you from dying of smallpox. Never can you doubt that we are all in this together.But to see smallpox from the perspective of a sovereign is the wrong perspective. You should see it from the perspective of a mother, watching her child develop this disease and standing by helplessly. Day one, day two, day three, day four, day five, day six. You're a mother and you're watching your child, and on day six, you see pustules that become hard. Day seven, they show the classic scars of smallpox umbilication. Day eight.And Al Gore said earlier that the most photographed image in the world, the most printed image in the world, was that of the Earth. But this was in 1974, and as of that moment, this photograph was the photograph that was the most widely printed, because we printed two billion copies of this photograph, and we took them hand to hand, door to door, to show people and ask them if there was smallpox in their house, because that was our surveillance system. We didn't have Google, we didn't have web crawlers, we didn't have computers.By day nine — you look at this picture and you're horrified; I look at this picture and I say, "Thank God," because it's clear that this is only an ordinary case of smallpox, and I know this child will live. And by day 13, the lesions are scabbing, his eyelids are swollen, but you know this child has no other secondary infection. And by day 20, while he will be scarred for life, he will live.There are other kinds of smallpox that are not like that. This is confluent smallpox, in which there isn't a single place on the body where you could put a finger and not be covered by lesions. Flat smallpox, which killed 100 percent of people who got it. And hemorrhagic smallpox, the most cruel of all, which had a predilection for pregnant women. I've probably had 50 women die. They all had hemorrhagic smallpox. I've never seen anybody die from it who wasn't a pregnant woman.In 1967, the WHO embarked on what was an outrageous program to eradicate a disease. In that year, there were 34 countries affected with smallpox. By 1970, we were down to 18 countries. 1974, we were down to five countries. But in that year, smallpox exploded throughout India. And India was the place where smallpox made its last stand. In 1974, India had a population of 600 million. There are 21 linguistic states in India, which is like saying 21 different countries. There are 20 million people on the road at any time, in buses and trains, walking; 500,000 villages, 120 million households, and none of them wanted to report if they had a case of smallpox in their house, because they thought that smallpox was the visitation of a deity, Shitala Mata, the cooling mother, and it was wrong to bring strangers into your house when the deity was in the house. No incentive to report smallpox.It wasn't just India that had smallpox deities; smallpox deities were prevalent all over the world. So, how we eradicated smallpox was — mass vaccination wouldn't work. You could vaccinate everybody in India, but one year later there'd be 21 million new babies, which was then the population of Canada. It wouldn't do just to vaccinate everyone. You had to find every single case of smallpox in the world at the same time, and draw a circle of immunity around it. And that's what we did. In India alone, my 150,000 best friends and I went door to door, with that same picture, to every single house in India. We made over one billion house calls.And in the process, I learned something very important. Every time we did a house-to-house search, we had a spike in the number of reports of smallpox. When we didn't search, we had the illusion that there was no disease. When we did search, we had the illusion that there was more disease. A surveillance system was necessary, because what we needed was early detection, early response. So we searched and we searched, and we found every case of smallpox in India. We had a reward. We raised the reward. We continued to increase the reward. We had a scorecard that we wrote on every house. And as we did that, the number of reported cases in the world dropped to zero. And in 1980, we declared the globe free of smallpox.It was the largest campaign in United Nations history, until the Iraq war. 150,000 people from all over the world — doctors of every race, religion, culture and nation, who fought side by side, brothers and sisters, with each other, not against each other, in a common cause to make the world better. But smallpox was the fourth disease that was intended for eradication. We failed three other times. We failed against malaria, yellow fever and yaws. But soon we may see polio eradicated. But the key to eradicating polio is early detection, early response. This may be the year we eradicate polio. That will make it the second disease in history. And David Heymann, who's watching this on the webcast — David, keep on going. We're close! We're down to four countries.(Applause)I feel like Hank Aaron. Barry Bonds can replace me any time.Let's get another disease off the list of terrible things to worry about. I was just in India working on the polio program. The polio surveillance program is four million people going door to door. That is the surveillance system. But we need to have early detection, early response. Blindness, the same thing. The key to discovering blindness is doing epidemiological surveys and finding out the causes of blindness, so you can mount the correct response.The Seva Foundation was started by a group of alumni of the Smallpox Eradication Programme, who, having climbed the highest mountain, tasted the elixir of the success of eradicating a disease, wanted to do it again. And over the last 27 years, Seva's programs in 15 countries have given back sight to more than two million blind people. Seva got started because we wanted to apply these lessons of surveillance and epidemiology to something which nobody else was looking at as a public health issue: blindness, which heretofore had been thought of only as a clinical disease.In 1980, Steve Jobs gave me that computer, which is Apple number 12, and it's still in Kathmandu, and it's still working, and we ought to go get it and auction it off and make more money for Seva. And we conducted the first Nepal survey ever done for health, and the first nationwide blindness survey ever done, and we had astonishing results. Instead of finding out what we thought was the case — that blindness was caused mostly by glaucoma and trachoma — we were astounded to find out that blindness was caused instead by cataract. You can't cure or prevent what you don't know is there.In your TED packages there's a DVD, "Infinite Vision," about Dr. V and the Aravind Eye Hospital. I hope that you will take a look at it. Aravind, which started as a Seva project, is now the world's largest and best eye hospital. This year, that one hospital will give back sight to more than 300,000 people in Tamil Nadu, India. (Applause) Bird flu. I stand here as a representative of all terrible things — this might be the worst. The key to preventing or mitigating pandemic bird flu is early detection and rapid response. We will not have a vaccine or adequate supplies of an antiviral to combat bird flu if it occurs in the next three years. WHO stages the progress of a pandemic. We are now at stage three on the pandemic alert stage, with just a little bit of human-to-human transmission, but no human-to-human-to-human sustained transmission.The moment WHO says we've moved to category four — this will not be like Katrina. The world as we know it will stop. There'll be no airplanes flying. Would you get in an airplane with 250 people you didn't know, coughing and sneezing, when you knew that some of them might carry a disease that could kill you, for which you had no antivirals or vaccine? I did a study of the top epidemiologists in the world in October. I asked them — these are all fluologists and specialists in influenza — and I asked them the questions you'd like to ask them: What do you think the likelihood is that there'll be a pandemic? If it happens, how bad do you think it will be?Fifteen percent said they thought there'd be a pandemic within three years. But much worse than that, 90 percent said they thought there'd be a pandemic within your children or your grandchildren's lifetime. And they thought that if there was a pandemic, a billion people would get sick. As many as 165 million people would die. There would be a global recession and depression as our just-in-time inventory system and the tight rubber band of globalization broke, and the cost to our economy of one to three trillion dollars would be far worse for everyone than merely 100 million people dying, because so many more people would lose their job and their healthcare benefits, that the consequences are almost unthinkable. And it's getting worse, because travel is getting so much better.Let me show you a simulation of what a pandemic looks like. So we know what we're talking about. Let's assume, for example, that the first case occurs in South Asia. It initially goes quite slowly. You get two or three discrete locations. Then there'll be secondary outbreaks, and the disease will spread from country to country so fast that you won't know what hit you. Within three weeks it will be everywhere in the world. Now, if we had an "undo" button, and we could go back and isolate it and grab it when it first started — if we could find it early, and we had early detection and early response, and we could put each one of those viruses in jail — that's the only way to deal with something like a pandemic. And let me show you why that is.We have a joke. This is an epidemic curve, and everyone in medicine, I think, ultimately gets to know what it is. But the joke is, an epidemiologist likes to arrive at an epidemic right here and ride to glory on the downhill curve. (Laughter) But you don't get to do that usually. You usually arrive right about here. What we really want is to arrive right here, so we can stop the epidemic. But you can't always do that. But there's an organization that has been able to find a way to learn when the first cases occur, and that is called GPHIN; it's the Global Public Health Information Network. And that simulation that I showed you that you thought was bird flu — that was SARS. And SARS is the pandemic that did not occur. And it didn't occur because GPHIN found the pandemic-to-be of SARS three months before WHO actually announced it, and because of that, we were able to stop the SARS pandemic. And I think we owe a great debt of gratitude to GPHIN and to Ron St. John, who I hope is in the audience some place — over there — who's the founder of GPHIN.(Applause)Hello, Ron!(Applause)And TED has flown Ron here from Ottawa, where GPHIN is located, because not only did GPHIN find SARS early, but you may have seen last week that Iran announced that they had bird flu in Iran, but GPHIN found the bird flu in Iran not February 14 — but last September. We need an early-warning system to protect us against the things that are humanity's worst nightmare. And so my TED wish is based on the common denominator of these experiences. Smallpox — early detection, early response. Blindness, polio — early detection, early response. Pandemic bird flu — early detection, early response. It is a litany. It is so obvious that our only way of dealing with these new diseases is to find them early and to kill them before they spread.So, my TED wish is for you to help build a global system — an early-warning system — to protect us against humanity's worst nightmares. And what I thought I would call it is "Early Detection," But it should really be called ... "Total Early Detection." [TED](Laughter) What?(Applause) What? (Applause)But in all seriousness, because this idea is birthed in TED, I would like it to be a legacy of TED, and I'd like to call it the "International System for Total Early Disease Detection." [INSTEDD] And INSTEDD then becomes our mantra. So instead of a hidden pandemic of bird flu, we find it and immediately contain it. Instead of a novel virus caused by bio-terror or bio-error, or shift or drift, we find it and we contain it. Instead of industrial accidents like oil spills or the catastrophe in Bhopal, we find them, and we respond to them. Instead of famine, hidden until it is too late, we detect it, and we respond. And instead of a system which is owned by a government, and hidden in the bowels of government, let's build an early detection system that's freely available to anyone in the world in their own language.Let's make it transparent, non-governmental, not owned by any single country or company, housed in a neutral country, with redundant backup in a different time zone and a different continent. And let's build it on GPHIN. Let's start with GPHIN. Let's increase the websites that they crawl from 20,000 to 20 million. Let's increase the languages they crawl from seven to 70, or more. Let's build in outbound confirmation messages, using text messages or SMS or instant messaging to find out from people who are within 100 meters of the rumor that you hear, if it is, in fact, valid. And let's add satellite confirmation. And we'll add Gapminder's amazing graphics to the front end.And we'll grow it as a moral force in the world, finding out those terrible things before anybody else knows about them, and sending our response to them, so that next year, instead of us meeting here, lamenting how many terrible things there are in the world, we will have pulled together, used the unique skills and the magic of this community, and be proud that we have done everything we can to stop pandemics, other catastrophes, and change the world, beginning right now.(Applause)Chris Anderson: An amazing presentation. First of all, just so everyone understands: you're saying that by creating web crawlers, looking on the Internet for patterns, they can detect something suspicious before WHO, before anyone else can see it? Give an example of how that could possibly be true.Larry Brilliant: You're not mad about the copyright violation?CA: No. I love it.(Laughter)LB: Well, as Ron St. John — I hope you'll go and meet him in the dinner afterwards and talk to him. When he started GPHIN — In 1997, there was an outbreak of bird flu — H5N1. It was in Hong Kong. And a remarkable doctor in Hong Kong responded immediately, by slaughtering 1.5 million chickens and birds, and they stopped that outbreak in its tracks. Immediate detection, immediate response. Then a number of years went by, and there were a lot of rumors about bird flu. Ron and his team in Ottawa began to crawl the web — only crawling 20,000 different websites, mostly periodicals — and they read about and heard about a concern, of a lot of children who had high fever and symptoms of bird flu.They reported this to WHO.WHO took a little while taking action, because WHO will only receive a report from a government, because it's the United Nations. But they were able to point to WHO and let them know that there was this surprising and unexplained cluster of illnesses that looked like bird flu. That turned out to be SARS. That's how the world found out about SARS. And because of that, we were able to stop SARS. Now, what's really important is that, before there was GPHIN, 100 percent of all the world's reports of bad things — whether you're talking about famine or you're talking about bird flu or you're talking about Ebola — 100 percent of all those reports came from nations.The moment these guys in Ottawa — on a budget of 800,000 dollars a year — got cracking, 75 percent of all the reports in the world came from GPHIN, 25 percent of all the reports in the world came from all the other 180 nations. Now, here's what's really interesting: after they'd been working for a couple years, what do you think happened to those nations? They felt pretty stupid. So they started sending in their reports early. And now, their reporting percentage is down to 50 percent, because other nations have started to report. So, can you find diseases early by crawling the web? Of course you can. Can you find it even earlier than GPHIN does now? Of course you can. You saw that they found SARS using their Chinese web crawler a full six weeks before they found it using their English web crawler. Well, they're only crawling in seven languages. These bad viruses really don't have any intention of showing up first in English or Spanish or French.(Laughter)So yes, I want to take GPHIN, I want to build on it. I want to add all the languages of the world that we possibly can. I want to make this open to everybody, so that the health officer in Nairobi or in Patna, Bihar will have as much access to it as the folks in Ottawa or in CDC. And I want to make it part of our culture that there is a community of people who are watching out for the worst nightmares of humanity, and that it's accessible to everyone.
