00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:04.214
so I became the doctor
in an absolutely awful movie

00:02:04.238 --> 00:02:06.136
called "Medicine Ball Caravan."

00:02:06.160 --> 00:02:07.206
(Laughter)

00:02:07.230 --> 00:02:08.702
Now, you know from the '60s,

00:02:08.726 --> 00:02:11.803
you're either on the bus
or you're off the bus; I was on the bus.

00:02:11.827 --> 00:02:14.824
My wife of 37 years and I joined the bus.

00:02:14.848 --> 00:02:17.528
Our bus ride took us
from San Francisco to London,

00:02:17.552 --> 00:02:19.751
then we switched buses at the big pond.

00:02:19.775 --> 00:02:23.203
We then got on two more buses

00:02:23.227 --> 00:02:26.299
and we drove through Turkey
and Iran, Afghanistan,

00:02:26.323 --> 00:02:29.934
over the Khyber Pass into Pakistan,
like every other young doctor.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.625
This is us at the Khyber Pass,
and that's our bus.

00:02:32.649 --> 00:02:35.304
We had some difficulty getting
over the Khyber Pass.

00:02:36.487 --> 00:02:37.958
But we wound up in India.

00:02:38.423 --> 00:02:40.672
And then, like everyone else
in our generation,

00:02:40.696 --> 00:02:42.981
we went to live in a Himalayan monastery.

00:02:43.005 --> 00:02:44.958
(Laughter)

00:02:46.378 --> 00:02:48.189
This is just like a residency program,

00:02:48.213 --> 00:02:50.369
for those of you
that are in medical school.

00:02:50.393 --> 00:02:52.026
(Laughter)

00:02:52.050 --> 00:02:57.250
And we studied with a wise man,
a guru named Karoli Baba,

00:02:57.274 --> 00:03:00.916
who then told me to get rid of the dress,

00:03:00.940 --> 00:03:02.683
put on a three-piece suit,

00:03:02.707 --> 00:03:05.961
go join the United Nations as a diplomat

00:03:05.985 --> 00:03:08.045
and work for the World
Health Organization.

00:03:08.069 --> 00:03:12.437
And he made an outrageous prediction
that smallpox would be eradicated,

00:03:12.461 --> 00:03:15.483
and that this was God's gift to humanity,

00:03:15.507 --> 00:03:18.012
because of the hard work
of dedicated scientists.

00:03:18.618 --> 00:03:20.622
And that prediction came true.

00:03:21.462 --> 00:03:23.772
This little girl is Rahima Banu,

00:03:23.796 --> 00:03:26.761
and she was the last case
of killer smallpox in the world.

00:03:27.190 --> 00:03:32.166
And this document is the certificate
that the global commission signed,

00:03:32.190 --> 00:03:36.958
certifying the world to have eradicated
the first disease in history.

00:03:38.294 --> 00:03:43.934
The key to eradicating smallpox
was early detection, early response.

00:03:44.619 --> 00:03:48.626
I'm going to ask you to repeat that:
early detection, early response.

00:03:48.650 --> 00:03:49.802
Can you say that?

00:03:49.826 --> 00:03:52.248
Audience: Early detection, early response.

00:03:52.920 --> 00:03:55.829
Larry Brilliant: Smallpox
was the worst disease in history.

00:03:55.853 --> 00:03:58.371
It killed more people
than all the wars in history.

00:03:58.395 --> 00:04:02.958
In the last century,
it killed 500 million people.

00:04:04.901 --> 00:04:06.807
You're reading about Larry Page already.

00:04:06.831 --> 00:04:08.403
Somebody reads very fast.

00:04:08.427 --> 00:04:09.981
(Laughter)

00:04:10.005 --> 00:04:12.179
In the year that Larry Page
and Sergey Brin --

00:04:12.203 --> 00:04:15.819
with whom I have a certain affection
and a new affiliation --

00:04:15.843 --> 00:04:18.023
in the year in which they were born,

00:04:18.047 --> 00:04:20.168
two million people died of smallpox.

00:04:21.017 --> 00:04:24.612
We declared smallpox eradicated in 1980.

00:04:25.718 --> 00:04:29.014
This is the most important slide
that I've ever seen in public health,

00:04:29.038 --> 00:04:31.522
[Sovereigns killed by smallpox]
because it shows you

00:04:31.546 --> 00:04:33.417
to be the richest and the strongest,

00:04:33.441 --> 00:04:35.366
and to be kings and queens of the world,

00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:37.464
did not protect you
from dying of smallpox.

00:04:37.488 --> 00:04:41.300
Never can you doubt
that we are all in this together.

00:04:42.427 --> 00:04:46.337
But to see smallpox
from the perspective of a sovereign

00:04:46.361 --> 00:04:47.861
is the wrong perspective.

00:04:48.260 --> 00:04:50.934
You should see it
from the perspective of a mother,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:54.775
watching her child develop
this disease and standing by helplessly.

00:04:54.799 --> 00:05:00.530
Day one, day two, day three,

00:05:00.554 --> 00:05:06.159
day four, day five, day six.

00:05:06.659 --> 00:05:09.572
You're a mother and you're
watching your child,

00:05:09.596 --> 00:05:14.572
and on day six, you see
pustules that become hard.

00:05:15.358 --> 00:05:20.082
Day seven, they show the classic scars
of smallpox umbilication.

00:05:20.106 --> 00:05:21.416
Day eight.

00:05:21.440 --> 00:05:23.168
And Al Gore said earlier

00:05:23.192 --> 00:05:26.081
that the most photographed
image in the world,

00:05:26.105 --> 00:05:27.852
the most printed image in the world,

00:05:27.876 --> 00:05:29.036
was that of the Earth.

00:05:29.474 --> 00:05:32.671
But this was in 1974,
and as of that moment,

00:05:32.695 --> 00:05:36.318
this photograph was the photograph
that was the most widely printed,

00:05:36.342 --> 00:05:39.827
because we printed two billion copies
of this photograph,

00:05:39.851 --> 00:05:43.005
and we took them
hand to hand, door to door,

00:05:43.029 --> 00:05:47.910
to show people and ask them
if there was smallpox in their house,

00:05:47.934 --> 00:05:50.040
because that was our surveillance system.

00:05:50.064 --> 00:05:52.619
We didn't have Google,
we didn't have web crawlers,

00:05:52.643 --> 00:05:54.373
we didn't have computers.

00:05:55.825 --> 00:05:59.682
By day nine -- you look at this picture
and you're horrified;

00:05:59.706 --> 00:06:02.239
I look at this picture
and I say, "Thank God,"

00:06:02.263 --> 00:06:06.224
because it's clear that this is only
an ordinary case of smallpox,

00:06:06.248 --> 00:06:08.239
and I know this child will live.

00:06:09.445 --> 00:06:14.788
And by day 13, the lesions
are scabbing, his eyelids are swollen,

00:06:14.812 --> 00:06:18.641
but you know this child has
no other secondary infection.

00:06:19.022 --> 00:06:23.339
And by day 20, while he will be
scarred for life, he will live.

00:06:24.133 --> 00:06:27.182
There are other kinds of smallpox
that are not like that.

00:06:27.206 --> 00:06:29.594
This is confluent smallpox,

00:06:29.618 --> 00:06:33.403
in which there isn't a single place
on the body where you could put a finger

00:06:33.427 --> 00:06:36.236
and not be covered by lesions.

00:06:36.260 --> 00:06:40.546
Flat smallpox, which killed 100 percent
of people who got it.

00:06:40.570 --> 00:06:43.539
And hemorrhagic smallpox,
the most cruel of all,

00:06:43.563 --> 00:06:46.831
which had a predilection
for pregnant women.

00:06:46.855 --> 00:06:48.822
I've probably had 50 women die.

00:06:49.268 --> 00:06:51.370
They all had hemorrhagic smallpox.

00:06:51.394 --> 00:06:54.718
I've never seen anybody die from it
who wasn't a pregnant woman.

00:06:55.416 --> 00:06:59.337
In 1967, the WHO embarked
on what was an outrageous program

00:06:59.361 --> 00:07:00.845
to eradicate a disease.

00:07:01.162 --> 00:07:04.734
In that year, there were 34 countries
affected with smallpox.

00:07:05.321 --> 00:07:08.227
By 1970, we were down to 18 countries.

00:07:08.806 --> 00:07:11.418
1974, we were down to five countries.

00:07:11.806 --> 00:07:16.120
But in that year,
smallpox exploded throughout India.

00:07:17.112 --> 00:07:20.934
And India was the place
where smallpox made its last stand.

00:07:21.506 --> 00:07:24.545
In 1974, India had
a population of 600 million.

00:07:24.569 --> 00:07:27.587
There are 21 linguistic states in India,

00:07:27.611 --> 00:07:29.803
which is like saying
21 different countries.

00:07:30.200 --> 00:07:33.097
There are 20 million people
on the road at any time,

00:07:33.121 --> 00:07:39.140
in buses and trains, walking;
500,000 villages, 120 million households,

00:07:39.164 --> 00:07:41.468
and none of them wanted to report

00:07:41.492 --> 00:07:43.934
if they had a case
of smallpox in their house,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:47.322
because they thought that smallpox
was the visitation of a deity,

00:07:47.346 --> 00:07:49.369
Shitala Mata, the cooling mother,

00:07:49.393 --> 00:07:53.569
and it was wrong to bring
strangers into your house

00:07:53.593 --> 00:07:55.340
when the deity was in the house.

00:07:56.006 --> 00:07:58.255
No incentive to report smallpox.

00:07:58.644 --> 00:08:01.249
It wasn't just India
that had smallpox deities;

00:08:01.273 --> 00:08:04.537
smallpox deities were
prevalent all over the world.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.370
So, how we eradicated smallpox was --

00:08:08.394 --> 00:08:10.668
mass vaccination wouldn't work.

00:08:10.692 --> 00:08:12.595
You could vaccinate everybody in India,

00:08:12.619 --> 00:08:15.119
but one year later there'd be
21 million new babies,

00:08:15.143 --> 00:08:17.238
which was then the population of Canada.

00:08:17.651 --> 00:08:19.839
It wouldn't do just to vaccinate everyone.

00:08:19.863 --> 00:08:22.934
You had to find every single
case of smallpox in the world

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.934
at the same time, and draw
a circle of immunity around it.

00:08:26.503 --> 00:08:27.958
And that's what we did.

00:08:29.273 --> 00:08:34.468
In India alone, my 150,000 best friends
and I went door to door,

00:08:34.492 --> 00:08:36.566
with that same picture,

00:08:36.590 --> 00:08:38.161
to every single house in India.

00:08:38.185 --> 00:08:40.061
We made over one billion house calls.

00:08:41.499 --> 00:08:45.015
And in the process,
I learned something very important.

00:08:45.721 --> 00:08:49.979
Every time we did a house-to-house search,

00:08:50.003 --> 00:08:54.727
we had a spike in the number
of reports of smallpox.

00:08:54.751 --> 00:08:59.886
When we didn't search, we had
the illusion that there was no disease.

00:08:59.910 --> 00:09:04.114
When we did search, we had the illusion
that there was more disease.

00:09:04.138 --> 00:09:06.377
A surveillance system was necessary,

00:09:06.401 --> 00:09:12.378
because what we needed
was early detection, early response.

00:09:13.680 --> 00:09:15.879
So we searched and we searched,

00:09:15.903 --> 00:09:18.753
and we found every case
of smallpox in India.

00:09:18.777 --> 00:09:21.738
We had a reward. We raised the reward.

00:09:21.762 --> 00:09:23.818
We continued to increase the reward.

00:09:23.842 --> 00:09:26.655
We had a scorecard
that we wrote on every house.

00:09:27.384 --> 00:09:29.115
And as we did that,

00:09:29.139 --> 00:09:32.515
the number of reported cases
in the world dropped to zero.

00:09:33.921 --> 00:09:38.601
And in 1980, we declared the globe
free of smallpox.

00:09:38.625 --> 00:09:43.130
It was the largest campaign
in United Nations history,

00:09:43.154 --> 00:09:44.764
until the Iraq war.

00:09:45.615 --> 00:09:48.934
150,000 people from all over the world --

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.874
doctors of every race,
religion, culture and nation,

00:09:51.898 --> 00:09:56.793
who fought side by side,
brothers and sisters,

00:09:56.817 --> 00:10:00.055
with each other, not against each other,

00:10:00.079 --> 00:10:02.301
in a common cause
to make the world better.

00:10:03.206 --> 00:10:07.002
But smallpox was the fourth disease
that was intended for eradication.

00:10:07.026 --> 00:10:09.279
We failed three other times.

00:10:09.303 --> 00:10:12.582
We failed against malaria,
yellow fever and yaws.

00:10:12.606 --> 00:10:15.934
But soon we may see polio eradicated.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:21.695
But the key to eradicating polio
is early detection, early response.

00:10:22.568 --> 00:10:25.417
This may be the year we eradicate polio.

00:10:25.441 --> 00:10:28.131
That will make it
the second disease in history.

00:10:28.155 --> 00:10:32.294
And David Heymann, who's watching
this on the webcast --

00:10:32.318 --> 00:10:35.278
David, keep on going. We're close!

00:10:35.302 --> 00:10:36.934
We're down to four countries.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:43.365
(Applause)

00:10:43.389 --> 00:10:44.604
I feel like Hank Aaron.

00:10:44.628 --> 00:10:46.631
Barry Bonds can replace me any time.

00:10:46.655 --> 00:10:50.789
Let's get another disease off the list
of terrible things to worry about.

00:10:51.773 --> 00:10:55.022
I was just in India working on
the polio program.

00:10:55.046 --> 00:11:00.809
The polio surveillance program
is four million people going door to door.

00:11:00.833 --> 00:11:02.934
That is the surveillance system.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:07.084
But we need to have
early detection, early response.

00:11:07.108 --> 00:11:08.735
Blindness, the same thing.

00:11:08.759 --> 00:11:13.711
The key to discovering blindness
is doing epidemiological surveys

00:11:13.735 --> 00:11:15.934
and finding out the causes of blindness,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.616
so you can mount the correct response.

00:11:19.219 --> 00:11:23.832
The Seva Foundation
was started by a group of alumni

00:11:23.856 --> 00:11:26.748
of the Smallpox Eradication Programme,

00:11:26.772 --> 00:11:29.463
who, having climbed the highest mountain,

00:11:29.487 --> 00:11:33.934
tasted the elixir of the success
of eradicating a disease,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.934
wanted to do it again.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:40.826
And over the last 27 years,
Seva's programs in 15 countries

00:11:40.850 --> 00:11:43.934
have given back sight
to more than two million blind people.

00:11:44.940 --> 00:11:48.071
Seva got started because we wanted
to apply these lessons

00:11:48.095 --> 00:11:50.690
of surveillance and epidemiology

00:11:50.714 --> 00:11:54.639
to something which nobody else
was looking at as a public health issue:

00:11:54.663 --> 00:11:58.649
blindness, which heretofore had been
thought of only as a clinical disease.

00:11:59.792 --> 00:12:06.064
In 1980, Steve Jobs gave me
that computer, which is Apple number 12,

00:12:06.088 --> 00:12:08.541
and it's still in Kathmandu,
and it's still working,

00:12:08.565 --> 00:12:12.410
and we ought to go get it and auction
it off and make more money for Seva.

00:12:13.172 --> 00:12:17.208
And we conducted the first Nepal survey
ever done for health,

00:12:17.232 --> 00:12:20.089
and the first nationwide
blindness survey ever done,

00:12:20.113 --> 00:12:21.934
and we had astonishing results.

00:12:22.520 --> 00:12:25.231
Instead of finding out
what we thought was the case --

00:12:25.255 --> 00:12:28.934
that blindness was caused mostly
by glaucoma and trachoma --

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.422
we were astounded to find out

00:12:31.446 --> 00:12:35.121
that blindness was caused
instead by cataract.

00:12:36.050 --> 00:12:40.177
You can't cure or prevent
what you don't know is there.

00:12:42.103 --> 00:12:46.299
In your TED packages
there's a DVD, "Infinite Vision,"

00:12:46.323 --> 00:12:48.934
about Dr. V and the Aravind Eye Hospital.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.990
I hope that you will take a look at it.

00:12:51.014 --> 00:12:53.188
Aravind, which started as a Seva project,

00:12:53.212 --> 00:12:56.160
is now the world's largest
and best eye hospital.

00:12:56.184 --> 00:12:59.581
This year, that one hospital
will give back sight

00:12:59.605 --> 00:13:03.156
to more than 300,000 people
in Tamil Nadu, India.

00:13:03.180 --> 00:13:07.454
(Applause)

00:13:07.478 --> 00:13:08.630
Bird flu.

00:13:08.654 --> 00:13:11.475
I stand here as a representative
of all terrible things --

00:13:11.499 --> 00:13:12.958
this might be the worst.

00:13:13.749 --> 00:13:18.503
The key to preventing
or mitigating pandemic bird flu

00:13:18.527 --> 00:13:20.934
is early detection and rapid response.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:26.761
We will not have a vaccine
or adequate supplies of an antiviral

00:13:26.785 --> 00:13:29.934
to combat bird flu if it occurs
in the next three years.

00:13:30.300 --> 00:13:33.934
WHO stages the progress of a pandemic.

00:13:34.304 --> 00:13:38.697
We are now at stage three
on the pandemic alert stage,

00:13:38.721 --> 00:13:42.276
with just a little bit
of human-to-human transmission,

00:13:42.300 --> 00:13:45.934
but no human-to-human-to-human
sustained transmission.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:50.186
The moment WHO says
we've moved to category four --

00:13:50.210 --> 00:13:52.373
this will not be like Katrina.

00:13:52.397 --> 00:13:54.476
The world as we know it will stop.

00:13:54.500 --> 00:13:56.242
There'll be no airplanes flying.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.107
Would you get in an airplane
with 250 people you didn't know,

00:14:00.131 --> 00:14:01.283
coughing and sneezing,

00:14:01.307 --> 00:14:04.800
when you knew that some of them
might carry a disease that could kill you,

00:14:04.824 --> 00:14:07.704
for which you had
no antivirals or vaccine?

00:14:08.835 --> 00:14:12.852
I did a study of the top epidemiologists
in the world in October.

00:14:12.876 --> 00:14:16.934
I asked them -- these are all fluologists
and specialists in influenza --

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.794
and I asked them the questions
you'd like to ask them:

00:14:19.818 --> 00:14:23.006
What do you think the likelihood
is that there'll be a pandemic?

00:14:23.030 --> 00:14:25.707
If it happens, how bad
do you think it will be?

00:14:26.580 --> 00:14:30.671
Fifteen percent said they thought
there'd be a pandemic within three years.

00:14:30.695 --> 00:14:32.631
But much worse than that,

00:14:32.655 --> 00:14:36.117
90 percent said they thought
there'd be a pandemic

00:14:36.141 --> 00:14:39.062
within your children
or your grandchildren's lifetime.

00:14:40.205 --> 00:14:43.729
And they thought
that if there was a pandemic,

00:14:43.753 --> 00:14:45.769
a billion people would get sick.

00:14:46.681 --> 00:14:50.110
As many as 165 million people would die.

00:14:50.808 --> 00:14:53.324
There would be a global
recession and depression

00:14:53.348 --> 00:14:55.526
as our just-in-time inventory system

00:14:55.550 --> 00:14:59.368
and the tight rubber band
of globalization broke,

00:14:59.392 --> 00:15:03.336
and the cost to our economy
of one to three trillion dollars

00:15:03.360 --> 00:15:08.982
would be far worse for everyone
than merely 100 million people dying,

00:15:09.006 --> 00:15:11.308
because so many more people
would lose their job

00:15:11.332 --> 00:15:12.934
and their healthcare benefits,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.413
that the consequences
are almost unthinkable.

00:15:17.127 --> 00:15:20.958
And it's getting worse,
because travel is getting so much better.

00:15:23.168 --> 00:15:28.867
Let me show you a simulation
of what a pandemic looks like.

00:15:29.704 --> 00:15:31.704
So we know what we're talking about.

00:15:32.351 --> 00:15:35.958
Let's assume, for example,
that the first case occurs in South Asia.

00:15:37.358 --> 00:15:39.708
It initially goes quite slowly.

00:15:39.732 --> 00:15:42.348
You get two or three discrete locations.

00:15:44.086 --> 00:15:48.699
Then there'll be secondary outbreaks,
and the disease will spread

00:15:48.723 --> 00:15:52.934
from country to country so fast
that you won't know what hit you.

00:15:53.468 --> 00:15:56.934
Within three weeks
it will be everywhere in the world.

00:15:57.744 --> 00:16:03.095
Now, if we had an "undo" button,
and we could go back and isolate it

00:16:03.119 --> 00:16:06.476
and grab it when it first started --
if we could find it early,

00:16:06.500 --> 00:16:08.934
and we had early detection
and early response,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.648
and we could put each one
of those viruses in jail --

00:16:12.672 --> 00:16:17.553
that's the only way to deal with
something like a pandemic.

00:16:19.307 --> 00:16:20.958
And let me show you why that is.

00:16:22.053 --> 00:16:23.213
We have a joke.

00:16:23.237 --> 00:16:26.061
This is an epidemic curve,
and everyone in medicine,

00:16:26.085 --> 00:16:28.508
I think, ultimately gets
to know what it is.

00:16:28.532 --> 00:16:29.686
But the joke is,

00:16:29.710 --> 00:16:32.819
an epidemiologist likes to arrive
at an epidemic right here

00:16:32.843 --> 00:16:34.981
and ride to glory on the downhill curve.

00:16:35.005 --> 00:16:36.108
(Laughter)

00:16:36.132 --> 00:16:37.934
But you don't get to do that usually.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.936
You usually arrive right about here.

00:16:40.483 --> 00:16:45.767
What we really want is to arrive
right here, so we can stop the epidemic.

00:16:46.283 --> 00:16:47.714
But you can't always do that.

00:16:48.150 --> 00:16:51.707
But there's an organization
that has been able to find a way

00:16:51.731 --> 00:16:53.934
to learn when the first cases occur,

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.307
and that is called GPHIN;

00:16:56.331 --> 00:16:58.854
it's the Global Public Health
Information Network.

00:16:59.204 --> 00:17:01.292
And that simulation that I showed you

00:17:01.316 --> 00:17:03.513
that you thought
was bird flu -- that was SARS.

00:17:03.921 --> 00:17:06.721
And SARS is the pandemic
that did not occur.

00:17:07.290 --> 00:17:08.689
And it didn't occur

00:17:08.713 --> 00:17:15.024
because GPHIN found
the pandemic-to-be of SARS

00:17:15.048 --> 00:17:21.086
three months before WHO actually
announced it, and because of that,

00:17:21.110 --> 00:17:24.276
we were able to stop the SARS pandemic.

00:17:24.300 --> 00:17:26.381
And I think we owe
a great debt of gratitude

00:17:26.405 --> 00:17:28.562
to GPHIN and to Ron St. John,

00:17:28.586 --> 00:17:32.037
who I hope is in the audience
some place -- over there --

00:17:32.061 --> 00:17:33.934
who's the founder of GPHIN.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.441
(Applause)

00:17:35.465 --> 00:17:36.934
Hello, Ron!

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:43.758
(Applause)

00:17:45.568 --> 00:17:50.182
And TED has flown Ron here
from Ottawa, where GPHIN is located,

00:17:50.206 --> 00:17:54.643
because not only
did GPHIN find SARS early,

00:17:54.667 --> 00:17:56.784
but you may have seen last week

00:17:56.808 --> 00:18:01.139
that Iran announced
that they had bird flu in Iran,

00:18:01.163 --> 00:18:04.855
but GPHIN found the bird flu
in Iran not February 14 --

00:18:04.879 --> 00:18:06.736
but last September.

00:18:06.760 --> 00:18:09.420
We need an early-warning system

00:18:09.444 --> 00:18:13.779
to protect us against the things
that are humanity's worst nightmare.

00:18:14.597 --> 00:18:18.399
And so my TED wish is based on
the common denominator

00:18:18.423 --> 00:18:19.789
of these experiences.

00:18:19.813 --> 00:18:22.699
Smallpox -- early detection,
early response.

00:18:22.723 --> 00:18:25.850
Blindness, polio --
early detection, early response.

00:18:26.207 --> 00:18:30.199
Pandemic bird flu --
early detection, early response.

00:18:30.223 --> 00:18:31.610
It is a litany.

00:18:31.634 --> 00:18:36.648
It is so obvious that our only way
of dealing with these new diseases

00:18:36.672 --> 00:18:40.999
is to find them early
and to kill them before they spread.

00:18:41.023 --> 00:18:45.431
So, my TED wish is for you
to help build a global system --

00:18:45.455 --> 00:18:46.934
an early-warning system --

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:50.689
to protect us against
humanity's worst nightmares.

00:18:51.339 --> 00:18:57.462
And what I thought I would call it
is "Early Detection,"

00:18:58.682 --> 00:19:00.806
But it should really be called ...

00:19:02.181 --> 00:19:03.830
"Total Early Detection."
[TED]

00:19:03.854 --> 00:19:04.937
(Laughter)

00:19:04.961 --> 00:19:06.112
What?

00:19:06.136 --> 00:19:13.121
(Applause)

00:19:13.551 --> 00:19:14.701
What?

00:19:14.725 --> 00:19:17.208
(Applause)

00:19:18.177 --> 00:19:20.020
But in all seriousness,

00:19:20.044 --> 00:19:23.567
because this idea is birthed in TED,

00:19:23.591 --> 00:19:28.934
I would like it to be
a legacy of TED, and I'd like to call it

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:34.179
the "International System for Total
Early Disease Detection."

00:19:34.203 --> 00:19:35.401
[INSTEDD]

00:19:37.758 --> 00:19:42.344
And INSTEDD then becomes our mantra.

00:19:45.193 --> 00:19:47.698
So instead of a hidden
pandemic of bird flu,

00:19:47.722 --> 00:19:49.722
we find it and immediately contain it.

00:19:50.681 --> 00:19:55.556
Instead of a novel virus
caused by bio-terror or bio-error,

00:19:55.580 --> 00:19:59.567
or shift or drift,
we find it and we contain it.

00:20:00.226 --> 00:20:02.712
Instead of industrial
accidents like oil spills

00:20:02.736 --> 00:20:04.934
or the catastrophe in Bhopal,

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:08.168
we find them, and we respond to them.

00:20:08.748 --> 00:20:11.871
Instead of famine,
hidden until it is too late,

00:20:11.895 --> 00:20:14.837
we detect it, and we respond.

00:20:16.019 --> 00:20:19.186
And instead of a system
which is owned by a government,

00:20:19.210 --> 00:20:21.631
and hidden in the bowels of government,

00:20:21.655 --> 00:20:24.257
let's build an early detection system

00:20:24.281 --> 00:20:28.110
that's freely available to anyone
in the world in their own language.

00:20:28.816 --> 00:20:33.584
Let's make it transparent,
non-governmental,

00:20:33.608 --> 00:20:36.664
not owned by any single
country or company,

00:20:36.688 --> 00:20:40.108
housed in a neutral country,
with redundant backup

00:20:40.132 --> 00:20:43.299
in a different time zone
and a different continent.

00:20:44.093 --> 00:20:46.086
And let's build it on GPHIN.

00:20:46.110 --> 00:20:47.492
Let's start with GPHIN.

00:20:48.008 --> 00:20:50.922
Let's increase the websites
that they crawl

00:20:50.946 --> 00:20:52.934
from 20,000 to 20 million.

00:20:53.456 --> 00:20:55.965
Let's increase the languages they crawl

00:20:55.989 --> 00:20:58.782
from seven to 70, or more.

00:20:59.131 --> 00:21:02.671
Let's build in outbound
confirmation messages,

00:21:02.695 --> 00:21:05.959
using text messages or SMS
or instant messaging

00:21:05.983 --> 00:21:08.793
to find out from people
who are within 100 meters

00:21:08.817 --> 00:21:10.568
of the rumor that you hear,

00:21:10.592 --> 00:21:11.934
if it is, in fact, valid.

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:14.199
And let's add satellite confirmation.

00:21:14.572 --> 00:21:18.479
And we'll add Gapminder's
amazing graphics to the front end.

00:21:18.503 --> 00:21:22.421
And we'll grow it
as a moral force in the world,

00:21:22.445 --> 00:21:24.537
finding out those terrible things

00:21:24.561 --> 00:21:26.648
before anybody else knows about them,

00:21:26.672 --> 00:21:29.098
and sending our response to them,

00:21:29.122 --> 00:21:32.636
so that next year,
instead of us meeting here,

00:21:32.660 --> 00:21:36.214
lamenting how many terrible things
there are in the world,

00:21:36.238 --> 00:21:37.976
we will have pulled together,

00:21:38.000 --> 00:21:42.879
used the unique skills
and the magic of this community,

00:21:42.903 --> 00:21:46.325
and be proud that we have done
everything we can to stop pandemics,

00:21:46.349 --> 00:21:50.359
other catastrophes, and change
the world, beginning right now.

00:21:52.041 --> 00:21:58.438
(Applause)

00:22:10.949 --> 00:22:13.134
Chris Anderson: An amazing presentation.

00:22:13.158 --> 00:22:15.941
First of all, just so
everyone understands:

00:22:15.965 --> 00:22:20.481
you're saying that
by creating web crawlers,

00:22:20.505 --> 00:22:23.386
looking on the Internet for patterns,

00:22:23.410 --> 00:22:27.815
they can detect something suspicious

00:22:27.839 --> 00:22:30.492
before WHO, before anyone else can see it?

00:22:31.436 --> 00:22:34.293
Give an example of how
that could possibly be true.

00:22:35.132 --> 00:22:38.069
Larry Brilliant: You're not mad
about the copyright violation?

00:22:38.093 --> 00:22:39.252
CA: No. I love it.

00:22:39.276 --> 00:22:40.478
(Laughter)

00:22:40.502 --> 00:22:42.055
LB: Well, as Ron St. John --

00:22:42.079 --> 00:22:45.499
I hope you'll go and meet him
in the dinner afterwards and talk to him.

00:22:45.523 --> 00:22:48.076
When he started GPHIN --

00:22:48.100 --> 00:22:52.496
In 1997, there was an outbreak
of bird flu -- H5N1.

00:22:52.520 --> 00:22:53.807
It was in Hong Kong.

00:22:53.831 --> 00:22:57.013
And a remarkable doctor in Hong Kong
responded immediately,

00:22:57.037 --> 00:23:01.854
by slaughtering 1.5 million
chickens and birds,

00:23:01.878 --> 00:23:04.766
and they stopped
that outbreak in its tracks.

00:23:04.790 --> 00:23:08.002
Immediate detection, immediate response.

00:23:08.026 --> 00:23:09.520
Then a number of years went by,

00:23:09.544 --> 00:23:11.828
and there were a lot
of rumors about bird flu.

00:23:12.542 --> 00:23:16.330
Ron and his team in Ottawa
began to crawl the web --

00:23:16.354 --> 00:23:21.544
only crawling 20,000 different websites,
mostly periodicals --

00:23:21.568 --> 00:23:24.791
and they read about
and heard about a concern,

00:23:24.815 --> 00:23:28.634
of a lot of children who had high fever
and symptoms of bird flu.

00:23:29.571 --> 00:23:31.472
They reported this to WHO.

00:23:32.119 --> 00:23:34.131
WHO took a little while taking action,

00:23:34.155 --> 00:23:38.814
because WHO will only receive
a report from a government,

00:23:38.838 --> 00:23:40.504
because it's the United Nations.

00:23:41.354 --> 00:23:44.756
But they were able to point
to WHO and let them know

00:23:44.780 --> 00:23:49.245
that there was this surprising
and unexplained cluster of illnesses

00:23:49.269 --> 00:23:50.673
that looked like bird flu.

00:23:51.038 --> 00:23:52.772
That turned out to be SARS.

00:23:52.796 --> 00:23:55.168
That's how the world found out about SARS.

00:23:55.763 --> 00:23:58.673
And because of that,
we were able to stop SARS.

00:23:58.697 --> 00:24:02.275
Now, what's really important is that,
before there was GPHIN,

00:24:02.299 --> 00:24:06.514
100 percent of all the world's
reports of bad things --

00:24:06.538 --> 00:24:08.206
whether you're talking about famine

00:24:08.230 --> 00:24:11.308
or you're talking about bird flu
or you're talking about Ebola --

00:24:11.332 --> 00:24:14.071
100 percent of all those reports
came from nations.

00:24:14.484 --> 00:24:16.143
The moment these guys in Ottawa --

00:24:16.167 --> 00:24:20.548
on a budget of 800,000 dollars
a year -- got cracking,

00:24:20.572 --> 00:24:24.704
75 percent of all the reports
in the world came from GPHIN,

00:24:24.728 --> 00:24:27.092
25 percent of all the reports in the world

00:24:27.116 --> 00:24:29.173
came from all the other 180 nations.

00:24:30.474 --> 00:24:32.442
Now, here's what's really interesting:

00:24:32.466 --> 00:24:35.109
after they'd been working
for a couple years,

00:24:35.133 --> 00:24:37.231
what do you think happened
to those nations?

00:24:37.255 --> 00:24:38.438
They felt pretty stupid.

00:24:38.462 --> 00:24:40.675
So they started sending in
their reports early.

00:24:40.699 --> 00:24:44.555
And now, their reporting percentage
is down to 50 percent,

00:24:44.579 --> 00:24:46.997
because other nations
have started to report.

00:24:47.021 --> 00:24:51.187
So, can you find diseases
early by crawling the web?

00:24:51.211 --> 00:24:52.392
Of course you can.

00:24:52.783 --> 00:24:55.631
Can you find it even earlier
than GPHIN does now?

00:24:55.655 --> 00:24:56.806
Of course you can.

00:24:56.830 --> 00:25:01.435
You saw that they found SARS
using their Chinese web crawler

00:25:01.459 --> 00:25:06.402
a full six weeks before they found it
using their English web crawler.

00:25:06.751 --> 00:25:09.140
Well, they're only crawling
in seven languages.

00:25:09.164 --> 00:25:11.670
These bad viruses really
don't have any intention

00:25:11.694 --> 00:25:14.152
of showing up first in English
or Spanish or French.

00:25:14.176 --> 00:25:16.175
(Laughter)

00:25:16.199 --> 00:25:20.683
So yes, I want to take GPHIN,
I want to build on it.

00:25:21.270 --> 00:25:24.622
I want to add all the languages
of the world that we possibly can.

00:25:24.646 --> 00:25:26.934
I want to make this open to everybody,

00:25:26.958 --> 00:25:29.934
so that the health officer
in Nairobi or in Patna, Bihar

00:25:29.958 --> 00:25:34.252
will have as much access to it
as the folks in Ottawa or in CDC.

00:25:34.682 --> 00:25:37.086
And I want to make it part of our culture

00:25:37.110 --> 00:25:40.697
that there is a community of people
who are watching out

00:25:40.721 --> 00:25:42.934
for the worst nightmares of humanity,

00:25:42.958 --> 00:25:44.958
and that it's accessible to everyone.

title: The radical promise of the multi-touch interface
transcript: I'm really excited to be here today. I'll show you some stuff that's just ready to come out of the lab, literally, and I'm really glad that you guys are going to be among the first to see it in person, because I really think this is going to really change the way we interact with machines from this point on.Now, this is a rear-projected drafting table. It's about 36 inches wide and it's equipped with a multi-touch sensor. Normal touch sensors that you see, like on a kiosk or interactive whiteboards, can only register one point of contact at a time. This thing allows you to have multiple points at the same time. They can use both my hands; I can use chording actions; I can just go right up and use all 10 fingers if I wanted to. You know, like that.Now, multi-touch sensing isn't completely new. People like Bill Buxton have been playing around with it in the '80s. However, the approach I built here is actually high-resolution, low-cost, and probably most importantly, very scalable. So, the technology, you know, isn't the most exciting thing here right now, other than probably its newfound accessibility. What's really interesting here is what you can do with it and the kind of interfaces you can build on top of it. So let's see.So, for instance, we have a lava lamp application here. Now, you can see, I can use both of my hands to kind of squeeze and put the blobs together. I can inject heat into the system here, or I can pull it apart with two of my fingers. It's completely intuitive; there's no instruction manual. The interface just kind of disappears. This started out as a screensaver app that one of the Ph.D. students in our lab, Ilya Rosenberg, made. But I think its true identity comes out here.Now what's great about a multi-touch sensor is that, you know, I could be doing this with as many fingers here, but of course multi-touch also inherently means multi-user. Chris could be interacting with another part of Lava, while I play around with it here. You can imagine a new kind of sculpting tool, where I'm kind of warming something up, making it malleable, and then letting it cool down and solidifying in a certain state. Google should have something like this in their lobby.(Laughter)I'll show you a little more of a concrete example here, as this thing loads. This is a photographer's light-box application. Again, I can use both of my hands to interact and move photos around. But what's even cooler is that if I have two fingers, I can actually grab a photo and then stretch it out like that really easily. I can pan, zoom and rotate it effortlessly. I can do that grossly with both of my hands, or I can do it just with two fingers on each of my hands together. If I grab the canvas, I can do the same thing — stretch it out. I can do it simultaneously, holding this down, and gripping on another one, stretching this out.Again, the interface just disappears here. There's no manual. This is exactly what you expect, especially if you haven't interacted with a computer before. Now, when you have initiatives like the $100 laptop, I kind of cringe at the idea of introducing a whole new generation to computing with this standard mouse-and-windows-pointer interface. This is something that I think is really the way we should be interacting with machines from now on.(Applause)Now, of course, I can bring up a keyboard.(Laughter) And I can bring that around, put that up there. Obviously, this is a standard keyboard, but of course I can rescale it to make it work well for my hands. That's really important, because there's no reason in this day and age that we should be conforming to a physical device. That leads to bad things, like RSI. We have so much technology nowadays that these interfaces should start conforming to us. There's so little applied now to actually improving the way we interact with interfaces from this point on. This keyboard is probably actually the really wrong direction to go. You can imagine, in the future, as we develop this kind of technology, a keyboard that kind of automatically drifts as your hand moves away, and really intelligently anticipates which key you're trying to stroke. So — again, isn't this great?(Laughter)Audience: Where's your lab?Jeff Han: I'm a research scientist at NYU in New York.Here's an example of another kind of app. I can make these little fuzz balls. It'll remember the strokes I'm making. Of course I can do it with all my hands. It's pressure-sensitive. What's neat about that is, I showed that two-finger gesture that zooms in really quickly. Because you don't have to switch to a hand tool or the magnifying glass tool, you can just continuously make things in real multiple scales, all at the same time. I can create big things out here, but I can go back and really quickly go back to where I started, and make even smaller things here.This is going to be really important as we start getting to things like data visualization. For instance, I think we all enjoyed Hans Rosling's talk, and he really emphasized the fact I've been thinking about for a long time: We have all this great data, but for some reason, it's just sitting there. We're not accessing it. And one of the reasons why I think that is will be helped by things like graphics and visualization and inference tools, but I also think a big part of it is going to be having better interfaces, to be able to drill down into this kind of data, while still thinking about the big picture here.Let me show you another app here. This is called WorldWind. It's done by NASA. We've all seen Google Earth; this is an open-source version of that. There are plug-ins to be able to load in different data sets that NASA's collected over the years. As you can see, I can use the same two-fingered gestures to go down and go in really seamlessly. There's no interface, again. It really allows anybody to kind of go in — and it just does what you'd expect, you know? Again, there's just no interface here. The interface just disappears. I can switch to different data views. That's what's neat about this app here. NASA's really cool. These hyper-spectral images are false-colored so you can — it's really good for determining vegetative use. Well, let's go back to this.The great thing about mapping applications — it's not really 2D, it's 3D. So, again, with a multi-point interface, you can do a gesture like this — so you can be able to tilt around like that —(Surprised laughter)It's not just simply relegated to a kind of 2D panning and motion. This gesture is just putting two fingers down — it's defining an axis of tilt — and I can tilt up and down that way. We just came up with that on the spot, it's probably not the right thing to do, but there's such interesting things you can do with this interface. It's just so much fun playing around with it, too.(Laughter)And so the last thing I want to show you is — I'm sure we can all think of a lot of entertainment apps that you can do with this thing. I'm more interested in the creative applications we can do with this. Now, here's a simple application here — I can draw out a curve. And when I close it, it becomes a character. But the neat thing about it is I can add control points. And then what I can do is manipulate them with both of my fingers at the same time. And you notice what it does. It's kind of a puppeteering thing, where I can use as many fingers as I have to draw and make —Now, there's a lot of actual math going on under here for this to control this mesh and do the right thing. This technique of being able to manipulate a mesh here, with multiple control points, is actually state of the art. It was released at SIGGRAPH last year. It's a great example of the kind of research I really love: all this compute power to make things do the right things, intuitive things, to do exactly what you expect.So, multi-touch interaction research is a very active field right now in HCI. I'm not the only one doing it, a lot of other people are getting into it. This kind of technology is going to let even more people get into it, I'm looking forward to interacting with all of you over the next few days and seeing how it can apply to your respective fields.Thank you.(Applause)

00:01:46.973 --> 00:01:50.994
But I think its true identity
comes out here.

00:01:52.111 --> 00:01:55.034
Now what's great about a multi-touch
sensor is that, you know,

00:01:55.058 --> 00:01:57.795
I could be doing this
with as many fingers here,

00:01:57.819 --> 00:02:00.797
but of course multi-touch
also inherently means multi-user.

00:02:00.821 --> 00:02:03.320
Chris could be interacting
with another part of Lava,

00:02:03.344 --> 00:02:04.978
while I play around with it here.

00:02:05.002 --> 00:02:07.098
You can imagine
a new kind of sculpting tool,

00:02:07.122 --> 00:02:10.101
where I'm kind of warming something up,
making it malleable,

00:02:10.125 --> 00:02:13.383
and then letting it cool down
and solidifying in a certain state.

00:02:17.670 --> 00:02:20.617
Google should have
something like this in their lobby.

00:02:20.641 --> 00:02:25.934
(Laughter)

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:29.230
I'll show you a little more
of a concrete example here,

00:02:29.254 --> 00:02:30.587
as this thing loads.

00:02:31.139 --> 00:02:33.856
This is a photographer's
light-box application.

00:02:33.880 --> 00:02:37.857
Again, I can use both of my hands
to interact and move photos around.

00:02:37.881 --> 00:02:41.436
But what's even cooler
is that if I have two fingers,

00:02:41.460 --> 00:02:45.590
I can actually grab a photo and then
stretch it out like that really easily.

00:02:45.614 --> 00:02:49.080
I can pan, zoom
and rotate it effortlessly.

00:02:49.104 --> 00:02:51.435
I can do that grossly
with both of my hands,

00:02:51.459 --> 00:02:54.663
or I can do it just with two fingers
on each of my hands together.

00:02:54.687 --> 00:02:57.714
If I grab the canvas, I can do
the same thing -- stretch it out.

00:02:57.738 --> 00:02:59.897
I can do it simultaneously,
holding this down,

00:02:59.921 --> 00:03:02.220
and gripping on another one,
stretching this out.

00:03:02.244 --> 00:03:04.472
Again, the interface just disappears here.

00:03:04.496 --> 00:03:05.529
There's no manual.

00:03:05.553 --> 00:03:07.855
This is exactly what you expect,

00:03:07.879 --> 00:03:10.934
especially if you haven't interacted
with a computer before.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.662
Now, when you have initiatives
like the $100 laptop,

00:03:13.686 --> 00:03:15.219
I kind of cringe at the idea

00:03:15.243 --> 00:03:17.820
of introducing a whole new
generation to computing

00:03:17.844 --> 00:03:20.582
with this standard
mouse-and-windows-pointer interface.

00:03:20.606 --> 00:03:23.742
This is something that I think
is really the way

00:03:23.766 --> 00:03:26.407
we should be interacting
with machines from now on.

00:03:26.431 --> 00:03:32.934
(Applause)

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
Now, of course, I can bring up a keyboard.

00:03:34.982 --> 00:03:37.280
(Laughter)

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.703
And I can bring that around,
put that up there.

00:03:43.171 --> 00:03:45.029
Obviously, this is a standard keyboard,

00:03:45.053 --> 00:03:48.135
but of course I can rescale it
to make it work well for my hands.

00:03:48.159 --> 00:03:51.492
That's really important, because
there's no reason in this day and age

00:03:51.516 --> 00:03:53.856
that we should be conforming
to a physical device.

00:03:53.880 --> 00:03:55.627
That leads to bad things, like RSI.

00:03:55.651 --> 00:03:58.428
We have so much technology nowadays

00:03:58.452 --> 00:04:02.481
that these interfaces
should start conforming to us.

00:04:02.505 --> 00:04:06.482
There's so little applied now
to actually improving

00:04:06.506 --> 00:04:09.085
the way we interact with interfaces
from this point on.

00:04:09.109 --> 00:04:12.300
This keyboard is probably actually
the really wrong direction to go.

00:04:12.324 --> 00:04:15.626
You can imagine, in the future,
as we develop this kind of technology,

00:04:15.650 --> 00:04:19.053
a keyboard that kind of automatically
drifts as your hand moves away,

00:04:19.077 --> 00:04:22.592
and really intelligently anticipates
which key you're trying to stroke.

00:04:23.435 --> 00:04:25.728
So -- again, isn't this great?

00:04:27.009 --> 00:04:28.981
(Laughter)

00:04:29.005 --> 00:04:30.768
Audience: Where's your lab?

00:04:30.792 --> 00:04:33.364
Jeff Han: I'm a research scientist
at NYU in New York.

00:04:37.299 --> 00:04:40.934
Here's an example of another kind of app.
I can make these little fuzz balls.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.292
It'll remember the strokes I'm making.

00:04:43.316 --> 00:04:45.235
Of course I can do it with all my hands.

00:04:45.259 --> 00:04:46.550
It's pressure-sensitive.

00:04:47.863 --> 00:04:49.419
What's neat about that is,

00:04:49.443 --> 00:04:52.408
I showed that two-finger gesture
that zooms in really quickly.

00:04:52.432 --> 00:04:54.639
Because you don't have
to switch to a hand tool

00:04:54.663 --> 00:04:56.069
or the magnifying glass tool,

00:04:56.093 --> 00:04:58.632
you can just continuously make things

00:04:58.656 --> 00:05:01.010
in real multiple scales,
all at the same time.

00:05:01.034 --> 00:05:03.047
I can create big things out here,

00:05:03.071 --> 00:05:05.169
but I can go back
and really quickly go back

00:05:05.193 --> 00:05:07.893
to where I started,
and make even smaller things here.

00:05:09.229 --> 00:05:11.116
This is going to be really important

00:05:11.140 --> 00:05:14.173
as we start getting to things
like data visualization.

00:05:14.197 --> 00:05:16.864
For instance, I think
we all enjoyed Hans Rosling's talk,

00:05:16.888 --> 00:05:20.414
and he really emphasized the fact
I've been thinking about for a long time:

00:05:20.438 --> 00:05:21.789
We have all this great data,

00:05:21.813 --> 00:05:23.910
but for some reason,
it's just sitting there.

00:05:23.934 --> 00:05:25.053
We're not accessing it.

00:05:25.077 --> 00:05:28.600
And one of the reasons why I think that is

00:05:28.624 --> 00:05:33.340
will be helped by things like graphics
and visualization and inference tools,

00:05:33.364 --> 00:05:35.225
but I also think a big part of it

00:05:35.249 --> 00:05:37.305
is going to be having better interfaces,

00:05:37.329 --> 00:05:39.569
to be able to drill down
into this kind of data,

00:05:39.593 --> 00:05:41.931
while still thinking
about the big picture here.

00:05:42.418 --> 00:05:45.397
Let me show you another app here.
This is called WorldWind.

00:05:45.421 --> 00:05:46.560
It's done by NASA.

00:05:46.584 --> 00:05:49.414
We've all seen Google Earth;

00:05:49.438 --> 00:05:51.396
this is an open-source version of that.

00:05:51.420 --> 00:05:54.944
There are plug-ins to be able
to load in different data sets

00:05:54.968 --> 00:05:56.767
that NASA's collected over the years.

00:05:56.791 --> 00:05:59.411
As you can see, I can use
the same two-fingered gestures

00:05:59.435 --> 00:06:01.917
to go down and go in really seamlessly.

00:06:01.941 --> 00:06:03.321
There's no interface, again.

00:06:03.345 --> 00:06:06.616
It really allows anybody
to kind of go in --

00:06:06.640 --> 00:06:09.603
and it just does
what you'd expect, you know?

00:06:09.627 --> 00:06:12.899
Again, there's just no interface here.
The interface just disappears.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.834
I can switch to different data views.

00:06:16.858 --> 00:06:19.052
That's what's neat about this app here.

00:06:19.076 --> 00:06:20.233
NASA's really cool.

00:06:20.257 --> 00:06:23.019
These hyper-spectral images
are false-colored so you can --

00:06:23.043 --> 00:06:26.986
it's really good for determining
vegetative use.

00:06:27.845 --> 00:06:29.431
Well, let's go back to this.

00:06:32.270 --> 00:06:34.444
The great thing
about mapping applications --

00:06:34.468 --> 00:06:35.958
it's not really 2D, it's 3D.

00:06:35.982 --> 00:06:39.474
So, again, with a multi-point interface,
you can do a gesture like this --

00:06:39.498 --> 00:06:42.935
so you can be able
to tilt around like that --

00:06:42.959 --> 00:06:44.833
(Surprised laughter)

00:06:44.857 --> 00:06:48.039
It's not just simply relegated
to a kind of 2D panning and motion.

00:06:48.063 --> 00:06:50.698
This gesture is just putting
two fingers down --

00:06:50.722 --> 00:06:54.375
it's defining an axis of tilt --
and I can tilt up and down that way.

00:06:54.399 --> 00:06:56.477
We just came up with that on the spot,

00:06:56.501 --> 00:06:58.438
it's probably not the right thing to do,

00:06:58.462 --> 00:07:01.691
but there's such interesting things
you can do with this interface.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.892
It's just so much fun
playing around with it, too.

00:07:05.916 --> 00:07:07.269
(Laughter)

00:07:07.293 --> 00:07:09.934
And so the last thing
I want to show you is --

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.635
I'm sure we can all think
of a lot of entertainment apps

00:07:12.659 --> 00:07:14.183
that you can do with this thing.

00:07:14.207 --> 00:07:18.257
I'm more interested in the creative
applications we can do with this.

00:07:18.281 --> 00:07:21.518
Now, here's a simple application here --
I can draw out a curve.

00:07:23.159 --> 00:07:26.425
And when I close it,
it becomes a character.

00:07:26.743 --> 00:07:29.720
But the neat thing about it
is I can add control points.

00:07:29.744 --> 00:07:33.721
And then what I can do is manipulate them
with both of my fingers at the same time.

00:07:33.745 --> 00:07:35.648
And you notice what it does.

00:07:36.211 --> 00:07:38.766
It's kind of a puppeteering thing,

00:07:38.790 --> 00:07:44.008
where I can use as many fingers
as I have to draw and make --

00:07:50.232 --> 00:07:52.934
Now, there's a lot of actual math
going on under here

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:57.400
for this to control this mesh
and do the right thing.

00:07:58.141 --> 00:08:03.833
This technique of being able to manipulate
a mesh here, with multiple control points,

00:08:03.857 --> 00:08:05.333
is actually state of the art.

00:08:05.357 --> 00:08:07.181
It was released at SIGGRAPH last year.

00:08:07.205 --> 00:08:09.975
It's a great example
of the kind of research I really love:

00:08:09.999 --> 00:08:12.798
all this compute power
to make things do the right things,

00:08:12.822 --> 00:08:15.543
intuitive things,
to do exactly what you expect.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.616
So, multi-touch interaction research
is a very active field right now in HCI.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.434
I'm not the only one doing it,
a lot of other people are getting into it.

00:08:27.458 --> 00:08:30.703
This kind of technology is going to let
even more people get into it,

00:08:30.727 --> 00:08:34.219
I'm looking forward to interacting
with all of you over the next few days

00:08:34.243 --> 00:08:36.780
and seeing how it can apply
to your respective fields.

00:08:36.804 --> 00:08:37.962
Thank you.

00:08:37.986 --> 00:08:40.555
(Applause)

title: One Laptop per Child
transcript: I've been at MIT for 44 years. I went to TED I. There's only one other person here, I think, who did that. All the other TEDs — and I went to them all, under Ricky's regime — I talked about what the Media Lab was doing, which today has almost 500 people in it.And if you read the press, last week it actually said I quit the Media Lab. I didn't quit the Media Lab, I stepped down as chairman — which was a kind of ridiculous title, but someone else has taken it on — and one of the things you can do as a professor is you stay on as a professor. And I will now do for the rest of my life the One Laptop Per Child, which I've sort of been doing for a year and a half, anyway. So I'm going to tell you about this, use my 18 minutes to tell you why we're doing it, how we're doing it and then what we're doing. And at some point I'll even pass around what the $100 laptop might be like.I was asked by Chris to talk about some of the big issues, and so I figured I'd start with the three that at least drove me to do this. And the first is pretty obvious. It's amazing when you meet a head of state, and you say, "What is your most precious natural resource?" They will not say "children" at first, and then when you say, "children," they will pretty quickly agree with you. And so that isn't very hard.(Laughter)Everybody agrees that whatever the solutions are to the big problems, they include education, sometimes can be just education and can never be without some element of education. So that's certainly part of it.And the third is a little bit less obvious. And that is that we all in this room learned how to walk, how to talk, not by being taught how to talk, or taught how to walk, but by interacting with the world, by having certain results as a consequence of being able to ask for something, or being able to stand up and reach it. Whereas at about the age six, we were told to stop learning that way, and that all learning from then on would happen through teaching, whether it's people standing up, like I'm doing now, or a book, or something. But it was really through teaching. And one of the things in general that computers have provided to learning is that it now includes a kind of learning which is a little bit more like walking and talking, in the sense that a lot of it is driven by the learner himself or herself.So with those as the principles — some of you may know Seymour Papert. This is back in 1982, when we were working in Senegal. Because some people think that the $100 laptop just happened a year ago, or two years ago, or we were struck by lightning — this actually has gone back a long time, and in fact, back to the '60s. Here we're in the '80s. Steve Jobs had given us some laptops. We were in Senegal. It didn't scale but it at least was bringing computers to developing countries and learning pretty quickly that these kids, even though English wasn't their language, the Latin alphabet barely was their language, but they could just swim like fish. They could play these like pianos.A little bit more recently, I got involved personally. And these are two anecdotes — one was in Cambodia, in a village that has no electricity, no water, no television, no telephone, but has broadband Internet now. And these kids, their first English word is "Google" and they only know Skype. They've never heard of telephony. They just use Skype. And they go home at night — they've got a broadband connection in a hut that doesn't have electricity. The parents love it, because when they open up the laptops, it's the brightest light source in the house. And talk about where metaphors and reality mix — this is the actual school.In parallel with this, Seymour Papert got the governor of Maine to legislate one laptop per child in the year 2002. Now at the time, I think it's fair to say that 80 percent of the teachers were — let me say, apprehensive. Really, they were actually against it. And they really preferred that the money would be used for higher salaries, more schools, whatever.And now, three and a half years later, guess what? They're reporting five things: drop of truancy to almost zero, attending parent-teacher meetings — which nobody did and now almost everybody does — drop in discipline problems, increase in student participation. Teachers are now saying it's kind of fun to teach. Kids are engaged — they have laptops! — and then the fifth, which interests me the most, is that the servers have to be turned off at certain times at night because the teachers are getting too much email from the kids asking them for help. So when you see that kind of thing — this is not something that you have to test. The days of pilot projects are over, when people say, "We'd like to do three or four thousand in our country to see how it works." Screw you. Go to the back of the line and someone else will do it, and then when you figure out that this works, you can join as well. And this is what we're doing.(Laughter) (Applause)So, One Laptop Per Child was formed about a year and a half ago. It's a nonprofit association. It raised about 20 million dollars to do the engineering to just get this built, and then have it produced afterwards. Scale is truly important. And it's not important because you can buy components at a lower price, OK? It's because you can go to a manufacturer — and I will leave the name out — but we wanted a small display, doesn't have to have perfect color uniformity. It can even have a pixel or two missing. It doesn't have to be that bright. And this particular manufacturer said, "We're not interested in that. We're interested in the living room. We're interested in perfect color uniformity. We're interested in big displays, bright displays. You're not part of our strategic plan." And I said, "That's kind of too bad, because we need 100 million units a year."(Laughter)And they said, "Oh, well, maybe we could become part of your strategic plan." And that's why scale counts. And that's why we will not launch this without five to 10 million units in the first run. And the idea is to launch with enough scale that the scale itself helps bring the price down, and that's why I said seven to 10 million there. And we're doing it without a sales-and-marketing team. I mean, you're looking at the sales-and-marketing team. We will do it by going to seven large countries and getting them to agree and launch it, and then the others can follow. We have partners. It's not hard to guess Google would be one. The others are all playing to pending. And this has been in the press a great deal. It's the so-called Green Machine that we introduced with Kofi Annan in November at the World Summit that was held in Tunisia.Now once people start looking at this, they say, "Ah, this is a laptop project." Well, no, it's not a laptop project. It's an education project. And the fun part — and I'm quite focused on it — I tell people I used to be a light bulb, but now I'm a laser — I'm just going to get that thing built, and it turns out it's not so hard. Because laptop economics are the following: I say 50 percent here — it's more like 60, 60 percent of the cost of your laptop is sales, marketing, distribution and profit. Now we have none of those, OK? None of those figure into our cost, because first of all, we sell it at cost, and the governments distribute it. It gets distributed to the school system like a textbook. So that piece disappears. Then you have display and everything else. Now the display on your laptop costs, in rough numbers, 10 dollars a diagonal inch. That can drop to eight; it can drop to seven but it's not going to drop to two, or to one and a half, unless we do some pretty clever things. It's the rest — that little brown box — that is pretty fascinating, because the rest of your laptop is devoted to itself. It's a little bit like an obese person having to use most of their energy to move their obesity.(Laughter)And we have a situation today which is incredible. I've been using laptops since their inception. And my laptop runs slower, less reliably and less pleasantly than it ever has before. And this year is worse.(Applause)People clap, sometimes you even get standing ovations, and I say, "What the hell's wrong with you? Why are we all sitting there?" And somebody — to remain nameless — called our laptop a "gadget" recently. And I said, "God, our laptop's going to go like a bat out of hell. When you open it up, it's going to go 'bing.'" It'll be on. It'll be just like it was in 1985, when you bought an Apple Macintosh 512. It worked really well. And we've been going steadily downhill.Now, people ask all the time what it is. That's what it is. The two pieces that are probably notable: it'll be a mesh network, so when the kids open up their laptops, they all become a network, and then just need one or two points of backhaul. You can serve a couple of thousand kids with two megabits. So you really can bring into a village, and then the villages can connect themselves, and you really can do it quite well.The dual mode display — the idea is to have a display that both works outdoors — isn't it fun using your cell phone outdoors in the sunlight? Well, you can't see it. And one of the reasons you can't see it is because it's backlighting most of the time, most cell phones. Now, what we're doing is, we're doing one that will be both frontlit and backlit. And whether you manually switch it or you do it in the software is to be seen. But when it's backlit, it's color. And when it's frontlit, it's black and white at three times the resolution.Is it all worked out? No. That's why a lot of our people are more or less living in Taiwan right now. And in about 30 days, we'll know for sure whether this works. Probably the most important piece there is that the kids really can do the maintenance. And this is again something that people don't believe, but I really think it's quite true. That's the machine we showed in Tunis. This is more the direction that we're going to go. And it's something that we didn't think was possible. Now, I'm going to pass this around. This isn't a design, OK? So this is just a mechanical engineering sort of embodiment of it for you to play with. And it's clearly just a model. The working one is at MIT. I'm going to pass it to this handsome gentleman. At least you can decide whether it goes left or —Chris Anderson: Before you do it, for the people down in simulcast —Nicholas Negroponte: Sorry! I forgot. CA: Just show it off a bit.So wherever the camera is — OK, good point. Thank you, Chris.The idea was that it would be not only a laptop, but that it could transform into an electronic book. So it's sort of an electronic book. This is where when you go outside, it's in black and white. The games buttons are missing, but it'll also be a games machine, book machine. Set it up this way, and it's a television set. Etc., etc. — is that enough for simulcast? OK, sorry. I'll let Jim decide which way to send it afterwards. OK. Seven countries.(Laughter)I say "maybe" for Massachusetts, because they actually have to do a bid. By law you've got to bid, and so on and so forth. So I can't quite name them. In the other cases, they don't have to do bids. They can decide — it's the federal government in each case. It's kind of agonizing, because a lot of people say, "Let's do it at the state level," because states are more nimble than the feds, just because of size. And yet we count. We're really dealing with the federal government. We're really dealing with ministries of education. And if you look at governments around the world, ministries of education tend to be the most conservative, and also the ones that have huge payrolls. Everybody thinks they know about education, a lot of culture is built into it as well. It's really hard. And so it's certainly the hard road. If you look at the countries, they're pretty geoculturally distributed.Have they all agreed? No, not completely. Probably Thailand, Brazil and Nigeria are the three that are the most active and most agreed. We're purposely not signing anything with anybody until we actually have the working ones. And since I visit each one of those countries within at least every three months, I'm just going around the world every three weeks. Here's sort of the schedule and I put at the bottom we might give some away free in two years at this meeting. Everybody says it's a $100 laptop — you can't do it. Well, guess what, we're not. We're coming in probably at 135, to start, then drift down. And that's very important, because so many things hit the market at a price and then drift up. It's kind of the loss leader, and then as soon as it looks interesting, it can't be afforded, or it can't be scaled out. So we're targeting 50 dollars in 2010.The gray market's a big issue. And one of the ways — just one — but one of the ways to help in the case of the gray market is to make something that is so utterly unique — It's a little bit like the fact that automobiles — thousands of automobiles are stolen every day in the United States. Not one single post-office truck is stolen.(Laughter)And why? Because there's no market for post-office trucks. It looks like a post-office truck. You can spray paint it. You can do anything you want. I just learned recently: in South Africa, no white Volvos are stolen. Period. None. Zero. So we want to make it very much like a white Volvo.Each government has a task force. This perhaps is less interesting, but we're trying to get the governments to all work together and it's not easy. The economics of this is to start with the federal governments and then later, to subsequently go to other — whether it's child-to-child funding, so a child in this country buys one for a child in the developing world, maybe of the same gender, maybe of the same age. An uncle gives a niece or a nephew that as a birthday present. I mean, there are all sorts of things that will happen, and they'll be very, very exciting.And everybody says — I say — it's an education project. Are we providing the software? The answer is: The system certainly has software, but no, we're not providing the education content. That is really done in the countries. But we are certainly constructionists. And we certainly believe in learning by doing and everything from Logo, which was started in 1968, to more modern things, like Scratch, if you've ever even heard of it, are very, very much part of it. And that's the rollout.Are we dreaming? Is this real? It actually is real. The only criticism, and people really don't want to criticize this, because it is a humanitarian effort, a nonprofit effort and to criticize it is a little bit stupid, actually.(Laughter)But the one thing that people could criticize was, "Great idea, but these guys can't do it." And that could either mean these guys, professors and so on couldn't do it, or that it's not possible. Well, on December 12, a company called Quanta agreed to build it, and since they make about one-third of all the laptops on the planet today, that question disappeared. So it's not a matter of whether it's going to happen. It is going to happen. And if it comes out at 138 dollars, so what? If it comes out six months late, so what? That's a pretty soft landing.Thank you.(Applause)
