We have exactly one employee,

00:03:25.518 --> 00:03:28.134
and that employee
is our lead software developer.

00:03:28.158 --> 00:03:31.334
And he's only been our employee
since January 2005,

00:03:31.358 --> 00:03:33.174
all the other growth before that ...

00:03:33.198 --> 00:03:36.814
So the servers are managed
by a ragtag band of volunteers.

00:03:36.838 --> 00:03:38.814
All the editing is done by volunteers.

00:03:38.838 --> 00:03:40.374
And the way that we're organized

00:03:40.398 --> 00:03:43.081
is not like any traditional
organization you can imagine.

00:03:43.105 --> 00:03:45.820
People are always asking,
"Well, who's in charge of this?"

00:03:45.844 --> 00:03:47.014
or "Who does that?"

00:03:47.038 --> 00:03:49.334
And the answer is:
anybody who wants to pitch in.

00:03:49.358 --> 00:03:52.838
It's a very unusual and chaotic thing.

00:03:53.438 --> 00:03:55.734
We've got over 90 servers now
in three locations.

00:03:55.758 --> 00:04:01.014
These are managed by volunteer
system administrators who are online.

00:04:01.038 --> 00:04:03.094
I can go online
any time of the day or night

00:04:03.118 --> 00:04:07.414
and see eight to 10 people waiting for me

00:04:07.438 --> 00:04:10.974
to ask a question or something,
anything about the servers.

00:04:10.998 --> 00:04:13.334
You could never afford
to do this in a company.

00:04:13.358 --> 00:04:14.574
You could never afford

00:04:14.598 --> 00:04:18.334
to have a standby crew of people
24 hours a day

00:04:18.358 --> 00:04:20.678
and do what we're doing at Wikipedia.

00:04:21.438 --> 00:04:24.654
So we're doing around
1.4 billion page views monthly,

00:04:24.678 --> 00:04:26.718
so it's really gotten to be a huge thing.

00:04:27.318 --> 00:04:29.694
And everything is managed
by the volunteers.

00:04:29.718 --> 00:04:33.934
And the total monthly cost
for our bandwidth is about 5,000 dollars.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.894
And that's essentially our main cost.

00:04:35.918 --> 00:04:38.174
We could actually do without the employee.

00:04:38.198 --> 00:04:42.614
We hired Brian because he was
working part-time for two years

00:04:42.638 --> 00:04:43.934
and full-time at Wikipedia,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.174
so we actually hired him,

00:04:45.198 --> 00:04:47.838
so he could get a life
and go to the movies sometimes.

00:04:48.913 --> 00:04:52.294
So the big question when you've got
this really chaotic organization is,

00:04:52.318 --> 00:04:53.534
why isn't it all rubbish?

00:04:53.558 --> 00:04:55.478
Why is the website as good as it is?

00:04:55.953 --> 00:04:57.334
First of all, how good is it?

00:04:57.358 --> 00:04:58.894
Well, it's pretty good.

00:04:58.918 --> 00:05:00.134
It isn't perfect,

00:05:00.158 --> 00:05:02.174
but it's much better
than you would expect,

00:05:02.198 --> 00:05:03.881
given our completely chaotic model.

00:05:03.905 --> 00:05:06.921
So when you saw him make
a ridiculous edit to the page about me,

00:05:06.945 --> 00:05:10.694
you think, "Oh, this is obviously
just going to degenerate into rubbish."

00:05:10.718 --> 00:05:12.449
But when we've seen quality tests --

00:05:12.473 --> 00:05:14.489
and there haven't been enough of these yet

00:05:14.513 --> 00:05:17.094
and I'm really encouraging
people to do more,

00:05:17.118 --> 00:05:19.254
comparing Wikipedia
to traditional things --

00:05:19.278 --> 00:05:21.054
we win hands down.

00:05:21.078 --> 00:05:23.814
So a German magazine
compared German Wikipedia,

00:05:23.838 --> 00:05:27.174
which is much, much smaller than English,

00:05:27.198 --> 00:05:31.294
to Microsoft Encarta
and to Brockhaus multimedial,

00:05:31.318 --> 00:05:32.774
and we won across the board.

00:05:32.798 --> 00:05:36.179
They hired experts to come and look
at articles and compare the quality,

00:05:36.203 --> 00:05:38.523
and we were very pleased with that result.

00:05:39.278 --> 00:05:44.814
So a lot of people have heard about
the Wikipedia Bush-Kerry controversy.

00:05:44.838 --> 00:05:47.494
The media has covered this
somewhat extensively.

00:05:47.518 --> 00:05:50.334
It started out
with an article in Red Herring.

00:05:50.358 --> 00:05:52.174
The reporters called me up and they --

00:05:52.198 --> 00:05:55.174
I mean, I have to say
they spelled my name right,

00:05:55.198 --> 00:06:00.134
but they really wanted to say
the Bush-Kerry election is so contentious,

00:06:00.158 --> 00:06:02.534
it's tearing apart
the Wikipedia community.

00:06:02.558 --> 00:06:04.054
And so they quote me as saying,

00:06:04.078 --> 00:06:06.974
"They're the most contentious
in the history of Wikipedia."

00:06:06.998 --> 00:06:09.574
What I actually said
is they're not contentious at all.

00:06:09.598 --> 00:06:11.694
So it's a slight misquote.

00:06:11.718 --> 00:06:13.494
(Laughter)

00:06:13.518 --> 00:06:15.534
The articles were edited quite heavily.

00:06:15.558 --> 00:06:18.014
And it is true that we did
have to lock the articles

00:06:18.038 --> 00:06:19.374
on a couple of occasions.

00:06:19.398 --> 00:06:21.774
Time magazine recently reported that

00:06:21.798 --> 00:06:23.814
"Extreme action sometimes has to be taken,

00:06:23.838 --> 00:06:28.694
and Wales locked the entries
on Kerry and Bush for most of 2004."

00:06:28.718 --> 00:06:32.974
This came after I told the reporter
that we had to lock it for --

00:06:32.998 --> 00:06:35.134
occasionally a little bit here and there.

00:06:35.158 --> 00:06:38.534
So the truth in general
is that the kinds of controversies

00:06:38.558 --> 00:06:41.749
that you would probably think
we have within the Wikipedia community

00:06:41.773 --> 00:06:44.494
are not really controversies at all.

00:06:44.518 --> 00:06:47.014
Articles on controversial topics
are edited a lot,

00:06:47.038 --> 00:06:50.014
but they don't cause much controversy
within the community.

00:06:50.038 --> 00:06:53.758
And the reason for this is that most
people understand the need for neutrality.

00:06:54.558 --> 00:07:01.254
The real struggle is not
between the right and the left --

00:07:01.278 --> 00:07:02.898
that's where most people assume --

00:07:02.922 --> 00:07:04.974
but it's between
the party of the thoughtful

00:07:04.998 --> 00:07:06.294
and the party of the jerks.

00:07:06.318 --> 00:07:08.134
And no side of the political spectrum

00:07:08.158 --> 00:07:10.614
has a monopoly
on either of those qualities.

00:07:10.638 --> 00:07:13.214
The actual truth
about the specific Bush-Kerry incident

00:07:13.238 --> 00:07:16.214
is that the Bush-Kerry articles

00:07:16.238 --> 00:07:19.214
were locked less than one percent
of the time in 2004,

00:07:19.238 --> 00:07:21.294
and it wasn't because
they were contentious;

00:07:21.318 --> 00:07:23.654
it was just because
there was routine vandalism --

00:07:23.678 --> 00:07:27.374
which happens sometimes even on stage ...

00:07:27.398 --> 00:07:28.534
(Laughter)

00:07:28.558 --> 00:07:32.094
Sometimes even reporters have reported
to me that they vandalized Wikipedia

00:07:32.118 --> 00:07:34.454
and were amazed
that it was fixed so quickly.

00:07:34.478 --> 00:07:37.254
And I said -- you know, I always say,
please don't do that.

00:07:37.278 --> 00:07:38.854
That's not a good thing.

00:07:38.878 --> 00:07:40.374
So how do we do this?

00:07:40.398 --> 00:07:43.254
How do we manage the quality control?

00:07:43.278 --> 00:07:44.478
How does it work?

00:07:46.078 --> 00:07:47.774
So there's a few elements,

00:07:47.798 --> 00:07:51.054
mostly social policies
and some elements of the software.

00:07:51.078 --> 00:07:53.814
So the biggest
and the most important thing

00:07:53.838 --> 00:07:55.569
is our neutral point of view policy.

00:07:55.593 --> 00:07:58.355
This is something
that I set down, from the very beginning,

00:07:58.379 --> 00:08:02.414
as a core principle of the community
that's completely not debatable.

00:08:02.438 --> 00:08:05.334
It's a social concept of cooperation,

00:08:05.358 --> 00:08:08.854
so we don't talk a lot
about truth and objectivity.

00:08:08.878 --> 00:08:10.934
The reason for this is if we say

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.534
we're only going to write
the "truth" about some topic,

00:08:13.558 --> 00:08:16.765
that doesn't do us a damn bit of good
of figuring out what to write,

00:08:16.789 --> 00:08:19.325
because I don't agree with you
about what's the truth.

00:08:19.349 --> 00:08:21.694
But we have this
jargon term of neutrality,

00:08:21.718 --> 00:08:24.174
which has its own long history
within the community,

00:08:24.198 --> 00:08:27.614
which basically says,
any time there's a controversial issue,

00:08:27.638 --> 00:08:30.214
Wikipedia itself should not
take a stand on the issue.

00:08:30.238 --> 00:08:33.477
We should merely report on what
reputable parties have said about it.

00:08:33.501 --> 00:08:36.574
So this neutrality policy
is really important for us

00:08:36.598 --> 00:08:39.854
because it empowers a community
that is very diverse

00:08:39.878 --> 00:08:42.174
to come together
and actually get some work done.

00:08:42.198 --> 00:08:44.334
So we have very diverse contributors

00:08:44.358 --> 00:08:47.574
in terms of political,
religious, cultural backgrounds.

00:08:47.598 --> 00:08:49.414
By having this firm neutrality policy,

00:08:49.438 --> 00:08:51.454
which is non-negotiable
from the beginning,

00:08:51.478 --> 00:08:53.336
we ensure that people can work together

00:08:53.360 --> 00:08:55.574
and that the entries
don't become simply a war

00:08:55.598 --> 00:08:57.741
back and forth
between the left and the right.

00:08:57.765 --> 00:09:01.480
If you engage in that type of behavior,
you'll be asked to leave the community.

00:09:03.198 --> 00:09:04.654
So, real-time peer review.

00:09:04.678 --> 00:09:07.814
Every single change on the site
goes to the "Recent changes" page.

00:09:07.838 --> 00:09:11.334
So as soon as he made his change,
it went to the "Recent changes" page.

00:09:11.358 --> 00:09:15.334
That recent changes page
was also fed into an IRC channel,

00:09:15.358 --> 00:09:16.934
which is an Internet chat channel

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:20.158
that people are monitoring
with various software tools.

00:09:20.878 --> 00:09:23.334
And people can get RSS feeds --

00:09:23.358 --> 00:09:26.454
they can get email
notifications of changes.

00:09:26.478 --> 00:09:29.134
And then users can set up
their own personal watch list.

00:09:29.158 --> 00:09:31.651
So my page is on quite a few
volunteers' watch lists,

00:09:31.675 --> 00:09:33.371
because it is sometimes vandalized.

00:09:33.395 --> 00:09:39.374
And therefore, what happens is someone
will notice the change very quickly,

00:09:39.398 --> 00:09:42.774
and then they'll just
simply revert the change.

00:09:42.798 --> 00:09:44.714
There's a "new pages feed," for example,

00:09:44.738 --> 00:09:46.794
so you can go
to a certain page of Wikipedia

00:09:46.818 --> 00:09:48.746
and see every new page as it's created.

00:09:48.778 --> 00:09:49.928
This is really important

00:09:49.938 --> 00:09:53.154
because a lot of new pages
are just garbage that has to be deleted,

00:09:53.158 --> 00:09:54.414
you know, "ASDFASDF."

00:09:54.438 --> 00:09:57.354
But also, that's some
of the most interesting and fun things,

00:09:57.378 --> 00:09:58.594
some of the new articles.

00:09:58.618 --> 00:10:01.194
People will start an article
on some interesting topic,

00:10:01.218 --> 00:10:03.034
other people will find that intriguing

00:10:03.058 --> 00:10:05.454
and jump in and help
and make it much better.

00:10:05.478 --> 00:10:07.374
So we do have edits by anonymous users,

00:10:07.398 --> 00:10:11.254
which is one of the most controversial
and intriguing things about Wikipedia.

00:10:11.278 --> 00:10:14.894
So, Chris was able to do his change --
he didn't have to log in or anything;

00:10:14.918 --> 00:10:17.734
he just went on the website
and made a change.

00:10:17.758 --> 00:10:19.814
But it turns out
that only about 18 percent

00:10:19.838 --> 00:10:21.334
of all the edits to the website

00:10:21.358 --> 00:10:22.694
are done by anonymous users.

00:10:22.718 --> 00:10:25.054
And that's a really important
thing to understand:

00:10:25.078 --> 00:10:28.334
the vast majority of the edits
that go on on the website

00:10:28.358 --> 00:10:32.054
are from a very close-knit community
of maybe 600 to 1,000 people

00:10:32.078 --> 00:10:33.698
who are in constant communication.

00:10:33.722 --> 00:10:36.294
And we have over 40 IRC channels,
40 mailing lists.

00:10:36.318 --> 00:10:37.894
All these people know each other.

00:10:37.918 --> 00:10:39.966
They communicate.
We have off-line meetings.

00:10:39.990 --> 00:10:42.610
These are the people
who are doing the bulk of the site,

00:10:42.634 --> 00:10:47.282
and they are, in a sense,
semi-professionals at what they're doing.

00:10:47.918 --> 00:10:50.254
The standards we set for ourselves

00:10:50.278 --> 00:10:53.334
are equal to or higher
than professional standards of quality.

00:10:53.358 --> 00:10:56.874
We don't always meet those standards,
but that's what we're striving for.

00:10:56.898 --> 00:10:59.756
And so that tight community
is who really cares for the site,

00:10:59.780 --> 00:11:02.414
and these are some
of the smartest people I've ever met.

00:11:02.438 --> 00:11:04.694
It's my job to say that,
but it's actually true.

00:11:04.718 --> 00:11:08.454
The type of people who were drawn
to writing an encyclopedia for fun

00:11:08.478 --> 00:11:10.814
tend to be pretty smart people.

00:11:10.838 --> 00:11:13.934
The tools and the software:
there's lots of tools that allow us --

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.578
allow us, meaning the community --

00:11:15.602 --> 00:11:17.654
to self-monitor
and to monitor all the work.

00:11:17.678 --> 00:11:20.174
This is an example
of a page history on "flat Earth,"

00:11:20.198 --> 00:11:22.254
and you can see some changes
that were made.

00:11:22.278 --> 00:11:25.574
What's nice about this page
is you can immediately take a look at this

00:11:25.598 --> 00:11:27.174
and see, "OK, I understand now."

00:11:27.198 --> 00:11:28.974
When somebody goes and looks at --

00:11:28.998 --> 00:11:31.141
they see that someone,
an anonymous IP number,

00:11:31.165 --> 00:11:32.654
made an edit to my page.

00:11:32.678 --> 00:11:34.734
That sounds suspicious.
Who is this person?

00:11:34.758 --> 00:11:35.974
Somebody looks at it --

00:11:35.998 --> 00:11:38.014
they can immediately see
highlighted in red

00:11:38.038 --> 00:11:39.934
all of the changes that took place --

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.574
to see, OK, well, these words
have changed, things like this.

00:11:43.598 --> 00:11:45.218
So that's one tool that we can use

00:11:45.242 --> 00:11:47.762
to very quickly monitor
the history of a page.

00:11:48.478 --> 00:11:50.774
Another thing that we do
within the community

00:11:50.798 --> 00:11:54.174
is we leave everything very open-ended.

00:11:54.198 --> 00:11:57.574
Most of the social rules
and the methods of work

00:11:57.598 --> 00:12:00.014
are left completely open-ended
in the software.

00:12:00.038 --> 00:12:02.054
All of that stuff is just on Wiki pages.

00:12:02.078 --> 00:12:05.174
And so there's nothing
in the software that enforces the rules.

00:12:05.198 --> 00:12:09.214
The example I've got up here
is the Votes for Deletion page.

00:12:09.238 --> 00:12:11.814
So, I mentioned earlier,
people type "ASDFASDF" --

00:12:11.838 --> 00:12:13.054
it needs to be deleted.

00:12:13.078 --> 00:12:15.554
Cases like that,
the administrators just delete it.

00:12:15.578 --> 00:12:17.914
There's no reason
to have a big argument about it.

00:12:17.938 --> 00:12:21.273
But you can imagine there's a lot
of other areas where the question is,

00:12:21.297 --> 00:12:23.537
is this notable enough
to go in an encyclopedia?

00:12:23.561 --> 00:12:27.134
Is the information verifiable?
Is it a hoax? Is it true? Is it what?

00:12:27.158 --> 00:12:30.214
So we needed a social method
for figuring out the answer to this.

00:12:30.238 --> 00:12:33.096
And so the method that arose
organically within the community

00:12:33.120 --> 00:12:34.694
is the Votes For Deletion page.

00:12:34.718 --> 00:12:36.734
And in the particular
example we have here,

00:12:36.758 --> 00:12:38.254
it's a film, "Twisted Issues,"

00:12:38.278 --> 00:12:39.734
and the first person says,

00:12:39.758 --> 00:12:43.454
"Now this is supposedly a film.
It fails the Google test miserably."

00:12:43.478 --> 00:12:46.294
The Google test is you look in Google
and see if it's there,

00:12:46.318 --> 00:12:50.214
because if something's not even in Google,
it probably doesn't exist at all.

00:12:50.238 --> 00:12:51.814
It's not a perfect rule,

00:12:51.838 --> 00:12:55.174
but it's a nice starting point
for quick research.

00:12:55.198 --> 00:12:58.453
So somebody says, "Delete it, please.
Delete it -- it's not notable."

00:12:58.477 --> 00:13:01.493
And then somebody says,
"Wait, I found it. I found it in a book,

00:13:01.517 --> 00:13:04.774
'Film Threat Video Guide:
the 20 Underground Films You Must See.'"

00:13:04.798 --> 00:13:06.703
So the next persons says, "Clean it up."

00:13:06.727 --> 00:13:10.134
Somebody says, "I've found it on IMDB.
Keep, keep, keep."

00:13:10.158 --> 00:13:12.974
And what's interesting about this
is that the software is --

00:13:12.998 --> 00:13:16.534
these votes are just text
typed into a page.

00:13:16.558 --> 00:13:20.614
This is not really a vote
so much as it is a dialogue.

00:13:20.638 --> 00:13:23.374
Now it is true that at the end of the day,

00:13:23.398 --> 00:13:26.637
an administrator can go through here
and take a look at this and say,

00:13:26.661 --> 00:13:29.134
"OK, 18 deletes, two keeps:
we'll delete it."

00:13:29.158 --> 00:13:32.934
But in other cases,
this could be 18 deletes and two keeps,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.754
and we would keep it,
because if those last two keeps say,

00:13:35.778 --> 00:13:38.683
"Wait a minute. Nobody else saw this
but I found it in a book,

00:13:38.707 --> 00:13:40.905
and I found a link
to a page that describes it,

00:13:40.929 --> 00:13:44.025
and I'm going to clean it up tomorrow,
so please don't delete it,"

00:13:44.049 --> 00:13:45.234
then it would survive.

00:13:45.258 --> 00:13:47.854
And it also matters
who the people are who are voting.

00:13:47.878 --> 00:13:49.783
Like I say, it's a tight-knit community.

00:13:49.807 --> 00:13:52.334
Down here at the bottom,
"Keep, real movie," RickK.

00:13:52.358 --> 00:13:55.739
RickK is a very famous Wikipedian
who does an enormous amount of work

00:13:55.763 --> 00:13:58.494
with vandalism, hoaxes
and votes for deletion.

00:13:58.518 --> 00:14:01.334
His voice carries a lot of weight
within the community

00:14:01.358 --> 00:14:02.930
because he knows what he's doing.

00:14:04.358 --> 00:14:06.294
So how is all this governed?

00:14:06.318 --> 00:14:09.454
People really want to know
about administrators, things like that.

00:14:09.478 --> 00:14:13.334
So the Wikipedia governance model,
the governance of the community,

00:14:13.358 --> 00:14:17.774
is a very confusing,
but workable mix of consensus --

00:14:17.798 --> 00:14:20.334
meaning we try not to vote
on the content of articles,

00:14:20.358 --> 00:14:24.254
because the majority view
is not necessarily neutral --

00:14:24.278 --> 00:14:25.574
some amount of democracy --

00:14:25.598 --> 00:14:26.934
all of the administrators --

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.754
these are the people
who have the ability to delete pages.

00:14:29.778 --> 00:14:32.614
That doesn't mean that they have
the right to delete pages.

00:14:32.638 --> 00:14:36.474
They still have to follow all the rules --
but they're elected by the community.

00:14:36.498 --> 00:14:38.928
Sometimes people --
random trolls on the Internet --

00:14:38.952 --> 00:14:41.335
like to accuse me
of handpicking the administrators

00:14:41.359 --> 00:14:43.264
to bias the content of the encyclopedia.

00:14:43.288 --> 00:14:47.054
I always laugh at this, because I have
no idea how they're elected, actually.

00:14:47.078 --> 00:14:49.054
There's a certain amount of aristocracy.

00:14:49.078 --> 00:14:51.221
You got a hint of that
when I mentioned, like,

00:14:51.245 --> 00:14:53.397
RickK's voice would carry
a lot more weight

00:14:53.421 --> 00:14:54.717
than someone we don't know.

00:14:54.741 --> 00:14:57.454
I give this talk sometimes with Angela,

00:14:57.478 --> 00:15:00.209
who was just re-elected to the board
from the community --

00:15:00.233 --> 00:15:01.729
to the Board of the Foundation,

00:15:01.753 --> 00:15:04.894
with more than twice the votes
of the person who didn't make it.

00:15:04.918 --> 00:15:07.854
And I always embarrass her because I say,

00:15:07.878 --> 00:15:09.174
"Well, Angela, for example,

00:15:09.198 --> 00:15:12.614
could get away with doing
absolutely anything within Wikipedia,

00:15:12.638 --> 00:15:14.654
because she's so admired and so powerful."

00:15:14.678 --> 00:15:18.494
But the irony is, of course, that Angela
can do this because she's the one person

00:15:18.518 --> 00:15:21.494
who you know would never, ever
break any rules of Wikipedia.

00:15:21.518 --> 00:15:23.574
And I also like to say
she's the only person

00:15:23.598 --> 00:15:26.814
who actually knows
all the rules of Wikipedia, so ...

00:15:26.838 --> 00:15:28.077
And then there's monarchy,

00:15:28.101 --> 00:15:30.117
and that's my role
on the community, so ...

00:15:30.141 --> 00:15:32.534
(Laughter)

00:15:32.558 --> 00:15:35.174
I was describing this in Berlin once,

00:15:35.198 --> 00:15:37.974
and the next day
in the newspaper the headline said,

00:15:37.998 --> 00:15:39.566
"I am the Queen of England."

00:15:39.590 --> 00:15:40.741
(Laughter)

00:15:40.765 --> 00:15:43.134
And that's not exactly what I said, but --

00:15:43.158 --> 00:15:44.654
(Laughter)

00:15:44.678 --> 00:15:47.254
the point is my role in the community --

00:15:47.278 --> 00:15:51.974
Within the free software world,
there's been a long-standing tradition

00:15:51.998 --> 00:15:55.214
of the "benevolent dictator" model.

00:15:55.238 --> 00:15:58.094
So if you look at most
of the major free software projects,

00:15:58.118 --> 00:15:59.894
they have one single person in charge

00:15:59.918 --> 00:16:03.254
who everyone agrees
is the benevolent dictator.

00:16:03.278 --> 00:16:05.774
Well, I don't like the term
"benevolent dictator,"

00:16:05.798 --> 00:16:09.774
and I don't think that it's my job
or my role in the world of ideas

00:16:09.798 --> 00:16:13.134
to be the dictator of the future
of all human knowledge

00:16:13.158 --> 00:16:14.374
compiled by the world.

00:16:14.398 --> 00:16:16.094
It just isn't appropriate.

00:16:16.118 --> 00:16:18.894
But there is a need still
for a certain amount of monarchy,

00:16:18.918 --> 00:16:20.494
a certain amount of --

00:16:20.518 --> 00:16:22.294
sometimes we have to make a decision

00:16:22.318 --> 00:16:24.557
and we don't want
to get bogged down too heavily

00:16:24.581 --> 00:16:27.294
in formal decision-making processes.

00:16:27.318 --> 00:16:32.214
So as an example
of how this can be important:

00:16:32.238 --> 00:16:36.214
we recently had a situation where
a neo-Nazi website discovered Wikipedia,

00:16:36.238 --> 00:16:39.094
and they said,
"Oh, well, this is horrible,

00:16:39.118 --> 00:16:41.014
this Jewish conspiracy of a website,

00:16:41.038 --> 00:16:44.197
and we're going to get certain articles
deleted that we don't like.

00:16:44.221 --> 00:16:47.221
And we see they have a voting process,
so we're going to send --

00:16:47.245 --> 00:16:50.054
we have 40,000 members
and we're going to send them over

00:16:50.078 --> 00:16:52.856
and they're all going to vote
and get these pages deleted."

00:16:52.880 --> 00:16:55.071
Well, they managed
to get 18 people to show up.

00:16:55.095 --> 00:16:57.854
That's neo-Nazi math for you.

00:16:57.878 --> 00:17:01.334
They always think they've got
40,000 members when they've got 18.

00:17:01.358 --> 00:17:04.854
But they managed to get 18 people
to come and vote in a fairly absurd way

00:17:04.878 --> 00:17:06.894
to delete a perfectly valid article.

00:17:06.918 --> 00:17:09.654
Of course, the vote ended up
being about 85 to 18,

00:17:09.678 --> 00:17:12.934
so there was no real danger
to our democratic processes.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:16.253
On the other hand, people said,
"But what are we going to do?

00:17:16.277 --> 00:17:17.533
I mean, this could happen.

00:17:17.557 --> 00:17:19.894
What if some group
gets really seriously organized

00:17:19.918 --> 00:17:22.494
and comes in and wants to vote?"

00:17:22.518 --> 00:17:25.293
Then I said, "Well, fuck it,
we'll just change the rules."

00:17:25.317 --> 00:17:27.013
That's my job in the community:

00:17:27.037 --> 00:17:30.614
to say we won't allow
our openness and freedom

00:17:30.638 --> 00:17:33.214
to undermine the quality of the content.

00:17:33.238 --> 00:17:36.533
And so, as long as people
trust me in my role,

00:17:36.557 --> 00:17:38.414
then that's a valid place for me.

00:17:38.438 --> 00:17:40.474
Of course, because of the free licensing,

00:17:40.498 --> 00:17:43.975
if I do a bad job, the volunteers
are more than happy to take and leave --

00:17:43.999 --> 00:17:45.479
I can't tell anyone what to do.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:50.654
So the final point here
is that to understand how Wikipedia works,

00:17:50.678 --> 00:17:53.869
it's important to understand
that our wiki model is the way we work,

00:17:53.893 --> 00:17:57.494
but we are not fanatical web anarchists.

00:17:57.518 --> 00:18:00.894
In fact, we're very flexible
about the social methodology,

00:18:00.918 --> 00:18:03.334
because ultimately,
the passion of the community

00:18:03.358 --> 00:18:05.374
is for the quality of the work,

00:18:05.398 --> 00:18:08.374
not necessarily for the process
that we use to generate it.

00:18:08.398 --> 00:18:09.614
Thank you.

00:18:09.638 --> 00:18:13.894
(Applause)

00:18:13.918 --> 00:18:15.694
Ben Saunders: Yeah, hi, Ben Saunders.

00:18:15.718 --> 00:18:19.854
Jimmy, you mentioned impartiality
being a key to Wikipedia's success.

00:18:19.878 --> 00:18:25.214
It strikes me that much of the textbooks
that are used to educate our children

00:18:25.238 --> 00:18:27.014
are inherently biased.

00:18:27.038 --> 00:18:30.654
Have you found Wikipedia
being used by teachers

00:18:30.678 --> 00:18:33.134
and how do you see Wikipedia
changing education?

00:18:33.158 --> 00:18:37.374
Jimmy Wales: Yeah, so, a lot of teachers
are beginning to use Wikipedia.

00:18:37.398 --> 00:18:41.974
There's a media storyline about Wikipedia,
which I think is false.

00:18:41.998 --> 00:18:45.574
It builds on the storyline
of bloggers versus newspapers.

00:18:45.598 --> 00:18:48.734
And the storyline is,
there's this crazy thing, Wikipedia,

00:18:48.758 --> 00:18:52.214
but academics hate it
and teachers hate it.

00:18:52.238 --> 00:18:54.814
And that turns out to not be true.

00:18:54.838 --> 00:18:57.374
The last time I got an email
from a journalist saying,

00:18:57.398 --> 00:18:59.114
"Why do academics hate Wikipedia?"

00:18:59.138 --> 00:19:00.996
I sent it from my Harvard email address

00:19:01.020 --> 00:19:03.273
because I was recently
appointed a fellow there.

00:19:03.297 --> 00:19:05.313
And I said, "Well,
they don't all hate it."

00:19:05.337 --> 00:19:06.414
(Laughter)

00:19:06.438 --> 00:19:09.294
But I think there's going
to be huge impacts.

00:19:09.318 --> 00:19:12.734
And we actually have a project
that I'm personally really excited about,

00:19:12.758 --> 00:19:14.254
which is the Wikibooks project,

00:19:14.278 --> 00:19:17.374
which is an effort to create
textbooks in all the languages.

00:19:17.398 --> 00:19:18.974
And that's a much bigger project.

00:19:18.998 --> 00:19:23.614
It's going to take 20 years or so
to come to fruition.

00:19:23.638 --> 00:19:25.654
But part of that is to fulfill our mission

00:19:25.678 --> 00:19:28.654
of giving an encyclopedia
to every single person on the planet.

00:19:28.678 --> 00:19:31.534
We don't mean we're going
to Spam them with AOL-style CDs.

00:19:31.558 --> 00:19:34.354
We mean we're going to give them
a tool that they can use.

00:19:34.378 --> 00:19:36.154
And for a lot of people in the world,

00:19:36.178 --> 00:19:39.354
if I give you an encyclopedia
that's written at a university level,

00:19:39.378 --> 00:19:42.934
it doesn't do you any good
without a whole host of literacy materials

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:45.734
to build you up to the point
where you can actually use it.

00:19:45.758 --> 00:19:47.901
The Wikibooks project
is an effort to do that.

00:19:47.925 --> 00:19:51.134
And I think that we're going to see --
it may not even come from us;

00:19:51.158 --> 00:19:53.134
there's all kinds of innovation going on.

00:19:53.158 --> 00:19:56.318
But freely licensed textbooks
are the next big thing in education.

title: The birth of the open-source learning revolution
transcript: I'm Rich Baraniuk and what I'd like to talk a little bit about today are some ideas that I think have just tremendous resonance with all the things that have been talked about the last two days. So many different points of resonance that it's going to be difficult to bring them all up, but I'll try to do my best. Does anybody remember these?(Laughter)OK, so these are LP records and they've been replaced, right? They've been swept away over the last two decades by these types of world-flattening digitization technologies, right? And I think it was best witnessed when Thomas was playing the music as we came in the room today. What's happened in the music world is there's a culture, or an ecosystem that's been created that, if you take some words from Apple, the catchphrase — that we create, rip, mix and burn. What I mean by that is that anyone in the world is free and allowed to create new music and musical ideas. Anyone in the world is allowed to rip or copy musical ideas, use them in innovative ways. Anyone is allowed to mix them in different types of ways, draw connections between musical ideas, and people can burn them or create final products and continue the circle. And what that's done is it's created, like I said, a vibrant community that's very inclusive, with people continually working to connect musical ideas, innovate them and keep things constantly up to date. Today's hit single is not last year's hit single.But I'm not here to talk about music today. I'm here to talk about books. In particular, textbooks and the kind of educational materials that we use every day in school. Has anyone here ever been to school?(Laughter)OK, does anybody realize there's a crisis in our schools, around the world? I'm not going to spend too much time on that, but what I want to talk about is some of the disconnects that appear when an author publishes a book. That in fact, the publishing process — just because of the fact that it's complicated, it's heavy, books are expensive — creates a sort of a wall between authors of books and the ultimate users of books, be they teachers, students or just general readers. And this is even more true if you happen to speak a language other than one of the world's major languages, and especially English. I'm going to call these people below the barrier "shutouts" because they're really shut out of the process of being able to share their knowledge with the world. And so what I want to talk about today is trying to take these ideas that we've seen in the musical culture and try to bring these towards reinventing the way we think about writing books, using them and teaching from them. So, that's what I'd like to talk about and, really, how we get from where we are now to where we need to go.The first thing I'd like you to do is a little thought experiment. Imagine taking all the world's books. OK, everybody imagine books and imagine just tearing out the pages. So, liberating these pages and imagine digitizing them and then storing them in a vast, interconnected, global repository. Think of it as a massive iTunes for book-type content. And then take that material and imagine making it all open, so that people can modify it, play with it, improve it. Imagine making it free, so that anyone in the world can have access to all of this knowledge, and imagine using information technology so that you can update this content, improve it, play with it, on a timescale that's more on the order of seconds instead of years. Instead of editions of a book coming out every two years, imagine them coming out every 25 seconds.So, imagine we could do that and imagine we could put people into this. So that we could truly build an ecosystem with not just authors, but all the people who could be or want to be authors in all the different languages of the world, and I think if you could do this, it would be called — I'm just going to refer to it as a knowledge ecosystem. So, really, this is the dream, and in a sense what you can think of it is we're trying to enable anyone in the world, I mean anyone in the world —(Laughter)to be their own educational DJ, creating educational materials, sharing them with the world, constantly innovating on them. So, this is the dream.In fact, this dream is actually being realized. Over the last six-and-a-half years, we've been working really hard at Rice University on a project called Connexions, and so what I'd like to do for the rest of the talk is just tell you a little bit about what people are doing with Connexions, which you can kind of think of as the counterpoint to Nicholas Negroponte's talk yesterday, where they're working on the hardware of bringing education to the world. We're working on the open-source tools and the content. So, that's sort of to put it in perspective here.So, create. What are some of the people that are using these kind of tools? Well, the first thing is, there's a community of engineering professors, from Cambridge to Kyoto, who are developing engineering content in electrical engineering to develop what you can think of as a massive, super textbook that covers the entire area of electrical engineering. And not only that — it can be customized for use in each of their own individual institutions. If people like Kitty Jones, a shut-out — a private music teacher and mom from Champagne, Illinois, who wanted to share her fantastic music content with the world, on how to teach kids how to play music — Her material is now used over 600,000 times per month. Tremendous use. In fact, a lot of this use coming from United States K-12 schools, because anyone who's involved in a school scale back, the first thing that's cut is the music curriculum. And so this is just indicating the tremendous thirst for this kind of open, free content. A lot of teachers are using this stuff.What about ripping? What about copying, reusing? A team of volunteers at the University of Texas at El Paso — graduate students translating this engineering super textbook ideas. And within about a week, having this be some of our most popular material in widespread use all over Latin America, and in particular in Mexico, because of the open, extensible nature of this. People, volunteers and even companies that are translating materials into Asian languages like Chinese, Japanese and Thai, to spread the knowledge even further.OK, what about people who are mixing? What does "mixing" mean? "Mixing" means building customized courses, means building customized books. Companies like National Instruments, who are embedding very powerful, interactive simulations into the materials, so that we can go way beyond our regular kind of textbook to an experience that all the teaching materials are things you can actually interact with and play around with and actually learn as you do.We've been working with Teachers Without Borders, who are very interested in mixing our materials. They're going to be using Connexions as their platform to develop and deliver teaching materials for teaching teachers how to teach in 84 countries around the world. TWB is currently in Iraq, training 20,000 teachers supported by USAID. And to them, this idea of being able to remix and customize to the local context is extraordinarily important, because just providing free content to people has actually been likened by people in the developing world to a kind of cultural imperialism — that if you don't empower people with the ability to re-contextualize the material, translate it into their own language and take ownership of it, it's not good.OK, other organizations we've been working with, UC Merced — people know about UC Merced. It's a new university in California, in the Central Valley, working very closely with community colleges. They're actually developing a lot of their science and engineering curriculum to spread widely around the world in our system. And they're also trying to develop all of their software tools completely open-source. We've been working with AMD, which has a project called 50x15, which is trying to bring Internet connectivity to 50 percent of the world's population by 2015. We're going to be providing content to them in a whole range of different languages. And we've also been working with a number of other organizations. In particular, a bunch of the projects that are funded by Hewlett Foundation, who have taken a real leadership role in this area of open content.OK, burn — I think this is, sort of, quite interesting. "Burn" is the idea of trying to create the physical instantiation of one of these courses. And I think a lot of you received — I think all of you received one of these music books in your gift pack. A little present for you. Just to tell you quickly about it: this is an engineering textbook. It's about 300 pages long, hardbound. This costs — anybody guess? How much would it cost in a bookstore?(Audience) 65 dollars.Richard Baraniuk: OK. This costs 22 dollars to the student. Why does it cost 22 dollars? Because it's published on demand and it's developed from this repository of open materials. If this book were to be published by a regular publisher, it would cost at least 122 dollars.So what we're seeing is moving this burning or publication process from the regular, sort of single-authored book towards community-authored materials that are modular, that are customized to each individual class and published on demand very inexpensively, either pushed out through Amazon or published directly through an on-demand press, like QOOP. And I think that this is an extraordinarily interesting area because there is tremendous area under this long tail in publishing. We're not talking about the Harry Potter end, right at the left side. We're talking about books on hypergeometric partial differential equations. Books that might sell 100 copies a year, 1,000 copies a year. There is tremendous sustaining revenue under this long tail to sustain open projects like ours, but also to sustain this new emergence of on-demand publishers, like QOOP, who produced these two books. And I think one of the things that you should take away from this talk is that there's an impending cut-out-the-middle-man disintermediation, that's going to be happening in the publishing industry. And it's going to reach a crescendo over the next few years, and I think that it's for our benefit, really, and for the world's benefit.OK, so what are the enablers? What's really making all of this happen? There's tons of technology, and the only piece of technology that I really want to talk about is XML. How many people know about XML? Oh, great. So it's the future of the web, right? It's semantic representation of content. And what you can really think of XML in this case is it's the packaging that we're putting around these pages. Remember we took the book, tore the pages out? Well, what the XML is going to do is it's going to turn those pages into Lego blocks. XML are the nubs on the Lego that allow us to combine the content together in a myriad different ways, and it provides us a framework to share content. So, it lets you take this ecosystem in its primordial state of all this content, all the pages you've torn out of books, and create highly sophisticated learning machines: books, courses, course packs.It gives you the ability to personalize the learning experience to each individual student, so that every student can have a book or a course that's customized to their learning style, their context, their language and the things that excite them. It lets you reuse the same materials in multiple different ways, and surprising new ways. It lets you interconnect ideas, indicating how fields relate to each other. And I'll just give you my personal story. We came up with this six-and-a-half years ago because I teach the stuff in the red box.And my day job, as Chris said — I'm an electrical engineering professor. I teach signal processing and my challenge was to show that this math — Wow, about half of you have already fallen asleep just looking at the equation.(Laughter)But this seemingly dry math is actually the center of this tremendously powerful web that links technology — that links really cool applications like music synthesizers to tremendous economic opportunities, but also governed by intellectual property. And the thing that I realized is there was no way that I, as an engineer, could write this book that would get all of this across. We needed a community to do it and we needed new tools to be able to interconnect these ideas. And I think that really, in a sense, what we're trying to do is make Minsky's dream come to a reality, where you can imagine all the books in a library actually starting to talk to each other. And people who are teachers out here — whoever taught, you know this — it's the interconnections between ideas that teaching is really all about.OK, back to math. Imagine — this is possible: that every single equation that you click on in one of your new e-texts is something that you're going to be able to explore and experiment with. So imagine your kid's algebra textbook in seventh grade. You can click on every single equation and bring up a little tool to be able to experiment with it, tinker with it, understand it. Because we really don't understand until we do. The same type of mark-up, like MathML, for chemistry. Imagine chemistry textbooks that actually understand the structure of how molecules are formed. Imagine Music XML that actually lets you delve into the semantic structure of music, play with it, understand it. It's no wonder that everybody's getting into it, right? Even the three wise men.(Laughter)OK, the second big enabler, and this is where I told a big lie. The second big enabler is intellectual property. Because, in fact, I got up here and I talked about how great the music culture is. We can share and rip, mix and burn, but in fact, that's all illegal. And we would be accused of [piracy] for doing that, because this music has been propertized. It's now owned, much of it by big industries. So, really, the key thing here is we can't let this happen. We can't let this Napster thing happen here. So, what we have to do is get it right from the very beginning. And what we have to do is find an intellectual property framework that makes sharing safe and makes it easily understandable. And the inspiration here is taken from open-source software. Things like Linux and the GPL.The Creative Commons licenses. How many people have heard of creative commons? If you have not, you must learn about it. Creativecommons.org. At the bottom of every piece of material in Connexions and in lots of other projects, you can find their logo. Clicking on that logo takes you to an absolute no-nonsense, human-readable document, a deed, that tells you exactly what you can do with this content. In fact, you're free to share it, to do all of these things: to copy it, to change it, even to make commercial use of it, as long as you attribute the author. Because in academic publishing and much of educational publishing, it's really this idea of sharing knowledge and making impact. That's why people write, not necessarily making bucks. We're not talking about Harry Potter, right? We're at the long tail end here. Behind that is the legal code, very carefully constructed.And Creative Commons is taking off — over 43 million things out there, licensed with a Creative Commons license. Not just text, but music, images, video. And there's actually a tremendous uptake of the number of people that are actually licensing music to make it free for people who do this whole idea of re-sampling, ripping, mixing, burning and sharing.OK, I'd like to conclude with just the last few points. So, we've built this idea of a commons. People are using it. We get over 500,000 unique visitors per month, just to our particular site. MIT OpenCourseWare, which is another large open-content site, gets a similar number of hits. But how do we protect this? How do we protect it into the future? And the first thing that people are probably thinking is quality control, right? Because we're saying that anybody can contribute things to this commons. Anybody can contribute anything. So that could be a problem.It didn't take long until people started contributing materials, for example, on lingerie, which is actually a pretty good module. The only problem is it's plagiarized from a major French feminist journal, and when you go to the supposed course website, it points to a lingerie-selling website. So this is a little bit of a problem. So we clearly need some kind of idea of quality control and this is really where the idea of review and peer review comes in. You come to TED. Why do you come to TED? Because Chris and his team have ensured that things are very, very high quality, right? And so we need to be able to do the same thing. And we need to be able to design structures, and what we're doing is designing social software to enable anyone to build their own peer review process, and we call these things "lenses." And basically what they allow is anyone out there can develop their own peer-review process, so that they can focus on the content in the repository that they think is really important. And you can think of TED as a potential lens.So I'd just like to end by saying: you can really view this as a call to action. Connexions and open content is all about sharing knowledge. All of you here are tremendously imbued with tremendous amounts of knowledge, and what I'd like to do is invite each and every one of you to contribute to this project and other projects of its type, because I think together we can truly change the landscape of education and educational publishing.So, thanks very much.

is it's created, like I said,

00:01:25.038 --> 00:01:27.038
a vibrant community that's very inclusive,

00:01:27.062 --> 00:01:30.774
with people continually working
to connect musical ideas,

00:01:30.798 --> 00:01:34.214
innovate them and keep things
constantly up to date.

00:01:34.238 --> 00:01:38.014
Today's hit single
is not last year's hit single.

00:01:38.038 --> 00:01:40.214
But I'm not here
to talk about music today.

00:01:40.238 --> 00:01:41.694
I'm here to talk about books.

00:01:41.718 --> 00:01:45.134
In particular, textbooks
and the kind of educational materials

00:01:45.158 --> 00:01:47.574
that we use every day in school.

00:01:47.598 --> 00:01:49.313
Has anyone here ever been to school?

00:01:49.337 --> 00:01:50.734
(Laughter)

00:01:50.758 --> 00:01:54.734
OK, does anybody realize
there's a crisis in our schools,

00:01:54.758 --> 00:01:56.534
around the world?

00:01:56.558 --> 00:01:59.094
I'm not going to spend
too much time on that,

00:01:59.118 --> 00:02:02.454
but what I want to talk about
is some of the disconnects

00:02:02.478 --> 00:02:04.974
that appear when an author
publishes a book.

00:02:04.998 --> 00:02:06.856
That in fact, the publishing process --

00:02:06.880 --> 00:02:09.071
just because of the fact
that it's complicated,

00:02:09.095 --> 00:02:10.774
it's heavy, books are expensive --

00:02:10.798 --> 00:02:14.094
creates a sort of a wall
between authors of books

00:02:14.118 --> 00:02:15.654
and the ultimate users of books,

00:02:15.678 --> 00:02:19.774
be they teachers, students
or just general readers.

00:02:19.798 --> 00:02:22.934
And this is even more true
if you happen to speak a language

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:26.894
other than one of the world's
major languages, and especially English.

00:02:26.918 --> 00:02:29.734
I'm going to call these people
below the barrier "shutouts"

00:02:29.758 --> 00:02:31.901
because they're really
shut out of the process

00:02:31.925 --> 00:02:34.453
of being able to share
their knowledge with the world.

00:02:34.477 --> 00:02:37.669
And so what I want to talk about today
is trying to take these ideas

00:02:37.693 --> 00:02:39.516
that we've seen in the musical culture

00:02:39.540 --> 00:02:41.881
and try to bring these
towards reinventing the way

00:02:41.905 --> 00:02:45.734
we think about writing books,
using them and teaching from them.

00:02:45.758 --> 00:02:47.574
So, that's what I'd like to talk about

00:02:47.598 --> 00:02:49.837
and, really, how we get
from where we are now

00:02:49.861 --> 00:02:51.134
to where we need to go.

00:02:51.158 --> 00:02:54.254
The first thing I'd like you to do
is a little thought experiment.

00:02:54.278 --> 00:02:56.040
Imagine taking all the world's books.

00:02:56.064 --> 00:02:59.574
OK, everybody imagine books
and imagine just tearing out the pages.

00:02:59.598 --> 00:03:01.694
So, liberating these pages

00:03:01.718 --> 00:03:04.974
and imagine digitizing them
and then storing them

00:03:04.998 --> 00:03:07.894
in a vast, interconnected,
global repository.

00:03:07.918 --> 00:03:13.534
Think of it as a massive iTunes
for book-type content.

00:03:13.558 --> 00:03:16.814
And then take that material
and imagine making it all open,

00:03:16.838 --> 00:03:19.894
so that people can modify it,
play with it, improve it.

00:03:19.918 --> 00:03:21.174
Imagine making it free,

00:03:21.198 --> 00:03:24.437
so that anyone in the world can have
access to all of this knowledge,

00:03:24.461 --> 00:03:26.814
and imagine using information technology

00:03:26.838 --> 00:03:30.174
so that you can update this content,
improve it, play with it,

00:03:30.198 --> 00:03:34.854
on a timescale that's more
on the order of seconds instead of years.

00:03:34.878 --> 00:03:37.734
Instead of editions of a book
coming out every two years,

00:03:37.758 --> 00:03:40.694
imagine them coming out every 25 seconds.

00:03:40.718 --> 00:03:44.974
So, imagine we could do that
and imagine we could put people into this.

00:03:44.998 --> 00:03:48.374
So that we could truly build
an ecosystem with not just authors,

00:03:48.398 --> 00:03:51.974
but all the people
who could be or want to be authors

00:03:51.998 --> 00:03:54.054
in all the different
languages of the world,

00:03:54.078 --> 00:03:56.654
and I think if you could do this,
it would be called --

00:03:56.678 --> 00:03:59.254
I'm just going to refer to it
as a knowledge ecosystem.

00:03:59.278 --> 00:04:01.374
So, really, this is the dream,

00:04:01.398 --> 00:04:03.256
and in a sense what you can think of it

00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:05.423
is we're trying
to enable anyone in the world,

00:04:05.447 --> 00:04:06.974
I mean anyone in the world --

00:04:06.998 --> 00:04:08.214
(Laughter)

00:04:08.238 --> 00:04:10.334
to be their own educational DJ,

00:04:10.358 --> 00:04:13.174
creating educational materials,
sharing them with the world,

00:04:13.198 --> 00:04:14.934
constantly innovating on them.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.174
So, this is the dream.

00:04:16.198 --> 00:04:19.014
In fact, this dream
is actually being realized.

00:04:19.038 --> 00:04:20.854
Over the last six-and-a-half years,

00:04:20.878 --> 00:04:23.534
we've been working really hard
at Rice University

00:04:23.558 --> 00:04:25.134
on a project called Connexions,

00:04:25.158 --> 00:04:27.574
and so what I'd like to do
for the rest of the talk

00:04:27.598 --> 00:04:28.979
is just tell you a little bit

00:04:29.003 --> 00:04:31.054
about what people are doing
with Connexions,

00:04:31.078 --> 00:04:33.414
which you can kind of
think of as the counterpoint

00:04:33.438 --> 00:04:35.343
to Nicholas Negroponte's talk yesterday,

00:04:35.367 --> 00:04:38.796
where they're working on the hardware
of bringing education to the world.

00:04:38.820 --> 00:04:41.294
We're working on the open-source tools

00:04:41.318 --> 00:04:42.854
and the content.

00:04:42.878 --> 00:04:45.694
So, that's sort of
to put it in perspective here.

00:04:45.718 --> 00:04:47.294
So, create.

00:04:47.318 --> 00:04:50.294
What are some of the people
that are using these kind of tools?

00:04:50.318 --> 00:04:51.534
Well, the first thing is,

00:04:51.558 --> 00:04:54.414
there's a community
of engineering professors,

00:04:54.438 --> 00:04:56.534
from Cambridge to Kyoto,

00:04:56.558 --> 00:05:00.494
who are developing engineering content
in electrical engineering

00:05:00.518 --> 00:05:04.494
to develop what you can think of
as a massive, super textbook

00:05:04.518 --> 00:05:07.454
that covers the entire area
of electrical engineering.

00:05:07.478 --> 00:05:08.694
And not only that --

00:05:08.718 --> 00:05:12.998
it can be customized for use in each
of their own individual institutions.

00:05:14.078 --> 00:05:17.534
If people like Kitty Jones, a shut-out --

00:05:17.558 --> 00:05:21.934
a private music teacher and mom
from Champagne, Illinois,

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:25.334
who wanted to share her fantastic
music content with the world,

00:05:25.358 --> 00:05:27.614
on how to teach kids how to play music --

00:05:27.638 --> 00:05:33.094
Her material is now used
over 600,000 times per month.

00:05:33.118 --> 00:05:34.614
Tremendous use.

00:05:34.638 --> 00:05:38.894
In fact, a lot of this use coming
from United States K-12 schools,

00:05:38.918 --> 00:05:43.334
because anyone who's involved
in a school scale back,

00:05:43.358 --> 00:05:46.014
the first thing that's cut
is the music curriculum.

00:05:46.038 --> 00:05:48.534
And so this is just indicating
the tremendous thirst

00:05:48.558 --> 00:05:50.694
for this kind of open, free content.

00:05:50.718 --> 00:05:53.094
A lot of teachers are using this stuff.

00:05:53.118 --> 00:05:56.174
What about ripping?
What about copying, reusing?

00:05:56.198 --> 00:05:59.614
A team of volunteers
at the University of Texas at El Paso --

00:05:59.638 --> 00:06:04.494
graduate students translating
this engineering super textbook ideas.

00:06:04.518 --> 00:06:06.134
And within about a week,

00:06:06.158 --> 00:06:08.494
having this be some
of our most popular material

00:06:08.518 --> 00:06:12.894
in widespread use all over Latin America,
and in particular in Mexico,

00:06:12.918 --> 00:06:15.734
because of the open,
extensible nature of this.

00:06:15.758 --> 00:06:18.574
People, volunteers and even companies

00:06:18.598 --> 00:06:21.214
that are translating materials
into Asian languages

00:06:21.238 --> 00:06:23.414
like Chinese, Japanese and Thai,

00:06:23.438 --> 00:06:26.838
to spread the knowledge even further.

00:06:27.718 --> 00:06:29.494
OK, what about people who are mixing?

00:06:29.518 --> 00:06:30.694
What does "mixing" mean?

00:06:30.718 --> 00:06:32.734
"Mixing" means
building customized courses,

00:06:32.758 --> 00:06:36.254
means building customized books.

00:06:36.278 --> 00:06:38.014
Companies like National Instruments,

00:06:38.038 --> 00:06:43.134
who are embedding very powerful,
interactive simulations

00:06:43.158 --> 00:06:44.334
into the materials,

00:06:44.358 --> 00:06:47.294
so that we can go way beyond
our regular kind of textbook

00:06:47.318 --> 00:06:48.534
to an experience

00:06:48.558 --> 00:06:52.494
that all the teaching materials
are things you can actually interact with

00:06:52.518 --> 00:06:56.454
and play around with
and actually learn as you do.

00:06:56.478 --> 00:06:58.814
We've been working
with Teachers Without Borders,

00:06:58.838 --> 00:07:01.077
who are very interested
in mixing our materials.

00:07:01.101 --> 00:07:03.774
They're going to be using
Connexions as their platform

00:07:03.798 --> 00:07:09.014
to develop and deliver teaching materials
for teaching teachers how to teach

00:07:09.038 --> 00:07:11.614
in 84 countries around the world.

00:07:11.638 --> 00:07:14.854
TWB is currently in Iraq,

00:07:14.878 --> 00:07:19.414
training 20,000 teachers
supported by USAID.

00:07:19.438 --> 00:07:22.254
And to them, this idea
of being able to remix

00:07:22.278 --> 00:07:26.934
and customize to the local context
is extraordinarily important,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.694
because just providing
free content to people

00:07:29.718 --> 00:07:32.734
has actually been likened
by people in the developing world

00:07:32.758 --> 00:07:35.094
to a kind of cultural imperialism --

00:07:35.118 --> 00:07:36.654
that if you don't empower people

00:07:36.678 --> 00:07:39.054
with the ability
to re-contextualize the material,

00:07:39.078 --> 00:07:42.254
translate it into their own language
and take ownership of it,

00:07:42.278 --> 00:07:44.014
it's not good.

00:07:44.038 --> 00:07:48.414
OK, other organizations
we've been working with, UC Merced --

00:07:48.438 --> 00:07:50.214
people know about UC Merced.

00:07:50.238 --> 00:07:54.134
It's a new university in California,
in the Central Valley,

00:07:54.158 --> 00:07:56.894
working very closely
with community colleges.

00:07:56.918 --> 00:07:58.254
They're actually developing

00:07:58.278 --> 00:08:00.574
a lot of their science
and engineering curriculum

00:08:00.598 --> 00:08:05.094
to spread widely
around the world in our system.

00:08:05.118 --> 00:08:08.023
And they're also trying to develop
all of their software tools

00:08:08.047 --> 00:08:09.454
completely open-source.

00:08:09.478 --> 00:08:14.214
We've been working with AMD,
which has a project called 50x15,

00:08:14.238 --> 00:08:16.974
which is trying to bring
Internet connectivity

00:08:16.998 --> 00:08:20.614
to 50 percent of the world's
population by 2015.

00:08:20.638 --> 00:08:22.654
We're going to be
providing content to them

00:08:22.678 --> 00:08:24.814
in a whole range of different languages.

00:08:24.838 --> 00:08:27.934
And we've also been working
with a number of other organizations.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:31.974
In particular, a bunch of the projects
that are funded by Hewlett Foundation,

00:08:31.998 --> 00:08:36.454
who have taken a real leadership role
in this area of open content.

00:08:36.478 --> 00:08:40.054
OK, burn -- I think
this is, sort of, quite interesting.

00:08:40.078 --> 00:08:44.334
"Burn" is the idea of trying
to create the physical instantiation

00:08:44.358 --> 00:08:45.574
of one of these courses.

00:08:45.598 --> 00:08:47.654
And I think a lot of you received --

00:08:47.678 --> 00:08:53.534
I think all of you received one
of these music books in your gift pack.

00:08:53.558 --> 00:08:55.014
A little present for you.

00:08:55.038 --> 00:08:58.534
Just to tell you quickly about it:
this is an engineering textbook.

00:08:58.558 --> 00:09:02.198
It's about 300 pages long, hardbound.

00:09:03.158 --> 00:09:05.478
This costs -- anybody guess?

00:09:07.278 --> 00:09:09.334
How much would it cost in a bookstore?

00:09:09.358 --> 00:09:10.574
(Audience) 65 dollars.

00:09:10.598 --> 00:09:15.334
Richard Baraniuk:
OK. This costs 22 dollars to the student.

00:09:15.358 --> 00:09:16.694
Why does it cost 22 dollars?

00:09:16.718 --> 00:09:18.694
Because it's published on demand

00:09:18.718 --> 00:09:22.254
and it's developed
from this repository of open materials.

00:09:22.278 --> 00:09:24.974
If this book were to be published
by a regular publisher,

00:09:24.998 --> 00:09:28.174
it would cost at least 122 dollars.

00:09:28.198 --> 00:09:29.414
So what we're seeing

00:09:29.438 --> 00:09:32.334
is moving this burning
or publication process

00:09:32.358 --> 00:09:35.854
from the regular,
sort of single-authored book

00:09:35.878 --> 00:09:38.254
towards community-authored materials

00:09:38.278 --> 00:09:42.014
that are modular, that are customized
to each individual class

00:09:42.038 --> 00:09:44.694
and published on demand
very inexpensively,

00:09:44.718 --> 00:09:47.214
either pushed out through Amazon

00:09:47.238 --> 00:09:51.414
or published directly
through an on-demand press, like QOOP.

00:09:51.438 --> 00:09:54.854
And I think that this is
an extraordinarily interesting area

00:09:54.878 --> 00:10:00.694
because there is tremendous area
under this long tail in publishing.

00:10:00.718 --> 00:10:02.854
We're not talking
about the Harry Potter end,

00:10:02.878 --> 00:10:04.094
right at the left side.

00:10:04.118 --> 00:10:05.334
We're talking about books

00:10:05.358 --> 00:10:07.974
on hypergeometric
partial differential equations.

00:10:07.998 --> 00:10:12.294
Books that might sell
100 copies a year, 1,000 copies a year.

00:10:12.318 --> 00:10:17.174
There is tremendous
sustaining revenue under this long tail

00:10:17.198 --> 00:10:19.614
to sustain open projects like ours,

00:10:19.638 --> 00:10:24.494
but also to sustain this new emergence
of on-demand publishers,

00:10:24.518 --> 00:10:26.814
like QOOP, who produced these two books.

00:10:26.838 --> 00:10:30.124
And I think one of the things
that you should take away from this talk

00:10:30.148 --> 00:10:34.174
is that there's an impending
cut-out-the-middle-man disintermediation,

00:10:34.198 --> 00:10:36.854
that's going to be happening
in the publishing industry.

00:10:36.878 --> 00:10:39.734
And it's going to reach a crescendo
over the next few years,

00:10:39.758 --> 00:10:43.574
and I think that it's for our benefit,
really, and for the world's benefit.

00:10:43.598 --> 00:10:45.254
OK, so what are the enablers?

00:10:45.278 --> 00:10:47.214
What's really making all of this happen?

00:10:47.238 --> 00:10:48.854
There's tons of technology,

00:10:48.878 --> 00:10:52.734
and the only piece of technology
that I really want to talk about is XML.

00:10:52.758 --> 00:10:54.494
How many people know about XML?

00:10:54.518 --> 00:10:55.734
Oh, great.

00:10:55.758 --> 00:10:57.534
So it's the future of the web, right?

00:10:57.558 --> 00:11:01.934
It's semantic representation of content.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.334
And what you can really
think of XML in this case

00:11:04.358 --> 00:11:07.254
is it's the packaging
that we're putting around these pages.

00:11:07.278 --> 00:11:09.534
Remember we took the book,
tore the pages out?

00:11:09.558 --> 00:11:11.454
Well, what the XML is going to do

00:11:11.478 --> 00:11:15.814
is it's going to turn those pages
into Lego blocks.

00:11:15.838 --> 00:11:17.734
XML are the nubs on the Lego

00:11:17.758 --> 00:11:21.814
that allow us to combine the content
together in a myriad different ways,

00:11:21.838 --> 00:11:25.334
and it provides us a framework
to share content.

00:11:25.358 --> 00:11:28.654
So, it lets you take this ecosystem

00:11:28.678 --> 00:11:31.254
in its primordial state
of all this content,

00:11:31.278 --> 00:11:33.136
all the pages you've torn out of books,

00:11:33.160 --> 00:11:37.134
and create highly sophisticated
learning machines:

00:11:37.158 --> 00:11:39.894
books, courses, course packs.

00:11:39.918 --> 00:11:43.614
It gives you the ability
to personalize the learning experience

00:11:43.638 --> 00:11:45.334
to each individual student,

00:11:45.358 --> 00:11:48.014
so that every student
can have a book or a course

00:11:48.038 --> 00:11:51.494
that's customized to their
learning style, their context,

00:11:51.518 --> 00:11:54.254
their language and the things
that excite them.

00:11:54.278 --> 00:11:57.894
It lets you reuse the same materials
in multiple different ways,

00:11:57.918 --> 00:11:59.894
and surprising new ways.

00:11:59.918 --> 00:12:01.854
It lets you interconnect ideas,

00:12:01.878 --> 00:12:06.054
indicating how fields
relate to each other.

00:12:06.078 --> 00:12:08.334
And I'll just give you my personal story.

00:12:08.358 --> 00:12:10.854
We came up with this
six-and-a-half years ago

00:12:10.878 --> 00:12:13.494
because I teach the stuff in the red box.

00:12:13.518 --> 00:12:17.294
And my day job, as Chris said --
I'm an electrical engineering professor.

00:12:17.318 --> 00:12:18.974
I teach signal processing

00:12:18.998 --> 00:12:21.534
and my challenge
was to show that this math --

00:12:21.558 --> 00:12:23.894
Wow, about half of you
have already fallen asleep

00:12:23.918 --> 00:12:25.374
just looking at the equation.

00:12:25.398 --> 00:12:26.574
(Laughter)

00:12:26.598 --> 00:12:28.054
But this seemingly dry math

00:12:28.078 --> 00:12:32.414
is actually the center
of this tremendously powerful web

00:12:32.438 --> 00:12:34.134
that links technology --

00:12:34.158 --> 00:12:37.894
that links really cool applications
like music synthesizers

00:12:37.918 --> 00:12:41.054
to tremendous economic opportunities,

00:12:41.078 --> 00:12:43.214
but also governed
by intellectual property.

00:12:43.238 --> 00:12:44.654
And the thing that I realized

00:12:44.678 --> 00:12:46.934
is there was no way
that I, as an engineer,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.578
could write this book
that would get all of this across.

00:12:49.602 --> 00:12:51.031
We needed a community to do it

00:12:51.055 --> 00:12:55.094
and we needed new tools
to be able to interconnect these ideas.

00:12:55.118 --> 00:12:57.974
And I think that really,
in a sense, what we're trying to do

00:12:57.998 --> 00:12:59.974
is make Minsky's dream come to a reality,

00:12:59.998 --> 00:13:02.254
where you can imagine
all the books in a library

00:13:02.278 --> 00:13:04.214
actually starting to talk to each other.

00:13:04.238 --> 00:13:07.934
And people who are teachers out here --
whoever taught, you know this --

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:12.454
it's the interconnections between ideas
that teaching is really all about.

00:13:12.478 --> 00:13:14.534
OK, back to math.

00:13:14.558 --> 00:13:17.054
Imagine -- this is possible:

00:13:17.078 --> 00:13:21.654
that every single equation that you
click on in one of your new e-texts

00:13:21.678 --> 00:13:25.414
is something that you're going to be able
to explore and experiment with.

00:13:25.438 --> 00:13:28.974
So imagine your kid's
algebra textbook in seventh grade.

00:13:28.998 --> 00:13:30.894
You can click on every single equation

00:13:30.918 --> 00:13:33.774
and bring up a little tool
to be able to experiment with it,

00:13:33.798 --> 00:13:35.654
tinker with it, understand it.

00:13:35.678 --> 00:13:38.414
Because we really
don't understand until we do.

00:13:38.438 --> 00:13:42.614
The same type of mark-up,
like MathML, for chemistry.

00:13:42.638 --> 00:13:43.934
Imagine chemistry textbooks

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:48.174
that actually understand the structure
of how molecules are formed.

00:13:48.198 --> 00:13:50.134
Imagine Music XML

00:13:50.158 --> 00:13:53.574
that actually lets you delve
into the semantic structure of music,

00:13:53.598 --> 00:13:55.414
play with it, understand it.

00:13:55.438 --> 00:13:58.614
It's no wonder that everybody's
getting into it, right?

00:13:58.638 --> 00:13:59.894
Even the three wise men.

00:13:59.918 --> 00:14:01.094
(Laughter)

00:14:01.118 --> 00:14:06.654
OK, the second big enabler,
and this is where I told a big lie.

00:14:06.678 --> 00:14:09.814
The second big enabler
is intellectual property.

00:14:09.838 --> 00:14:11.334
Because, in fact, I got up here

00:14:11.358 --> 00:14:13.694
and I talked about how great
the music culture is.

00:14:13.718 --> 00:14:17.334
We can share and rip, mix and burn,
but in fact, that's all illegal.

00:14:17.358 --> 00:14:20.734
And we would be accused
of [piracy] for doing that,

00:14:20.758 --> 00:14:24.094
because this music has been propertized.

00:14:24.118 --> 00:14:28.414
It's now owned,
much of it by big industries.

00:14:28.438 --> 00:14:31.200
So, really, the key thing here
is we can't let this happen.

00:14:31.224 --> 00:14:33.934
We can't let this
Napster thing happen here.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.911
So, what we have to do
is get it right from the very beginning.

00:14:36.935 --> 00:14:40.334
And what we have to do
is find an intellectual property framework

00:14:40.358 --> 00:14:45.414
that makes sharing safe
and makes it easily understandable.

00:14:45.438 --> 00:14:49.254
And the inspiration here
is taken from open-source software.

00:14:49.278 --> 00:14:52.854
Things like Linux and the GPL.

00:14:52.878 --> 00:14:55.259
The Creative Commons licenses.

00:14:55.283 --> 00:14:57.474
How many people
have heard of creative commons?

00:14:57.498 --> 00:14:59.454
If you have not, you must learn about it.

00:14:59.478 --> 00:15:01.054
Creativecommons.org.

00:15:01.078 --> 00:15:04.414
At the bottom of every piece
of material in Connexions

00:15:04.438 --> 00:15:06.294
and in lots of other projects,

00:15:06.318 --> 00:15:07.894
you can find their logo.

00:15:07.918 --> 00:15:11.494
Clicking on that logo
takes you to an absolute no-nonsense,

00:15:11.518 --> 00:15:14.654
human-readable document, a deed,

00:15:14.678 --> 00:15:17.345
that tells you exactly
what you can do with this content.

00:15:17.369 --> 00:15:20.974
In fact, you're free to share it,
to do all of these things:

00:15:20.998 --> 00:15:24.054
to copy it, to change it,
even to make commercial use of it,

00:15:24.078 --> 00:15:26.974
as long as you attribute the author.

00:15:26.998 --> 00:15:31.414
Because in academic publishing
and much of educational publishing,

00:15:31.438 --> 00:15:35.774
it's really this idea of sharing knowledge

00:15:35.798 --> 00:15:37.094
and making impact.

00:15:37.118 --> 00:15:40.974
That's why people write,
not necessarily making bucks.

00:15:40.998 --> 00:15:43.094
We're not talking
about Harry Potter, right?

00:15:43.118 --> 00:15:44.814
We're at the long tail end here.

00:15:44.838 --> 00:15:49.494
Behind that is the legal code,
very carefully constructed.

00:15:49.518 --> 00:15:51.374
And Creative Commons is taking off --

00:15:51.398 --> 00:15:55.534
over 43 million things out there,

00:15:55.558 --> 00:15:57.654
licensed with a Creative Commons license.

00:15:57.678 --> 00:16:00.774
Not just text,

00:16:00.798 --> 00:16:03.294
but music, images, video.

00:16:03.318 --> 00:16:05.334
And there's actually a tremendous uptake

00:16:05.358 --> 00:16:08.814
of the number of people
that are actually licensing music

00:16:08.838 --> 00:16:12.054
to make it free for people
who do this whole idea of re-sampling,

00:16:12.078 --> 00:16:14.214
ripping, mixing, burning and sharing.

00:16:14.238 --> 00:16:17.934
OK, I'd like to conclude
with just the last few points.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.334
So, we've built this idea of a commons.

00:16:20.358 --> 00:16:22.254
People are using it.

00:16:22.278 --> 00:16:28.574
We get over 500,000 unique visitors
per month, just to our particular site.

00:16:28.598 --> 00:16:32.654
MIT OpenCourseWare,
which is another large open-content site,

00:16:32.678 --> 00:16:34.894
gets a similar number of hits.

00:16:34.918 --> 00:16:36.574
But how do we protect this?

00:16:36.598 --> 00:16:38.374
How do we protect it into the future?

00:16:38.398 --> 00:16:41.134
And the first thing
that people are probably thinking

00:16:41.158 --> 00:16:42.774
is quality control, right?

00:16:42.798 --> 00:16:47.494
Because we're saying that anybody
can contribute things to this commons.

00:16:47.518 --> 00:16:50.334
Anybody can contribute anything.

00:16:50.358 --> 00:16:52.894
So that could be a problem.

00:16:52.918 --> 00:16:57.134
It didn't take long until people
started contributing materials,

00:16:57.158 --> 00:16:59.294
for example, on lingerie,

00:16:59.318 --> 00:17:01.294
which is actually a pretty good module.

00:17:01.318 --> 00:17:06.894
The only problem is it's plagiarized
from a major French feminist journal,

00:17:06.918 --> 00:17:09.734
and when you go
to the supposed course website,

00:17:09.758 --> 00:17:13.934
it points to a lingerie-selling website.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.134
So this is a little bit of a problem.

00:17:16.158 --> 00:17:19.214
So we clearly need some kind
of idea of quality control

00:17:19.238 --> 00:17:22.934
and this is really where the idea
of review and peer review comes in.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.863
You come to TED. Why do you come to TED?

00:17:25.358 --> 00:17:27.773
Because Chris and his team have ensured

00:17:27.797 --> 00:17:30.974
that things are
very, very high quality, right?

00:17:30.998 --> 00:17:33.414
And so we need to be able
to do the same thing.

00:17:33.438 --> 00:17:36.494
And we need to be able
to design structures,

00:17:36.518 --> 00:17:39.574
and what we're doing
is designing social software

00:17:39.598 --> 00:17:42.694
to enable anyone to build
their own peer review process,

00:17:42.718 --> 00:17:44.534
and we call these things "lenses."

00:17:44.558 --> 00:17:45.974
And basically what they allow

00:17:45.998 --> 00:17:49.414
is anyone out there can develop
their own peer-review process,

00:17:49.438 --> 00:17:53.414
so that they can focus
on the content in the repository

00:17:53.438 --> 00:17:55.153
that they think is really important.

00:17:55.177 --> 00:17:58.454
And you can think of TED
as a potential lens.

00:17:58.478 --> 00:18:00.255
So I'd just like to end by saying:

00:18:00.279 --> 00:18:04.934
you can really view this
as a call to action.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:09.934
Connexions and open content
is all about sharing knowledge.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:14.974
All of you here are tremendously imbued
with tremendous amounts of knowledge,

00:18:14.998 --> 00:18:17.774
and what I'd like to do
is invite each and every one of you

00:18:17.798 --> 00:18:21.014
to contribute to this project
and other projects of its type,

00:18:21.038 --> 00:18:24.814
because I think together
we can truly change the landscape

00:18:24.838 --> 00:18:27.054
of education and educational publishing.

00:18:27.078 --> 00:18:28.278
So, thanks very much.
