00:07:31.868 --> 00:07:35.375
he had this to say: "I'm happier
than I would have been with the Beatles."

00:07:35.399 --> 00:07:38.531
Okay. There's something important
to be learned from these people,

00:07:38.555 --> 00:07:40.430
and it is the secret of happiness.

00:07:40.454 --> 00:07:42.827
Here it is, finally to be revealed.

00:07:42.851 --> 00:07:46.073
First: accrue wealth, power,
and prestige, then lose it.

00:07:46.097 --> 00:07:48.749
(Laughter)

00:07:48.773 --> 00:07:52.531
Second: spend as much of your life
in prison as you possibly can.

00:07:52.555 --> 00:07:53.556
(Laughter)

00:07:53.580 --> 00:07:56.810
Third: make somebody else
really, really rich.

00:07:56.834 --> 00:07:59.557
And finally: never ever join the Beatles.

00:07:59.581 --> 00:08:00.605
(Laughter)

00:08:00.629 --> 00:08:01.780
Yeah, right.

00:08:01.804 --> 00:08:03.890
Because when people synthesize happiness,

00:08:03.914 --> 00:08:06.108
as these gentlemen seem to have done,

00:08:06.132 --> 00:08:09.911
we all smile at them,
but we kind of roll our eyes and say,

00:08:09.935 --> 00:08:12.471
"Yeah right, you never
really wanted the job."

00:08:12.495 --> 00:08:16.471
"Oh yeah, right. You really didn't have
that much in common with her,

00:08:16.495 --> 00:08:18.591
and you figured that out just
about the time

00:08:18.615 --> 00:08:20.711
she threw the engagement
ring in your face."

00:08:20.735 --> 00:08:24.471
We smirk because we believe
that synthetic happiness

00:08:24.495 --> 00:08:27.971
is not of the same quality
as what we might call "natural happiness."

00:08:27.995 --> 00:08:29.447
What are these terms?

00:08:29.471 --> 00:08:32.875
Natural happiness is what we get
when we get what we wanted,

00:08:32.899 --> 00:08:37.803
and synthetic happiness is what we make
when we don't get what we wanted.

00:08:37.827 --> 00:08:40.803
And in our society,
we have a strong belief

00:08:40.827 --> 00:08:43.803
that synthetic happiness
is of an inferior kind.

00:08:43.827 --> 00:08:45.350
Why do we have that belief?

00:08:45.858 --> 00:08:47.532
Well, it's very simple.

00:08:47.556 --> 00:08:51.349
What kind of economic engine
would keep churning

00:08:51.373 --> 00:08:54.309
if we believed
that not getting what we want

00:08:54.333 --> 00:08:56.849
could make us just as happy as getting it?

00:08:57.802 --> 00:09:00.905
With all apologies
to my friend Matthieu Ricard,

00:09:00.929 --> 00:09:03.131
a shopping mall full of Zen monks

00:09:03.155 --> 00:09:05.269
is not going to be
particularly profitable,

00:09:05.293 --> 00:09:07.895
because they don't want stuff enough.

00:09:07.919 --> 00:09:09.000
(Laughter)

00:09:09.024 --> 00:09:12.121
I want to suggest to you
that synthetic happiness

00:09:12.145 --> 00:09:14.350
is every bit as real and enduring

00:09:14.374 --> 00:09:17.025
as the kind of happiness you stumble upon

00:09:17.049 --> 00:09:19.612
when you get exactly
what you were aiming for.

00:09:19.636 --> 00:09:22.412
I'm a scientist, so I'm going
to do this not with rhetoric,

00:09:22.436 --> 00:09:24.587
but by marinating you
in a little bit of data.

00:09:24.611 --> 00:09:27.557
Let me first show you an experimental
paradigm that is used

00:09:27.581 --> 00:09:31.763
to demonstrate the synthesis of happiness
among regular old folks.

00:09:31.787 --> 00:09:32.945
And this isn't mine.

00:09:32.969 --> 00:09:35.945
It's a 50-year-old paradigm
called the "free choice paradigm."

00:09:35.969 --> 00:09:37.350
It's very simple.

00:09:37.374 --> 00:09:40.080
You bring in, say, six objects,

00:09:40.104 --> 00:09:43.365
and you ask a subject to rank them
from the most to the least liked.

00:09:43.389 --> 00:09:45.947
In this case, because
this experiment uses them,

00:09:45.971 --> 00:09:47.350
these are Monet prints.

00:09:47.374 --> 00:09:49.350
So, everybody can rank these Monet prints

00:09:49.374 --> 00:09:52.375
from the one they like the most,
to the one they like the least.

00:09:52.399 --> 00:09:54.089
Now we give you a choice:

00:09:54.113 --> 00:09:56.515
"We happen to have
some extra prints in the closet.

00:09:56.539 --> 00:09:59.160
We're going to give you
one as your prize to take home.

00:09:59.184 --> 00:10:03.016
We happen to have number three
and number four," we tell the subject.

00:10:03.040 --> 00:10:04.938
This is a bit of a difficult choice,

00:10:04.962 --> 00:10:07.564
because neither one is preferred
strongly to the other,

00:10:07.588 --> 00:10:10.208
but naturally, people
tend to pick number three

00:10:10.232 --> 00:10:12.810
because they liked it
a little better than number four.

00:10:13.722 --> 00:10:17.242
Sometime later -- it could be
15 minutes; it could be 15 days --

00:10:17.266 --> 00:10:19.350
the same stimuli are put
before the subject,

00:10:19.374 --> 00:10:22.079
and the subject is asked
to re-rank the stimuli.

00:10:22.103 --> 00:10:24.080
"Tell us how much you like them now."

00:10:24.104 --> 00:10:25.311
What happens?

00:10:25.335 --> 00:10:27.304
Watch as happiness is synthesized.

00:10:27.328 --> 00:10:30.350
This is the result that has
been replicated over and over again.

00:10:30.374 --> 00:10:32.365
You're watching happiness be synthesized.

00:10:32.389 --> 00:10:33.881
Would you like to see it again?

00:10:34.981 --> 00:10:36.350
Happiness!

00:10:36.374 --> 00:10:38.613
"The one I got is really
better than I thought!

00:10:38.637 --> 00:10:40.350
That other one I didn't get sucks!"

00:10:40.374 --> 00:10:42.517
That's the synthesis of happiness.

00:10:42.541 --> 00:10:43.578
(Laughter)

00:10:43.602 --> 00:10:46.651
Now, what's the right response to that?

00:10:46.675 --> 00:10:48.349
"Yeah, right!"

00:10:49.292 --> 00:10:51.350
Now, here's the experiment we did,

00:10:51.374 --> 00:10:53.289
and I hope this is going to convince you

00:10:53.313 --> 00:10:55.590
that "Yeah, right!"
was not the right response.

00:10:55.614 --> 00:10:57.836
We did this experiment
with a group of patients

00:10:57.860 --> 00:10:59.257
who had anterograde amnesia.

00:10:59.281 --> 00:11:00.940
These are hospitalized patients.

00:11:00.964 --> 00:11:03.129
Most of them have Korsakoff's syndrome,

00:11:03.153 --> 00:11:05.153
a polyneuritic psychosis.

00:11:05.913 --> 00:11:09.350
They drank way too much,
and they can't make new memories.

00:11:09.374 --> 00:11:13.287
OK? They remember their childhood,
but if you walk in and introduce yourself,

00:11:13.311 --> 00:11:14.504
and then leave the room,

00:11:14.528 --> 00:11:16.782
when you come back,
they don't know who you are.

00:11:17.937 --> 00:11:20.635
We took our Monet prints to the hospital.

00:11:21.350 --> 00:11:24.350
And we asked these patients to rank them

00:11:24.374 --> 00:11:27.470
from the one they liked
the most to the one they liked the least.

00:11:27.494 --> 00:11:31.350
We then gave them the choice
between number three and number four.

00:11:31.374 --> 00:11:33.350
Like everybody else, they said,

00:11:33.374 --> 00:11:36.041
"Gee, thanks Doc! That's great!
I could use a new print.

00:11:36.065 --> 00:11:37.350
I'll take number three."

00:11:37.818 --> 00:11:41.350
We explained we would have
number three mailed to them.

00:11:41.374 --> 00:11:44.350
We gathered up our materials
and we went out of the room,

00:11:44.374 --> 00:11:45.737
and counted to a half hour.

00:11:45.761 --> 00:11:46.762
(Laughter)

00:11:46.786 --> 00:11:50.270
Back into the room,
we say, "Hi, we're back."

00:11:50.294 --> 00:11:53.350
The patients, bless them,
say, "Ah, Doc, I'm sorry,

00:11:53.374 --> 00:11:56.111
I've got a memory problem;
that's why I'm here.

00:11:56.135 --> 00:11:58.136
If I've met you before, I don't remember."

00:11:58.160 --> 00:12:01.352
"Really, you don't remember?
I was just here with the Monet prints?"

00:12:01.376 --> 00:12:03.970
"Sorry, Doc, I just don't have a clue."

00:12:03.994 --> 00:12:07.612
"No problem, Jim. All I want
you to do is rank these for me

00:12:07.636 --> 00:12:11.446
from the one you like the most
to the one you like the least."

00:12:11.756 --> 00:12:12.907
What do they do?

00:12:12.931 --> 00:12:15.837
Well, let's first check and make sure
they're really amnesiac.

00:12:15.861 --> 00:12:19.851
We ask these amnesiac patients
to tell us which one they own,

00:12:19.875 --> 00:12:23.173
which one they chose last
time, which one is theirs.

00:12:23.197 --> 00:12:26.350
And what we find is amnesiac
patients just guess.

00:12:26.374 --> 00:12:29.010
These are normal controls,
where if I did this with you,

00:12:29.034 --> 00:12:31.137
all of you would know
which print you chose.

00:12:31.161 --> 00:12:34.965
But if I do this with amnesiac patients,
they don't have a clue.

00:12:34.989 --> 00:12:37.441
They can't pick
their print out of a lineup.

00:12:38.783 --> 00:12:42.350
Here's what normal controls do:
they synthesize happiness.

00:12:42.374 --> 00:12:44.933
Right? This is the change in liking score,

00:12:44.957 --> 00:12:48.464
the change from the first time they ranked
to the second time they ranked.

00:12:48.488 --> 00:12:51.167
Normal controls show --
that was the magic I showed you;

00:12:51.191 --> 00:12:53.350
now I'm showing it to you
in graphical form --

00:12:53.374 --> 00:12:55.511
"The one I own is better than I thought.

00:12:55.535 --> 00:12:57.900
The one I didn't own,
the one I left behind,

00:12:57.924 --> 00:12:59.621
is not as good as I thought."

00:13:00.478 --> 00:13:04.961
Amnesiacs do exactly the same thing.
Think about this result.

00:13:04.985 --> 00:13:07.795
These people like better the one they own,

00:13:07.819 --> 00:13:10.064
but they don't know they own it.

00:13:11.484 --> 00:13:15.254
"Yeah, right" is not the right response!

00:13:15.843 --> 00:13:19.025
What these people did
when they synthesized happiness

00:13:19.049 --> 00:13:21.684
is they really, truly changed

00:13:21.708 --> 00:13:26.175
their affective, hedonic, aesthetic
reactions to that poster.

00:13:26.961 --> 00:13:29.350
They're not just saying it
because they own it,

00:13:29.374 --> 00:13:31.739
because they don't know they own it.

00:13:32.646 --> 00:13:35.273
When psychologists show you bars,

00:13:35.297 --> 00:13:38.852
you know that they are showing
you averages of lots of people.

00:13:38.876 --> 00:13:42.185
And yet, all of us have this
psychological immune system,

00:13:42.209 --> 00:13:44.683
this capacity to synthesize happiness,

00:13:44.707 --> 00:13:47.858
but some of us do this trick
better than others.

00:13:47.882 --> 00:13:51.915
And some situations allow anybody
to do it more effectively

00:13:51.939 --> 00:13:53.699
than other situations do.

00:13:55.279 --> 00:13:58.524
It turns out that freedom,

00:13:58.548 --> 00:14:01.874
the ability to make up your mind
and change your mind,

00:14:01.898 --> 00:14:05.453
is the friend of natural happiness,
because it allows you to choose

00:14:05.477 --> 00:14:07.653
among all those delicious futures

00:14:07.677 --> 00:14:10.160
and find the one
that you would most enjoy.

00:14:10.184 --> 00:14:11.936
But freedom to choose,

00:14:11.960 --> 00:14:13.717
to change and make up your mind,

00:14:13.741 --> 00:14:16.663
is the enemy of synthetic happiness.

00:14:16.687 --> 00:14:19.733
And I'm going to show you why.
Dilbert already knows, of course.

00:14:19.757 --> 00:14:21.939
"Dogbert's tech support.
How may I abuse you?"

00:14:21.963 --> 00:14:24.577
"My printer prints a blank
page after every document."

00:14:24.601 --> 00:14:26.577
"Why complain about getting free paper?"

00:14:26.601 --> 00:14:28.877
"Free? Aren't you just
giving me my own paper?"

00:14:28.901 --> 00:14:32.577
"Look at the quality of the free paper
compared to your lousy regular paper!

00:14:32.601 --> 00:14:35.377
Only a fool or a liar would say
that they look the same!"

00:14:35.401 --> 00:14:38.163
"Now that you mention it,
it does seem a little silkier!"

00:14:38.187 --> 00:14:39.363
"What are you doing?"

00:14:39.387 --> 00:14:42.942
"I'm helping people accept the things
they cannot change." Indeed.

00:14:43.733 --> 00:14:46.059
The psychological immune system works best

00:14:46.083 --> 00:14:49.278
when we are totally stuck,
when we are trapped.

00:14:49.302 --> 00:14:51.684
This is the difference
between dating and marriage.

00:14:51.708 --> 00:14:53.277
You go out on a date with a guy,

00:14:53.301 --> 00:14:55.937
and he picks his nose;
you don't go out on another date.

00:14:55.961 --> 00:14:58.135
You're married to a guy
and he picks his nose?

00:14:58.159 --> 00:15:00.641
He has a heart of gold.
Don't touch the fruitcake!

00:15:00.665 --> 00:15:04.378
You find a way to be happy
with what's happened.

00:15:04.402 --> 00:15:05.403
(Laughter)

00:15:05.427 --> 00:15:06.816
Now, what I want to show you

00:15:06.840 --> 00:15:09.443
is that people don't know
this about themselves,

00:15:09.467 --> 00:15:13.745
and not knowing this can work
to our supreme disadvantage.

00:15:13.769 --> 00:15:15.746
Here's an experiment we did at Harvard.

00:15:15.770 --> 00:15:18.798
We created a black-and-white
photography course,

00:15:18.822 --> 00:15:22.277
and we allowed students to come in
and learn how to use a darkroom.

00:15:22.301 --> 00:15:24.635
So we gave them cameras;
they went around campus;

00:15:24.659 --> 00:15:27.016
they took 12 pictures
of their favorite professors

00:15:27.040 --> 00:15:29.230
and their dorm room and their dog,

00:15:29.254 --> 00:15:32.372
and all the other things they wanted
to have Harvard memories of.

00:15:32.396 --> 00:15:34.922
They bring us the camera;
we make up a contact sheet;

00:15:34.946 --> 00:15:37.241
they figure out which are
the two best pictures;

00:15:37.265 --> 00:15:39.947
and we now spend six hours
teaching them about darkrooms.

00:15:39.971 --> 00:15:41.412
And they blow two of them up,

00:15:41.436 --> 00:15:43.682
and they have two gorgeous
eight-by-10 glossies

00:15:43.706 --> 00:15:45.690
of meaningful things to them, and we say,

00:15:45.714 --> 00:15:47.554
"Which one would you like to give up?"

00:15:47.578 --> 00:15:48.729
"I have to give one up?"

00:15:48.753 --> 00:15:51.865
"Yes, we need one as evidence
of the class project.

00:15:51.889 --> 00:15:54.507
So you have to give me one.
You have to make a choice.

00:15:54.531 --> 00:15:57.277
You get to keep one,
and I get to keep one."

00:15:57.301 --> 00:16:00.277
Now, there are two conditions
in this experiment.

00:16:00.301 --> 00:16:02.579
In one case, the students are told,

00:16:02.603 --> 00:16:04.959
"But you know,
if you want to change your mind,

00:16:04.983 --> 00:16:06.836
I'll always have the other one here,

00:16:06.860 --> 00:16:11.223
and in the next four days, before
I actually mail it to headquarters" --

00:16:11.247 --> 00:16:13.572
Yeah, "headquarters" --

00:16:13.596 --> 00:16:16.277
"I'll be glad to swap it out with you.

00:16:16.301 --> 00:16:19.271
In fact, I'll come to your dorm room,
just give me an email.

00:16:19.295 --> 00:16:21.286
Better yet, I'll check with you.

00:16:21.310 --> 00:16:24.198
You ever want to change your mind,
it's totally returnable."

00:16:24.222 --> 00:16:27.119
The other half of the students
are told exactly the opposite:

00:16:27.143 --> 00:16:28.770
"Make your choice, and by the way,

00:16:28.794 --> 00:16:31.787
the mail is going out, gosh,
in two minutes, to England.

00:16:31.811 --> 00:16:34.533
Your picture will be winging
its way over the Atlantic.

00:16:34.557 --> 00:16:36.723
You will never see it again."

00:16:36.747 --> 00:16:39.001
Half of the students
in each of these conditions

00:16:39.025 --> 00:16:40.437
are asked to make predictions

00:16:40.461 --> 00:16:44.072
about how much they're going to come
to like the picture that they keep

00:16:44.096 --> 00:16:45.777
and the picture they leave behind.

00:16:45.801 --> 00:16:48.708
Other students are just sent back
to their little dorm rooms

00:16:48.732 --> 00:16:51.843
and they are measured
over the next three to six days

00:16:51.867 --> 00:16:54.142
on their liking, satisfaction
with the pictures.

00:16:54.166 --> 00:16:55.358
And look at what we find.

00:16:55.382 --> 00:16:58.506
First of all, here's what students
think is going to happen.

00:16:58.530 --> 00:17:02.330
They think they're going to maybe
come to like the picture they chose

00:17:02.354 --> 00:17:04.843
a little more
than the one they left behind,

00:17:04.867 --> 00:17:07.927
but these are not statistically
significant differences.

00:17:07.951 --> 00:17:11.615
It's a very small increase,
and it doesn't much matter

00:17:11.639 --> 00:17:14.607
whether they were in the reversible
or irreversible condition.

00:17:14.631 --> 00:17:18.843
Wrong-o. Bad simulators. Because
here's what's really happening.

00:17:18.867 --> 00:17:22.264
Both right before the swap
and five days later,

00:17:22.288 --> 00:17:24.474
people who are stuck with that picture,

00:17:24.498 --> 00:17:25.650
who have no choice,

00:17:25.674 --> 00:17:27.714
who can never change their mind,

00:17:27.738 --> 00:17:29.070
like it a lot!

00:17:29.892 --> 00:17:32.843
And people who are deliberating
-- "Should I return it?

00:17:32.867 --> 00:17:36.082
Have I gotten the right one?
Maybe this isn't the good one?

00:17:36.106 --> 00:17:38.698
Maybe I left the good one?" --
have killed themselves.

00:17:38.722 --> 00:17:40.159
They don't like their picture,

00:17:40.183 --> 00:17:43.016
and in fact even after the opportunity
to swap has expired,

00:17:43.040 --> 00:17:45.133
they still don't like their picture.

00:17:45.157 --> 00:17:46.307
Why?

00:17:46.331 --> 00:17:50.326
Because the [reversible] condition
is not conducive

00:17:50.350 --> 00:17:52.098
to the synthesis of happiness.

00:17:52.122 --> 00:17:55.010
So here's the final piece
of this experiment.

00:17:55.034 --> 00:17:58.843
We bring in a whole new group
of naive Harvard students

00:17:58.867 --> 00:18:02.223
and we say, "You know,
we're doing a photography course,

00:18:02.247 --> 00:18:03.819
and we can do it one of two ways.

00:18:04.565 --> 00:18:07.096
We could do it so that when
you take the two pictures,

00:18:07.120 --> 00:18:09.119
you'd have four days to change your mind,

00:18:09.143 --> 00:18:12.016
or we're doing another course
where you take the two pictures

00:18:12.040 --> 00:18:15.123
and you make up your mind right away
and you can never change it.

00:18:15.147 --> 00:18:17.193
Which course would you like
to be in?" Duh!

00:18:17.217 --> 00:18:19.843
66 percent of the students, two-thirds,

00:18:19.867 --> 00:18:23.843
prefer to be in the course where they have
the opportunity to change their mind.

00:18:23.867 --> 00:18:27.843
Hello? 66 percent of the students
choose to be in the course

00:18:27.867 --> 00:18:31.843
in which they will ultimately be deeply
dissatisfied with the picture.

00:18:31.867 --> 00:18:37.843
Because they do not know the conditions
under which synthetic happiness grows.

00:18:38.705 --> 00:18:43.795
The Bard said everything best,
of course, and he's making my point here

00:18:43.819 --> 00:18:45.843
but he's making it hyperbolically:

00:18:45.867 --> 00:18:48.843
"'Tis nothing good or bad /
But thinking makes it so."

00:18:48.867 --> 00:18:52.306
It's nice poetry,
but that can't exactly be right.

00:18:52.330 --> 00:18:54.843
Is there really nothing good or bad?

00:18:54.867 --> 00:18:58.216
Is it really the case that gall bladder
surgery and a trip to Paris

00:18:58.240 --> 00:18:59.851
are just the same thing?

00:18:59.875 --> 00:19:00.962
(Laughter)

00:19:00.986 --> 00:19:04.843
That seems like a one-question IQ test.

00:19:04.867 --> 00:19:06.843
They can't be exactly the same.

00:19:06.867 --> 00:19:09.843
In more turgid prose,
but closer to the truth,

00:19:09.867 --> 00:19:13.241
was the father of modern capitalism,
Adam Smith, and he said this.

00:19:13.265 --> 00:19:15.220
This is worth contemplating:

00:19:15.244 --> 00:19:19.196
"The great source of both the misery
and disorders of human life

00:19:19.220 --> 00:19:21.843
seems to arise from overrating
the difference

00:19:21.867 --> 00:19:24.843
between one permanent
situation and another --

00:19:24.867 --> 00:19:30.164
Some of these situations may, no doubt,
deserve to be preferred to others,

00:19:30.188 --> 00:19:33.117
but none of them can deserve to be pursued

00:19:33.141 --> 00:19:37.585
with that passionate ardor
which drives us to violate the rules

00:19:37.609 --> 00:19:40.204
either of prudence or of justice,

00:19:40.228 --> 00:19:42.993
or to corrupt the future
tranquility of our minds,

00:19:43.017 --> 00:19:46.554
either by shame from the remembrance
of our own folly,

00:19:46.578 --> 00:19:50.650
or by remorse for the horror
of our own injustice."

00:19:50.674 --> 00:19:55.406
In other words: yes, some things
are better than others.

00:19:55.430 --> 00:20:00.933
We should have preferences that lead us
into one future over another.

00:20:00.957 --> 00:20:04.738
But when those preferences
drive us too hard and too fast

00:20:04.762 --> 00:20:08.453
because we have overrated
the difference between these futures,

00:20:08.477 --> 00:20:10.446
we are at risk.

00:20:10.470 --> 00:20:14.755
When our ambition is bounded,
it leads us to work joyfully.

00:20:14.779 --> 00:20:16.651
When our ambition is unbounded,

00:20:16.675 --> 00:20:21.089
it leads us to lie, to cheat,
to steal, to hurt others,

00:20:21.113 --> 00:20:23.112
to sacrifice things of real value.

00:20:23.136 --> 00:20:25.153
When our fears are bounded,

00:20:25.177 --> 00:20:27.312
we're prudent, we're cautious,

00:20:27.336 --> 00:20:28.547
we're thoughtful.

00:20:28.571 --> 00:20:31.806
When our fears
are unbounded and overblown,

00:20:31.830 --> 00:20:33.856
we're reckless, and we're cowardly.

00:20:34.583 --> 00:20:37.933
The lesson I want to leave
you with, from these data,

00:20:37.957 --> 00:20:42.036
is that our longings and our worries
are both to some degree overblown,

00:20:42.060 --> 00:20:48.232
because we have within us the capacity
to manufacture the very commodity

00:20:48.256 --> 00:20:52.675
we are constantly chasing
when we choose experience.

00:20:52.699 --> 00:20:53.850
Thank you.

00:20:53.874 --> 00:20:58.799
(Applause)

title: The paradox of choice
transcript: I'm going to talk to you about some stuff that's in this book of mine that I hope will resonate with other things you've already heard, and I'll try to make some connections myself, in case you missed them.But I want to start with what I call the "official dogma." The official dogma of what? The official dogma of all Western industrial societies. And the official dogma runs like this: if we are interested in maximizing the welfare of our citizens, the way to do that is to maximize individual freedom. The reason for this is both that freedom is in and of itself good, valuable, worthwhile, essential to being human. And because if people have freedom, then each of us can act on our own to do the things that will maximize our welfare, and no one has to decide on our behalf. The way to maximize freedom is to maximize choice.The more choice people have, the more freedom they have, and the more freedom they have, the more welfare they have. This, I think, is so deeply embedded in the water supply that it wouldn't occur to anyone to question it. And it's also deeply embedded in our lives. I'll give you some examples of what modern progress has made possible for us.This is my supermarket. Not such a big one. I want to say just a word about salad dressing. 175 salad dressings in my supermarket, if you don't count the 10 extra-virgin olive oils and 12 balsamic vinegars you could buy to make a very large number of your own salad dressings, in the off-chance that none of the 175 the store has on offer suit you. So this is what the supermarket is like. And then you go to the consumer electronics store to set up a stereo system — speakers, CD player, tape player, tuner, amplifier — and in this one single consumer electronics store, there are that many stereo systems. We can construct six-and-a-half-million different stereo systems out of the components that are on offer in one store.You've got to admit that's a lot of choice. In other domains — the world of communications. There was a time, when I was a boy, when you could get any kind of telephone service you wanted, as long as it came from Ma Bell. You rented your phone. You didn't buy it. One consequence of that, by the way, is that the phone never broke. And those days are gone. We now have an almost unlimited variety of phones, especially in the world of cell phones. These are cell phones of the future. My favorite is the middle one — the MP3 player, nose hair trimmer, and crème brûlée torch.(Laughter)And if by some chance you haven't seen that in your store yet, you can rest assured that one day soon, you will. And what this does is it leads people to walk into their stores asking this question. And do you know what the answer to this question now is? The answer is "no." It is not possible to buy a cell phone that doesn't do too much.So, in other aspects of life that are much more significant than buying things, the same explosion of choice is true. Health care. It is no longer the case in the United States that you go to the doctor, and the doctor tells you what to do. Instead, you go to the doctor, and the doctor tells you, "Well, we could do A, or we could do B. A has these benefits, and these risks. B has these benefits, and these risks. What do you want to do?" And you say, "Doc, what should I do?" And the doc says, "A has these benefits and risks, and B has these benefits and risks. What do you want to do?" And you say, "If you were me, Doc, what would you do?" And the doc says, "But I'm not you." And the result is — we call it "patient autonomy," which makes it sound like a good thing, but it really is a shifting of the burden and the responsibility for decision-making from somebody who knows something — namely, the doctor — to somebody who knows nothing and is almost certainly sick and thus not in the best shape to be making decisions — namely, the patient. There's enormous marketing of prescription drugs to people like you and me, which, if you think about it, makes no sense at all, since we can't buy them. Why do they market to us if we can't buy them? The answer is that they expect us to call our doctors the next morning and ask for our prescriptions to be changed.Something as dramatic as our identity has now become a matter of choice, as this slide is meant to indicate. We don't inherit an identity; we get to invent it. And we get to re-invent ourselves as often as we like. And that means that every day, when you wake up in the morning, you have to decide what kind of person you want to be. With respect to marriage and family, there was a time when the default assumption that almost everyone had is that you got married as soon as you could, and then you started having kids as soon as you could. The only real choice was who, not when, and not what you did after.Nowadays, everything is very much up for grabs. I teach wonderfully intelligent students, and I assign 20 percent less work than I used to. And it's not because they're less smart, and it's not because they're less diligent. It's because they are preoccupied, asking themselves, "Should I get married or not? Should I get married now? Should I get married later? Should I have kids first, or a career first?" All of these are consuming questions. And they're going to answer these questions, whether or not it means not doing all the work I assign and not getting a good grade in my courses. And indeed they should. These are important questions to answer.Work — we are blessed, as Carl was pointing out, with the technology that enables us to work every minute of every day from any place on the planet — except the Randolph Hotel.(Laughter)(Applause)There is one corner, by the way, that I'm not going to tell anybody about, where the WiFi actually works. I'm not telling you about it because I want to use it. So what this means, this incredible freedom of choice we have with respect to work, is that we have to make a decision, again and again and again, about whether we should or shouldn't be working. We can go to watch our kid play soccer, and we have our cell phone on one hip, and our Blackberry on our other hip, and our laptop, presumably, on our laps. And even if they're all shut off, every minute that we're watching our kid mutilate a soccer game, we are also asking ourselves, "Should I answer this cell phone call? Should I respond to this email? Should I draft this letter?" And even if the answer to the question is "no," it's certainly going to make the experience of your kid's soccer game very different than it would've been.So everywhere we look, big things and small things, material things and lifestyle things, life is a matter of choice. And the world we used to live in looked like this. [Well, actually, they are written in stone.] That is to say, there were some choices, but not everything was a matter of choice. And the world we now live in looks like this.[The Ten Commandments DYI Kit]And the question is, is this good news, or bad news? And the answer is, "yes."(Laughter)We all know what's good about it, so I'm going to talk about what's bad about it. All of this choice has two effects, two negative effects on people. One effect, paradoxically, is that it produces paralysis, rather than liberation. With so many options to choose from, people find it very difficult to choose at all. I'll give you one very dramatic example of this: a study that was done of investments in voluntary retirement plans. A colleague of mine got access to investment records from Vanguard, the gigantic mutual-fund company of about a million employees and about 2,000 different workplaces. And what she found is that for every 10 mutual funds the employer offered, rate of participation went down two percent. You offer 50 funds — 10 percent fewer employees participate than if you only offer five. Why? Because with 50 funds to choose from, it's so damn hard to decide which fund to choose, that you'll just put it off until tomorrow. And then tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow, and of course tomorrow never comes. Understand that not only does this mean that people are going to have to eat dog food when they retire because they don't have enough money put away, it also means that making the decision is so hard that they pass up significant matching money from the employer. By not participating, they are passing up as much as 5,000 dollars a year from the employer, who would happily match their contribution.So paralysis is a consequence of having too many choices. And I think it makes the world look like this.[And lastly, for all eternity, French, bleu cheese, or ranch?](Laughter)You really want to get the decision right if it's for all eternity, right? You don't want to pick the wrong mutual fund, or the wrong salad dressing. So that's one effect. The second effect is that even if we manage to overcome the paralysis and make a choice, we end up less satisfied with the result of the choice than we would be if we had fewer options to choose from. And there are several reasons for this. One of them is that with a lot of different salad dressings to choose from, if you buy one, and it's not perfect — and what salad dressing is? — it's easy to imagine you could have made a different choice that would have been better. And what happens is this imagined alternative induces you to regret the decision you made, and this regret subtracts from the satisfaction you get out of the decision you made, even if it was a good decision. The more options there are, the easier it is to regret anything at all that is disappointing about the option that you chose.Second, what economists call "opportunity costs." Dan Gilbert made a big point this morning of talking about how much the way in which we value things depends on what we compare them to. Well, when there are lots of alternatives to consider, it is easy to imagine the attractive features of alternatives that you reject that make you less satisfied with the alternative that you've chosen. Here's an example.[I can't stop thinking about those other available parking spaces on W 85th street]Sorry if you're not New Yorkers. Here's what you're supposed to be thinking. Here's this couple on the Hamptons. Very expensive real estate. Gorgeous beach. Beautiful day. They have it all to themselves. What could be better? "Well, damn it," this guy is thinking, "It's August. Everybody in my Manhattan neighborhood is away. I could be parking right in front of my building." And he spends two weeks nagged by the idea that he is missing the opportunity, day after day, to have a great parking space. Opportunity costs subtract from the satisfaction we get out of what we choose, even when what we choose is terrific. And the more options there are to consider, the more attractive features of these options are going to be reflected by us as opportunity costs.Here's another example.(Laughter)Now this cartoon makes a lot of points. It makes points about living in the moment as well, and probably about doing things slowly. But one point it makes is that whenever you're choosing one thing, you're choosing not to do other things that may have lots of attractive features, and it's going to make what you're doing less attractive.Third: escalation of expectations. This hit me when I went to replace my jeans. I wear jeans almost all the time. There was a time when jeans came in one flavor, and you bought them, and they fit like crap, they were incredibly uncomfortable, if you wore them and washed them enough times, they started to feel OK. I went to replace my jeans after years of wearing these old ones, and I said, "I want a pair of jeans. Here's my size." And the shopkeeper said, "Do you want slim fit, easy fit, relaxed fit? You want button fly or zipper fly? You want stonewashed or acid-washed? Do you want them distressed? You want boot cut, tapered, blah blah." On and on he went. My jaw dropped. And after I recovered, I said, "I want the kind that used to be the only kind."(Laughter)He had no idea what that was,(Laughter)so I spent an hour trying on all these damn jeans, and I walked out of the store — truth! — with the best-fitting jeans I had ever had. I did better.All this choice made it possible for me to do better. But — I felt worse. Why? I wrote a whole book to try to explain this to myself. The reason —(Laughter)The reason I felt worse is that, with all of these options available, my expectations about how good a pair of jeans should be went up. I had very low, no particular expectations when they only came in one flavor. When they came in 100 flavors, damn it, one of them should've been perfect. And what I got was good, but it wasn't perfect. And so I compared what I got to what I expected, and what I got was disappointing in comparison to what I expected. Adding options to people's lives can't help but increase the expectations people have about how good those options will be. And what that's going to produce is less satisfaction with results, even when they're good results. Nobody in the world of marketing knows this.[It all looks so great. I can't wait to be disappointed.]Because if they did, you wouldn't all know what this was about. The truth is more like this.[Everything was better back when everything was worse]The reason that everything was better back when everything was worse is that when everything was worse, it was actually possible for people to have experiences that were a pleasant surprise. Nowadays, the world we live in — we affluent, industrialized citizens, with perfection the expectation — the best you can ever hope for is that stuff is as good as you expect it to be. You will never be pleasantly surprised because your expectations, my expectations, have gone through the roof. The secret to happiness — this is what you all came for — the secret to happiness is low expectations.(Laughter)[You'll do](Applause)(Laughter)I want to say — just a little autobiographical moment — that I actually am married to a wife, and she's really quite wonderful. I couldn't have done better. I didn't settle. But settling isn't always such a bad thing.Finally — One consequence of buying a bad-fitting pair of jeans when there is only one kind to buy is that when you are dissatisfied, and you ask why, who's responsible, the answer is clear: the world is responsible. What could you do? When there are hundreds of different styles of jeans available, and you buy one that is disappointing, and you ask why, who's responsible? It is equally clear that the answer to the question is "you." You could have done better. With a hundred different kinds of jeans on display, there is no excuse for failure. And so when people make decisions, and even though the results of the decisions are good, they feel disappointed about them; they blame themselves.Clinical depression has exploded in the industrial world in the last generation. I believe a significant — not the only, but a significant — contributor to this explosion of depression, and also suicide, is that people have experiences that are disappointing because their standards are so high, and then when they have to explain these experiences to themselves, they think they're at fault. And so the net result is that we do better in general, objectively, and we feel worse. So let me remind you. This is the official dogma, the one that we all take to be true, and it's all false. It is not true. There's no question that some choice is better than none, but it doesn't follow from that that more choice is better than some choice. There's some magical amount. I don't know what it is. I'm pretty confident that we have long since passed the point where options improve our welfare.Now, as a policy matter — I'm almost done — as a policy matter, the thing to think about is this: what enables all of this choice in industrial societies is material affluence. There are lots of places in the world, and we have heard about several of them, where their problem is not that they have too much choice. Their problem is that they have too little. So the stuff I'm talking about is the peculiar problem of modern, affluent, Western societies. And what is so frustrating and infuriating is this: Steve Levitt talked to you yesterday about how these expensive and difficult-to-install child seats don't help. It's a waste of money. What I'm telling you is that these expensive, complicated choices — it's not simply that they don't help. They actually hurt. They actually make us worse off.If some of what enables people in our societies to make all of the choices we make were shifted to societies in which people have too few options, not only would those people's lives be improved, but ours would be improved also, which is what economists call a "Pareto-improving move." Income redistribution will make everyone better off — not just poor people — because of how all this excess choice plagues us. So to conclude. [You can be anything you want to be — no limits] You're supposed to read this cartoon, and, being a sophisticated person, say, "Ah! What does this fish know? You know, nothing is possible in this fishbowl." Impoverished imagination, a myopic view of the world — and that's the way I read it at first. The more I thought about it, however, the more I came to the view that this fish knows something. Because the truth of the matter is that if you shatter the fishbowl so that everything is possible, you don't have freedom. You have paralysis. If you shatter this fishbowl so that everything is possible, you decrease satisfaction. You increase paralysis, and you decrease satisfaction.Everybody needs a fishbowl. This one is almost certainly too limited — perhaps even for the fish, certainly for us. But the absence of some metaphorical fishbowl is a recipe for misery, and, I suspect, disaster.Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.244
I'm going to talk to you about some stuff
that's in this book of mine

00:00:15.268 --> 00:00:18.365
that I hope will resonate with other
things you've already heard,

00:00:18.389 --> 00:00:20.690
and I'll try to make
some connections myself,

00:00:20.714 --> 00:00:22.034
in case you missed them.

00:00:22.058 --> 00:00:26.251
But I want to start with
what I call the "official dogma."

00:00:26.894 --> 00:00:28.346
The official dogma of what?

00:00:28.370 --> 00:00:31.676
The official dogma of all Western
industrial societies.

00:00:31.700 --> 00:00:34.013
And the official dogma runs like this:

00:00:34.037 --> 00:00:38.735
if we are interested in maximizing
the welfare of our citizens,

00:00:38.759 --> 00:00:43.699
the way to do that
is to maximize individual freedom.

00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:48.934
The reason for this is both that freedom
is in and of itself good,

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:52.080
valuable, worthwhile,
essential to being human.

00:00:52.477 --> 00:00:54.934
And because if people have freedom,

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.934
then each of us can act on our own

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.244
to do the things
that will maximize our welfare,

00:00:59.268 --> 00:01:01.568
and no one has to decide on our behalf.

00:01:02.656 --> 00:01:06.695
The way to maximize freedom
is to maximize choice.

00:01:07.696 --> 00:01:11.386
The more choice people have,
the more freedom they have,

00:01:11.410 --> 00:01:13.093
and the more freedom they have,

00:01:13.117 --> 00:01:14.744
the more welfare they have.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:20.934
This, I think, is so deeply embedded
in the water supply

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:24.198
that it wouldn't occur
to anyone to question it.

00:01:25.253 --> 00:01:28.934
And it's also deeply
embedded in our lives.

00:01:29.606 --> 00:01:31.270
I'll give you some examples

00:01:31.294 --> 00:01:34.934
of what modern progress
has made possible for us.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.311
This is my supermarket.

00:01:36.788 --> 00:01:38.055
Not such a big one.

00:01:38.798 --> 00:01:41.197
I want to say just a word
about salad dressing.

00:01:41.221 --> 00:01:43.934
175 salad dressings in my supermarket,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.934
if you don't count the 10
extra-virgin olive oils

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.934
and 12 balsamic vinegars you could buy

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.934
to make a very large number
of your own salad dressings,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:57.711
in the off-chance that none of the 175
the store has on offer suit you.

00:01:58.434 --> 00:02:00.371
So this is what the supermarket is like.

00:02:00.395 --> 00:02:02.823
And then you go
to the consumer electronics store

00:02:02.847 --> 00:02:04.442
to set up a stereo system --

00:02:04.466 --> 00:02:07.934
speakers, CD player,
tape player, tuner, amplifier --

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:11.934
and in this one single
consumer electronics store,

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:15.237
there are that many stereo systems.

00:02:15.878 --> 00:02:20.855
We can construct six-and-a-half-million
different stereo systems

00:02:20.879 --> 00:02:23.537
out of the components
that are on offer in one store.

00:02:23.561 --> 00:02:25.575
You've got to admit
that's a lot of choice.

00:02:26.252 --> 00:02:29.934
In other domains --
the world of communications.

00:02:30.347 --> 00:02:32.189
There was a time, when I was a boy,

00:02:32.213 --> 00:02:35.030
when you could get any kind
of telephone service you wanted,

00:02:35.054 --> 00:02:36.872
as long as it came from Ma Bell.

00:02:36.896 --> 00:02:38.934
You rented your phone. You didn't buy it.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:42.149
One consequence of that, by the way,
is that the phone never broke.

00:02:42.173 --> 00:02:44.934
And those days are gone.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.934
We now have an almost
unlimited variety of phones,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.934
especially in the world of cell phones.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.196
These are cell phones of the future.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.934
My favorite is the middle one --

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:59.143
the MP3 player, nose hair trimmer,
and crème brûlée torch.

00:02:59.167 --> 00:03:01.654
(Laughter)

00:03:01.678 --> 00:03:04.934
And if by some chance you haven't
seen that in your store yet,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.844
you can rest assured
that one day soon, you will.

00:03:07.868 --> 00:03:09.045
And what this does

00:03:09.069 --> 00:03:12.228
is it leads people to walk
into their stores asking this question.

00:03:12.743 --> 00:03:15.411
And do you know what the answer
to this question now is?

00:03:15.435 --> 00:03:16.950
The answer is "no."

00:03:17.474 --> 00:03:20.934
It is not possible to buy a cell phone
that doesn't do too much.

00:03:21.536 --> 00:03:25.934
So, in other aspects of life that are much
more significant than buying things,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.451
the same explosion of choice is true.

00:03:29.475 --> 00:03:30.981
Health care.

00:03:31.005 --> 00:03:33.538
It is no longer the case
in the United States

00:03:33.562 --> 00:03:37.057
that you go to the doctor,
and the doctor tells you what to do.

00:03:37.438 --> 00:03:39.097
Instead, you go to the doctor,

00:03:39.121 --> 00:03:42.271
and the doctor tells you,
"Well, we could do A, or we could do B.

00:03:42.295 --> 00:03:44.677
A has these benefits, and these risks.

00:03:44.701 --> 00:03:46.906
B has these benefits, and these risks.

00:03:47.333 --> 00:03:48.659
What do you want to do?"

00:03:49.096 --> 00:03:51.310
And you say, "Doc, what should I do?"

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.714
And the doc says, "A has
these benefits and risks,

00:03:54.738 --> 00:03:56.696
and B has these benefits and risks.

00:03:56.720 --> 00:03:58.259
What do you want to do?"

00:03:58.735 --> 00:04:02.068
And you say, "If you were me,
Doc, what would you do?"

00:04:02.751 --> 00:04:04.792
And the doc says, "But I'm not you."

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.776
And the result is --
we call it "patient autonomy,"

00:04:08.800 --> 00:04:10.673
which makes it sound like a good thing,

00:04:10.697 --> 00:04:13.760
but it really is a shifting
of the burden and the responsibility

00:04:13.784 --> 00:04:16.433
for decision-making from somebody
who knows something --

00:04:16.457 --> 00:04:17.471
namely, the doctor --

00:04:17.495 --> 00:04:20.227
to somebody who knows nothing
and is almost certainly sick

00:04:20.251 --> 00:04:22.934
and thus not in the best shape
to be making decisions --

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.830
namely, the patient.

00:04:24.854 --> 00:04:27.680
There's enormous marketing
of prescription drugs

00:04:27.704 --> 00:04:28.955
to people like you and me,

00:04:28.979 --> 00:04:31.435
which, if you think about it,
makes no sense at all,

00:04:31.459 --> 00:04:32.672
since we can't buy them.

00:04:32.696 --> 00:04:35.149
Why do they market to us
if we can't buy them?

00:04:35.173 --> 00:04:38.934
The answer is that they expect us
to call our doctors the next morning

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.207
and ask for our prescriptions
to be changed.

00:04:42.490 --> 00:04:46.467
Something as dramatic as our identity

00:04:46.491 --> 00:04:49.251
has now become a matter of choice,

00:04:49.275 --> 00:04:52.728
as this slide is meant to indicate.

00:04:52.752 --> 00:04:55.580
We don't inherit an identity;
we get to invent it.

00:04:55.604 --> 00:04:58.934
And we get to re-invent
ourselves as often as we like.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.911
And that means that every day,
when you wake up in the morning,

00:05:01.935 --> 00:05:04.870
you have to decide what kind
of person you want to be.

00:05:05.679 --> 00:05:09.378
With respect to marriage and family,

00:05:09.402 --> 00:05:14.223
there was a time when the default
assumption that almost everyone had

00:05:14.247 --> 00:05:16.349
is that you got married
as soon as you could,

00:05:16.373 --> 00:05:18.983
and then you started having kids
as soon as you could.

00:05:19.007 --> 00:05:21.862
The only real choice was who,

00:05:21.886 --> 00:05:24.499
not when, and not what you did after.

00:05:25.070 --> 00:05:27.934
Nowadays, everything
is very much up for grabs.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.679
I teach wonderfully intelligent students,

00:05:30.703 --> 00:05:34.477
and I assign 20 percent
less work than I used to.

00:05:34.501 --> 00:05:36.934
And it's not because they're less smart,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.351
and it's not because
they're less diligent.

00:05:39.375 --> 00:05:42.828
It's because they are preoccupied,
asking themselves,

00:05:42.852 --> 00:05:45.464
"Should I get married or not?
Should I get married now?

00:05:45.488 --> 00:05:46.781
Should I get married later?

00:05:46.805 --> 00:05:49.192
Should I have kids first,
or a career first?"

00:05:49.216 --> 00:05:51.934
All of these are consuming questions.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.054
And they're going to answer
these questions,

00:05:54.078 --> 00:05:56.699
whether or not it means
not doing all the work I assign

00:05:56.723 --> 00:05:58.777
and not getting a good grade
in my courses.

00:05:58.801 --> 00:05:59.935
And indeed they should.

00:05:59.959 --> 00:06:02.293
These are important questions to answer.

00:06:03.845 --> 00:06:05.008
Work --

00:06:05.032 --> 00:06:07.327
we are blessed, as Carl was pointing out,

00:06:07.351 --> 00:06:09.328
with the technology that enables us

00:06:09.352 --> 00:06:15.394
to work every minute of every day
from any place on the planet --

00:06:15.418 --> 00:06:17.196
except the Randolph Hotel.

00:06:17.735 --> 00:06:20.775
(Laughter)

00:06:20.799 --> 00:06:22.568
(Applause)

00:06:22.592 --> 00:06:24.934
There is one corner, by the way,

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:29.564
that I'm not going to tell anybody about,
where the WiFi actually works.

00:06:29.588 --> 00:06:32.373
I'm not telling you about it
because I want to use it.

00:06:32.397 --> 00:06:33.642
So what this means,

00:06:33.666 --> 00:06:36.705
this incredible freedom of choice
we have with respect to work,

00:06:36.729 --> 00:06:38.402
is that we have to make a decision,

00:06:38.426 --> 00:06:40.514
again and again and again,

00:06:40.538 --> 00:06:42.934
about whether we should
or shouldn't be working.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.563
We can go to watch our kid play soccer,

00:06:45.587 --> 00:06:47.564
and we have our cell phone on one hip,

00:06:47.588 --> 00:06:49.635
and our Blackberry on our other hip,

00:06:49.659 --> 00:06:52.369
and our laptop, presumably, on our laps.

00:06:52.393 --> 00:06:54.505
And even if they're all shut off,

00:06:54.529 --> 00:06:57.600
every minute that we're watching
our kid mutilate a soccer game,

00:06:57.624 --> 00:06:59.406
we are also asking ourselves,

00:06:59.430 --> 00:07:01.456
"Should I answer this cell phone call?

00:07:01.480 --> 00:07:04.353
Should I respond to this email?
Should I draft this letter?"

00:07:04.377 --> 00:07:06.934
And even if the answer
to the question is "no,"

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.244
it's certainly going to make
the experience of your kid's soccer game

00:07:10.268 --> 00:07:12.182
very different than it would've been.

00:07:12.624 --> 00:07:14.665
So everywhere we look,

00:07:14.689 --> 00:07:18.447
big things and small things,
material things and lifestyle things,

00:07:18.471 --> 00:07:20.639
life is a matter of choice.

00:07:21.402 --> 00:07:24.934
And the world we used
to live in looked like this.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.169
[Well, actually,
they are written in stone.]

00:07:27.193 --> 00:07:29.135
That is to say, there were some choices,

00:07:29.159 --> 00:07:31.160
but not everything was a matter of choice.

00:07:31.184 --> 00:07:33.319
And the world we now live in
looks like this.

00:07:33.343 --> 00:07:34.919
[The Ten Commandments DYI Kit]

00:07:34.943 --> 00:07:38.674
And the question is,
is this good news, or bad news?

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.157
And the answer is, "yes."

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.569
(Laughter)

00:07:45.315 --> 00:07:47.421
We all know what's good about it,

00:07:47.445 --> 00:07:49.934
so I'm going to talk
about what's bad about it.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.405
All of this choice has two effects,

00:07:53.429 --> 00:07:55.378
two negative effects on people.

00:07:56.118 --> 00:07:58.570
One effect, paradoxically,

00:07:58.594 --> 00:08:02.051
is that it produces paralysis,
rather than liberation.

00:08:02.656 --> 00:08:04.934
With so many options to choose from,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.526
people find it very difficult
to choose at all.

00:08:09.251 --> 00:08:11.934
I'll give you one very
dramatic example of this:

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:17.514
a study that was done of investments
in voluntary retirement plans.

00:08:18.067 --> 00:08:23.389
A colleague of mine got access
to investment records from Vanguard,

00:08:23.413 --> 00:08:25.034
the gigantic mutual-fund company

00:08:25.058 --> 00:08:28.934
of about a million employees
and about 2,000 different workplaces.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.326
And what she found

00:08:30.350 --> 00:08:34.618
is that for every 10 mutual funds
the employer offered,

00:08:34.642 --> 00:08:38.324
rate of participation
went down two percent.

00:08:39.228 --> 00:08:43.456
You offer 50 funds -- 10 percent
fewer employees participate

00:08:43.480 --> 00:08:45.137
than if you only offer five.

00:08:45.972 --> 00:08:47.131
Why?

00:08:47.155 --> 00:08:49.139
Because with 50 funds to choose from,

00:08:49.163 --> 00:08:52.934
it's so damn hard to decide
which fund to choose,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.006
that you'll just put it off
until tomorrow.

00:08:55.030 --> 00:08:56.229
And then tomorrow,

00:08:56.253 --> 00:08:58.230
and tomorrow, and tomorrow,

00:08:58.254 --> 00:09:00.259
and of course tomorrow never comes.

00:09:00.283 --> 00:09:02.412
Understand that not only does this mean

00:09:02.436 --> 00:09:05.386
that people are going to have
to eat dog food when they retire

00:09:05.410 --> 00:09:07.592
because they don't have
enough money put away,

00:09:07.616 --> 00:09:10.203
it also means that making
the decision is so hard

00:09:10.227 --> 00:09:13.934
that they pass up significant
matching money from the employer.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.934
By not participating, they are passing up
as much as 5,000 dollars a year

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.255
from the employer,

00:09:19.279 --> 00:09:21.378
who would happily
match their contribution.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.638
So paralysis is a consequence
of having too many choices.

00:09:25.662 --> 00:09:28.148
And I think it makes
the world look like this.

00:09:28.829 --> 00:09:33.164
[And lastly, for all eternity,
French, bleu cheese, or ranch?]

00:09:33.188 --> 00:09:34.934
(Laughter)

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.832
You really want to get the decision
right if it's for all eternity, right?

00:09:38.856 --> 00:09:42.398
You don't want to pick the wrong
mutual fund, or the wrong salad dressing.

00:09:42.422 --> 00:09:43.574
So that's one effect.

00:09:43.598 --> 00:09:44.732
The second effect

00:09:44.756 --> 00:09:50.314
is that even if we manage to overcome
the paralysis and make a choice,

00:09:50.338 --> 00:09:54.251
we end up less satisfied
with the result of the choice

00:09:54.275 --> 00:09:56.934
than we would be if we had
fewer options to choose from.

00:09:57.727 --> 00:09:59.605
And there are several reasons for this.

00:10:00.320 --> 00:10:01.327
One of them

00:10:01.351 --> 00:10:04.308
is that with a lot of different
salad dressings to choose from,

00:10:04.332 --> 00:10:07.675
if you buy one, and it's not perfect --
and what salad dressing is? --

00:10:07.699 --> 00:10:10.518
it's easy to imagine
you could have made a different choice

00:10:10.542 --> 00:10:11.919
that would have been better.

00:10:12.666 --> 00:10:13.934
And what happens

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:18.760
is this imagined alternative induces you
to regret the decision you made,

00:10:18.784 --> 00:10:21.362
and this regret subtracts
from the satisfaction

00:10:21.386 --> 00:10:23.164
you get out of the decision you made,

00:10:23.188 --> 00:10:24.766
even if it was a good decision.

00:10:25.568 --> 00:10:29.292
The more options there are,
the easier it is to regret anything at all

00:10:29.316 --> 00:10:31.840
that is disappointing
about the option that you chose.

00:10:32.300 --> 00:10:34.934
Second, what economists
call "opportunity costs."

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.934
Dan Gilbert made a big point this morning

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:41.934
of talking about how much the way
in which we value things

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.934
depends on what we compare them to.

00:10:44.349 --> 00:10:47.934
Well, when there are lots
of alternatives to consider,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.113
it is easy to imagine
the attractive features

00:10:51.137 --> 00:10:53.934
of alternatives that you reject

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:58.591
that make you less satisfied
with the alternative that you've chosen.

00:10:58.615 --> 00:10:59.698
Here's an example.

00:10:59.722 --> 00:11:03.631
[I can't stop thinking about those other
available parking spaces on W 85th street]

00:11:03.655 --> 00:11:05.195
Sorry if you're not New Yorkers.

00:11:05.219 --> 00:11:07.228
Here's what you're
supposed to be thinking.

00:11:07.252 --> 00:11:09.014
Here's this couple on the Hamptons.

00:11:09.038 --> 00:11:10.334
Very expensive real estate.

00:11:10.358 --> 00:11:13.334
Gorgeous beach. Beautiful day.
They have it all to themselves.

00:11:13.358 --> 00:11:14.729
What could be better?

00:11:14.753 --> 00:11:16.630
"Well, damn it," this guy is thinking,

00:11:16.654 --> 00:11:20.628
"It's August. Everybody
in my Manhattan neighborhood is away.

00:11:20.652 --> 00:11:23.486
I could be parking
right in front of my building."

00:11:24.775 --> 00:11:28.370
And he spends two weeks nagged by the idea

00:11:28.394 --> 00:11:30.248
that he is missing the opportunity,

00:11:30.272 --> 00:11:33.240
day after day, to have
a great parking space.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.353
Opportunity costs

00:11:36.377 --> 00:11:39.447
subtract from the satisfaction
we get out of what we choose,

00:11:39.471 --> 00:11:41.304
even when what we choose is terrific.

00:11:42.050 --> 00:11:44.105
And the more options
there are to consider,

00:11:44.129 --> 00:11:46.335
the more attractive
features of these options

00:11:46.359 --> 00:11:49.577
are going to be reflected
by us as opportunity costs.

00:11:50.155 --> 00:11:51.560
Here's another example.

00:11:52.132 --> 00:11:55.744
(Laughter)

00:11:55.847 --> 00:11:58.267
Now this cartoon makes a lot of points.

00:11:58.291 --> 00:12:01.689
It makes points about living
in the moment as well,

00:12:01.713 --> 00:12:03.690
and probably about doing things slowly.

00:12:03.714 --> 00:12:04.857
But one point it makes

00:12:04.881 --> 00:12:07.042
is that whenever
you're choosing one thing,

00:12:07.066 --> 00:12:08.934
you're choosing not to do other things

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.022
that may have lots of attractive features,

00:12:11.046 --> 00:12:13.793
and it's going to make
what you're doing less attractive.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.259
Third: escalation of expectations.

00:12:16.283 --> 00:12:19.164
This hit me when I went
to replace my jeans.

00:12:19.188 --> 00:12:20.934
I wear jeans almost all the time.

00:12:21.489 --> 00:12:23.704
There was a time
when jeans came in one flavor,

00:12:23.728 --> 00:12:25.799
and you bought them,
and they fit like crap,

00:12:25.823 --> 00:12:27.513
they were incredibly uncomfortable,

00:12:27.537 --> 00:12:29.934
if you wore them
and washed them enough times,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.518
they started to feel OK.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.083
I went to replace my jeans after years
of wearing these old ones,

00:12:35.107 --> 00:12:37.958
and I said, "I want
a pair of jeans. Here's my size."

00:12:37.982 --> 00:12:39.168
And the shopkeeper said,

00:12:39.192 --> 00:12:41.934
"Do you want slim fit,
easy fit, relaxed fit?

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:45.339
You want button fly or zipper fly?
You want stonewashed or acid-washed?

00:12:45.363 --> 00:12:46.728
Do you want them distressed?

00:12:46.752 --> 00:12:49.589
You want boot cut, tapered, blah blah."
On and on he went.

00:12:49.613 --> 00:12:50.762
My jaw dropped.

00:12:51.524 --> 00:12:53.024
And after I recovered, I said,

00:12:53.048 --> 00:12:56.048
"I want the kind that used
to be the only kind."

00:12:56.246 --> 00:13:00.841
(Laughter)

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.935
He had no idea what that was,

00:13:02.959 --> 00:13:04.116
(Laughter)

00:13:04.140 --> 00:13:06.934
so I spent an hour trying on
all these damn jeans,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.005
and I walked out of the store -- truth! --

00:13:09.029 --> 00:13:11.670
with the best-fitting jeans
I had ever had.

00:13:11.694 --> 00:13:12.853
I did better.

00:13:12.877 --> 00:13:16.121
All this choice made
it possible for me to do better.

00:13:16.740 --> 00:13:17.812
But --

00:13:17.836 --> 00:13:19.256
I felt worse.

00:13:20.502 --> 00:13:23.934
Why? I wrote a whole book
to try to explain this to myself.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.300
The reason --

00:13:25.324 --> 00:13:29.557
(Laughter)

00:13:29.703 --> 00:13:31.934
The reason I felt worse is that,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.672
with all of these options available,

00:13:34.696 --> 00:13:39.877
my expectations about how good
a pair of jeans should be went up.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:45.172
I had very low, no particular expectations
when they only came in one flavor.

00:13:45.196 --> 00:13:48.836
When they came in 100 flavors, damn it,
one of them should've been perfect.

00:13:48.860 --> 00:13:51.197
And what I got was good,
but it wasn't perfect.

00:13:51.221 --> 00:13:54.307
And so I compared what I got
to what I expected,

00:13:54.331 --> 00:13:57.561
and what I got was disappointing
in comparison to what I expected.

00:13:58.156 --> 00:14:00.196
Adding options to people's lives

00:14:00.220 --> 00:14:03.824
can't help but increase
the expectations people have

00:14:03.848 --> 00:14:05.934
about how good those options will be.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.149
And what that's going to produce
is less satisfaction with results,

00:14:09.173 --> 00:14:10.926
even when they're good results.

00:14:11.736 --> 00:14:14.200
Nobody in the world
of marketing knows this.

00:14:14.224 --> 00:14:16.993
[It all looks so great.
I can't wait to be disappointed.]

00:14:17.017 --> 00:14:20.502
Because if they did, you wouldn't all know
what this was about.

00:14:20.917 --> 00:14:22.821
The truth is more like this.

00:14:23.479 --> 00:14:26.548
[Everything was better back
when everything was worse]

00:14:26.572 --> 00:14:30.584
The reason that everything was better
back when everything was worse

00:14:30.608 --> 00:14:32.750
is that when everything was worse,

00:14:32.774 --> 00:14:34.545
it was actually possible for people

00:14:34.569 --> 00:14:36.964
to have experiences
that were a pleasant surprise.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:42.243
Nowadays, the world we live in --
we affluent, industrialized citizens,

00:14:42.267 --> 00:14:44.094
with perfection the expectation --

00:14:44.118 --> 00:14:45.999
the best you can ever hope for

00:14:46.023 --> 00:14:48.688
is that stuff is as good
as you expect it to be.

00:14:48.712 --> 00:14:50.554
You will never be pleasantly surprised

00:14:50.578 --> 00:14:52.624
because your expectations,
my expectations,

00:14:52.648 --> 00:14:53.997
have gone through the roof.

00:14:54.021 --> 00:14:57.442
The secret to happiness --
this is what you all came for --

00:14:57.466 --> 00:15:00.015
the secret to happiness

00:15:00.039 --> 00:15:02.007
is low expectations.

00:15:02.031 --> 00:15:05.275
(Laughter)

00:15:05.575 --> 00:15:06.784
[You'll do]

00:15:06.808 --> 00:15:07.966
(Applause)

00:15:07.990 --> 00:15:11.299
(Laughter)

00:15:11.323 --> 00:15:12.575
I want to say --

00:15:12.599 --> 00:15:15.242
just a little autobiographical moment --

00:15:15.266 --> 00:15:18.256
that I actually am married to a wife,

00:15:18.280 --> 00:15:19.934
and she's really quite wonderful.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.532
I couldn't have done better.

00:15:21.556 --> 00:15:23.116
I didn't settle.

00:15:23.140 --> 00:15:25.553
But settling isn't
always such a bad thing.

00:15:26.116 --> 00:15:27.124
Finally --

00:15:28.038 --> 00:15:31.355
One consequence of buying
a bad-fitting pair of jeans

00:15:31.379 --> 00:15:33.427
when there is only one kind to buy

00:15:33.451 --> 00:15:35.934
is that when you are dissatisfied,
and you ask why,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.195
who's responsible,

00:15:37.219 --> 00:15:39.727
the answer is clear:
the world is responsible.

00:15:39.751 --> 00:15:41.344
What could you do?

00:15:41.368 --> 00:15:44.336
When there are hundreds
of different styles of jeans available,

00:15:44.360 --> 00:15:46.732
and you buy one that is disappointing,

00:15:46.756 --> 00:15:48.934
and you ask why, who's responsible?

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:53.277
It is equally clear that the answer
to the question is "you."

00:15:54.118 --> 00:15:55.934
You could have done better.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.934
With a hundred different kinds
of jeans on display,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.934
there is no excuse for failure.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.342
And so when people make decisions,

00:16:03.366 --> 00:16:05.934
and even though the results
of the decisions are good,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.684
they feel disappointed about them;

00:16:08.708 --> 00:16:10.685
they blame themselves.

00:16:10.709 --> 00:16:12.660
Clinical depression has exploded

00:16:12.684 --> 00:16:15.175
in the industrial world
in the last generation.

00:16:15.199 --> 00:16:18.934
I believe a significant -- not the only,
but a significant -- contributor

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.231
to this explosion of depression,
and also suicide,

00:16:22.255 --> 00:16:24.934
is that people have experiences
that are disappointing

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.816
because their standards are so high,

00:16:26.840 --> 00:16:30.032
and then when they have to explain
these experiences to themselves,

00:16:30.056 --> 00:16:31.398
they think they're at fault.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:35.934
And so the net result is that we do
better in general, objectively,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.968
and we feel worse.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.512
So let me remind you.

00:16:41.536 --> 00:16:45.934
This is the official dogma,
the one that we all take to be true,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.072
and it's all false.

00:16:48.599 --> 00:16:49.666
It is not true.

00:16:50.250 --> 00:16:54.449
There's no question that some choice
is better than none,

00:16:54.473 --> 00:16:56.572
but it doesn't follow from that

00:16:56.596 --> 00:16:58.934
that more choice
is better than some choice.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.835
There's some magical amount.
I don't know what it is.

00:17:01.859 --> 00:17:04.752
I'm pretty confident that we have
long since passed the point

00:17:04.776 --> 00:17:06.862
where options improve our welfare.

00:17:07.410 --> 00:17:10.266
Now, as a policy matter --
I'm almost done --

00:17:10.290 --> 00:17:13.775
as a policy matter,
the thing to think about is this:

00:17:13.799 --> 00:17:16.421
what enables all of this choice

00:17:16.445 --> 00:17:20.516
in industrial societies
is material affluence.

00:17:21.341 --> 00:17:23.245
There are lots of places in the world,

00:17:23.269 --> 00:17:25.234
and we have heard about several of them,

00:17:25.258 --> 00:17:28.020
where their problem
is not that they have too much choice.

00:17:28.044 --> 00:17:30.142
Their problem
is that they have too little.

00:17:30.166 --> 00:17:32.934
So the stuff I'm talking about
is the peculiar problem

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.606
of modern, affluent, Western societies.

00:17:36.630 --> 00:17:39.855
And what is so frustrating
and infuriating is this:

00:17:39.879 --> 00:17:42.149
Steve Levitt talked to you yesterday

00:17:42.173 --> 00:17:48.428
about how these expensive
and difficult-to-install child seats

00:17:48.452 --> 00:17:50.062
don't help.

00:17:50.952 --> 00:17:52.619
It's a waste of money.

00:17:52.643 --> 00:17:53.928
What I'm telling you

00:17:53.952 --> 00:17:57.153
is that these expensive,
complicated choices --

00:17:57.177 --> 00:17:59.341
it's not simply that they don't help.

00:17:59.365 --> 00:18:00.934
They actually hurt.

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:03.341
They actually make us worse off.

00:18:03.886 --> 00:18:07.637
If some of what enables
people in our societies

00:18:07.661 --> 00:18:09.660
to make all of the choices we make

00:18:09.684 --> 00:18:14.272
were shifted to societies
in which people have too few options,

00:18:14.296 --> 00:18:16.576
not only would those
people's lives be improved,

00:18:16.600 --> 00:18:18.934
but ours would be improved also,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.935
which is what economists call
a "Pareto-improving move."

00:18:21.959 --> 00:18:25.671
Income redistribution will make
everyone better off --

00:18:25.695 --> 00:18:27.107
not just poor people --

00:18:27.131 --> 00:18:30.038
because of how all this excess
choice plagues us.

00:18:30.672 --> 00:18:31.720
So to conclude.

00:18:31.744 --> 00:18:34.054
[You can be anything
you want to be -- no limits]

00:18:34.078 --> 00:18:37.717
You're supposed to read this cartoon,
and, being a sophisticated person, say,

00:18:37.741 --> 00:18:39.196
"Ah! What does this fish know?

00:18:39.220 --> 00:18:42.317
You know, nothing is possible
in this fishbowl."

00:18:42.711 --> 00:18:45.314
Impoverished imagination,
a myopic view of the world --

00:18:45.338 --> 00:18:47.172
and that's the way I read it at first.

00:18:47.196 --> 00:18:49.013
The more I thought about it, however,

00:18:49.037 --> 00:18:52.575
the more I came to the view
that this fish knows something.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:54.934
Because the truth of the matter

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:59.427
is that if you shatter the fishbowl
so that everything is possible,

00:18:59.451 --> 00:19:00.864
you don't have freedom.

00:19:00.888 --> 00:19:02.482
You have paralysis.

00:19:03.260 --> 00:19:06.427
If you shatter this fishbowl
so that everything is possible,

00:19:06.451 --> 00:19:09.389
you decrease satisfaction.

00:19:10.142 --> 00:19:13.714
You increase paralysis,
and you decrease satisfaction.

00:19:13.738 --> 00:19:15.403
Everybody needs a fishbowl.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:18.006
This one is almost
certainly too limited --

00:19:18.030 --> 00:19:21.267
perhaps even for the fish,
certainly for us.

00:19:21.291 --> 00:19:25.656
But the absence of some metaphorical
fishbowl is a recipe for misery,

00:19:25.680 --> 00:19:27.465
and, I suspect, disaster.

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.228
Thank you very much.

00:19:29.252 --> 00:19:30.894
(Applause)

title: Meet the future of cancer research
transcript: Thank you. It's really an honor and a privilege to be here spending my last day as a teenager. Today I want to talk to you about the future, but first I'm going to tell you a bit about the past. My story starts way before I was born. My grandmother was on a train to Auschwitz, the death camp. And she was going along the tracks, and the tracks split. And somehow — we don't really know exactly the whole story — but the train took the wrong track and went to a work camp rather than the death camp. My grandmother survived and married my grandfather. They were living in Hungary, and my mother was born. And when my mother was two years old, the Hungarian revolution was raging, and they decided to escape Hungary. They got on a boat, and yet another divergence — the boat was either going to Canada or to Australia. They got on and didn't know where they were going, and ended up in Canada. So, to make a long story short, they came to Canada. My grandmother was a chemist. She worked at the Banting Institute in Toronto, and at 44 she died of stomach cancer. I never met my grandmother, but I carry on her name — her exact name, Eva Vertes — and I like to think I carry on her scientific passion, too.I found this passion not far from here, actually, when I was nine years old. My family was on a road trip and we were in the Grand Canyon. or somehow -- you know, it's contained. It's very contained.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
But once it starts moving throughout the body, that's when it becomes deadly.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:59.958
So the fact that not only did cancer not seem to originate in skeletal muscles,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
but cancer didn't seem to go to skeletal muscle --

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
there seemed to be something here.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
So these articles were saying, you know, "Skeletal --

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
metastasis to skeletal muscle -- is very rare."

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
But it was left at that. No one seemed to be asking why.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:20.958
So I decided to ask why. At first -- the first thing I did

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
was I emailed some professors who

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
specialized in skeletal muscle physiology, and pretty much said,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:31.958
"Hey, it seems like cancer doesn't really go to skeletal muscle.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:35.958
Is there a reason for this?" And a lot of the replies I got were that

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:39.958
muscle is terminally differentiated tissue.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Meaning that you have muscle cells, but they're not dividing,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
so it doesn't seem like a good target for cancer to hijack.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
But then again, this fact that the metastases

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
didn't go to skeletal muscle made that seem unlikely.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:58.958
And furthermore, that nervous tissue -- brain -- gets cancer,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
and brain cells are also terminally differentiated.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:07.958
So I decided to ask why. And here's some of, I guess, my hypotheses

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:16.958
that I'll be starting to investigate this May at the Sylvester Cancer Institute in Miami.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And I guess I'll keep investigating until I get the answers.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
But I know that in science, once you get the answers,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
inevitably you're going to have more questions.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:31.958
So I guess you could say that I'll probably be doing this for the rest of my life.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
Some of my hypotheses are that

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
when you first think about skeletal muscle,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
there's a lot of blood vessels going to skeletal muscle.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:44.958
And the first thing that makes me think is that

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
blood vessels are like highways for the tumor cells.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
Tumor cells can travel through the blood vessels.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And you think, the more highways there are in a tissue,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
the more likely it is to get cancer or to get metastases.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
So first of all I thought, you know, "Wouldn't it be favorable

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
to cancer getting to skeletal muscle?" And as well,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:08.958
cancer tumors require a process called angiogenesis,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:12.958
which is really, the tumor recruits the blood vessels to itself

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
to supply itself with nutrients so it can grow.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:22.958
Without angiogenesis, the tumor remains the size of a pinpoint and it's not harmful.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:28.958
So angiogenesis is really a central process to the pathogenesis of cancer.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
And one article that really stood out to me

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
when I was just reading about this, trying to figure out why cancer doesn't go to skeletal

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:42.958
muscle, was that it had reported 16 percent of micro-metastases

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
to skeletal muscle upon autopsy.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:49.958
16 percent! Meaning that there were these pinpoint tumors in skeletal muscle,

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:54.958
but only .16 percent of actual metastases --

00:12:54.958 --> 00:13:00.958
suggesting that maybe skeletal muscle is able to control the angiogenesis,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:05.958
is able to control the tumors recruiting these blood vessels.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:10.958
We use skeletal muscles so much. It's the one portion of our body --

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
our heart's always beating. We're always moving our muscles.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
Is it possible that muscle somehow intuitively knows

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:21.958
that it needs this blood supply? It needs to be constantly contracting,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
so therefore it's almost selfish. It's grabbing its blood vessels for itself.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
Therefore, when a tumor comes into skeletal muscle tissue,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
it can't get a blood supply, and can't grow.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:36.958
So this suggests that maybe if there is an anti-angiogenic factor

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
in skeletal muscle -- or perhaps even more,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:43.958
an angiogenic routing factor, so it can actually direct where the blood vessels grow --

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
this could be a potential future therapy for cancer.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:52.958
And another thing that's really interesting is that

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:56.958
there's this whole -- the way tumors move throughout the body,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
it's a very complex system -- and there's something called the chemokine network.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
And chemokines are essentially chemical attractants,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
and they're the stop and go signals for cancer.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:12.958
So a tumor expresses chemokine receptors,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
and another organ -- a distant organ somewhere in the body --

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
will have the corresponding chemokines,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
and the tumor will see these chemokines and migrate towards it.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:26.958
Is it possible that skeletal muscle doesn't express this type of molecules?

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
And the other really interesting thing is that

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:33.958
when skeletal muscle -- there's been several reports that when skeletal

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:40.958
muscle is injured, that's what correlates with metastases going to skeletal muscle.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And, furthermore, when skeletal muscle is injured,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
that's what causes chemokines -- these signals saying,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
"Cancer, you can come to me," the "go signs" for the tumors --

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:55.958
it causes them to highly express these chemokines.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:15:02.958
So, there's so much interplay here.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
I mean, there are so many possibilities

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
for why tumors don't go to skeletal muscle.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
But it seems like by investigating, by attacking cancer,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
by searching where cancer is not, there has got to be something --
