00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:21.958
there's got to be something -- that's making this tissue resistant to tumors.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
And can we utilize -- can we take this property,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:28.958
this compound, this receptor, whatever it is that's controlling these

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:35.958
anti-tumor properties and apply it to cancer therapy in general?

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:43.958
Now, one thing that kind of ties the resistance of skeletal muscle to cancer --

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:48.958
to the cancer as a repair response gone out of control in the body --

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:56.958
is that skeletal muscle has a factor in it called "MyoD."

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:01.958
And what MyoD essentially does is, it causes cells to differentiate

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:06.958
into muscle cells. So this compound, MyoD,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
has been tested on a lot of different cell types and been shown to

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:14.958
actually convert this variety of cell types into skeletal muscle cells.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:20.958
So, is it possible that the tumor cells are going to the skeletal muscle tissue,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:24.958
but once in contact inside the skeletal muscle tissue,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:29.958
MyoD acts upon these tumor cells and causes them

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
to become skeletal muscle cells?

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
Maybe tumor cells are being disguised as skeletal muscle cells,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:40.958
and this is why it seems as if it is so rare.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
It's not harmful; it has just repaired the muscle.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
Muscle is constantly being used -- constantly being damaged.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
If every time we tore a muscle

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
or every time we stretched a muscle or moved in a wrong way,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:59.958
cancer occurred -- I mean, everybody would have cancer almost.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:03.958
And I hate to say that. But it seems as though muscle cell,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
possibly because of all its use, has adapted

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
faster than other body tissues to respond to injury,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:15.958
to fine-tune this repair response and actually be able to finish the process

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:20.958
which the body wants to finish. I really believe that the human body is very,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:26.958
very smart, and we can't counteract something the body is saying to do.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
It's different when a bacteria comes into the body --

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:33.958
that's a foreign object -- we want that out.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
But when the body is actually initiating a process

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:39.958
and we're calling it a disease, it doesn't seem as though elimination is

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:47.958
the right solution. So even to go from there, it's possible, although far-fetched,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:54.958
that in the future we could almost think of cancer being used as a therapy.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
If those diseases where tissues are deteriorating --

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:02.958
for example Alzheimer's, where the brain, the brain cells, die

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:06.958
and we need to restore new brain cells, new functional brain cells --

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:10.958
what if we could, in the future, use cancer? A tumor --

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:15.958
put it in the brain and cause it to differentiate into brain cells?

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:21.958
That's a very far-fetched idea, but I really believe that it may be possible.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:25.958
These cells are so versatile, these cancer cells are so versatile --

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:28.958
we just have to manipulate them in the right way.

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:32.958
And again, some of these may be far-fetched, but

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:37.958
I figured if there's anywhere to present far-fetched ideas, it's here at TED, so

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
thank you very much.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.958
(Applause)

title: A roadmap to end aging
transcript: 18 minutes is an absolutely brutal time limit, so I'm going to dive straight in, right at the point where I get this thing to work. Here we go. I'm going to talk about five different things. I'm going to talk about why defeating aging is desirable. I'm going to talk about why we have to get our shit together, and actually talk about this a bit more than we do. I'm going to talk about feasibility as well, of course. I'm going to talk about why we are so fatalistic about doing anything about aging. And then I'm going spend perhaps the second half of the talk talking about, you know, how we might actually be able to prove that fatalism is wrong, namely, by actually doing something about it.I'm going to do that in two steps. The first one I'm going to talk about is how to get from a relatively modest amount of life extension — which I'm going to define as 30 years, applied to people who are already in middle-age when you start — to a point which can genuinely be called defeating aging. Namely, essentially an elimination of the relationship between how old you are and how likely you are to die in the next year — or indeed, to get sick in the first place. And of course, the last thing I'm going to talk about is how to reach that intermediate step, that point of maybe 30 years life extension.So I'm going to start with why we should. Now, I want to ask a question. Hands up: anyone in the audience who is in favor of malaria? That was easy. OK. OK. Hands up: anyone in the audience who's not sure whether malaria is a good thing or a bad thing? OK. So we all think malaria is a bad thing. That's very good news, because I thought that was what the answer would be. Now the thing is, I would like to put it to you that the main reason why we think that malaria is a bad thing is because of a characteristic of malaria that it shares with aging. And here is that characteristic. The only real difference is that aging kills considerably more people than malaria does.Now, I like in an audience, in Britain especially, to talk about the comparison with foxhunting, which is something that was banned after a long struggle, by the government not very many months ago. I mean, I know I'm with a sympathetic audience here, but, as we know, a lot of people are not entirely persuaded by this logic. And this is actually a rather good comparison, it seems to me. You know, a lot of people said, "Well, you know, city boys have no business telling us rural types what to do with our time. It's a traditional part of the way of life, and we should be allowed to carry on doing it. It's ecologically sound; it stops the population explosion of foxes." But ultimately, the government prevailed in the end, because the majority of the British public, and certainly the majority of members of Parliament, came to the conclusion that it was really something that should not be tolerated in a civilized society.And I think that human aging shares all of these characteristics in spades. What part of this do people not understand? It's not just about life, of course — (Laughter) — it's about healthy life, you know — getting frail and miserable and dependent is no fun, whether or not dying may be fun. So really, this is how I would like to describe it. It's a global trance. These are the sorts of unbelievable excuses that people give for aging. And, I mean, OK, I'm not actually saying that these excuses are completely valueless. There are some good points to be made here, things that we ought to be thinking about, forward planning so that nothing goes too — well, so that we minimize the turbulence when we actually figure out how to fix aging.But these are completely crazy, when you actually remember your sense of proportion. You know, these are arguments; these are things that would be legitimate to be concerned about. But the question is, are they so dangerous — these risks of doing something about aging — that they outweigh the downside of doing the opposite, namely, leaving aging as it is? Are these so bad that they outweigh condemning 100,000 people a day to an unnecessarily early death? You know, if you haven't got an argument that's that strong, then just don't waste my time, is what I say. (Laughter)Now, there is one argument that some people do think really is that strong, and here it is. People worry about overpopulation; they say, "Well, if we fix aging, no one's going to die to speak of, or at least the death toll is going to be much lower, only from crossing St. Giles carelessly. And therefore, we're not going to be able to have many kids, and kids are really important to most people." And that's true. And you know, a lot of people try to fudge this question, and give answers like this. I don't agree with those answers. I think they basically don't work. I think it's true, that we will face a dilemma in this respect. We will have to decide whether to have a low birth rate, or a high death rate. A high death rate will, of course, arise from simply rejecting these therapies, in favor of carrying on having a lot of kids.And, I say that that's fine — the future of humanity is entitled to make that choice. What's not fine is for us to make that choice on behalf of the future. If we vacillate, hesitate, and do not actually develop these therapies, then we are condemning a whole cohort of people — who would have been young enough and healthy enough to benefit from those therapies, but will not be, because we haven't developed them as quickly as we could — we'll be denying those people an indefinite life span, and I consider that that is immoral. That's my answer to the overpopulation question.Right. So the next thing is, now why should we get a little bit more active on this? And the fundamental answer is that the pro-aging trance is not as dumb as it looks. It's actually a sensible way of coping with the inevitability of aging. Aging is ghastly, but it's inevitable, so, you know, we've got to find some way to put it out of our minds, and it's rational to do anything that we might want to do, to do that. Like, for example, making up these ridiculous reasons why aging is actually a good thing after all. But of course, that only works when we have both of these components. And as soon as the inevitability bit becomes a little bit unclear — and we might be in range of doing something about aging — this becomes part of the problem. This pro-aging trance is what stops us from agitating about these things. And that's why we have to really talk about this a lot — evangelize, I will go so far as to say, quite a lot — in order to get people's attention, and make people realize that they are in a trance in this regard. So that's all I'm going to say about that.I'm now going to talk about feasibility. And the fundamental reason, I think, why we feel that aging is inevitable is summed up in a definition of aging that I'm giving here. A very simple definition. Aging is a side effect of being alive in the first place, which is to say, metabolism. This is not a completely tautological statement; it's a reasonable statement. Aging is basically a process that happens to inanimate objects like cars, and it also happens to us, despite the fact that we have a lot of clever self-repair mechanisms, because those self-repair mechanisms are not perfect.So basically, metabolism, which is defined as basically everything that keeps us alive from one day to the next, has side effects. Those side effects accumulate and eventually cause pathology. That's a fine definition. So we can put it this way: we can say that, you know, we have this chain of events. And there are really two games in town, according to most people, with regard to postponing aging. They're what I'm calling here the "gerontology approach" and the "geriatrics approach." The geriatrician will intervene late in the day, when pathology is becoming evident, and the geriatrician will try and hold back the sands of time, and stop the accumulation of side effects from causing the pathology quite so soon. Of course, it's a very short-term-ist strategy; it's a losing battle, because the things that are causing the pathology are becoming more abundant as time goes on.The gerontology approach looks much more promising on the surface, because, you know, prevention is better than cure. But unfortunately the thing is that we don't understand metabolism very well. In fact, we have a pitifully poor understanding of how organisms work — even cells we're not really too good on yet. We've discovered things like, for example, RNA interference only a few years ago, and this is a really fundamental component of how cells work. Basically, gerontology is a fine approach in the end, but it is not an approach whose time has come when we're talking about intervention. So then, what do we do about that? I mean, that's a fine logic, that sounds pretty convincing, pretty ironclad, doesn't it?But it isn't. Before I tell you why it isn't, I'm going to go a little bit into what I'm calling step two. Just suppose, as I said, that we do acquire — let's say we do it today for the sake of argument — the ability to confer 30 extra years of healthy life on people who are already in middle age, let's say 55. I'm going to call that "robust human rejuvenation." OK. What would that actually mean for how long people of various ages today — or equivalently, of various ages at the time that these therapies arrive — would actually live? In order to answer that question — you might think it's simple, but it's not simple. We can't just say, "Well, if they're young enough to benefit from these therapies, then they'll live 30 years longer." That's the wrong answer. And the reason it's the wrong answer is because of progress.There are two sorts of technological progress really, for this purpose. There are fundamental, major breakthroughs, and there are incremental refinements of those breakthroughs. Now, they differ a great deal in terms of the predictability of time frames. Fundamental breakthroughs: very hard to predict how long it's going to take to make a fundamental breakthrough. It was a very long time ago that we decided that flying would be fun, and it took us until 1903 to actually work out how to do it. But after that, things were pretty steady and pretty uniform. I think this is a reasonable sequence of events that happened in the progression of the technology of powered flight. We can think, really, that each one is sort of beyond the imagination of the inventor of the previous one, if you like. The incremental advances have added up to something which is not incremental anymore.This is the sort of thing you see after a fundamental breakthrough. And you see it in all sorts of technologies. Computers: you can look at a more or less parallel time line, happening of course a bit later. You can look at medical care. I mean, hygiene, vaccines, antibiotics — you know, the same sort of time frame. So I think that actually step two, that I called a step a moment ago, isn't a step at all. That in fact, the people who are young enough to benefit from these first therapies that give this moderate amount of life extension, even though those people are already middle-aged when the therapies arrive, will be at some sort of cusp. They will mostly survive long enough to receive improved treatments that will give them a further 30 or maybe 50 years. In other words, they will be staying ahead of the game. The therapies will be improving faster than the remaining imperfections in the therapies are catching up with us.This is a very important point for me to get across. Because, you know, most people, when they hear that I predict that a lot of people alive today are going to live to 1,000 or more, they think that I'm saying that we're going to invent therapies in the next few decades that are so thoroughly eliminating aging that those therapies will let us live to 1,000 or more. I'm not saying that at all. I'm saying that the rate of improvement of those therapies will be enough. They'll never be perfect, but we'll be able to fix the things that 200-year-olds die of, before we have any 200-year-olds. And the same for 300 and 400 and so on. I decided to give this a little name, which is "longevity escape velocity." (Laughter) Well, it seems to get the point across.So, these trajectories here are basically how we would expect people to live, in terms of remaining life expectancy, as measured by their health, for given ages that they were at the time that these therapies arrive. If you're already 100, or even if you're 80 — and an average 80-year-old, we probably can't do a lot for you with these therapies, because you're too close to death's door for the really initial, experimental therapies to be good enough for you. You won't be able to withstand them. But if you're only 50, then there's a chance that you might be able to pull out of the dive and, you know — (Laughter) — eventually get through this and start becoming biologically younger in a meaningful sense, in terms of your youthfulness, both physical and mental, and in terms of your risk of death from age-related causes. And of course, if you're a bit younger than that, then you're never really even going to get near to being fragile enough to die of age-related causes.So this is a genuine conclusion that I come to, that the first 150-year-old — we don't know how old that person is today, because we don't know how long it's going to take to get these first-generation therapies. But irrespective of that age, I'm claiming that the first person to live to 1,000 — subject of course, to, you know, global catastrophes — is actually, probably, only about 10 years younger than the first 150-year-old. And that's quite a thought.Alright, so finally I'm going to spend the rest of the talk, my last seven-and-a-half minutes, on step one; namely, how do we actually get to this moderate amount of life extension that will allow us to get to escape velocity? And in order to do that, I need to talk about mice a little bit. I have a corresponding milestone to robust human rejuvenation. I'm calling it "robust mouse rejuvenation," not very imaginatively. And this is what it is. I say we're going to take a long-lived strain of mouse, which basically means mice that live about three years on average. We do exactly nothing to them until they're already two years old. And then we do a whole bunch of stuff to them, and with those therapies, we get them to live, on average, to their fifth birthday. So, in other words, we add two years — we treble their remaining lifespan, starting from the point that we started the therapies.The question then is, what would that actually mean for the time frame until we get to the milestone I talked about earlier for humans? Which we can now, as I've explained, equivalently call either robust human rejuvenation or longevity escape velocity. Secondly, what does it mean for the public's perception of how long it's going to take for us to get to those things, starting from the time we get the mice? And thirdly, the question is, what will it do to actually how much people want it? And it seems to me that the first question is entirely a biology question, and it's extremely hard to answer. One has to be very speculative, and many of my colleagues would say that we should not do this speculation, that we should simply keep our counsel until we know more.I say that's nonsense. I say we absolutely are irresponsible if we stay silent on this. We need to give our best guess as to the time frame, in order to give people a sense of proportion so that they can assess their priorities. So, I say that we have a 50/50 chance of reaching this RHR milestone, robust human rejuvenation, within 15 years from the point that we get to robust mouse rejuvenation. 15 years from the robust mouse. The public's perception will probably be somewhat better than that. The public tends to underestimate how difficult scientific things are. So they'll probably think it's five years away. They'll be wrong, but that actually won't matter too much. And finally, of course, I think it's fair to say that a large part of the reason why the public is so ambivalent about aging now is the global trance I spoke about earlier, the coping strategy. That will be history at this point, because it will no longer be possible to believe that aging is inevitable in humans, since it's been postponed so very effectively in mice. So we're likely to end up with a very strong change in people's attitudes, and of course that has enormous implications.So in order to tell you now how we're going to get these mice, I'm going to add a little bit to my description of aging. I'm going to use this word "damage" to denote these intermediate things that are caused by metabolism and that eventually cause pathology. Because the critical thing about this is that even though the damage only eventually causes pathology, the damage itself is caused ongoing-ly throughout life, starting before we're born. But it is not part of metabolism itself. And this turns out to be useful. Because we can re-draw our original diagram this way. We can say that, fundamentally, the difference between gerontology and geriatrics is that gerontology tries to inhibit the rate at which metabolism lays down this damage. And I'm going to explain exactly what damage is in concrete biological terms in a moment. And geriatricians try to hold back the sands of time by stopping the damage converting into pathology. And the reason it's a losing battle is because the damage is continuing to accumulate.So there's a third approach, if we look at it this way. We can call it the "engineering approach," and I claim that the engineering approach is within range. The engineering approach does not intervene in any processes. It does not intervene in this process or this one. And that's good because it means that it's not a losing battle, and it's something that we are within range of being able to do, because it doesn't involve improving on evolution. The engineering approach simply says, "Let's go and periodically repair all of these various types of damage — not necessarily repair them completely, but repair them quite a lot, so that we keep the level of damage down below the threshold that must exist, that causes it to be pathogenic." We know that this threshold exists, because we don't get age-related diseases until we're in middle age, even though the damage has been accumulating since before we were born.Why do I say that we're in range? Well, this is basically it. The point about this slide is actually the bottom. If we try to say which bits of metabolism are important for aging, we will be here all night, because basically all of metabolism is important for aging in one way or another. This list is just for illustration; it is incomplete. The list on the right is also incomplete. It's a list of types of pathology that are age-related, and it's just an incomplete list. But I would like to claim to you that this list in the middle is actually complete — this is the list of types of thing that qualify as damage, side effects of metabolism that cause pathology in the end, or that might cause pathology. And there are only seven of them. They're categories of things, of course, but there's only seven of them. Cell loss, mutations in chromosomes, mutations in the mitochondria and so on.First of all, I'd like to give you an argument for why that list is complete. Of course one can make a biological argument. One can say, "OK, what are we made of?" We're made of cells and stuff between cells. What can damage accumulate in? The answer is: long-lived molecules, because if a short-lived molecule undergoes damage, but then the molecule is destroyed — like by a protein being destroyed by proteolysis — then the damage is gone, too. It's got to be long-lived molecules. So, these seven things were all under discussion in gerontology a long time ago and that is pretty good news, because it means that, you know, we've come a long way in biology in these 20 years, so the fact that we haven't extended this list is a pretty good indication that there's no extension to be done. However, it's better than that; we actually know how to fix them all, in mice, in principle — and what I mean by in principle is, we probably can actually implement these fixes within a decade. Some of them are partially implemented already, the ones at the top.I haven't got time to go through them at all, but my conclusion is that, if we can actually get suitable funding for this, then we can probably develop robust mouse rejuvenation in only 10 years, but we do need to get serious about it. We do need to really start trying. So of course, there are some biologists in the audience, and I want to give some answers to some of the questions that you may have. You may have been dissatisfied with this talk, but fundamentally you have to go and read this stuff. I've published a great deal on this; I cite the experimental work on which my optimism is based, and there's quite a lot of detail there. The detail is what makes me confident of my rather aggressive time frames that I'm predicting here. So if you think that I'm wrong, you'd better damn well go and find out why you think I'm wrong.And of course the main thing is that you shouldn't trust people who call themselves gerontologists because, as with any radical departure from previous thinking within a particular field, you know, you expect people in the mainstream to be a bit resistant and not really to take it seriously. So, you know, you've got to actually do your homework, in order to understand whether this is true.And we'll just end with a few things. One thing is, you know, you'll be hearing from a guy in the next session who said some time ago that he could sequence the human genome in half no time, and everyone said, "Well, it's obviously impossible." And you know what happened. So, you know, this does happen. We have various strategies — there's the Methuselah Mouse Prize, which is basically an incentive to innovate, and to do what you think is going to work, and you get money for it if you win. There's a proposal to actually put together an institute. This is what's going to take a bit of money. But, I mean, look — how long does it take to spend that on the war in Iraq? Not very long. OK. (Laughter) It's got to be philanthropic, because profits distract biotech, but it's basically got a 90 percent chance, I think, of succeeding in this. And I think we know how to do it. And I'll stop there. Thank you. (Applause)Chris Anderson: OK. I don't know if there's going to be any questions but I thought I would give people the chance. Audience: Since you've been talking about aging and trying to defeat it, why is it that you make yourself appear like an old man? (Laughter)AG: Because I am an old man. I am actually 158. (Laughter) (Applause)Audience: Species on this planet have evolved with immune systems to fight off all the diseases so that individuals live long enough to procreate. However, as far as I know, all the species have evolved to actually die, so when cells divide, the telomerase get shorter, and eventually species die. So, why does — evolution has — seems to have selected against immortality, when it is so advantageous, or is evolution just incomplete?AG: Brilliant. Thank you for asking a question that I can answer with an uncontroversial answer. I'm going to tell you the genuine mainstream answer to your question, which I happen to agree with, which is that, no, aging is not a product of selection, evolution; [aging] is simply a product of evolutionary neglect. In other words, we have aging because it's hard work not to have aging; you need more genetic pathways, more sophistication in your genes in order to age more slowly, and that carries on being true the longer you push it out. So, to the extent that evolution doesn't matter, doesn't care whether genes are passed on by individuals, living a long time or by procreation, there's a certain amount of modulation of that, which is why different species have different lifespans, but that's why there are no immortal species.CA: The genes don't care but we do?AG: That's right.Audience: Hello. I read somewhere that in the last 20 years, the average lifespan of basically anyone on the planet has grown by 10 years. If I project that, that would make me think that I would live until 120 if I don't crash on my motorbike. That means that I'm one of your subjects to become a 1,000-year-old?AG: If you lose a bit of weight. (Laughter) Your numbers are a bit out. The standard numbers are that lifespans have been growing at between one and two years per decade. So, it's not quite as good as you might think, you might hope. But I intend to move it up to one year per year as soon as possible.Audience: I was told that many of the brain cells we have as adults are actually in the human embryo, and that the brain cells last 80 years or so. If that is indeed true, biologically are there implications in the world of rejuvenation? If there are cells in my body that live all 80 years, as opposed to a typical, you know, couple of months?AG: There are technical implications certainly. Basically what we need to do is replace cells in those few areas of the brain that lose cells at a respectable rate, especially neurons, but we don't want to replace them any faster than that — or not much faster anyway, because replacing them too fast would degrade cognitive function. What I said about there being no non-aging species earlier on was a little bit of an oversimplification. There are species that have no aging — Hydra for example — but they do it by not having a nervous system — and not having any tissues in fact that rely for their function on very long-lived cells.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
18 minutes is an absolutely brutal time limit,

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:15.958
so I'm going to dive straight in, right at the point

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:17.958
where I get this thing to work.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:19.958
Here we go. I'm going to talk about five different things.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
I'm going to talk about why defeating aging is desirable.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
I'm going to talk about why we have to get our shit together,

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
and actually talk about this a bit more than we do.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:28.958
I'm going to talk about feasibility as well, of course.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
I'm going to talk about why we are so fatalistic

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
about doing anything about aging.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
And then I'm going spend perhaps the second half of the talk

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:39.958
talking about, you know, how we might actually be able to prove that fatalism is wrong,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
namely, by actually doing something about it.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
I'm going to do that in two steps.

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
The first one I'm going to talk about is

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
how to get from a relatively modest amount of life extension --

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
which I'm going to define as 30 years, applied to people

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
who are already in middle-age when you start --

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:56.958
to a point which can genuinely be called defeating aging.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:01:00.958
Namely, essentially an elimination of the relationship between

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
how old you are and how likely you are to die in the next year --

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
or indeed, to get sick in the first place.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
And of course, the last thing I'm going to talk about

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
is how to reach that intermediate step,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
that point of maybe 30 years life extension.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
So I'm going to start with why we should.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
Now, I want to ask a question.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
Hands up: anyone in the audience who is in favor of malaria?

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:20.958
That was easy. OK.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
OK. Hands up: anyone in the audience

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
who's not sure whether malaria is a good thing or a bad thing?

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
OK. So we all think malaria is a bad thing.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
That's very good news, because I thought that was what the answer would be.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
Now the thing is, I would like to put it to you

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
that the main reason why we think that malaria is a bad thing

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:38.958
is because of a characteristic of malaria that it shares with aging.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
And here is that characteristic.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:46.958
The only real difference is that aging kills considerably more people than malaria does.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
Now, I like in an audience, in Britain especially,

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
to talk about the comparison with foxhunting,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
which is something that was banned after a long struggle,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
by the government not very many months ago.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
I mean, I know I'm with a sympathetic audience here,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
but, as we know, a lot of people are not entirely persuaded by this logic.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
And this is actually a rather good comparison, it seems to me.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
You know, a lot of people said, "Well, you know,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:11.958
city boys have no business telling us rural types what to do with our time.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
It's a traditional part of the way of life,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and we should be allowed to carry on doing it.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
It's ecologically sound; it stops the population explosion of foxes."

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
But ultimately, the government prevailed in the end,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:21.958
because the majority of the British public,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
and certainly the majority of members of Parliament,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
came to the conclusion that it was really something

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
that should not be tolerated in a civilized society.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:28.958
And I think that human aging shares

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
all of these characteristics in spades.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
What part of this do people not understand?

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
It's not just about life, of course --

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:36.958
(Laughter) --

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
it's about healthy life, you know --

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
getting frail and miserable and dependent is no fun,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
whether or not dying may be fun.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
So really, this is how I would like to describe it.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
It's a global trance.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
These are the sorts of unbelievable excuses

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
that people give for aging.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
And, I mean, OK, I'm not actually saying

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
that these excuses are completely valueless.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
There are some good points to be made here,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
things that we ought to be thinking about, forward planning

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
so that nothing goes too -- well, so that we minimize

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
the turbulence when we actually figure out how to fix aging.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
But these are completely crazy, when you actually

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
remember your sense of proportion.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:15.958
You know, these are arguments; these are things that

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
would be legitimate to be concerned about.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
But the question is, are they so dangerous --

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
these risks of doing something about aging --

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:26.958
that they outweigh the downside of doing the opposite,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
namely, leaving aging as it is?

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
Are these so bad that they outweigh

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:36.958
condemning 100,000 people a day to an unnecessarily early death?

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
You know, if you haven't got an argument that's that strong,

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
then just don't waste my time, is what I say.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:42.958
(Laughter)

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:43.958
Now, there is one argument

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
that some people do think really is that strong, and here it is.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
People worry about overpopulation; they say,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
"Well, if we fix aging, no one's going to die to speak of,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
or at least the death toll is going to be much lower,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
only from crossing St. Giles carelessly.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
And therefore, we're not going to be able to have many kids,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and kids are really important to most people."

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
And that's true.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
And you know, a lot of people try to fudge this question,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:04.958
and give answers like this.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
I don't agree with those answers. I think they basically don't work.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
I think it's true, that we will face a dilemma in this respect.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:14.958
We will have to decide whether to have a low birth rate,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
or a high death rate.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
A high death rate will, of course, arise from simply rejecting these therapies,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
in favor of carrying on having a lot of kids.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
And, I say that that's fine --

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
the future of humanity is entitled to make that choice.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
What's not fine is for us to make that choice on behalf of the future.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
If we vacillate, hesitate,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
and do not actually develop these therapies,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:41.958
then we are condemning a whole cohort of people --

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
who would have been young enough and healthy enough

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
to benefit from those therapies, but will not be,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
because we haven't developed them as quickly as we could --

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
we'll be denying those people an indefinite life span,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
and I consider that that is immoral.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
That's my answer to the overpopulation question.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Right. So the next thing is,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
now why should we get a little bit more active on this?

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
And the fundamental answer is that

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
the pro-aging trance is not as dumb as it looks.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:07.958
It's actually a sensible way of coping with the inevitability of aging.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:11.958
Aging is ghastly, but it's inevitable, so, you know,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
we've got to find some way to put it out of our minds,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:17.958
and it's rational to do anything that we might want to do, to do that.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
Like, for example, making up these ridiculous reasons

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
why aging is actually a good thing after all.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:26.958
But of course, that only works when we have both of these components.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
And as soon as the inevitability bit becomes a little bit unclear --

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
and we might be in range of doing something about aging --

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
this becomes part of the problem.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.958
This pro-aging trance is what stops us from agitating about these things.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
And that's why we have to really talk about this a lot --

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
evangelize, I will go so far as to say, quite a lot --

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
in order to get people's attention, and make people realize

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
that they are in a trance in this regard.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
So that's all I'm going to say about that.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
I'm now going to talk about feasibility.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And the fundamental reason, I think, why we feel that aging is inevitable

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
is summed up in a definition of aging that I'm giving here.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:01.958
A very simple definition.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
Aging is a side effect of being alive in the first place,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
which is to say, metabolism.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
This is not a completely tautological statement;

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:10.958
it's a reasonable statement.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
Aging is basically a process that happens to inanimate objects like cars,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
and it also happens to us,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
despite the fact that we have a lot of clever self-repair mechanisms,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
because those self-repair mechanisms are not perfect.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
So basically, metabolism, which is defined as

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
basically everything that keeps us alive from one day to the next,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
has side effects.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
Those side effects accumulate and eventually cause pathology.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
That's a fine definition. So we can put it this way:

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
we can say that, you know, we have this chain of events.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
And there are really two games in town,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
according to most people, with regard to postponing aging.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:43.958
They're what I'm calling here the "gerontology approach" and the "geriatrics approach."

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
The geriatrician will intervene late in the day,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
when pathology is becoming evident,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
and the geriatrician will try and hold back the sands of time,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
and stop the accumulation of side effects

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
from causing the pathology quite so soon.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Of course, it's a very short-term-ist strategy; it's a losing battle,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
because the things that are causing the pathology

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
are becoming more abundant as time goes on.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:07.958
The gerontology approach looks much more promising on the surface,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
because, you know, prevention is better than cure.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
But unfortunately the thing is that we don't understand metabolism very well.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
In fact, we have a pitifully poor understanding of how organisms work --

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
even cells we're not really too good on yet.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
We've discovered things like, for example,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
RNA interference only a few years ago,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and this is a really fundamental component of how cells work.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
Basically, gerontology is a fine approach in the end,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
but it is not an approach whose time has come

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
when we're talking about intervention.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
So then, what do we do about that?

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
I mean, that's a fine logic, that sounds pretty convincing,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
pretty ironclad, doesn't it?

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
But it isn't.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Before I tell you why it isn't, I'm going to go a little bit

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
into what I'm calling step two.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:50.958
Just suppose, as I said, that we do acquire --

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
let's say we do it today for the sake of argument --

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958
the ability to confer 30 extra years of healthy life

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
on people who are already in middle age, let's say 55.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
I'm going to call that "robust human rejuvenation." OK.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:03.958
What would that actually mean

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
for how long people of various ages today --

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
or equivalently, of various ages at the time that these therapies arrive --

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:11.958
would actually live?

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
In order to answer that question -- you might think it's simple,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:15.958
but it's not simple.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
We can't just say, "Well, if they're young enough to benefit from these therapies,

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:19.958
then they'll live 30 years longer."

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
That's the wrong answer.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
And the reason it's the wrong answer is because of progress.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
There are two sorts of technological progress really,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:26.958
for this purpose.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
There are fundamental, major breakthroughs,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and there are incremental refinements of those breakthroughs.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
Now, they differ a great deal

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
in terms of the predictability of time frames.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:39.958
Fundamental breakthroughs:

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
very hard to predict how long it's going to take

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:42.958
to make a fundamental breakthrough.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
It was a very long time ago that we decided that flying would be fun,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
and it took us until 1903 to actually work out how to do it.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
But after that, things were pretty steady and pretty uniform.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
I think this is a reasonable sequence of events that happened

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:59.958
in the progression of the technology of powered flight.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
We can think, really, that each one is sort of

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
beyond the imagination of the inventor of the previous one, if you like.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
The incremental advances have added up to something

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
which is not incremental anymore.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
This is the sort of thing you see after a fundamental breakthrough.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
And you see it in all sorts of technologies.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Computers: you can look at a more or less parallel time line,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:21.958
happening of course a bit later.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
You can look at medical care. I mean, hygiene, vaccines, antibiotics --

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
you know, the same sort of time frame.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
So I think that actually step two, that I called a step a moment ago,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:31.958
isn't a step at all.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
That in fact, the people who are young enough

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
to benefit from these first therapies

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
that give this moderate amount of life extension,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:42.958
even though those people are already middle-aged when the therapies arrive,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
will be at some sort of cusp.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
They will mostly survive long enough to receive improved treatments

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
that will give them a further 30 or maybe 50 years.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
In other words, they will be staying ahead of the game.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
The therapies will be improving faster than

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
the remaining imperfections in the therapies are catching up with us.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
This is a very important point for me to get across.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
Because, you know, most people, when they hear

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:09.958
that I predict that a lot of people alive today are going to live to 1,000 or more,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
they think that I'm saying that we're going to invent therapies in the next few decades

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
that are so thoroughly eliminating aging

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
that those therapies will let us live to 1,000 or more.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
I'm not saying that at all.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
I'm saying that the rate of improvement of those therapies

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:24.958
will be enough.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
They'll never be perfect, but we'll be able to fix the things

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
that 200-year-olds die of, before we have any 200-year-olds.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
And the same for 300 and 400 and so on.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
I decided to give this a little name,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:36.958
which is "longevity escape velocity."

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
(Laughter)

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Well, it seems to get the point across.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:47.958
So, these trajectories here are basically how we would expect people to live,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
in terms of remaining life expectancy,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
as measured by their health,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
for given ages that they were at the time that these therapies arrive.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
If you're already 100, or even if you're 80 --

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
and an average 80-year-old,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
we probably can't do a lot for you with these therapies,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
because you're too close to death's door

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:06.958
for the really initial, experimental therapies to be good enough for you.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:07.958
You won't be able to withstand them.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
But if you're only 50, then there's a chance

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
that you might be able to pull out of the dive and, you know --

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:13.958
(Laughter) --

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
eventually get through this

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
and start becoming biologically younger in a meaningful sense,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
in terms of your youthfulness, both physical and mental,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
and in terms of your risk of death from age-related causes.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
And of course, if you're a bit younger than that,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
then you're never really even going

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
to get near to being fragile enough to die of age-related causes.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:35.958
So this is a genuine conclusion that I come to, that the first 150-year-old --

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
we don't know how old that person is today,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
because we don't know how long it's going to take

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
to get these first-generation therapies.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
But irrespective of that age,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:47.958
I'm claiming that the first person to live to 1,000 --

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
subject of course, to, you know, global catastrophes --

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.958
is actually, probably, only about 10 years younger than the first 150-year-old.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
And that's quite a thought.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Alright, so finally I'm going to spend the rest of the talk,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
my last seven-and-a-half minutes, on step one;

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:07.958
namely, how do we actually get to this moderate amount of life extension

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
that will allow us to get to escape velocity?

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
And in order to do that, I need to talk about mice a little bit.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
I have a corresponding milestone to robust human rejuvenation.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
I'm calling it "robust mouse rejuvenation," not very imaginatively.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And this is what it is.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
I say we're going to take a long-lived strain of mouse,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
which basically means mice that live about three years on average.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
We do exactly nothing to them until they're already two years old.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
And then we do a whole bunch of stuff to them,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and with those therapies, we get them to live,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
on average, to their fifth birthday.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
So, in other words, we add two years --

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
we treble their remaining lifespan,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
starting from the point that we started the therapies.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
The question then is, what would that actually mean for the time frame

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
until we get to the milestone I talked about earlier for humans?

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Which we can now, as I've explained,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
equivalently call either robust human rejuvenation or longevity escape velocity.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Secondly, what does it mean for the public's perception

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
of how long it's going to take for us to get to those things,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
starting from the time we get the mice?

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
And thirdly, the question is, what will it do

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:04.958
to actually how much people want it?

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
And it seems to me that the first question

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:08.958
is entirely a biology question,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and it's extremely hard to answer.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
One has to be very speculative,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
and many of my colleagues would say that we should not do this speculation,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:19.958
that we should simply keep our counsel until we know more.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:20.958
I say that's nonsense.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
I say we absolutely are irresponsible if we stay silent on this.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
We need to give our best guess as to the time frame,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
in order to give people a sense of proportion

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
so that they can assess their priorities.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
So, I say that we have a 50/50 chance

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
of reaching this RHR milestone,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
robust human rejuvenation, within 15 years from the point

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
that we get to robust mouse rejuvenation.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
15 years from the robust mouse.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
The public's perception will probably be somewhat better than that.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
The public tends to underestimate how difficult scientific things are.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
So they'll probably think it's five years away.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
They'll be wrong, but that actually won't matter too much.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
And finally, of course, I think it's fair to say

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
that a large part of the reason why the public is so ambivalent about aging now

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
is the global trance I spoke about earlier, the coping strategy.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
That will be history at this point,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
because it will no longer be possible to believe that aging is inevitable in humans,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
since it's been postponed so very effectively in mice.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
So we're likely to end up with a very strong change in people's attitudes,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
and of course that has enormous implications.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
So in order to tell you now how we're going to get these mice,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
I'm going to add a little bit to my description of aging.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
I'm going to use this word "damage"

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:28.958
to denote these intermediate things that are caused by metabolism

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
and that eventually cause pathology.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
Because the critical thing about this

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
is that even though the damage only eventually causes pathology,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:39.958
the damage itself is caused ongoing-ly throughout life, starting before we're born.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
But it is not part of metabolism itself.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And this turns out to be useful.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
Because we can re-draw our original diagram this way.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
We can say that, fundamentally, the difference between gerontology and geriatrics

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
is that gerontology tries to inhibit the rate

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
at which metabolism lays down this damage.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
And I'm going to explain exactly what damage is

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
in concrete biological terms in a moment.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
And geriatricians try to hold back the sands of time

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
by stopping the damage converting into pathology.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
And the reason it's a losing battle

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
is because the damage is continuing to accumulate.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
So there's a third approach, if we look at it this way.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
We can call it the "engineering approach,"

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
and I claim that the engineering approach is within range.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
The engineering approach does not intervene in any processes.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
It does not intervene in this process or this one.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
And that's good because it means that it's not a losing battle,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
and it's something that we are within range of being able to do,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
because it doesn't involve improving on evolution.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
The engineering approach simply says,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:34.958
"Let's go and periodically repair all of these various types of damage --

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.958
not necessarily repair them completely, but repair them quite a lot,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
so that we keep the level of damage down below the threshold

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
that must exist, that causes it to be pathogenic."

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
We know that this threshold exists,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
because we don't get age-related diseases until we're in middle age,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
even though the damage has been accumulating since before we were born.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Why do I say that we're in range? Well, this is basically it.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
The point about this slide is actually the bottom.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
If we try to say which bits of metabolism are important for aging,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
we will be here all night, because basically all of metabolism

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
is important for aging in one way or another.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
This list is just for illustration; it is incomplete.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
The list on the right is also incomplete.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
It's a list of types of pathology that are age-related,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
and it's just an incomplete list.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
But I would like to claim to you that this list in the middle is actually complete --

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
this is the list of types of thing that qualify as damage,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
side effects of metabolism that cause pathology in the end,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
or that might cause pathology.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
And there are only seven of them.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
They're categories of things, of course, but there's only seven of them.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:39.958
Cell loss, mutations in chromosomes, mutations in the mitochondria and so on.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:44.958
First of all, I'd like to give you an argument for why that list is complete.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
Of course one can make a biological argument.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
One can say, "OK, what are we made of?"

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
We're made of cells and stuff between cells.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
What can damage accumulate in?

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
The answer is: long-lived molecules,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
because if a short-lived molecule undergoes damage, but then the molecule is destroyed --

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:02.958
like by a protein being destroyed by proteolysis -- then the damage is gone, too.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
It's got to be long-lived molecules.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
So, these seven things were all under discussion in gerontology a long time ago

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:11.958
and that is pretty good news, because it means that,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
you know, we've come a long way in biology in these 20 years,

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
so the fact that we haven't extended this list

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
is a pretty good indication that there's no extension to be done.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
However, it's better than that; we actually know how to fix them all,

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
in mice, in principle -- and what I mean by in principle is,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
we probably can actually implement these fixes within a decade.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:31.958
Some of them are partially implemented already, the ones at the top.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
I haven't got time to go through them at all, but

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:38.958
my conclusion is that, if we can actually get suitable funding for this,

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:42.958
then we can probably develop robust mouse rejuvenation in only 10 years,

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
but we do need to get serious about it.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:46.958
We do need to really start trying.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
So of course, there are some biologists in the audience,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
and I want to give some answers to some of the questions that you may have.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
You may have been dissatisfied with this talk,

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
but fundamentally you have to go and read this stuff.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
I've published a great deal on this;

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
I cite the experimental work on which my optimism is based,

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
and there's quite a lot of detail there.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
The detail is what makes me confident

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
of my rather aggressive time frames that I'm predicting here.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
So if you think that I'm wrong,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
you'd better damn well go and find out why you think I'm wrong.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
And of course the main thing is that you shouldn't trust people

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
who call themselves gerontologists because,

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:23.958
as with any radical departure from previous thinking within a particular field,

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:27.958
you know, you expect people in the mainstream to be a bit resistant

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
and not really to take it seriously.

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.958
So, you know, you've got to actually do your homework,

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:32.958
in order to understand whether this is true.

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:34.958
And we'll just end with a few things.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
One thing is, you know, you'll be hearing from a guy in the next session

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:41.958
who said some time ago that he could sequence the human genome in half no time,

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
and everyone said, "Well, it's obviously impossible."

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:44.958
And you know what happened.

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:48.958
So, you know, this does happen.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:50.958
We have various strategies -- there's the Methuselah Mouse Prize,

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
which is basically an incentive to innovate,

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
and to do what you think is going to work,

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:58.958
and you get money for it if you win.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:02.958
There's a proposal to actually put together an institute.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:04.958
This is what's going to take a bit of money.

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:07.958
But, I mean, look -- how long does it take to spend that on the war in Iraq?

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:08.958
Not very long. OK.

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:09.958
(Laughter)

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
It's got to be philanthropic, because profits distract biotech,

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:16.958
but it's basically got a 90 percent chance, I think, of succeeding in this.

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:19.958
And I think we know how to do it. And I'll stop there.

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:20.958
Thank you.

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:25.958
(Applause)

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
Chris Anderson: OK. I don't know if there's going to be any questions

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
but I thought I would give people the chance.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:34.958
Audience: Since you've been talking about aging and trying to defeat it,

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:38.958
why is it that you make yourself appear like an old man?

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:42.958
(Laughter)

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:45.958
AG: Because I am an old man. I am actually 158.

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:46.958
(Laughter)

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:49.958
(Applause)

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:53.958
Audience: Species on this planet have evolved with immune systems

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:57.958
to fight off all the diseases so that individuals live long enough to procreate.

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:02.958
However, as far as I know, all the species have evolved to actually die,

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:07.958
so when cells divide, the telomerase get shorter, and eventually species die.

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:12.958
So, why does -- evolution has -- seems to have selected against immortality,

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:16.958
when it is so advantageous, or is evolution just incomplete?

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:18.958
AG: Brilliant. Thank you for asking a question

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:20.958
that I can answer with an uncontroversial answer.

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:23.958
I'm going to tell you the genuine mainstream answer to your question,

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:25.958
which I happen to agree with,

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:28.958
which is that, no, aging is not a product of selection, evolution;

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:30.958
[aging] is simply a product of evolutionary neglect.

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:36.958
In other words, we have aging because it's hard work not to have aging;

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:38.958
you need more genetic pathways, more sophistication in your genes

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:40.958
in order to age more slowly,

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:43.958
and that carries on being true the longer you push it out.

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:48.958
So, to the extent that evolution doesn't matter,

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:50.958
doesn't care whether genes are passed on by individuals,

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:52.958
living a long time or by procreation,

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:55.958
there's a certain amount of modulation of that,

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:58.958
which is why different species have different lifespans,

00:20:58.958 --> 00:21:00.958
but that's why there are no immortal species.

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:03.958
CA: The genes don't care but we do?

00:21:03.958 --> 00:21:04.958
AG: That's right.

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:10.958
Audience: Hello. I read somewhere that in the last 20 years,

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:15.958
the average lifespan of basically anyone on the planet has grown by 10 years.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
If I project that, that would make me think

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:22.958
that I would live until 120 if I don't crash on my motorbike.

00:21:23.958 --> 00:21:28.958
That means that I'm one of your subjects to become a 1,000-year-old?

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:29.958
AG: If you lose a bit of weight.

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:33.958
(Laughter)

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
Your numbers are a bit out.

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:39.958
The standard numbers are that lifespans

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:42.958
have been growing at between one and two years per decade.

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:45.958
So, it's not quite as good as you might think, you might hope.

00:21:46.958 --> 00:21:48.958
But I intend to move it up to one year per year as soon as possible.

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:52.958
Audience: I was told that many of the brain cells we have as adults

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:53.958
are actually in the human embryo,

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:56.958
and that the brain cells last 80 years or so.

00:21:56.958 --> 00:21:58.958
If that is indeed true,

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:01.958
biologically are there implications in the world of rejuvenation?

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:04.958
If there are cells in my body that live all 80 years,

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:06.958
as opposed to a typical, you know, couple of months?

00:22:06.958 --> 00:22:08.958
AG: There are technical implications certainly.

00:22:08.958 --> 00:22:11.958
Basically what we need to do is replace cells

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:15.958
in those few areas of the brain that lose cells at a respectable rate,

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:18.958
especially neurons, but we don't want to replace them

00:22:18.958 --> 00:22:20.958
any faster than that -- or not much faster anyway,

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:24.958
because replacing them too fast would degrade cognitive function.

00:22:24.958 --> 00:22:27.958
What I said about there being no non-aging species earlier on

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:29.958
was a little bit of an oversimplification.

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:33.958
There are species that have no aging -- Hydra for example --

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:35.958
but they do it by not having a nervous system --

00:22:35.958 --> 00:22:37.958
and not having any tissues in fact that rely for their function

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:39.958
on very long-lived cells.

title: How mobile phones can fight poverty
transcript: I'll just take you to Bangladesh for a minute.Before I tell that story, we should ask ourselves the question: Why does poverty exist? I mean, there is plenty of knowledge and scientific breakthroughs. We all live in the same planet, but there's still a great deal of poverty in the world. And I think — so I want to throw a perspective that I have, so that we can assess this project, or any other project, for that matter, to see whether it's contributing or — contributing to poverty or trying to alleviate it.Rich countries have been sending aid to poor countries for the last 60 years. And by and large, this has failed. And you can see this book, written by someone who worked in the World Bank for 20 years, and he finds economic growth in this country to be elusive. By and large, it did not work. So the question is, why is that?In my mind, there is something to learn from the history of Europe. I mean, even here, yesterday I was walking across the street, and they showed three bishops were executed 500 years ago, right across the street from here. So my point is, there's a lot of struggle has gone in Europe, where citizens were empowered by technologies. And they demanded authorities from — to come down from their high horses. And in the end, there's better bargaining between the authorities and citizens, and democracies, capitalism — everything else flourished. And so you can see, the real process of — and this is backed up by this 500-page book — that the authorities came down and citizens got up.But if you look, if you have that perspective, then you can see what happened in the last 60 years. Aid actually did the opposite. It empowered authorities, and, as a result, marginalized citizens. The authorities did not have the reason to make economic growth happen so that they could tax people and make more money for to run their business. Because they were getting it from abroad. And in fact, if you see oil-rich countries, where citizens are not yet empowered, the same thing goes — Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, all sorts of countries. Because the aid and oil or mineral money acts the same way. It empowers authorities, without activating the citizens — their hands, legs, brains, what have you.And if you agree with that, then I think the best way to improve these countries is to recognize that economic development is of the people, by the people, for the people. And that is the real network effect. If citizens can network and make themselves more organized and productive, so that their voices are heard, so then things would improve.And to contrast that, you can see the most important institution in the world, the World Bank, is an organization of the government, by the government, for the governments. Just see the contrast. And that is the perspective I have, and then I can start my story.Of course, how would you empower citizens? There could be all sorts of technologies. And one is cell phones. Recently "The Economist" recognized this, but I stumbled upon the idea 12 years ago, and that's what I've been working on. So 12 years ago, I was trying to be an investment banker in New York.We had — quite a few our colleagues were connected by a computer network. And we got more productive because we didn't have to exchange floppy disks; we could update each other more often. But one time it broke down. And it reminded me of a day in 1971. There was a war going on in my country. And my family moved out of an urban place, where we used to live, to a remote rural area where it was safer. And one time my mother asked me to get some medicine for a younger sibling. And I walked 10 miles or so, all morning, to get there, to the medicine man. And he wasn't there, so I walked all afternoon back. So I had another unproductive day.So while I was sitting in a tall building in New York, I put those two experiences together side by side, and basically concluded that connectivity is productivity — whether it's in a modern office or an underdeveloped village. So naturally, I — the implication of that is that the telephone is a weapon against poverty. And if that's the case, then the question is how many telephones did we have at that time?And it turns out, that there was one telephone in Bangladesh for every 500 people. And all those phones were in the few urban places. The vast rural areas, where 100 million people lived, there were no telephones. So just imagine how many man-months or man-years are wasted, just like I wasted a day. If you just multiply by 100 million people, let's say losing one day a month, whatever, and you see a vast amount of resource wasted. And after all, poor countries, like rich countries, one thing we've got equal, is their days are the same length: 24 hours. So if you lose that precious resource, where you are somewhat equal to the richer countries, that's a huge waste.So I started looking for any evidence that — does connectivity really increase productivity? And I couldn't find much, really, but I found this graph produced by the ITU, which is the International Telecommunication Union, based in Geneva. They show an interesting thing. That you see, the horizontal axis is where you place your country. So the United States or the UK would be here, outside. And so the impact of one new telephone, which is on the vertical axis, is very little.But if you come back to a poorer country, where the GNP per capita is, let's say, 500 dollars, or 300 dollars, then the impact is huge: 6,000 dollars. Or 5,000 dollars. The question was, how much did it cost to install a new telephone in Bangladesh? It turns out: 2,000 dollars. So if you spend 2,000 dollars, and let's say the telephone lasts 10 years, and if 5,000 dollars every year — so that's 50,000 dollars.So obviously this was a gadget to have. And of course, if the cost of installing a telephone is going down, because there's a digital revolution going on, then it would be even more dramatic.And I knew a little economics by then — it says Adam Smith taught us that specialization leads to productivity. But how would you specialize? Let's say I'm a fisherman and a farmer. And Chris is a fisherman farmer. Both are generalists. So the point is that we could only — the only way we could depend on each other, is if we can connect with each other. And if we are neighbors, I could just walk over to his house.But then we are limiting our economic sphere to something very small area. But in order to expand that, you need a river, or you need a highway, or you need telephone lines. But in any event, it's connectivity that leads to dependability. And that leads to specialization. That leads to productivity.So the question was, I started looking at this issue, and going back and forth between Bangladesh and New York. There were a lot of reasons people told me why we don't have enough telephones. And one of them is the lacking buying power. Poor people apparently don't have the power to buy.But the point is, if it's a production tool, why do we have to worry about that? I mean, in America, people buy cars, and they put very little money down. They get a car, and they go to work. The work pays them a salary; the salary allows them to pay for the car over time. The car pays for itself.So if the telephone is a production tool, then we don't quite have to worry about the purchasing power. And of course, even if that's true, then what about initial buying power? So then the question is, why can't we have some kind of shared access? In the United States, we have — everybody needs a banking service, but very few of us are trying to buy a bank. So it's — a bank tends to serve a whole community. So we could do that for telephones.And also people told me that we have a lot of important primary needs to meet: food, clothing, shelter, whatever. But again, it's very paternalistic. You should be raising income and let people decide what they want to do with their money.But the real problem is the lack of other infrastructures.
