00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:40.958
that may actually get some traction out there and make a difference?

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:44.958
Inspired by nature -- that's the theme here.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:49.958
And I think, quite frankly, that's where I started.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:54.958
I became very interested in the landscape as a Canadian.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:57.958
We have this Great North. And there was a pretty small population,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
and my father was an avid outdoorsman.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
So I really had a chance to experience that.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:06.958
And I could never really understand exactly what it was, or how it was informing me.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
But what I think it was telling me

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:13.958
is that we are this transient thing that's happening,

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:17.958
and that the nature that you see out there -- the untouched shorelines,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
the untouched forest that I was able to see --

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:27.958
really bring in a sense of that geological time,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
that this has gone on for a long time,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
and we're experiencing it in a different way.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:38.958
And that, to me, was a reference point that I think I needed to have

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
to be able to make the work that I did.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:45.958
And I did go out, and I did this picture of grasses coming through in the spring,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
along a roadside.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
This rebirth of grass. And then I went out for years

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
trying to photograph the pristine landscape.

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
But as a fine-art photographer I somehow felt

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
that it wouldn't catch on out there,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:02.958
that there would be a problem with trying to make this as a fine-art career.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:07.958
And I kept being sucked into this genre of the calendar picture,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
or something of that nature, and I couldn't get away from it.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.958
So I started to think of, how can I rethink the landscape?

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
I decided to rethink the landscape

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
as the landscape that we've transformed.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
I had a bit of an epiphany being lost in Pennsylvania,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:24.958
and I took a left turn trying to get back to the highway.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
And I ended up in a town called Frackville.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
I got out of the car, and I stood up,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:32.958
and it was a coal-mining town. I did a 360 turnaround,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
and that became one of the most surreal landscapes I've ever seen.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
Totally transformed by man.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
And that got me to go out and look at mines like this,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
and go out and look at the largest industrial incursions

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
in the landscape that I could find.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
And that became the baseline of what I was doing.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:55.958
And it also became the theme that I felt that I could hold onto,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
and not have to re-invent myself --

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
that this theme was large enough to become a life's work,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:04.958
to become something that I could sink my teeth into

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
and just research and find out where these industries are.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
And I think one of the things I also wanted to say in my thanks,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
which I kind of missed,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
was to thank all the corporations who helped me get in.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:20.958
Because it took negotiation for almost every one of these photographs --

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
to get into that place to make those photographs,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
and if it wasn't for those people letting me in

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
at the heads of those corporations,

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
I would have never made this body of work.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:36.958
So in that respect, to me, I'm not against the corporation.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
I own a corporation. I work with them,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
and I feel that we all need them and they're important.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
But I am also for sustainability.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
So there's this thing that is pulling me in both directions.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And I'm not making an indictment towards what's happening here,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
but it is a slow progression.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
So I started thinking, well, we live in all these ages of man:

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:00.958
the Stone Age, and the Iron Age, and the Copper Age.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And these ages of man are still at work today.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
But we've become totally disconnected from them.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
There's something that we're not seeing there.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.958
And it's a scary thing as well. Because when we start looking

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
at the collective appetite for our lifestyles,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
and what we're doing to that landscape --

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:25.958
that, to me, is something that is a very sobering moment for me to contemplate.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
And through my photographs,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:33.958
I'm hoping to be able to engage the audiences of my work,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
and to come up to it and not immediately be rejected by the image.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
Not to say, "Oh my God, what is it?" but to be challenged by it --

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
to say, "Wow, this is beautiful," on one level,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:45.958
but on the other level, "This is scary. I shouldn't be enjoying it."

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
Like a forbidden pleasure. And it's that forbidden pleasure

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
that I think is what resonates out there,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
and it gets people to look at these things,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:59.958
and it gets people to enter it. And it also, in a way, defines kind of what I feel, too --

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
that I'm drawn to have a good life.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
I want a house, and I want a car.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
But there's this consequence out there.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
And how do I begin to have that attraction, repulsion?

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
It's even in my own conscience I'm having it,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
and here in my work, I'm trying to build that same toggle.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
These things that I photographed -- this tire pile here

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
had 45 million tires in it. It was the largest one.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
It was only about an hour-and-a-half away from me, and it caught fire

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:29.958
about four years ago. It's around Westley, California, around Modesto.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And I decided to start looking at something that, to me, had --

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
if the earlier work of looking at the landscape

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
had a sense of lament to what we were doing to nature,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
in the recycling work that you're seeing here

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.958
was starting to point to a direction. To me, it was our redemption.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
That in the recycling work that I was doing,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:54.958
I'm looking for a practice, a human activity that is sustainable.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:59.958
That if we keep putting things, through industrial and urban existence,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
back into the system --

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
if we keep doing that -- we can continue on.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
Of course, listening at the conference,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
there's many, many things that are coming. Bio-mimicry,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
and there's many other things that are coming on stream --

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:16.958
nanotechnology that may also prevent us from having

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
to go into that landscape and tear it apart.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
And we all look forward to those things.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
But in the meantime, these things are scaling up.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
These things are continuing to happen.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
What you're looking at here -- I went to Bangladesh,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
so I started to move away from North America;

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
I started to look at our world globally.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
These images of Bangladesh

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
came out of a radio program I was listening to.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
They were talking about Exxon Valdez,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
and that there was going to be a glut of oil tankers

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
because of the insurance industries.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
And that those oil tankers needed to be decommissioned,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
and 2004 was going to be the pinnacle.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
And I thought, "My God, wouldn't that be something?"

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
To see the largest vessels of man being deconstructed by hand,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
literally, in third-world countries.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
So originally I was going to go to India.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And I was shut out of India because of a Greenpeace situation there,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
and then I was able to get into Bangladesh,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:09.958
and saw for the first time a third world, a view of it,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
that I had never actually thought was possible.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
130 million people living in an area the size of Wisconsin --

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
people everywhere -- the pollution was intense,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
and the working conditions were horrible.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
Here you're looking at some oil fields in California,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:29.958
some of the biggest oil fields. And again, I started to think that --

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
there was another epiphany --

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
that the whole world I was living in was

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
a result of having plentiful oil.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And that, to me, was again something that I started building on,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
and I continued to build on.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:47.958
So this is a series I'm hoping to have ready

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
in about two or three years,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
under the heading of "The Oil Party."

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
Because I think everything that we're involved in --

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:57.958
our clothing, our cars, our roads, and everything -- are directly a result.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:02.958
I'm going to move to some pictures of China.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
And for me China -- I started photographing it four years ago,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
and China truly is a question of sustainability in my mind,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
not to mention that China, as well,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
has a great effect on the industries that I grew up around.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
I came out of a blue-collar town,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
a GM town, and my father worked at GM,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
so I was very familiar with that kind of industry

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:28.958
and that also informed my work. But you know,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:34.958
to see China and the scale at which it's evolving, is quite something.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
So what you see here is the Three Gorges Dam,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and this is the largest dam by 50 percent ever attempted by man.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
Most of the engineers around the world left the project

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
because they said, "It's just too big."

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
In fact, when it did actually fill with water a year and a half ago,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
they were able to measure a wobble within the earth as it was spinning.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
It took fifteen days to fill it.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:02.958
So this created a reservoir 600 kilometers long,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
one of the largest reservoirs ever created.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:09.958
And what was also one of the bigger projects around that

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
was moving 13 full-size cities up out of the reservoir,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
and flattening all the buildings so they could make way for the ships.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:20.958
This is a "before and after." So that was before.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
And this is like 10 weeks later, demolished by hand.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
I think 11 of the buildings they used dynamite,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
everything else was by hand. That was 10 weeks later.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
And this gives you an idea.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
And it was all the people who lived in those homes,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
were the ones that were actually taking it apart

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
and working, and getting paid per brick to take their cities apart.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
And these are some of the images from that.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
So I spent about three trips to the Three Gorges Dam,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
looking at that massive transformation of a landscape.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
And it looks like a bombed-out landscape, but it isn't.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
What it is, it's a landscape that is an intentional one.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:10:00.958
This is a need for power, and they're willing to go through this

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:07.958
massive transformation, on this scale, to get that power.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:13.958
And again, it's actually a relief for what's going on in China

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
because I think on the table right now,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
there's 27 nuclear power stations to be built.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
There hasn't been one built in North America for 20 years

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
because of the "NIMBY" problem -- "Not In My BackYard."

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
But in China they're saying, "No, we're putting in 27 in the next 10 years."

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:29.958
And coal-burning furnaces are going in there

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
for hydroelectric power literally weekly.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:37.958
So coal itself is probably one of the largest problems.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
And one of the other things that happened in the Three Gorges --

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:44.958
a lot of the agricultural land that you see there on the left was also lost;

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
some of the most fertile agricultural land was lost in that.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
And 1.2 to 2 million people were relocated,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
depending on whose statistics you're looking at.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
And this is what they were building.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
This is Wushan, one of the largest cities that was relocated.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
This is the town hall for the city.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:07.958
And again, the rebuilding of the city -- to me, it was sad to see

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
that they didn't really grab a lot of, I guess,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
what we know here, in terms of urban planning.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
There were no parks; there were no green spaces.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
Very high-density living on the side of a hill.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And here they had a chance to rebuild cities from the bottom up,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
but somehow were not connecting with them.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.958
Here is a sign that, translated, says, "Obey the birth control law.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:33.958
Build our science, civilized and advanced idea of marriage and giving birth."

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
So here, if you look at this poster,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
it has all the trappings of Western culture.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
You're seeing the tuxedos, the bouquets.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
But what's really, to me, frightening about the picture

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and about this billboard is the refinery in the background.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
So it's like marrying up all the things that we have

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and it's an adaptation of our way of life, full stop.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:04.958
And again, when you start seeing that kind of embrace,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and you start looking at them leading their rural lifestyle

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:13.958
with a very, very small footprint and moving into an urban lifestyle

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
with a much higher footprint, it starts to become very sobering.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
This is a shot in one of the biggest squares in Guangdong --

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:24.958
and this is where a lot of migrant workers are coming in from the country.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And there's about 130 million people in migration

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
trying to get into urban centers at all times,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:33.958
and in the next 10 to 15 years, are expecting

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
another 400 to 500 million people to migrate

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:41.958
into the urban centers like Shanghai and the manufacturing centers.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
The manufacturers are --

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:47.958
the domestics are usually -- you can tell a domestic factory by the fact

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
that they all use the same color uniforms.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
So this is a pink uniform at this factory. It's a shoe factory.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And they have dorms for the workers.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
So they bring them in from the country and put them up in the dorms.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
This is one of the biggest shoe factories, the Yuyuan shoe factory

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:07.958
near Shenzhen. It has 90,000 employees making shoes.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
This is a shift change, one of three.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
There's two factories of this scale in the same town.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
This is one with 45,000, so every lunch,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
there's about 12,000 coming through for lunch.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
They sit down; they have about 20 minutes.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
The next round comes in. It's an incredible workforce

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
that's building there. Shanghai --

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
I'm looking at the urban renewal in Shanghai,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
and this is a whole area that will be flattened

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:36.958
and turned into skyscrapers in the next five years.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
What's also happening in Shanghai is --

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
China is changing because this wouldn't have happened

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
five years ago, for instance. This is a holdout.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
They're called dengzahoos -- they're like pin tacks to the ground.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
They won't move. They're not negotiating.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
They're not getting enough, so they're not going to move.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And so they're holding off until they get a deal with them.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
And they've been actually quite successful in getting better deals

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
because most of them are getting a raw deal.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
They're being put out about two hours --

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
the communities that have been around for literally hundreds of years,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
or maybe even thousands of years,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
are being broken up and spread across in the suburban areas

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
outside of Shanghai. But these are a whole series of guys

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:18.958
holding out in this reconstruction of Shanghai.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
Probably the largest urban-renewal project, I think,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
ever attempted on the planet.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And then the embrace of the things that they're replacing it with --

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
again, one of my wishes, and I never ended up going there,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
was to somehow tell them that there were better ways to build a house.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:40.958
The kinds of collisions of styles and things were quite something,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and these are called the villas.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
And also, like right now, they're just moving.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
The scaffolding is still on, and this is an e-waste area,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and if you looked in the foreground on the big print,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
you'd see that the industry -- their industry -- they're all recycling.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
So the industry's already growing

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
around these new developments.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
This is a five-level bridge in Shanghai.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:09.958
Shanghai was a very intriguing city -- it's exploding on a level

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
that I don't think any city has experienced.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:18.958
In fact, even Shenzhen, the economic zone --

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:23.958
one of the first ones -- 15 years ago was about 100,000 people,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
and today it boasts about 10 to 11 million.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:31.958
So that gives you an idea of the kinds of migrations and the speed with which --

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
this is just the taxis being built by Volkswagen.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
There's 9,000 of them here,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
and they're being built for most of the big cities,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
Beijing and Shanghai, Shenzhen.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:51.958
And this isn't even the domestic car market; this is the taxi market.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:58.958
And what we would see here as a suburban development --

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
a similar thing, but they're all high-rises.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
So they'll put 20 or 40 up at a time,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
and they just go up in the same way

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:12.958
as a single-family dwelling would go up here in an area.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
And the density is quite incredible.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:22.958
And one of the things in this picture that I wanted to point out

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
is that when I saw these kinds of buildings,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
I was shocked to see

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:31.958
that they're not using a central air-conditioning system;

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
every window has an air conditioner in it.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:37.958
And I'm sure there are people here who probably

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
know better than I do about efficiencies,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
but I can't imagine that every apartment having its own air conditioner

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
is a very efficient way to cool a building on this scale.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
And when you start looking at that,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:52.958
and then you start factoring up into a city the size of Shanghai,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
it's literally a forest of skyscrapers.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:17:01.958
It's breathtaking, in terms of the speed at which this city is transforming.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
And you can see in the foreground of this picture,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
it's still one of the last areas that was being held up.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
Right now that's all cleared out -- this was done about eight months ago --

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
and high-rises are now going up into that central spot.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:20.958
So a skyscraper is built, literally, overnight in Shanghai.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
Most recently I went in, and I started looking

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
at some of the biggest industries in China.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.958
And this is Baosteel, right outside of Shanghai.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:35.958
This is the coal supply for the steel factory -- 18 square kilometers.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:42.958
It's an incredibly massive operation, I think 15,000 workers,

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:46.958
five cupolas, and the sixth one's coming in here.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:51.958
So they're building very large blast furnaces

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:55.958
to try to deal with the demand for steel in China.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:18:00.958
So this is three of the visible blast furnaces within that shot.

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:06.958
And again, looking at these images, there's this constant, like, haze that you're seeing.

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:11.958
This is going to show you, real time, an assembler. It's a circuit breaker.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:28.958
10 hours a day at this speed.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:44.958
I think one of the issues

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:50.958
that we here are facing with China,

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
is that they're using a lot of the latest production technology.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
In that one, there were 400 people that worked on the floor.

00:18:56.958 --> 00:19:01.958
And I asked the manager to point out five of your fastest producers,

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.958
and then I went and looked at each one of them for about 15 or 20 minutes,

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
and picked this one woman.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
And it was just lightning fast;

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:11.958
the way she was working was almost unbelievable.

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:14.958
But that is the trick that they've got right now,

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:17.958
that they're winning with, is that they're using

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:19.958
all the latest technologies and extrusion machines,

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:23.958
and bringing all the components into play,

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:26.958
but the assembly is where they're actually bringing in --

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:31.958
the country workers are very willing to work. They want to work.

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:35.958
There's a massive backlog of people wanting their jobs.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:38.958
That condition's going to be there for the next 10 to 15 years

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:41.958
if they realize what they want, which is, you know,

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:44.958
400 to 500 million more people coming into the cities.

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:47.958
In this particular case -- this is the assembly line that you saw;

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:48.958
this is a shot of it.

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:51.958
I had to use a very small aperture to get the depth of field.

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:56.958
I had to have them freeze for 10 seconds to get this shot.

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:59.958
It took me five fake tries

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:03.958
because they were just going. To slow them down was literally impossible.

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:06.958
They were just wound up doing these things all day long,

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:08.958
until the manager had to, with a stern voice, say,

00:20:08.958 --> 00:20:10.958
"Okay, everybody freeze."

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.958
It wasn't too bad,

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:19.958
but they're driven to produce these things at an incredible rate.

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:26.958
This is a textile mill doing synthetic silk, an oil byproduct.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:28.958
And what you're seeing here is,

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:32.958
again, one of the most state-of-the-art textile mills.

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:35.958
There are 500 of these machines; they're worth about 200,000 dollars each.

00:20:35.958 --> 00:20:37.958
So you have about 12 people running this,

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:40.958
and they're just inspecting it -- and they're just walking the lines.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:42.958
The machines are all running,

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:45.958
absolutely incredible to see what the scale of industries are.

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:50.958
And I started getting in further and further into the factories.

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:53.958
And that's a diptych. I do a lot of pairings

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:56.958
to try and get the sense of scale in these places.

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:58.958
This is a line where they get the threads

00:20:58.958 --> 00:21:00.958
and they wind the threads together,

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:04.958
pre-going into the textile mills.

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:06.958
Here's something that's far more labor-intensive,

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:08.958
which is the making of shoes.

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:13.958
This floor has about 1,500 workers on this floor.

00:21:13.958 --> 00:21:17.958
The company itself had about 10,000 employees,

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:20.958
and they're doing domestic shoes.

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:23.958
It was very hard to get into the international companies

00:21:23.958 --> 00:21:27.958
because I had to get permission from companies like Nike and Adidas,

00:21:27.958 --> 00:21:29.958
and that's very hard to get.

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:31.958
And they don't want to let me in.

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:33.958
But the domestic was much easier to do.

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
It just gives you a sense of, again -- and that's where,

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:39.958
really, the whole migration of jobs started going over to China

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:42.958
and making the shoes. Nike was one of the early ones.

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:47.958
It was such a high labor component to it

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:50.958
that it made a lot of sense to go after that labor market.

00:21:50.958 --> 00:21:54.958
This is a high-tech mobile phone: Bird mobile phone,

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:56.958
one of the largest mobile makers in China.

00:21:56.958 --> 00:21:59.958
I think mobile phone companies

00:21:59.958 --> 00:22:03.958
are popping up, literally, on a weekly basis,

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:07.958
and they have an explosive growth in mobile phones.

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:11.958
This is a textile where they're doing shirts --

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:14.958
Youngor, the biggest shirt factory and clothing factory in China.

00:22:14.958 --> 00:22:18.958
And this next shot here is one of the lunchrooms.

00:22:18.958 --> 00:22:20.958
Everything is very efficient.

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:22.958
While setting up this shot,

00:22:22.958 --> 00:22:28.958
people on average would spend eight to 10 minutes having a lunch.

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:32.958
This was one of the biggest factories I've ever seen.

00:22:32.958 --> 00:22:37.958
They make coffeemakers here, the biggest coffeemaker

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:41.958
and the biggest iron makers --

00:22:41.958 --> 00:22:43.958
they make 20 million of them in the world.

00:22:43.958 --> 00:22:48.958
There's 21,000 employees. This one factory -- and they had several of them --

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:50.958
is half a kilometer long.

00:22:50.958 --> 00:22:53.958
These are just recently shot -- I just came back about a month ago,

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:56.958
so you're the first ones to be seeing these,

00:22:56.958 --> 00:22:59.958
these new factory pictures I've taken.

00:22:59.958 --> 00:23:04.958
So it's taken me almost a year to gain access into these places.

00:23:05.958 --> 00:23:08.958
The other aspect of what's happening in China

00:23:08.958 --> 00:23:11.958
is that there's a real need for materials there.

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:14.958
So a lot of the recycled materials that are collected here

00:23:14.958 --> 00:23:17.958
are being recycled and taken to China by ships.

00:23:17.958 --> 00:23:21.958
That's cubed metal. This is armatures, electrical armatures,

00:23:21.958 --> 00:23:23.958
where they're getting the copper and the high-end steel

00:23:23.958 --> 00:23:28.958
from electrical motors out, and recycling them.

00:23:28.958 --> 00:23:31.958
This is certainly connected to California and Silicon Valley.

00:23:31.958 --> 00:23:34.958
But this is what happens to most of the computers.

00:23:34.958 --> 00:23:38.958
Fifty percent of the world's computers end up in China to be recycled.

00:23:38.958 --> 00:23:40.958
It's referred to as "e-waste" there.

00:23:40.958 --> 00:23:44.958
And it is a bit of a problem. The way they recycle the boards

00:23:44.958 --> 00:23:47.958
is that they actually use the coal briquettes,

00:23:47.958 --> 00:23:50.958
which are used all through China, but they heat up the boards,

00:23:50.958 --> 00:23:53.958
and with pairs of pliers they pull off all the components.

00:23:53.958 --> 00:23:56.958
They're trying to get all the valued metals out of those components.

00:23:56.958 --> 00:23:59.958
But the toxic smells -- when you come into a town

00:23:59.958 --> 00:24:02.958
that's actually doing this kind of burning of the boards,

00:24:02.958 --> 00:24:05.958
you can smell it a good five or 10 kilometers before you get there.

00:24:05.958 --> 00:24:08.958
Here's another operation. It's all cottage industries,

00:24:08.958 --> 00:24:13.958
so it's not big places -- it's all in people's front porches,

00:24:13.958 --> 00:24:19.958
in their backyards, even in their homes they're burning boards,

00:24:19.958 --> 00:24:22.958
if there's a concern for somebody coming by --

00:24:22.958 --> 00:24:25.958
because it is considered in China to be illegal, doing it,

00:24:25.958 --> 00:24:29.958
but they can't stop the product from coming in.

00:24:29.958 --> 00:24:32.958
This portrait -- I'm not usually known for portraits,

00:24:32.958 --> 00:24:36.958
but I couldn't resist this one, where she's been through Mao,

00:24:36.958 --> 00:24:38.958
and she's been through the Great Leap Forward,

00:24:38.958 --> 00:24:41.958
and the Cultural Revolution, and now she's sitting on her porch

00:24:41.958 --> 00:24:44.958
with this e-waste beside her. It's quite something.

00:24:44.958 --> 00:24:48.958
This is a road where it's been shored up by computer boards

00:24:48.958 --> 00:24:50.958
in one of the biggest towns where they're recycling.

00:24:51.958 --> 00:24:55.958
So that's the photographs that I wanted to show you.

00:24:55.958 --> 00:24:57.958
(Applause)

00:24:57.958 --> 00:24:59.958
I want to dedicate my wishes to my two girls.

00:24:59.958 --> 00:25:02.958
They've been sitting on my shoulder the whole time while I've been thinking.

00:25:02.958 --> 00:25:05.958
One's Megan, the one of the right, and Katja there.

00:25:05.958 --> 00:25:07.958
And to me the whole notion --

00:25:07.958 --> 00:25:09.958
the things I'm photographing are out of a great concern

00:25:09.958 --> 00:25:14.958
about the scale of our progress and what we call progress.

00:25:14.958 --> 00:25:17.958
And as much as there are great things around the corner --

00:25:17.958 --> 00:25:20.958
and it's palpable in this room --

00:25:20.958 --> 00:25:22.958
of all of the things that are just about to break

00:25:22.958 --> 00:25:25.958
that can solve so many problems,

00:25:25.958 --> 00:25:28.958
I'm really hoping that those things will spread around the world

00:25:28.958 --> 00:25:31.958
and will start to have a positive effect.

00:25:31.958 --> 00:25:33.958
And it isn't something that isn't just affecting our world,

00:25:33.958 --> 00:25:36.958
but it starts to go up -- because I think we can start correcting

00:25:36.958 --> 00:25:41.958
our footprint and bring it down -- but there's a growing footprint

00:25:41.958 --> 00:25:45.958
that's happening in Asia, and is growing at a rapid, rapid rate,

00:25:45.958 --> 00:25:50.958
and so I don't think we can equalize it. So ultimately the strategy,

00:25:50.958 --> 00:25:54.958
I think, here is that we have to be very concerned about their evolution,

00:25:54.958 --> 00:25:58.958
because it is going to be connected to our evolution as well.

00:25:58.958 --> 00:26:01.958
So part of my thinking, and part of my wishes,

00:26:01.958 --> 00:26:04.958
is sitting with these thoughts in mind,

00:26:04.958 --> 00:26:06.958
and thinking about,

00:26:06.958 --> 00:26:09.958
"How is their life going to be when they want to have children,

00:26:09.958 --> 00:26:12.958
or when they're ready to get married 20 years from now -- or whatever,

00:26:12.958 --> 00:26:14.958
15 years from now?"

00:26:14.958 --> 00:26:17.958
And to me that has been the core behind most of my thinking --

00:26:17.958 --> 00:26:25.958
in my work, and also for this incredible chance to have some wishes.

00:26:25.958 --> 00:26:29.958
Wish one: world-changing. I want to use my images

00:26:29.958 --> 00:26:34.958
to persuade millions of people to join in the global conversation on sustainability.

00:26:34.958 --> 00:26:37.958
And it is through communications today

00:26:37.958 --> 00:26:41.958
that I believe that that is not an unreal idea.

00:26:41.958 --> 00:26:45.958
Oh, and I went in search -- I wanted to put what I had in mind,

00:26:45.958 --> 00:26:49.958
hitch it onto something. I didn't want a wish just to start from nowhere.

00:26:49.958 --> 00:26:52.958
One of them I'm starting from almost nothing, but the other one,

00:26:52.958 --> 00:26:55.958
I wanted to find out what's going on that's working right now.

00:26:55.958 --> 00:27:03.958
And Worldchanging.com is a fantastic blog, and that blog

00:27:03.958 --> 00:27:08.958
is now being visited by close to half-a-million people a month.

00:27:08.958 --> 00:27:13.958
And it just started about 14 months ago.

00:27:13.958 --> 00:27:15.958
And the beauty of what's going on there

00:27:15.958 --> 00:27:21.958
is that the tone of the conversation is the tone that I like.

00:27:21.958 --> 00:27:24.958
What they're doing there is that they're not --

00:27:24.958 --> 00:27:27.958
I think the environmental movement has failed

00:27:27.958 --> 00:27:29.958
in that it's used the stick too much;

00:27:29.958 --> 00:27:32.958
it's used the apocalyptic tone too much;

00:27:32.958 --> 00:27:37.958
it hasn't sold the positive aspects of

00:27:37.958 --> 00:27:40.958
being environmentally concerned and trying to pull us out.

00:27:40.958 --> 00:27:43.958
Whereas this conversation that is going on in this blog

00:27:43.958 --> 00:27:46.958
is about positive movements,

00:27:46.958 --> 00:27:49.958
about how to change our world in a better way, quickly.

00:27:49.958 --> 00:27:54.958
And it's looking at technology, and it's looking at new energy-saving devices,

00:27:54.958 --> 00:27:58.958
and it's looking at how to rethink and how to re-strategize

00:27:58.958 --> 00:28:01.958
the movement towards sustainability.

00:28:01.958 --> 00:28:05.958
And so for me, one of the things that I thought

00:28:05.958 --> 00:28:11.958
would be to put some of my work in the service of promoting

00:28:11.958 --> 00:28:14.958
the Worldchanging.com website.

00:28:14.958 --> 00:28:19.958
Some of you might know, he's a TEDster -- Stephen Sagmeister and I

00:28:19.958 --> 00:28:23.958
are working on some layouts. And this is still in preliminary stages;

00:28:23.958 --> 00:28:29.958
these aren't the finals. But these images, with Worldchanging.com,

00:28:29.958 --> 00:28:31.958
can be placed into any kind of media.

00:28:31.958 --> 00:28:34.958
They could be posted through the Web;

00:28:34.958 --> 00:28:41.958
they could be used as a billboard or a bus shelter, or anything of that nature.

00:28:41.958 --> 00:28:45.958
So we're looking at this as trying to build out.

00:28:45.958 --> 00:28:47.958
And what we ended up discussing

00:28:47.958 --> 00:28:52.958
was that in most media you get mostly an image with a lot of text,

00:28:52.958 --> 00:28:54.958
and the text is blasted all over.

00:28:54.958 --> 00:28:56.958
What was unusual, according to Stephen,

00:28:56.958 --> 00:29:01.958
is less than five percent of ads are actually leading with image.

00:29:01.958 --> 00:29:03.958
And so in this case,

00:29:03.958 --> 00:29:06.958
because it's about a lot of these images and what they represent,

00:29:06.958 --> 00:29:08.958
and the kinds of questions they bring up,

00:29:08.958 --> 00:29:13.958
that we thought letting the images play out and bring someone to say,

00:29:13.958 --> 00:29:18.958
"Well, what's Worldchanging.com, with these images, have to do?"

00:29:18.958 --> 00:29:22.958
And hopefully inspire people to go to that website.

00:29:22.958 --> 00:29:26.958
So Worldchanging.com, and building that blog, and it is a blog,

00:29:26.958 --> 00:29:29.958
and I'm hoping that it isn't -- I don't see it as the kind of blog

00:29:29.958 --> 00:29:31.958
where we're all going to follow each other to death.

00:29:31.958 --> 00:29:34.958
This one is one that will spoke out, and will go out,

00:29:34.958 --> 00:29:37.958
and to start reaching. Because right now there's conversations

00:29:37.958 --> 00:29:39.958
in India, in China, in South America --

00:29:39.958 --> 00:29:42.958
there's entries coming from all around the world.

00:29:42.958 --> 00:29:45.958
I think there's a chance to have a dialogue, a conversation

00:29:45.958 --> 00:29:48.958
about sustainability at Worldchanging.com.

00:29:48.958 --> 00:29:53.958
And anything that you can do to promote that would be fantastic.

00:29:53.958 --> 00:29:56.958
Wish two is more of the bottom-up, ground-up one that I'm trying to work with.

00:29:56.958 --> 00:30:00.958
And this one is: I wish to launch a groundbreaking competition

00:30:00.958 --> 00:30:07.958
that motivates kids to invest ideas on, and invent ideas on, sustainability.

00:30:07.958 --> 00:30:09.958
And one of the things that came out --

00:30:09.958 --> 00:30:12.958
Allison, who actually nominated me, said something earlier on

00:30:12.958 --> 00:30:15.958
in a brainstorming. She said that recycling in Canada

00:30:15.958 --> 00:30:23.958
had a fantastic entry into our psyche through kids between grade four and six.

00:30:23.958 --> 00:30:25.958
And you think about it, you know,

00:30:25.958 --> 00:30:29.958
grade four -- my wife and I, we say age seven is the age of reason,

00:30:29.958 --> 00:30:33.958
so they're into the age of reason. And they're pre-puberty.

00:30:33.958 --> 00:30:35.958
So it's this great window where they actually are --

00:30:35.958 --> 00:30:38.958
you can influence them. You know what happens at puberty?

00:30:38.958 --> 00:30:41.958
You know, we know that from earlier presentations.

00:30:41.958 --> 00:30:48.958
So my thinking here is that we try to motivate those kids

00:30:48.958 --> 00:30:52.958
to start driving home ideas. Let them understand what sustainability is,

00:30:52.958 --> 00:30:54.958
and that they have a vested interest in it to happen.

00:30:54.958 --> 00:30:59.958
And one of the ways I thought of doing it is to use my prize,

00:30:59.958 --> 00:31:03.958
so I would take 30,000 or 40,000 dollars of the winnings,

00:31:03.958 --> 00:31:05.958
and the rest is going to be to manage this project,

00:31:05.958 --> 00:31:08.958
but to use that as prizes for kids to get into their hands.

00:31:08.958 --> 00:31:10.958
But the other thing that I thought would be fantastic

00:31:10.958 --> 00:31:14.958
was to create these -- call them "prize targets."

00:31:14.958 --> 00:31:18.958
And so one could be for the best sustainable idea

00:31:18.958 --> 00:31:23.958
for an in-school project, the best one for a household project,

00:31:23.958 --> 00:31:26.958
or it could be the best community project for sustainability.

00:31:26.958 --> 00:31:29.958
And I also thought there should be a nice prize

00:31:29.958 --> 00:31:33.958
for the best artwork for "In My World." And what would happen --

00:31:33.958 --> 00:31:38.958
it's a scalable thing. And if we can get people to put in things --

00:31:38.958 --> 00:31:40.958
whether it's equipment, like a media lab,

00:31:40.958 --> 00:31:42.958
or money to make the prize significant enough --

00:31:42.958 --> 00:31:47.958
and to open it up to all the schools that are public schools,

00:31:47.958 --> 00:31:49.958
or schools that are with kids that age,

00:31:49.958 --> 00:31:52.958
and make it a wide-open competition for them

00:31:52.958 --> 00:31:54.958
to go after those prizes and to submit them.

00:31:54.958 --> 00:31:59.958
And the prize has to be a verifiable thing, so it's not about just ideas.

00:31:59.958 --> 00:32:02.958
The art pieces are about the ideas and how they present them

00:32:02.958 --> 00:32:05.958
and do them, but the actual things have to be verifiable.

00:32:05.958 --> 00:32:07.958
In that way, what's happening is that

00:32:07.958 --> 00:32:10.958
we're motivating a certain age group to start thinking.

00:32:10.958 --> 00:32:15.958
And they're going to push that up, from the bottom -- up into,

00:32:15.958 --> 00:32:19.958
I believe, into the households. And parents will be reacting to it,

00:32:19.958 --> 00:32:21.958
and trying to help them with the projects.

00:32:21.958 --> 00:32:25.958
And I think it starts to motivate the whole idea towards sustainability

00:32:25.958 --> 00:32:27.958
in a very positive way,

00:32:27.958 --> 00:32:30.958
and starts to teach them. They know about recycling now,

00:32:30.958 --> 00:32:33.958
but they don't really, I think, get sustainability in all the things,

00:32:33.958 --> 00:32:36.958
and the energy footprint, and how that matters.

00:32:36.958 --> 00:32:40.958
And to teach them, to me, would be a fantastic wish,

00:32:40.958 --> 00:32:44.958
and it would be something that I would certainly put my shoulder into.

00:32:45.958 --> 00:32:47.958
And again, in "In My World," the competition --

00:32:47.958 --> 00:32:51.958
we would use the artwork that comes in from that competition to promote it.

00:32:51.958 --> 00:32:53.958
And I like the words, "in my world,"

00:32:53.958 --> 00:32:56.958
because it gives possession of the world to the person who's doing it.

00:32:56.958 --> 00:32:59.958
It is my world; it's not someone else's. I want to help it;

00:32:59.958 --> 00:33:04.958
I want to do something with it. So I think it has a great opportunity

00:33:04.958 --> 00:33:09.958
to engage the imaginations -- and great ideas, I think, come from kids --

00:33:09.958 --> 00:33:11.958
and engage their imagination into a project,

00:33:11.958 --> 00:33:13.958
and do something for schools.

00:33:13.958 --> 00:33:16.958
I think all schools could use extra equipment, extra cash --

00:33:16.958 --> 00:33:20.958
it's going to be an incentive for them to do that.

00:33:20.958 --> 00:33:23.958
And these are some of the ideas in terms of where

00:33:23.958 --> 00:33:29.958
we could possibly put in some promotion for "In My World."

00:33:29.958 --> 00:33:35.958
And wish three is: Imax film. So I was told I should do one for myself,

00:33:35.958 --> 00:33:39.958
and I've always wanted to actually get involved with doing something.

00:33:39.958 --> 00:33:42.958
And the scale of my work, and the kinds of ideas I'm playing with --

00:33:42.958 --> 00:33:45.958
when I first saw an Imax film, I almost immediately thought,

00:33:45.958 --> 00:33:47.958
"There's a real resonance between what I'm trying to do

00:33:47.958 --> 00:33:50.958
and the scale of what I try to do as a photographer."

00:33:50.958 --> 00:33:54.958
And I think there's a real possibility

00:33:54.958 --> 00:33:56.958
to reach new audiences if I had a chance.

00:33:56.958 --> 00:34:00.958
So I'm looking, really, for a mentor, because I just had my birthday.

00:34:00.958 --> 00:34:03.958
I'm 50, and I don't have time to go back to school right now --

00:34:03.958 --> 00:34:05.958
I'm too busy. So I need somebody

00:34:05.958 --> 00:34:10.958
who can put me on a quick catch-up course on how to do something like that,

00:34:10.958 --> 00:34:14.958
and lead me through the maze of how one does something like this.

00:34:14.958 --> 00:34:17.958
That would be fantastic. So those are my three wishes.

00:34:17.958 --> 00:34:18.958
(Applause)

title: My wish: Three unusual medical inventions
transcript: I'm going to discuss with you three of my inventions that can have an effect on 10 to a 100 million people, which we will hope to see happen. We discussed, in the prior film, some of the old things that we did, like stents and insulin pumps for the diabetic. And I'd like to talk very briefly about three new inventions that will change the lives of many people.At the present time, it takes an average of three hours after the first symptoms of a heart attack are recognized by the patient, before that patient arrives at an emergency room. And people with silent ischemia — which, translated into English, means they don't have any symptoms — it takes even longer for them to get to the hospital. The AMI, Acute Myocardial Infarction, which is a doctor's big word so they can charge you more money — (Laughter) — means a heart attack. Annual incidence: 1.2 million Americans. Mortality: 300,000 people dying each year. About half of them, 600,000, have permanent damage to their heart that will cause them to have very bad problems later on. Thus 900,000 people either have died or have significant damage to their heart muscle. Symptoms are often denied by the patient, particularly us men, because we are very brave. We are very brave, and we don't want to admit that I'm having a hell of a chest pain. Then, approximately 25 percent of all patients never have any symptoms. What are we going to do about them? How can we save their lives? It's particularly true of diabetics and elderly women.Well, what is needed for the earliest possible warning of a heart attack? A means to determine if there's a complete blockage of a coronary artery. That, ladies and gentlemen, is a heart attack. The means consist of noting something a little technical, ST segment elevation of the electrogram — translated into English, that means that if there's an electrical signal in the heart, and one part of the ECG — which we call the ST segment — elevates, that is a sure sign of a heart attack. And if we had a computer put into the body of a person who's at risk, we could know, before they even have symptoms, that they're having a heart attack, to save their life. Well, the doctor can program a level of this ST elevation voltage that will trigger an emergency alarm, vibration like your cell phone, but right by your clavicle bone. And when it goes beep, beep, beep, you better do something about it, because if you want to live you have to get to some medical treatment.So we have to try these devices out because the FDA won't just let us use them on people unless we try it out first, and the best model for this happens to be pigs. And what we tried with the pig was external electrodes on the skin, like you see in an emergency room, and I'm going to show you why they don't work very well. And then we put a lead, which is a wire, in the right ventricle inside the heart, which does the electrogram, which is the signal voltage from inside the heart. Well, with the pig, at the baseline, before we blocked the pig's artery to simulate a heart attack, that was the signal. After 43 seconds, even an expert couldn't tell the difference, and after three minutes — well, if you really studied it, you'd see a difference. But what happened when we looked inside the pig's heart, to the electrogram?There was the baseline — first of all, a much bigger and more reliable signal. Second of all, I'll bet even you people who are untrained can see the difference, and we see here an ST segment elevation right after this sharp line. Look at the difference there. It doesn't take much — every layperson could see that difference, and computers can be programmed to easily detect it. Then, look at that after three minutes. We see that the signal that's actually in the heart, we can use it to tell people that they're having a heart attack even before they have symptoms so we can save their life.Then we tried it with my son, Dr. Tim Fischell, we tried it on some human patients who had to have a stent put in. Well, he kept the balloon filled to block the artery, to simulate a blockage, which is what a heart attack is. And it's not hard to see that — the baseline is the first picture on the upper left. Next to it, at 30 seconds, you see this rise here, then this rise — that's the ST elevation. And if we had a computer that could detect it, we could tell you you're having a heart attack so early it could save your life and prevent congestive heart failure. And then he did it again. We filled the balloon again a few minutes later and here you see, even after 10 seconds, a great rise in this piece, which we can have computers inside, under your chest like a pacemaker, with a wire into your heart like a pacemaker. And computers don't go to sleep. We have a little battery and on this little battery that computer will run for five years without needing replacement.What does the system look like? Well, on the left is the IMD, which is Implantable Medical Device, and tonight in the tent you can see it — they've exhibited it. It's about this big, the size of a pacemaker. It's implanted with very conventional techniques. And the EXD is an External Device that you can have on your night table. It'll wake you up and tell you to get your tail to the emergency room when the thing goes off because, if you don't, you're in deep doo-doo. And then, finally, a programmer that will set the level of the stimulation, which is the level which says you are having a heart attack.The FDA says, OK, test this final device after it's built in some animal, which we said is a pig, so we had to get this pig to have a heart attack. And when you go to the farmyard, you can't easily get pigs to have heart attacks, so we said, well, we're experts in stents. Tonight you'll see some of our invented stents. We said, so we'll put in a stent, but we're not going to put in a stent that we'd put in people. We're putting in a copper stent, and this copper stent erodes the artery and causes heart attacks. That's not very nice, but, after all, we had to find out what the answer is. So we took two copper stents and we put it in the artery of this pig, and let me show you the result that's very gratifying as far as people who have heart disease are concerned.So there it was, Thursday morning we stopped the pig's medication and there is his electrogram, the signal from inside the pig's heart coming out by radio telemetry. Then, on Friday at 6:43, he began to get certain signs, which later we had the pig run around — I'm not going to go into this early stage. But look what happened at 10:06 after we removed this pig's medication that kept him from having a heart attack. Any one of you now is an expert on ST elevation. Can you see it there? Can you see it in the picture after the big rise of the QRS — you see ST elevation? This pig at 10:06 was having a heart attack. What happens after you have the heart attack, this blockage? Your rhythm becomes irregular, and that's what happened 45 minutes later. Then, ventricular fibrillation, the heart quivers instead of beats — this is just before death of the pig — and then the pig died; it went flat-line. But we had a little bit over an hour where we could've saved this pig's life. Well, because of the FDA, we didn't save the pig's life, because we need to do this type of animal research for humans. But when it comes to the sake of a human, we can save their life. We can save the lives of people who are at high risk for a heart attack.What is the response to acute myocardial infarction, a heart attack, today? Well, you feel some chest pain or indigestion. It's not all that bad; you decide not to do anything. Several hours pass and it gets worse, and even the man won't ignore it. Finally, you go to the emergency room. You wait as burns and other critical patients are treated, because 75 percent of the patients who go to an emergency room with chest pains don't have AMI, so you're not taken very seriously. They finally see you. It takes more time to get your electrocardiogram on your skin and diagnose it, and it's hard to do because they don't have the baseline data, which the computer we put in you gets. Finally, if you're lucky, you are treated in three or four hours after the incident, but the heart muscle has died. And that is the typical treatment in the advanced world — not Africa — that's the typical treatment in the advanced world today.So we developed the AngelMed Guardian System and we have a device inside this patient, called the Implanted AngelMed Guardian. And when you have a blockage, the alarm goes off and it sends the alarm and the electrogram to an external device, which gets your baseline electrogram from 24 hours ago and the one that caused the alarm, so you can take it to the emergency room and show them, and say, take care of me right away. Then it goes to a network operations center, where they get your data from your patient database that's been put in at some central location, say, in the United States. Then it goes to a diagnostic center, and within one minute of your heart attack, your signal appears on the screen of a computer and the computer analyzes what your problem is. And the person who's there, the medical practitioner, calls you — this is also a cell phone — and says, "Mr. Smith, you're in deep doo-doo; you have a problem. We've called the ambulance. The ambulance is on the way. It'll pick you up, and then we're going to call your doctor, tell him about it. We're going to send him the signal that we have, that says you have a heart attack, and we're going to send the signal to the hospital and we're going to have it analyzed there, and there you're going to be with your doctor and you'll be taken care of so you won't die of a heart attack." That's the first invention that I wanted to describe. (Applause)And now I want to talk about something entirely different. At first I didn't think migraine headaches were a big problem because I'd never had a migraine headache, but then I spoke to some people who have three or four every week of their life, and their lives are being totally ruined by it. We have a mission statement for our company doing migraine, which is, "Prevent or ameliorate migraine headaches by the application of a safe, controlled magnetic pulse applied, as needed, by the patient." Now, you're probably very few physicists here. If you're a physicist you'd know there's a certain Faraday's Law, which says if I apply a magnetic pulse on salt water — that's your brains by the way — it'll generate electric currents, and the electric current in the brain can erase a migraine headache. That's what we have discovered.So here's a picture of what we're doing. The patients who have a migraine preceded by an aura have a band of excited neurons — that's shown in red — that moves at three to five millimeters a minute towards the mid-brain. And when it hits the mid-brain, that's when the headache begins. There's this migraine that is preceded by a visual aura, and this visual aura, by the way — and I'll show you a picture — but it sort of begins with little dancing lights, gets bigger and bigger until it fills your whole visual field. And what we tried was this; here is a device called the Cadwell Model MES10. Weighs about 70 pounds, has a wire about an inch in diameter. And here's one of the patients who has an aura and always has a headache, bad one, after the aura. What do we do?This is what an aura looks like. It's sort of funny dancing lights, shown there on the left and right side. And that's a fully developed visual aura, as we see on top. In the middle, our experimentalist, the neurologist, who said, "I'm going to move this down a little and I'm going to erase half your aura." And, by God, the neurologist did erase it, and that's the middle picture: half of the aura erased by a short magnetic pulse. What does that mean? That means that the magnetic pulse is generating an electric current that's interfering with the erroneous electrical activity in the brain. And finally he says, "OK, now I'm going to — " all of the aura get erased with an appropriately placed magnetic pulse.What is the result? We designed a magnetic depolarizer that looks like this, that you could have — a lady, in her pocket book — and when you get an aura you can try it and see how it works. Well, the next thing they have to show is what was on ABC News, Channel 7, last week in New York City, in the 11 o'clock news.Anchor: For anyone who suffers from migraine headaches — and there are 30 million Americans who do — tonight: a possible answer. Eyewitness news reporter Stacy Sager tonight, with a small and portable machine that literally zaps your migraines away. Christina Sidebottom: Well, my first reaction was that it was — looked awfully gun-like, and it was very strange. Stacy Sager: But for Christina Sidebottom, almost anything was worth trying if it could stop a migraine. It may look silly or even frightening as you walk around with it in your purse, but researchers here in Ohio organizing clinical trials for this migraine zapper, say it is scientifically sound — that, in fact, when the average person gets a migraine, it's caused by something similar to an electrical impulse. The zapper creates a magnetic field to counteract that. Yousef Mohammed: In other words, we're treating electricity with electricity, rather than treating electricity with the chemicals that we're using nowadays. SS: But is it safe to use everyday? Experts say the research has actually been around for more than a decade, and more long-term studies need to be done. Christina now swears by it. CS: It's been the most wonderful thing for my migraine. SS: Researchers are hoping to present their studies to the FDA this summer.Robert Fischell: And that is the invention to treat migraines. (Applause) You see, the problem is, 30 million Americans have migraine headaches, and we need a means to treat it, and I think that we now have it. And this is the first device that we did, and I'm going to talk about my second wish, which has something to do with this. Our conclusions from our studies so far, at three research centers, is there is a marked improvement in pain levels after using it just once. The most severe headaches responded better after we did it several times, and the unexpected finding indicates that even established headaches, not only those with aura, get treated and get diminished. And auras can be erased and the migraine, then, does not occur. And that is the migraine invention that we are talking about and that we are working on. (Applause)The third and last invention began with an idea. Epilepsy can best be treated by responsive electrical stimulation. Now, why do we use — add on, nearly, an epileptic focus? Now, unfortunately, us technical people, unlike Mr. Bono, have to get into all these technical words. Well, "responsive electrical stimulation" means that we sense, at a place in your brain which is called an "epileptic focus," which is where the epileptic seizure begins — we sense there, that it's going to happen, and then we respond by applying an electrical energy at that spot, which erases the errant signal so that you don't get the clinical manifestations of the migraine headache. We use current pacemaker defibrillator technology that's used for the heart. We thought we could adapt it for the brain. The device could be implanted under the scalp to be totally hidden and avoid wire breakage, which occurs if you put it in the chest and you try to move your neck around. Form a company to develop a neuro-pacemaker for epilepsy, as well as other diseases of the brain, because all diseases of the brain are a result of some electrical malfunction in it, that causes many, if not all, of brain disorders.We formed a company called NeuroPace and we started work on responsive neurostimulation, and this is a picture of what the device looked like, that's placed into the cranial bone. This is probably a better picture. Here we have our device in which we put in a frame. There's a cut made in the scalp; it's opened; the neurosurgeon has a template; he marks it around, and uses a dental burr to remove a piece of the cranial bone exactly the size of our device. And tonight, you'll be able to see the device in the tent. And then with four screws, we put in a frame, then we snap in the device and we run with wires — the one shown in green will go to the surface of the brain with electrodes, to the epileptic focus, the origin of the epilepsy, where we can sense the electrical signal and have computer analysis that tells us when to hit it with some electrical current to prevent the clinical manifestation of the seizure. In the blue wire, we see what's called a deep brain electrode. If that's the source of the epilepsy, we can attack that as well.The comprehensive solution: this is the device; it's about one inches by two inches and, oddly enough, just the thickness of most cranial bones. The advantages of responsive neurostimulation: It can detect and terminate seizures before the clinical symptoms occur, provide stimulation only when needed, can be turned off if seizures disappear; it has minimal side effects — as a matter of fact, in all our clinical trials to date, we've seen no side effects in the 40 or so patients in whom it's been implanted — and it's invisible, cosmetically hidden, so, if you have epilepsy and you have the device, no one will know it because you can't tell that it's there. And this shows what an electroencephalogram is, and on the left is the signal of a spontaneous seizure of one of the patients. Then we stimulated, and you see how that heavy black line and then you see the electroencephalogram signal going to normal, which means they did not get the epileptic seizure. That concludes my discussion of epilepsy, which is the third invention that I want to discuss here this afternoon. (Applause)I have three wishes. Well, I can't do much about Africa. I'm a tech; I'm into medical gadgetry, which is mostly high-tech stuff like Mr. Bono talked about. The first wish is to use the epilepsy responsive neurostimulator, called RNS, for Responsive NeuroStimulator — that's a brilliant acronym — for the treatment of other brain disorders. Well, if we're going to do it for epilepsy, why the hell not try it for something else? Then you saw what that device looked like, that the woman was using to fix her migraines? I tell you this: that's something which some research engineer like me would concoct, not a real designer of good equipment. (Laughter) We want to have some people, who really know how to do this, perform human engineering studies to develop the optimum design for the portable device for treating migraine headaches. And some of the sponsors of this TED meeting are such organizations. Then we're going to challenge the TED attendees to come up with a way to improve health care in the USA, where we have problems that Africa doesn't have. And by reducing malpractice litigation — malpractice litigation is not an African problem; it's an American problem. (Applause)So, to get quickly to my first wish — the brain operates by electrical signals. If the electrical signals create a brain disorder, electro-stimulation can overcome that disorder by acting on the brain's neurons. In other words, if you've screwed up electrical signals, maybe, by putting other electrical signals from a computer in the brain, we can counteract that. A signal in the brain that triggers brain dysfunction might be sensed as a trigger for electro-stimulation like we're doing with epilepsy. But even if there is no signal, electro-stimulation of an appropriate part of the brain can turn off a brain disorder. And consider treating psychotic disorders — and I want this involved with the TED group — such as obsessive-compulsive disorder that, presently, is not well treated with drugs, and includes five million Americans. And Mr. Fischer, and his group at NeuroPace, and myself believe that we can have a dramatic effect in improving OCD in America and in the world. That is the first wish. (Applause)The second wish is, at the present time, the clinical trials of transcranial magnetic stimulators — that's what TMS means, device to treat migraine headaches — appears to be quite successful. Well, that's the good news. The present portable device is far from optimally designed, both as to human factors as appearance. I think she said it looks like a gun. A lot of people don't like guns. (Laughter) Engage a company having prior successes for human factors engineering and industrial design to optimize the design of the first portable TMS device that will be sold to the patients who have migraine headaches. And that is the second wish. (Applause)And, of the 100,000-dollar prize money, that TED was so generous to give me, I am donating 50,000 dollars to the NeuroPace people to get on with the treatment of OCD, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and I'm making another 50,000 available for a company to optimize the design of the device for migraines. And that's how I'll use my 100,000-dollar prize money. (Applause)Well, the third and final wish is somewhat — unfortunately, it's much more complicated because it involves lawyers. (Laughter) Well, medical malpractice litigation in the US has escalated the cost of malpractice insurance, so that competent physicians are leaving their practice. Lawyers take cases on contingency with the hope of a big share of a big settlement by a sympathetic jury, because this patient really ended up badly. The high cost of health care in the US is partly due to litigation and insurance costs. I've seen pictures, graphs in today's USA Today showing it skyrocketing out of control, and this is one factor. Well, how can the TED community help with this situation?I have a couple of ideas to begin with. As a starting point for discussion with the TED group, a major part of the problem is the nature of the written extent of informed consent that the patient or spouse must read and sign. For example, I asked the epilepsy people what are they using for informed consent. Would you believe, 12 pages, single space, the patient has to read before they're in our trial to cure their epilepsy? What do you think someone has at the end of reading 12 single-spaced pages? They don't understand what the hell it's about. (Laughter) That's the present system. How about making a video? We have entertainment people here; we have people who know how to do videos, with visual presentation of the anatomy and procedure done with animation. Everybody knows that we can do better with a visual thing that can be interactive with the patient, where they see the video and they're being videoed and they press, do you understand this? No, I don't. Well, then let's go to a simpler explanation. Then there's a simpler one and, oh yes, I understand that. Well, press the button and you're on record, you understand. And that is one of the ideas.Now, also a video is done of the patient or spouse and medical presenter, with the patient agreeing that he understands the procedure to be done, including all the possible failure modes. The patient or spouse agrees not to file a lawsuit if one of the known procedure failures occurs. Now, in America, in fact, you cannot give up your right to trial by jury. However, if a video is there that everything was explained to you, and you have it all in the video file, it'll be much less likely that some hotshot lawyer will take this case on contingency, because it won't be nearly as good a case. If a medical error occurs, the patient or spouse agrees to a settlement for fair compensation by arbitration instead of going to court. That would save hundreds of millions of dollars in legal costs in the United States and would decrease the cost of medicine for everyone.These are just some starting points. And, so there, that's the end of all my wishes. I wish I had more wishes but three is what I've got and there they are. (Applause)

Well, what is needed for the earliest possible warning of a heart attack?

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:05.958
A means to determine if there's a complete blockage of a coronary artery.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:09.958
That, ladies and gentlemen, is a heart attack.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.958
The means consist of noting something a little technical,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
ST segment elevation of the electrogram --

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
translated into English, that means that

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:25.958
if there's an electrical signal in the heart, and one part of the ECG --

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:29.958
which we call the ST segment -- elevates,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
that is a sure sign of a heart attack.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:36.958
And if we had a computer put into the body of a person who's at risk,

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
we could know, before they even have symptoms,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
that they're having a heart attack, to save their life.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:48.958
Well, the doctor can program a level of this ST elevation voltage

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
that will trigger an emergency alarm,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:56.958
vibration like your cell phone, but right by your clavicle bone.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:00.958
And when it goes beep, beep, beep, you better do something about it,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:06.958
because if you want to live you have to get to some medical treatment.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
So we have to try these devices out

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
because the FDA won't just let us use them on people

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
unless we try it out first,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:17.958
and the best model for this happens to be pigs.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:22.958
And what we tried with the pig was external electrodes on the skin,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
like you see in an emergency room,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
and I'm going to show you why they don't work very well.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:32.958
And then we put a lead, which is a wire, in the right ventricle inside the heart,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:36.958
which does the electrogram, which is the signal voltage from inside the heart.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
Well, with the pig, at the baseline,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:44.958
before we blocked the pig's artery to simulate a heart attack, that was the signal.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:49.958
After 43 seconds, even an expert couldn't tell the difference,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
and after three minutes -- well,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
if you really studied it, you'd see a difference.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:58.958
But what happened when we looked inside the pig's heart, to the electrogram?

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:03.958
There was the baseline -- first of all, a much bigger and more reliable signal.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:08.958
Second of all, I'll bet even you people who are untrained can see the difference,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:13.958
and we see here an ST segment elevation right after this sharp line.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:17.958
Look at the difference there. It doesn't take much --

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
every layperson could see that difference,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:24.958
and computers can be programmed to easily detect it.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
Then, look at that after three minutes.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:30.958
We see that the signal that's actually in the heart,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:34.958
we can use it to tell people that they're having a heart attack

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
even before they have symptoms so we can save their life.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
Then we tried it with my son, Dr. Tim Fischell,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:45.958
we tried it on some human patients who had to have a stent put in.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
Well, he kept the balloon filled to block the artery,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
to simulate a blockage, which is what a heart attack is.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
And it's not hard to see that -- the baseline

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
is the first picture on the upper left.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:05:00.958
Next to it, at 30 seconds, you see this rise here,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:04.958
then this rise -- that's the ST elevation.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
And if we had a computer that could detect it,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
we could tell you you're having a heart attack so early

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:15.958
it could save your life and prevent congestive heart failure.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:20.958
And then he did it again. We filled the balloon again a few minutes later

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
and here you see, even after 10 seconds, a great rise in this piece,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:29.958
which we can have computers inside, under your chest like a pacemaker,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
with a wire into your heart like a pacemaker.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
And computers don't go to sleep.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
We have a little battery and on this little battery

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
that computer will run for five years without needing replacement.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
What does the system look like?

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:48.958
Well, on the left is the IMD, which is Implantable Medical Device,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
and tonight in the tent you can see it -- they've exhibited it.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
It's about this big, the size of a pacemaker.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
It's implanted with very conventional techniques.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
And the EXD is an External Device that you can have on your night table.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:07.958
It'll wake you up and tell you to get your tail to the emergency room

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
when the thing goes off because, if you don't, you're in deep doo-doo.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:16.958
And then, finally, a programmer that will set the level of the stimulation,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
which is the level which says you are having a heart attack.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:28.958
The FDA says, OK, test this final device after it's built in some animal,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
which we said is a pig, so we had to get this pig to have a heart attack.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:36.958
And when you go to the farmyard, you can't easily get pigs to have heart attacks,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
so we said, well, we're experts in stents.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
