Tonight you'll see some of our invented stents.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
We said, so we'll put in a stent,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
but we're not going to put in a stent that we'd put in people.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
We're putting in a copper stent,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and this copper stent erodes the artery and causes heart attacks.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
That's not very nice, but, after all, we had to find out what the answer is.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:07:00.958
So we took two copper stents and we put it in the artery of this pig,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
and let me show you the result that's very gratifying

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
as far as people who have heart disease are concerned.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:13.958
So there it was, Thursday morning we stopped the pig's medication

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:18.958
and there is his electrogram, the signal from inside the pig's heart

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
coming out by radio telemetry.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Then, on Friday at 6:43, he began to get certain signs,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
which later we had the pig run around --

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
I'm not going to go into this early stage.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:37.958
But look what happened at 10:06 after we removed this pig's medication

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
that kept him from having a heart attack.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Any one of you now is an expert on ST elevation. Can you see it there?

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:49.958
Can you see it in the picture after the big rise of the QRS -- you see ST elevation?

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:54.958
This pig at 10:06 was having a heart attack.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:58.958
What happens after you have the heart attack, this blockage?

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:05.958
Your rhythm becomes irregular, and that's what happened 45 minutes later.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
Then, ventricular fibrillation, the heart quivers instead of beats --

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:15.958
this is just before death of the pig -- and then the pig died; it went flat-line.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
But we had a little bit over an hour where we could've saved this pig's life.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:22.958
Well, because of the FDA, we didn't save the pig's life,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:26.958
because we need to do this type of animal research for humans.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
But when it comes to the sake of a human, we can save their life.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:37.958
We can save the lives of people who are at high risk for a heart attack.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:43.958
What is the response to acute myocardial infarction, a heart attack, today?

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
Well, you feel some chest pain or indigestion.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
It's not all that bad; you decide not to do anything.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:54.958
Several hours pass and it gets worse, and even the man won't ignore it.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
Finally, you go to the emergency room.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
You wait as burns and other critical patients are treated,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:05.958
because 75 percent of the patients who go to an emergency room with chest pains

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:09.958
don't have AMI, so you're not taken very seriously.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
They finally see you. It takes more time

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
to get your electrocardiogram on your skin and diagnose it,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and it's hard to do because they don't have the baseline data,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
which the computer we put in you gets.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
Finally, if you're lucky, you are treated in three or four hours after the incident,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
but the heart muscle has died.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And that is the typical treatment in the advanced world -- not Africa --

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
that's the typical treatment in the advanced world today.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
So we developed the AngelMed Guardian System

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and we have a device inside this patient, called the Implanted AngelMed Guardian.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
And when you have a blockage, the alarm goes off

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
and it sends the alarm and the electrogram to an external device,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
which gets your baseline electrogram from 24 hours ago

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
and the one that caused the alarm, so you can take it to the emergency room

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
and show them, and say, take care of me right away.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Then it goes to a network operations center,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
where they get your data from your patient database

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:10.958
that's been put in at some central location, say, in the United States.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
Then it goes to a diagnostic center, and within one minute of your heart attack,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:18.958
your signal appears on the screen of a computer

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and the computer analyzes what your problem is.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And the person who's there, the medical practitioner, calls you --

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
this is also a cell phone -- and says,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
"Mr. Smith, you're in deep doo-doo; you have a problem.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:34.958
We've called the ambulance. The ambulance is on the way.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:39.958
It'll pick you up, and then we're going to call your doctor, tell him about it.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
We're going to send him the signal that we have, that says you have a heart attack,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and we're going to send the signal to the hospital

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
and we're going to have it analyzed there,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and there you're going to be with your doctor

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and you'll be taken care of so you won't die of a heart attack."

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
That's the first invention that I wanted to describe.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
(Applause)

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And now I want to talk about something entirely different.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:07.958
At first I didn't think migraine headaches were a big problem

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
because I'd never had a migraine headache,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:14.958
but then I spoke to some people who have three or four every week of their life,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
and their lives are being totally ruined by it.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
We have a mission statement for our company doing migraine, which is,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
"Prevent or ameliorate migraine headaches

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:27.958
by the application of a safe, controlled magnetic pulse

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
applied, as needed, by the patient."

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
Now, you're probably very few physicists here.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
If you're a physicist you'd know there's a certain Faraday's Law,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:41.958
which says if I apply a magnetic pulse on salt water --

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
that's your brains by the way --

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:48.958
it'll generate electric currents, and the electric current in the brain

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
can erase a migraine headache.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
That's what we have discovered.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
So here's a picture of what we're doing.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:00.958
The patients who have a migraine preceded by an aura

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:04.958
have a band of excited neurons -- that's shown in red --

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:09.958
that moves at three to five millimeters a minute towards the mid-brain.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:14.958
And when it hits the mid-brain, that's when the headache begins.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:19.958
There's this migraine that is preceded by a visual aura,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
and this visual aura, by the way -- and I'll show you a picture --

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
but it sort of begins with little dancing lights,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
gets bigger and bigger until it fills your whole visual field.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:35.958
And what we tried was this; here is a device called the Cadwell Model MES10.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:39.958
Weighs about 70 pounds, has a wire about an inch in diameter.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
And here's one of the patients who has an aura

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:48.958
and always has a headache, bad one, after the aura. What do we do?

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
This is what an aura looks like.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
It's sort of funny dancing lights, shown there on the left and right side.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:58.958
And that's a fully developed visual aura, as we see on top.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:04.958
In the middle, our experimentalist, the neurologist, who said,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
"I'm going to move this down a little and I'm going to erase half your aura."

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And, by God, the neurologist did erase it, and that's the middle picture:

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
half of the aura erased by a short magnetic pulse.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
What does that mean?

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:21.958
That means that the magnetic pulse is generating an electric current

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
that's interfering with the erroneous electrical activity in the brain.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
And finally he says, "OK, now I'm going to -- "

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:33.958
all of the aura get erased with an appropriately placed magnetic pulse.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
What is the result? We designed a magnetic depolarizer

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:42.958
that looks like this, that you could have -- a lady, in her pocket book --

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:46.958
and when you get an aura you can try it and see how it works.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Well, the next thing they have to show is what was on ABC News,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
Channel 7, last week in New York City, in the 11 o'clock news.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
Anchor: For anyone who suffers from migraine headaches --

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
and there are 30 million Americans who do -- tonight: a possible answer.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
Eyewitness news reporter Stacy Sager tonight, with a small and portable machine

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
that literally zaps your migraines away.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
Christina Sidebottom: Well, my first reaction was that it was --

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
looked awfully gun-like, and it was very strange.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:18.958
Stacy Sager: But for Christina Sidebottom, almost anything was worth trying

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
if it could stop a migraine.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:26.958
It may look silly or even frightening as you walk around with it in your purse,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:31.958
but researchers here in Ohio organizing clinical trials for this migraine zapper,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
say it is scientifically sound --

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
that, in fact, when the average person gets a migraine,

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:40.958
it's caused by something similar to an electrical impulse.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
The zapper creates a magnetic field to counteract that.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
Yousef Mohammed: In other words, we're treating electricity with electricity,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:52.958
rather than treating electricity with the chemicals that we're using nowadays.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
SS: But is it safe to use everyday?

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Experts say the research has actually been around for more than a decade,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:03.958
and more long-term studies need to be done. Christina now swears by it.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
CS: It's been the most wonderful thing for my migraine.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:10.958
SS: Researchers are hoping to present their studies to the FDA this summer.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
Robert Fischell: And that is the invention to treat migraines.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
(Applause)

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:19.958
You see, the problem is, 30 million Americans have migraine headaches,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and we need a means to treat it, and I think that we now have it.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:28.958
And this is the first device that we did, and I'm going to talk about my second wish,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
which has something to do with this.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
Our conclusions from our studies so far, at three research centers,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
is there is a marked improvement in pain levels after using it just once.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:42.958
The most severe headaches responded better after we did it several times,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:46.958
and the unexpected finding indicates that even established headaches,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:50.958
not only those with aura, get treated and get diminished.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:55.958
And auras can be erased and the migraine, then, does not occur.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:16:02.958
And that is the migraine invention that we are talking about and that we are working on.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
(Applause)

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:09.958
The third and last invention began with an idea.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:14.958
Epilepsy can best be treated by responsive electrical stimulation.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:18.958
Now, why do we use -- add on, nearly, an epileptic focus?

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.958
Now, unfortunately, us technical people, unlike Mr. Bono,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
have to get into all these technical words.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:29.958
Well, "responsive electrical stimulation" means

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:34.958
that we sense, at a place in your brain which is called an "epileptic focus,"

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:39.958
which is where the epileptic seizure begins --

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
we sense there, that it's going to happen,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:47.958
and then we respond by applying an electrical energy at that spot,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
which erases the errant signal

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:55.958
so that you don't get the clinical manifestations of the migraine headache.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:17:00.958
We use current pacemaker defibrillator technology that's used for the heart.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
We thought we could adapt it for the brain.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
The device could be implanted under the scalp

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:08.958
to be totally hidden and avoid wire breakage,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.958
which occurs if you put it in the chest and you try to move your neck around.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:15.958
Form a company to develop a neuro-pacemaker for epilepsy,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:21.958
as well as other diseases of the brain, because all diseases of the brain

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:25.958
are a result of some electrical malfunction in it,

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:30.958
that causes many, if not all, of brain disorders.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:34.958
We formed a company called NeuroPace

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
and we started work on responsive neurostimulation,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
and this is a picture of what the device looked like,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958
that's placed into the cranial bone.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
This is probably a better picture.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:50.958
Here we have our device in which we put in a frame.

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:56.958
There's a cut made in the scalp; it's opened; the neurosurgeon has a template;

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
he marks it around, and uses a dental burr

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:03.958
to remove a piece of the cranial bone exactly the size of our device.

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
And tonight, you'll be able to see the device in the tent.

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:10.958
And then with four screws, we put in a frame,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
then we snap in the device and we run with wires --

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:18.958
the one shown in green will go to the surface of the brain with electrodes,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
to the epileptic focus, the origin of the epilepsy,

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
where we can sense the electrical signal

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:29.958
and have computer analysis that tells us when to hit it with some electrical current

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:32.958
to prevent the clinical manifestation of the seizure.

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:35.958
In the blue wire, we see what's called a deep brain electrode.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:40.958
If that's the source of the epilepsy, we can attack that as well.

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.958
The comprehensive solution: this is the device;

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:46.958
it's about one inches by two inches and, oddly enough,

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:50.958
just the thickness of most cranial bones.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
The advantages of responsive neurostimulation:

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:57.958
It can detect and terminate seizures before the clinical symptoms occur,

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:00.958
provide stimulation only when needed,

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:05.958
can be turned off if seizures disappear; it has minimal side effects --

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:08.958
as a matter of fact, in all our clinical trials to date,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:13.958
we've seen no side effects in the 40 or so patients in whom it's been implanted --

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:16.958
and it's invisible, cosmetically hidden,

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:19.958
so, if you have epilepsy and you have the device,

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
no one will know it because you can't tell that it's there.

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:26.958
And this shows what an electroencephalogram is,

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:30.958
and on the left is the signal of a spontaneous seizure of one of the patients.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:34.958
Then we stimulated, and you see how that heavy black line

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:38.958
and then you see the electroencephalogram signal going to normal,

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:41.958
which means they did not get the epileptic seizure.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:46.958
That concludes my discussion of epilepsy,

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:50.958
which is the third invention that I want to discuss here this afternoon.

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:54.958
(Applause)

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:59.958
I have three wishes. Well, I can't do much about Africa.

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:02.958
I'm a tech; I'm into medical gadgetry,

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:06.958
which is mostly high-tech stuff like Mr. Bono talked about.

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:11.958
The first wish is to use the epilepsy responsive neurostimulator,

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:16.958
called RNS, for Responsive NeuroStimulator -- that's a brilliant acronym --

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:18.958
for the treatment of other brain disorders.

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:23.958
Well, if we're going to do it for epilepsy, why the hell not try it for something else?

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:26.958
Then you saw what that device looked like,

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:28.958
that the woman was using to fix her migraines?

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:33.958
I tell you this: that's something which some research engineer like me would concoct,

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:35.958
not a real designer of good equipment.

00:20:35.958 --> 00:20:37.958
(Laughter)

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:40.958
We want to have some people, who really know how to do this,

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:44.958
perform human engineering studies to develop the optimum design

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:47.958
for the portable device for treating migraine headaches.

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:52.958
And some of the sponsors of this TED meeting are such organizations.

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:55.958
Then we're going to challenge the TED attendees

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:59.958
to come up with a way to improve health care in the USA,

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:02.958
where we have problems that Africa doesn't have.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:05.958
And by reducing malpractice litigation --

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:09.958
malpractice litigation is not an African problem; it's an American problem.

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:12.958
(Applause)

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:15.958
So, to get quickly to my first wish --

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
the brain operates by electrical signals.

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:21.958
If the electrical signals create a brain disorder,

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:25.958
electro-stimulation can overcome that disorder by acting on the brain's neurons.

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:29.958
In other words, if you've screwed up electrical signals,

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:33.958
maybe, by putting other electrical signals from a computer in the brain,

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
we can counteract that.

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:39.958
A signal in the brain that triggers brain dysfunction

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:42.958
might be sensed as a trigger for electro-stimulation

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:44.958
like we're doing with epilepsy.

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:46.958
But even if there is no signal,

00:21:46.958 --> 00:21:51.958
electro-stimulation of an appropriate part of the brain can turn off a brain disorder.

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:55.958
And consider treating psychotic disorders --

00:21:55.958 --> 00:21:58.958
and I want this involved with the TED group --

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:00.958
such as obsessive-compulsive disorder

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:06.958
that, presently, is not well treated with drugs, and includes five million Americans.

00:22:06.958 --> 00:22:10.958
And Mr. Fischer, and his group at NeuroPace, and myself believe

00:22:10.958 --> 00:22:16.958
that we can have a dramatic effect in improving OCD in America and in the world.

00:22:16.958 --> 00:22:19.958
That is the first wish.

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:24.958
(Applause)

00:22:24.958 --> 00:22:27.958
The second wish is, at the present time,

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:32.958
the clinical trials of transcranial magnetic stimulators --

00:22:32.958 --> 00:22:36.958
that's what TMS means, device to treat migraine headaches --

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:38.958
appears to be quite successful.

00:22:38.958 --> 00:22:40.958
Well, that's the good news.

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:42.958
The present portable device is far from optimally designed,

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:45.958
both as to human factors as appearance.

00:22:45.958 --> 00:22:49.958
I think she said it looks like a gun. A lot of people don't like guns.

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:51.958
(Laughter)

00:22:51.958 --> 00:22:53.958
Engage a company having prior successes

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:56.958
for human factors engineering and industrial design

00:22:56.958 --> 00:23:01.958
to optimize the design of the first portable TMS device

00:23:01.958 --> 00:23:04.958
that will be sold to the patients who have migraine headaches.

00:23:04.958 --> 00:23:06.958
And that is the second wish.

00:23:06.958 --> 00:23:11.958
(Applause)

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:15.958
And, of the 100,000-dollar prize money, that TED was so generous to give me,

00:23:15.958 --> 00:23:19.958
I am donating 50,000 dollars to the NeuroPace people

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:24.958
to get on with the treatment of OCD, obsessive-compulsive disorder,

00:23:24.958 --> 00:23:28.958
and I'm making another 50,000 available for a company

00:23:28.958 --> 00:23:31.958
to optimize the design of the device for migraines.

00:23:31.958 --> 00:23:35.958
And that's how I'll use my 100,000-dollar prize money.

00:23:35.958 --> 00:23:41.958
(Applause)

00:23:41.958 --> 00:23:43.958
Well, the third and final wish is somewhat --

00:23:43.958 --> 00:23:48.958
unfortunately, it's much more complicated because it involves lawyers.

00:23:48.958 --> 00:23:50.958
(Laughter)

00:23:50.958 --> 00:23:52.958
Well, medical malpractice litigation in the US

00:23:52.958 --> 00:23:54.958
has escalated the cost of malpractice insurance,

00:23:54.958 --> 00:23:57.958
so that competent physicians are leaving their practice.

00:23:57.958 --> 00:24:01.958
Lawyers take cases on contingency with the hope of a big share

00:24:01.958 --> 00:24:06.958
of a big settlement by a sympathetic jury, because this patient really ended up badly.

00:24:06.958 --> 00:24:11.958
The high cost of health care in the US is partly due to litigation and insurance costs.

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:16.958
I've seen pictures, graphs in today's USA Today

00:24:16.958 --> 00:24:19.958
showing it skyrocketing out of control, and this is one factor.

00:24:19.958 --> 00:24:23.958
Well, how can the TED community help with this situation?

00:24:23.958 --> 00:24:26.958
I have a couple of ideas to begin with.

00:24:26.958 --> 00:24:30.958
As a starting point for discussion with the TED group,

00:24:30.958 --> 00:24:33.958
a major part of the problem is the nature of the written extent

00:24:33.958 --> 00:24:37.958
of informed consent that the patient or spouse must read and sign.

00:24:37.958 --> 00:24:40.958
For example, I asked the epilepsy people

00:24:40.958 --> 00:24:42.958
what are they using for informed consent.

00:24:42.958 --> 00:24:46.958
Would you believe, 12 pages, single space,

00:24:46.958 --> 00:24:51.958
the patient has to read before they're in our trial to cure their epilepsy?

00:24:51.958 --> 00:24:55.958
What do you think someone has at the end of reading 12 single-spaced pages?

00:24:55.958 --> 00:24:57.958
They don't understand what the hell it's about.

00:24:57.958 --> 00:24:59.958
(Laughter)

00:24:59.958 --> 00:25:02.958
That's the present system. How about making a video?

00:25:02.958 --> 00:25:04.958
We have entertainment people here;

00:25:04.958 --> 00:25:06.958
we have people who know how to do videos,

00:25:06.958 --> 00:25:10.958
with visual presentation of the anatomy and procedure done with animation.

00:25:10.958 --> 00:25:15.958
Everybody knows that we can do better with a visual thing

00:25:15.958 --> 00:25:19.958
that can be interactive with the patient, where they see the video

00:25:19.958 --> 00:25:24.958
and they're being videoed and they press, do you understand this? No, I don't.

00:25:24.958 --> 00:25:26.958
Well, then let's go to a simpler explanation.

00:25:26.958 --> 00:25:29.958
Then there's a simpler one and, oh yes, I understand that.

00:25:29.958 --> 00:25:32.958
Well, press the button and you're on record, you understand.

00:25:32.958 --> 00:25:35.958
And that is one of the ideas.

00:25:35.958 --> 00:25:38.958
Now, also a video is done of the patient or spouse and medical presenter,

00:25:38.958 --> 00:25:43.958
with the patient agreeing that he understands the procedure to be done,

00:25:43.958 --> 00:25:46.958
including all the possible failure modes.

00:25:46.958 --> 00:25:48.958
The patient or spouse agrees not to file a lawsuit

00:25:48.958 --> 00:25:51.958
if one of the known procedure failures occurs.

00:25:51.958 --> 00:25:57.958
Now, in America, in fact, you cannot give up your right to trial by jury.

00:25:57.958 --> 00:26:01.958
However, if a video is there that everything was explained to you,

00:26:01.958 --> 00:26:03.958
and you have it all in the video file,

00:26:03.958 --> 00:26:06.958
it'll be much less likely that some hotshot lawyer

00:26:06.958 --> 00:26:11.958
will take this case on contingency, because it won't be nearly as good a case.

00:26:11.958 --> 00:26:16.958
If a medical error occurs, the patient or spouse agrees to a settlement

00:26:16.958 --> 00:26:21.958
for fair compensation by arbitration instead of going to court.

00:26:21.958 --> 00:26:26.958
That would save hundreds of millions of dollars in legal costs in the United States

00:26:26.958 --> 00:26:29.958
and would decrease the cost of medicine for everyone.

00:26:29.958 --> 00:26:32.958
These are just some starting points.

00:26:32.958 --> 00:26:36.958
And, so there, that's the end of all my wishes.

00:26:36.958 --> 00:26:40.958
I wish I had more wishes but three is what I've got and there they are.

00:26:40.958 --> 00:26:43.958
(Applause)

title: How juries are fooled by statistics
transcript: As other speakers have said, it's a rather daunting experience — a particularly daunting experience — to be speaking in front of this audience. But unlike the other speakers, I'm not going to tell you about the mysteries of the universe, or the wonders of evolution, or the really clever, innovative ways people are attacking the major inequalities in our world. Or even the challenges of nation-states in the modern global economy. My brief, as you've just heard, is to tell you about statistics — and, to be more precise, to tell you some exciting things about statistics. And that's — (Laughter) — that's rather more challenging than all the speakers before me and all the ones coming after me. (Laughter) One of my senior colleagues told me, when I was a youngster in this profession, rather proudly, that statisticians were people who liked figures but didn't have the personality skills to become accountants. (Laughter) And there's another in-joke among statisticians, and that's, "How do you tell the introverted statistician from the extroverted statistician?" To which the answer is, "The extroverted statistician's the one who looks at the other person's shoes." (Laughter) But I want to tell you something useful — and here it is, so concentrate now. This evening, there's a reception in the University's Museum of Natural History. And it's a wonderful setting, as I hope you'll find, and a great icon to the best of the Victorian tradition. It's very unlikely — in this special setting, and this collection of people — but you might just find yourself talking to someone you'd rather wish that you weren't. So here's what you do. When they say to you, "What do you do?" — you say, "I'm a statistician." (Laughter) Well, except they've been pre-warned now, and they'll know you're making it up. And then one of two things will happen. They'll either discover their long-lost cousin in the other corner of the room and run over and talk to them. Or they'll suddenly become parched and/or hungry — and often both — and sprint off for a drink and some food. And you'll be left in peace to talk to the person you really want to talk to.It's one of the challenges in our profession to try and explain what we do. We're not top on people's lists for dinner party guests and conversations and so on. And it's something I've never really found a good way of doing. But my wife — who was then my girlfriend — managed it much better than I've ever been able to. Many years ago, when we first started going out, she was working for the BBC in Britain, and I was, at that stage, working in America. I was coming back to visit her. She told this to one of her colleagues, who said, "Well, what does your boyfriend do?" Sarah thought quite hard about the things I'd explained — and she concentrated, in those days, on listening. (Laughter) Don't tell her I said that. And she was thinking about the work I did developing mathematical models for understanding evolution and modern genetics. So when her colleague said, "What does he do?" She paused and said, "He models things." (Laughter) Well, her colleague suddenly got much more interested than I had any right to expect and went on and said, "What does he model?" Well, Sarah thought a little bit more about my work and said, "Genes." (Laughter) "He models genes."That is my first love, and that's what I'll tell you a little bit about. What I want to do more generally is to get you thinking about the place of uncertainty and randomness and chance in our world, and how we react to that, and how well we do or don't think about it. So you've had a pretty easy time up till now — a few laughs, and all that kind of thing — in the talks to date. You've got to think, and I'm going to ask you some questions. So here's the scene for the first question I'm going to ask you. Can you imagine tossing a coin successively? And for some reason — which shall remain rather vague — we're interested in a particular pattern. Here's one — a head, followed by a tail, followed by a tail.So suppose we toss a coin repeatedly. Then the pattern, head-tail-tail, that we've suddenly become fixated with happens here. And you can count: one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, 10 — it happens after the 10th toss. So you might think there are more interesting things to do, but humor me for the moment. Imagine this half of the audience each get out coins, and they toss them until they first see the pattern head-tail-tail. The first time they do it, maybe it happens after the 10th toss, as here. The second time, maybe it's after the fourth toss. The next time, after the 15th toss. So you do that lots and lots of times, and you average those numbers. That's what I want this side to think about.The other half of the audience doesn't like head-tail-tail — they think, for deep cultural reasons, that's boring — and they're much more interested in a different pattern — head-tail-head. So, on this side, you get out your coins, and you toss and toss and toss. And you count the number of times until the pattern head-tail-head appears and you average them. OK? So on this side, you've got a number — you've done it lots of times, so you get it accurately — which is the average number of tosses until head-tail-tail. On this side, you've got a number — the average number of tosses until head-tail-head.So here's a deep mathematical fact — if you've got two numbers, one of three things must be true. Either they're the same, or this one's bigger than this one, or this one's bigger than that one. So what's going on here? So you've all got to think about this, and you've all got to vote — and we're not moving on. And I don't want to end up in the two-minute silence to give you more time to think about it, until everyone's expressed a view. OK. So what you want to do is compare the average number of tosses until we first see head-tail-head with the average number of tosses until we first see head-tail-tail.Who thinks that A is true — that, on average, it'll take longer to see head-tail-head than head-tail-tail? Who thinks that B is true — that on average, they're the same? Who thinks that C is true — that, on average, it'll take less time to see head-tail-head than head-tail-tail? OK, who hasn't voted yet? Because that's really naughty — I said you had to. (Laughter) OK. So most people think B is true. And you might be relieved to know even rather distinguished mathematicians think that. It's not. A is true here. It takes longer, on average. In fact, the average number of tosses till head-tail-head is 10 and the average number of tosses until head-tail-tail is eight. How could that be? Anything different about the two patterns? There is. Head-tail-head overlaps itself. If you went head-tail-head-tail-head, you can cunningly get two occurrences of the pattern in only five tosses. You can't do that with head-tail-tail. That turns out to be important.There are two ways of thinking about this. I'll give you one of them. So imagine — let's suppose we're doing it. On this side — remember, you're excited about head-tail-tail; you're excited about head-tail-head. We start tossing a coin, and we get a head — and you start sitting on the edge of your seat because something great and wonderful, or awesome, might be about to happen. The next toss is a tail — you get really excited. The champagne's on ice just next to you; you've got the glasses chilled to celebrate. You're waiting with bated breath for the final toss. And if it comes down a head, that's great. You're done, and you celebrate. If it's a tail — well, rather disappointedly, you put the glasses away and put the champagne back. And you keep tossing, to wait for the next head, to get excited.On this side, there's a different experience. It's the same for the first two parts of the sequence. You're a little bit excited with the first head — you get rather more excited with the next tail. Then you toss the coin. If it's a tail, you crack open the champagne. If it's a head you're disappointed, but you're still a third of the way to your pattern again. And that's an informal way of presenting it — that's why there's a difference. Another way of thinking about it — if we tossed a coin eight million times, then we'd expect a million head-tail-heads and a million head-tail-tails — but the head-tail-heads could occur in clumps. So if you want to put a million things down amongst eight million positions and you can have some of them overlapping, the clumps will be further apart. It's another way of getting the intuition.What's the point I want to make? It's a very, very simple example, an easily stated question in probability, which every — you're in good company — everybody gets wrong. This is my little diversion into my real passion, which is genetics. There's a connection between head-tail-heads and head-tail-tails in genetics, and it's the following. When you toss a coin, you get a sequence of heads and tails. When you look at DNA, there's a sequence of not two things — heads and tails — but four letters — As, Gs, Cs and Ts. And there are little chemical scissors, called restriction enzymes which cut DNA whenever they see particular patterns. And they're an enormously useful tool in modern molecular biology. And instead of asking the question, "How long until I see a head-tail-head?" — you can ask, "How big will the chunks be when I use a restriction enzyme which cuts whenever it sees G-A-A-G, for example? How long will those chunks be?"That's a rather trivial connection between probability and genetics. There's a much deeper connection, which I don't have time to go into and that is that modern genetics is a really exciting area of science. And we'll hear some talks later in the conference specifically about that. But it turns out that unlocking the secrets in the information generated by modern experimental technologies, a key part of that has to do with fairly sophisticated — you'll be relieved to know that I do something useful in my day job, rather more sophisticated than the head-tail-head story — but quite sophisticated computer modelings and mathematical modelings and modern statistical techniques. And I will give you two little snippets — two examples — of projects we're involved in in my group in Oxford, both of which I think are rather exciting. You know about the Human Genome Project. That was a project which aimed to read one copy of the human genome. The natural thing to do after you've done that — and that's what this project, the International HapMap Project, which is a collaboration between labs in five or six different countries. Think of the Human Genome Project as learning what we've got in common, and the HapMap Project is trying to understand where there are differences between different people.Why do we care about that? Well, there are lots of reasons. The most pressing one is that we want to understand how some differences make some people susceptible to one disease — type-2 diabetes, for example — and other differences make people more susceptible to heart disease, or stroke, or autism and so on. That's one big project. There's a second big project, recently funded by the Wellcome Trust in this country, involving very large studies — thousands of individuals, with each of eight different diseases, common diseases like type-1 and type-2 diabetes, and coronary heart disease, bipolar disease and so on — to try and understand the genetics. To try and understand what it is about genetic differences that causes the diseases. Why do we want to do that? Because we understand very little about most human diseases. We don't know what causes them. And if we can get in at the bottom and understand the genetics, we'll have a window on the way the disease works, and a whole new way about thinking about disease therapies and preventative treatment and so on. So that's, as I said, the little diversion on my main love.Back to some of the more mundane issues of thinking about uncertainty. Here's another quiz for you — now suppose we've got a test for a disease which isn't infallible, but it's pretty good. It gets it right 99 percent of the time. And I take one of you, or I take someone off the street, and I test them for the disease in question. Let's suppose there's a test for HIV — the virus that causes AIDS — and the test says the person has the disease. What's the chance that they do? The test gets it right 99 percent of the time. So a natural answer is 99 percent. Who likes that answer? Come on — everyone's got to get involved. Don't think you don't trust me anymore. (Laughter) Well, you're right to be a bit skeptical, because that's not the answer. That's what you might think. It's not the answer, and it's not because it's only part of the story. It actually depends on how common or how rare the disease is. So let me try and illustrate that. Here's a little caricature of a million individuals. So let's think about a disease that affects — it's pretty rare, it affects one person in 10,000. Amongst these million individuals, most of them are healthy and some of them will have the disease. And in fact, if this is the prevalence of the disease, about 100 will have the disease and the rest won't. So now suppose we test them all. What happens? Well, amongst the 100 who do have the disease, the test will get it right 99 percent of the time, and 99 will test positive. Amongst all these other people who don't have the disease, the test will get it right 99 percent of the time. It'll only get it wrong one percent of the time. But there are so many of them that there'll be an enormous number of false positives. Put that another way — of all of them who test positive — so here they are, the individuals involved — less than one in 100 actually have the disease. So even though we think the test is accurate, the important part of the story is there's another bit of information we need.Here's the key intuition. What we have to do, once we know the test is positive, is to weigh up the plausibility, or the likelihood, of two competing explanations. Each of those explanations has a likely bit and an unlikely bit. One explanation is that the person doesn't have the disease — that's overwhelmingly likely, if you pick someone at random — but the test gets it wrong, which is unlikely. The other explanation is that the person does have the disease — that's unlikely — but the test gets it right, which is likely. And the number we end up with — that number which is a little bit less than one in 100 — is to do with how likely one of those explanations is relative to the other. Each of them taken together is unlikely.Here's a more topical example of exactly the same thing. Those of you in Britain will know about what's become rather a celebrated case of a woman called Sally Clark, who had two babies who died suddenly. And initially, it was thought that they died of what's known informally as "cot death," and more formally as "Sudden Infant Death Syndrome." For various reasons, she was later charged with murder. And at the trial, her trial, a very distinguished pediatrician gave evidence that the chance of two cot deaths, innocent deaths, in a family like hers — which was professional and non-smoking — was one in 73 million. To cut a long story short, she was convicted at the time. Later, and fairly recently, acquitted on appeal — in fact, on the second appeal. And just to set it in context, you can imagine how awful it is for someone to have lost one child, and then two, if they're innocent, to be convicted of murdering them. To be put through the stress of the trial, convicted of murdering them — and to spend time in a women's prison, where all the other prisoners think you killed your children — is a really awful thing to happen to someone. And it happened in large part here because the expert got the statistics horribly wrong, in two different ways.So where did he get the one in 73 million number? He looked at some research, which said the chance of one cot death in a family like Sally Clark's is about one in 8,500. So he said, "I'll assume that if you have one cot death in a family, the chance of a second child dying from cot death aren't changed." So that's what statisticians would call an assumption of independence. It's like saying, "If you toss a coin and get a head the first time, that won't affect the chance of getting a head the second time." So if you toss a coin twice, the chance of getting a head twice are a half — that's the chance the first time — times a half — the chance a second time. So he said, "Here, I'll assume that these events are independent. When you multiply 8,500 together twice, you get about 73 million." And none of this was stated to the court as an assumption or presented to the jury that way. Unfortunately here — and, really, regrettably — first of all, in a situation like this you'd have to verify it empirically. And secondly, it's palpably false. There are lots and lots of things that we don't know about sudden infant deaths. It might well be that there are environmental factors that we're not aware of, and it's pretty likely to be the case that there are genetic factors we're not aware of. So if a family suffers from one cot death, you'd put them in a high-risk group. They've probably got these environmental risk factors and/or genetic risk factors we don't know about. And to argue, then, that the chance of a second death is as if you didn't know that information is really silly. It's worse than silly — it's really bad science. Nonetheless, that's how it was presented, and at trial nobody even argued it. That's the first problem. The second problem is, what does the number of one in 73 million mean? So after Sally Clark was convicted — you can imagine, it made rather a splash in the press — one of the journalists from one of Britain's more reputable newspapers wrote that what the expert had said was, "The chance that she was innocent was one in 73 million." Now, that's a logical error. It's exactly the same logical error as the logical error of thinking that after the disease test, which is 99 percent accurate, the chance of having the disease is 99 percent. In the disease example, we had to bear in mind two things, one of which was the possibility that the test got it right or not. And the other one was the chance, a priori, that the person had the disease or not. It's exactly the same in this context. There are two things involved — two parts to the explanation. We want to know how likely, or relatively how likely, two different explanations are. One of them is that Sally Clark was innocent — which is, a priori, overwhelmingly likely — most mothers don't kill their children. And the second part of the explanation is that she suffered an incredibly unlikely event. Not as unlikely as one in 73 million, but nonetheless rather unlikely. The other explanation is that she was guilty. Now, we probably think a priori that's unlikely. And we certainly should think in the context of a criminal trial that that's unlikely, because of the presumption of innocence. And then if she were trying to kill the children, she succeeded. So the chance that she's innocent isn't one in 73 million. We don't know what it is. It has to do with weighing up the strength of the other evidence against her and the statistical evidence. We know the children died. What matters is how likely or unlikely, relative to each other, the two explanations are. And they're both implausible. There's a situation where errors in statistics had really profound and really unfortunate consequences. In fact, there are two other women who were convicted on the basis of the evidence of this pediatrician, who have subsequently been released on appeal. Many cases were reviewed. And it's particularly topical because he's currently facing a disrepute charge at Britain's General Medical Council.So just to conclude — what are the take-home messages from this? Well, we know that randomness and uncertainty and chance are very much a part of our everyday life. It's also true — and, although, you, as a collective, are very special in many ways, you're completely typical in not getting the examples I gave right. It's very well documented that people get things wrong. They make errors of logic in reasoning with uncertainty. We can cope with the subtleties of language brilliantly — and there are interesting evolutionary questions about how we got here. We are not good at reasoning with uncertainty. That's an issue in our everyday lives. As you've heard from many of the talks, statistics underpins an enormous amount of research in science — in social science, in medicine and indeed, quite a lot of industry. All of quality control, which has had a major impact on industrial processing, is underpinned by statistics. It's something we're bad at doing. At the very least, we should recognize that, and we tend not to. To go back to the legal context, at the Sally Clark trial all of the lawyers just accepted what the expert said. So if a pediatrician had come out and said to a jury, "I know how to build bridges. I've built one down the road. Please drive your car home over it," they would have said, "Well, pediatricians don't know how to build bridges. That's what engineers do." On the other hand, he came out and effectively said, or implied, "I know how to reason with uncertainty. I know how to do statistics." And everyone said, "Well, that's fine. He's an expert." So we need to understand where our competence is and isn't. Exactly the same kinds of issues arose in the early days of DNA profiling, when scientists, and lawyers and in some cases judges, routinely misrepresented evidence. Usually — one hopes — innocently, but misrepresented evidence. Forensic scientists said, "The chance that this guy's innocent is one in three million." Even if you believe the number, just like the 73 million to one, that's not what it meant. And there have been celebrated appeal cases in Britain and elsewhere because of that.And just to finish in the context of the legal system. It's all very well to say, "Let's do our best to present the evidence." But more and more, in cases of DNA profiling — this is another one — we expect juries, who are ordinary people — and it's documented they're very bad at this — we expect juries to be able to cope with the sorts of reasoning that goes on. In other spheres of life, if people argued — well, except possibly for politics — but in other spheres of life, if people argued illogically, we'd say that's not a good thing. We sort of expect it of politicians and don't hope for much more. In the case of uncertainty, we get it wrong all the time — and at the very least, we should be aware of that, and ideally, we might try and do something about it. Thanks very much.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
As other speakers have said, it's a rather daunting experience --

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.958
a particularly daunting experience -- to be speaking in front of this audience.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
But unlike the other speakers, I'm not going to tell you about

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:21.958
the mysteries of the universe, or the wonders of evolution,

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:25.958
or the really clever, innovative ways people are attacking

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
the major inequalities in our world.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:32.958
Or even the challenges of nation-states in the modern global economy.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:36.958
My brief, as you've just heard, is to tell you about statistics --

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.958
and, to be more precise, to tell you some exciting things about statistics.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:40.958
And that's --

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:41.958
(Laughter)

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
-- that's rather more challenging

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
than all the speakers before me and all the ones coming after me.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:46.958
(Laughter)

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:52.958
One of my senior colleagues told me, when I was a youngster in this profession,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:56.958
rather proudly, that statisticians were people who liked figures

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
but didn't have the personality skills to become accountants.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
(Laughter)

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
And there's another in-joke among statisticians, and that's,

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
"How do you tell the introverted statistician from the extroverted statistician?"

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
To which the answer is,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:14.958
"The extroverted statistician's the one who looks at the other person's shoes."

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
(Laughter)

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:22.958
But I want to tell you something useful -- and here it is, so concentrate now.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
This evening, there's a reception in the University's Museum of Natural History.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And it's a wonderful setting, as I hope you'll find,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:32.958
and a great icon to the best of the Victorian tradition.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:37.958
It's very unlikely -- in this special setting, and this collection of people --

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
but you might just find yourself talking to someone you'd rather wish that you weren't.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
So here's what you do.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:46.958
When they say to you, "What do you do?" -- you say, "I'm a statistician."

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:47.958
(Laughter)

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:51.958
Well, except they've been pre-warned now, and they'll know you're making it up.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
And then one of two things will happen.

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.958
They'll either discover their long-lost cousin in the other corner of the room

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.958
and run over and talk to them.

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
Or they'll suddenly become parched and/or hungry -- and often both --

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
and sprint off for a drink and some food.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:06.958
And you'll be left in peace to talk to the person you really want to talk to.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
It's one of the challenges in our profession to try and explain what we do.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:14.958
We're not top on people's lists for dinner party guests and conversations and so on.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
And it's something I've never really found a good way of doing.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
But my wife -- who was then my girlfriend --

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
managed it much better than I've ever been able to.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
Many years ago, when we first started going out, she was working for the BBC in Britain,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
and I was, at that stage, working in America.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
I was coming back to visit her.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:35.958
She told this to one of her colleagues, who said, "Well, what does your boyfriend do?"

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
Sarah thought quite hard about the things I'd explained --

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:41.958
and she concentrated, in those days, on listening.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
(Laughter)

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
Don't tell her I said that.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:50.958
And she was thinking about the work I did developing mathematical models

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
for understanding evolution and modern genetics.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
So when her colleague said, "What does he do?"

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:00.958
She paused and said, "He models things."

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:01.958
(Laughter)

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.958
Well, her colleague suddenly got much more interested than I had any right to expect

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
and went on and said, "What does he model?"

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
Well, Sarah thought a little bit more about my work and said, "Genes."

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:15.958
(Laughter)

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
"He models genes."

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.958
That is my first love, and that's what I'll tell you a little bit about.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:25.958
What I want to do more generally is to get you thinking about

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
the place of uncertainty and randomness and chance in our world,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:33.958
and how we react to that, and how well we do or don't think about it.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
So you've had a pretty easy time up till now --

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
a few laughs, and all that kind of thing -- in the talks to date.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
You've got to think, and I'm going to ask you some questions.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
So here's the scene for the first question I'm going to ask you.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
Can you imagine tossing a coin successively?

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
And for some reason -- which shall remain rather vague --

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
we're interested in a particular pattern.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
Here's one -- a head, followed by a tail, followed by a tail.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
So suppose we toss a coin repeatedly.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:01.958
Then the pattern, head-tail-tail, that we've suddenly become fixated with happens here.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
And you can count: one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, 10 --

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
it happens after the 10th toss.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
So you might think there are more interesting things to do, but humor me for the moment.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:14.958
Imagine this half of the audience each get out coins, and they toss them

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
until they first see the pattern head-tail-tail.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
The first time they do it, maybe it happens after the 10th toss, as here.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
The second time, maybe it's after the fourth toss.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
The next time, after the 15th toss.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
So you do that lots and lots of times, and you average those numbers.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
That's what I want this side to think about.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
The other half of the audience doesn't like head-tail-tail --

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
they think, for deep cultural reasons, that's boring --

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
and they're much more interested in a different pattern -- head-tail-head.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
So, on this side, you get out your coins, and you toss and toss and toss.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
And you count the number of times until the pattern head-tail-head appears

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
and you average them. OK?

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
So on this side, you've got a number --

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
you've done it lots of times, so you get it accurately --

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
which is the average number of tosses until head-tail-tail.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:57.958
On this side, you've got a number -- the average number of tosses until head-tail-head.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
So here's a deep mathematical fact --

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
if you've got two numbers, one of three things must be true.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
Either they're the same, or this one's bigger than this one,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:06.958
or this one's bigger than that one.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
So what's going on here?

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
So you've all got to think about this, and you've all got to vote --

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:12.958
and we're not moving on.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
And I don't want to end up in the two-minute silence

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
to give you more time to think about it, until everyone's expressed a view. OK.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.958
So what you want to do is compare the average number of tosses until we first see

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:26.958
head-tail-head with the average number of tosses until we first see head-tail-tail.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
Who thinks that A is true --

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
that, on average, it'll take longer to see head-tail-head than head-tail-tail?

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
Who thinks that B is true -- that on average, they're the same?

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
Who thinks that C is true -- that, on average, it'll take less time

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
to see head-tail-head than head-tail-tail?

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
OK, who hasn't voted yet? Because that's really naughty -- I said you had to.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:47.958
(Laughter)

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
OK. So most people think B is true.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
And you might be relieved to know even rather distinguished mathematicians think that.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:58.958
It's not. A is true here.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
It takes longer, on average.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
In fact, the average number of tosses till head-tail-head is 10

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:07.958
and the average number of tosses until head-tail-tail is eight.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
How could that be?

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
Anything different about the two patterns?

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:21.958
There is. Head-tail-head overlaps itself.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:25.958
If you went head-tail-head-tail-head, you can cunningly get two occurrences

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
of the pattern in only five tosses.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
You can't do that with head-tail-tail.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
That turns out to be important.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
There are two ways of thinking about this.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
I'll give you one of them.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
So imagine -- let's suppose we're doing it.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
On this side -- remember, you're excited about head-tail-tail;

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
you're excited about head-tail-head.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
We start tossing a coin, and we get a head --

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:46.958
and you start sitting on the edge of your seat

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:51.958
because something great and wonderful, or awesome, might be about to happen.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
The next toss is a tail -- you get really excited.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:57.958
The champagne's on ice just next to you; you've got the glasses chilled to celebrate.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
You're waiting with bated breath for the final toss.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
And if it comes down a head, that's great.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
You're done, and you celebrate.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
If it's a tail -- well, rather disappointedly, you put the glasses away

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
and put the champagne back.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
And you keep tossing, to wait for the next head, to get excited.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
On this side, there's a different experience.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
It's the same for the first two parts of the sequence.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
You're a little bit excited with the first head --

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
you get rather more excited with the next tail.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
Then you toss the coin.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
If it's a tail, you crack open the champagne.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
If it's a head you're disappointed,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
but you're still a third of the way to your pattern again.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:34.958
And that's an informal way of presenting it -- that's why there's a difference.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Another way of thinking about it --

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
if we tossed a coin eight million times,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
then we'd expect a million head-tail-heads

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:47.958
and a million head-tail-tails -- but the head-tail-heads could occur in clumps.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
So if you want to put a million things down amongst eight million positions

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:54.958
and you can have some of them overlapping, the clumps will be further apart.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
It's another way of getting the intuition.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
What's the point I want to make?

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
It's a very, very simple example, an easily stated question in probability,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
which every -- you're in good company -- everybody gets wrong.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
This is my little diversion into my real passion, which is genetics.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
There's a connection between head-tail-heads and head-tail-tails in genetics,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
and it's the following.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
When you toss a coin, you get a sequence of heads and tails.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
When you look at DNA, there's a sequence of not two things -- heads and tails --

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
but four letters -- As, Gs, Cs and Ts.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
And there are little chemical scissors, called restriction enzymes

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
which cut DNA whenever they see particular patterns.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:33.958
And they're an enormously useful tool in modern molecular biology.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
And instead of asking the question, "How long until I see a head-tail-head?" --

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
you can ask, "How big will the chunks be when I use a restriction enzyme

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
which cuts whenever it sees G-A-A-G, for example?

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
How long will those chunks be?"

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:51.958
That's a rather trivial connection between probability and genetics.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
There's a much deeper connection, which I don't have time to go into

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
and that is that modern genetics is a really exciting area of science.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:01.958
And we'll hear some talks later in the conference specifically about that.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
But it turns out that unlocking the secrets in the information generated by modern

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:10.958
experimental technologies, a key part of that has to do with fairly sophisticated --

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
you'll be relieved to know that I do something useful in my day job,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
rather more sophisticated than the head-tail-head story --

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
but quite sophisticated computer modelings and mathematical modelings

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
and modern statistical techniques.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
And I will give you two little snippets -- two examples --

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
of projects we're involved in in my group in Oxford,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
both of which I think are rather exciting.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
You know about the Human Genome Project.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
That was a project which aimed to read one copy of the human genome.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
The natural thing to do after you've done that --

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
and that's what this project, the International HapMap Project,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:46.958
which is a collaboration between labs in five or six different countries.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
Think of the Human Genome Project as learning what we've got in common,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
and the HapMap Project is trying to understand

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
where there are differences between different people.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Why do we care about that?

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
Well, there are lots of reasons.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
The most pressing one is that we want to understand how some differences

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
make some people susceptible to one disease -- type-2 diabetes, for example --

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:11.958
and other differences make people more susceptible to heart disease,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
or stroke, or autism and so on.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
That's one big project.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
There's a second big project,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
recently funded by the Wellcome Trust in this country,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
involving very large studies --

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
thousands of individuals, with each of eight different diseases,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.958
common diseases like type-1 and type-2 diabetes, and coronary heart disease,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
bipolar disease and so on -- to try and understand the genetics.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
To try and understand what it is about genetic differences that causes the diseases.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
Why do we want to do that?

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
Because we understand very little about most human diseases.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
We don't know what causes them.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
And if we can get in at the bottom and understand the genetics,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
we'll have a window on the way the disease works,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
and a whole new way about thinking about disease therapies

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and preventative treatment and so on.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
So that's, as I said, the little diversion on my main love.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:11:00.958
Back to some of the more mundane issues of thinking about uncertainty.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Here's another quiz for you --

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
now suppose we've got a test for a disease

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
which isn't infallible, but it's pretty good.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
It gets it right 99 percent of the time.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
And I take one of you, or I take someone off the street,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and I test them for the disease in question.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
Let's suppose there's a test for HIV -- the virus that causes AIDS --

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
and the test says the person has the disease.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
What's the chance that they do?

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
The test gets it right 99 percent of the time.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
So a natural answer is 99 percent.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Who likes that answer?

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:33.958
Come on -- everyone's got to get involved.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Don't think you don't trust me anymore.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:36.958
(Laughter)

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
Well, you're right to be a bit skeptical, because that's not the answer.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
That's what you might think.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
It's not the answer, and it's not because it's only part of the story.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
It actually depends on how common or how rare the disease is.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
So let me try and illustrate that.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
Here's a little caricature of a million individuals.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
So let's think about a disease that affects --

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
it's pretty rare, it affects one person in 10,000.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
Amongst these million individuals, most of them are healthy

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
and some of them will have the disease.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
And in fact, if this is the prevalence of the disease,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
about 100 will have the disease and the rest won't.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
So now suppose we test them all.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
What happens?

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Well, amongst the 100 who do have the disease,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:20.958
the test will get it right 99 percent of the time, and 99 will test positive.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
Amongst all these other people who don't have the disease,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
the test will get it right 99 percent of the time.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
It'll only get it wrong one percent of the time.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
But there are so many of them that there'll be an enormous number of false positives.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
Put that another way --

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:38.958
of all of them who test positive -- so here they are, the individuals involved --

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:43.958
less than one in 100 actually have the disease.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:47.958
So even though we think the test is accurate, the important part of the story is

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
there's another bit of information we need.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Here's the key intuition.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
What we have to do, once we know the test is positive,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:02.958
is to weigh up the plausibility, or the likelihood, of two competing explanations.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
Each of those explanations has a likely bit and an unlikely bit.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
One explanation is that the person doesn't have the disease --

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
that's overwhelmingly likely, if you pick someone at random --

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
but the test gets it wrong, which is unlikely.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
The other explanation is that the person does have the disease -- that's unlikely --

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
but the test gets it right, which is likely.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
And the number we end up with --

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
that number which is a little bit less than one in 100 --

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:32.958
is to do with how likely one of those explanations is relative to the other.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
Each of them taken together is unlikely.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
Here's a more topical example of exactly the same thing.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
Those of you in Britain will know about what's become rather a celebrated case

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:47.958
of a woman called Sally Clark, who had two babies who died suddenly.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:51.958
And initially, it was thought that they died of what's known informally as "cot death,"

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and more formally as "Sudden Infant Death Syndrome."

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
For various reasons, she was later charged with murder.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
And at the trial, her trial, a very distinguished pediatrician gave evidence

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:05.958
that the chance of two cot deaths, innocent deaths, in a family like hers --

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:11.958
which was professional and non-smoking -- was one in 73 million.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
To cut a long story short, she was convicted at the time.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:20.958
Later, and fairly recently, acquitted on appeal -- in fact, on the second appeal.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:24.958
And just to set it in context, you can imagine how awful it is for someone

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
to have lost one child, and then two, if they're innocent,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
to be convicted of murdering them.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
To be put through the stress of the trial, convicted of murdering them --

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
and to spend time in a women's prison, where all the other prisoners

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:39.958
think you killed your children -- is a really awful thing to happen to someone.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And it happened in large part here because the expert got the statistics

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
horribly wrong, in two different ways.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
So where did he get the one in 73 million number?

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
He looked at some research, which said the chance of one cot death in a family

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:59.958
like Sally Clark's is about one in 8,500.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:03.958
So he said, "I'll assume that if you have one cot death in a family,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:07.958
the chance of a second child dying from cot death aren't changed."

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
So that's what statisticians would call an assumption of independence.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
It's like saying, "If you toss a coin and get a head the first time,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
that won't affect the chance of getting a head the second time."

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:20.958
So if you toss a coin twice, the chance of getting a head twice are a half --

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
that's the chance the first time -- times a half -- the chance a second time.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
So he said, "Here,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.958
I'll assume that these events are independent.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
When you multiply 8,500 together twice,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
you get about 73 million."

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
And none of this was stated to the court as an assumption

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
or presented to the jury that way.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Unfortunately here -- and, really, regrettably --

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:45.958
first of all, in a situation like this you'd have to verify it empirically.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
And secondly, it's palpably false.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:53.958
There are lots and lots of things that we don't know about sudden infant deaths.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
It might well be that there are environmental factors that we're not aware of,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
and it's pretty likely to be the case that there are

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
genetic factors we're not aware of.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
So if a family suffers from one cot death, you'd put them in a high-risk group.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
They've probably got these environmental risk factors

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
and/or genetic risk factors we don't know about.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
And to argue, then, that the chance of a second death is as if you didn't know

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
that information is really silly.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:18.958
It's worse than silly -- it's really bad science.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:23.958
Nonetheless, that's how it was presented, and at trial nobody even argued it.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
That's the first problem.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:29.958
The second problem is, what does the number of one in 73 million mean?

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
So after Sally Clark was convicted --

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:35.958
you can imagine, it made rather a splash in the press --

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:42.958
one of the journalists from one of Britain's more reputable newspapers wrote that

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
what the expert had said was,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:49.958
"The chance that she was innocent was one in 73 million."

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
Now, that's a logical error.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
It's exactly the same logical error as the logical error of thinking that

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
after the disease test, which is 99 percent accurate,
